HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Live From Radio City!

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
After closing for a restoration that left it dark for seven months and cost $70 million -- twice the original estimate -- Radio City Music Hall was scheduled to reopen last Monday in a blaze of lights befitting one of New York City's most enduring show-business icons.
The doubling in restoration costs demonstrated not only the perils of sophisticated restoration work in Manhattan but also the determination of its owner, Cablevision Systems Corporation, to have the new hall ready in time for the Nov. 4 opening of its venerable Radio City Christmas Spectacular, the first major event in the renovated hall that is open to the public. 
 The Music Hall is not only a monument to Art Deco splendor but also a magnet for tourism: Cablevision has estimated that it will attract 2 million visitors and contribute more than $300 million to the city's economy each year.
The restoration, the most ambitious since the hall opened in 1932 as a vaudeville and movie house, was headed by the architect Hugh Hardy, of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates. It employed 2,000 workers, who burnished ceilings with 720,000 sheets of gold and aluminum leaf, hung a new 112-foot-wide shimmery gold-silk curtain and installed 5,901 new plush salmon-pink seats.
Furniture, walls, carpets, lighting fixtures and appointments have been cleaned, repaired or remade. And the three-story "Fountain of Youth" mural by Ezra Winter, which looms above the grand staircase, was cleaned of decades of grime and varnish.
For local merchants, the reopening was a joyous occasion. "It's been a long seven months, when Rockefeller Center looked like a deserted area," said David Liederman, owner of Chez Louis, the restaurant across the street on West 50th Street.
Tickets for the Christmas Spectacular cost $29 to $97; call (212) 307-1000.
 GLENN COLLINS

HEADLINE: THEATER;
When the Commercial Theater Moves In on Nonprofits

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
"MARTIN GUERRE," the British musical that has returned more often than, well, Martin Guerre, finally had its American premiere here on Sept. 29. It was the fourth opening for the show, counting its first one in London's West End in 1996, and a climactic night for Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg, who first brought the idea to the producer Cameron Mackintosh a full seven years ago.
"It's been as long as it took Martin Guerre to go to war and come back," said Mr. Schonberg, who wrote the score. The show -- based on the often-told true story of the 16th-century Frenchman who, left for dead on the battlefield, returns home to find his identity has been assumed by his friend and fellow soldier -- has been streamlined, reordered and rewritten by its persistent creators. Forty percent of the current material was not in the original, Mr. Mackintosh said. 
 "That's it," said Mr. Boublil, co-writer of the book and lyrics. "That's the show they get." The creators sounded relieved, but in the theater world "Martin Guerre" has been perceived as something of an obsession for its legendary producer. Mr. Mackintosh, who, as the man behind the musicals "Cats," "The Phantom of the Opera," "Les Miserables" and "Miss Saigon" (the last two written by Mr. Boublil and Mr. Schonberg), is perhaps the world's most successful theater producer. "Martin Guerre" has yet to garner the same acclaim; it was revised and re-opened in mid-run in London, then revamped and re-opened at the Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds.
That version, the first to be praised by critics, is the one Mr. Mackintosh has brought here to the venerable Guthrie Theater, one of the nation's leading nonprofit houses, where the opening of "Martin Guerre" is a striking anomaly. Even though the show has been trimmed down considerably, this is a theater that has historically focused on classic drama on its thrust stage. With "Martin Guerre," the Guthrie has joined the lengthening list of nonprofit regional theaters to collaborate on expensive productions with commercial producers. Never in its 36-year history has the theater given its subscribers a show with the glamour and extravagance of this one.
"What's really blowing our audiences away," said David Hawkanson, the Guthrie's managing director, "is that it's like having a 100-piece orchestra in your den."
But does a 100-piece orchestra belong in your den? Indeed, the arrival of "Martin Guerre" has further obscured the increasingly murky distinction between nonprofit and commercial theater enterprises and stirs, with particular vigor, the debate over whether collaborations between the two entities are appropriate or even desirable.
The show is headed for Broadway in the spring, though it does not yet have a theater, which is one reason the top officers of the Shubert Organization and Jujamcyn Theaters, leading theater owners in New York, made the trip out here for opening night. It will be the second musical Mr. Mackintosh brings to Broadway this season: the Stephen Sondheim revue, "Putting It Together," which he has been nurturing since 1991, is to open next month at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, starring Carol Burnett, in an incarnation that was developed in collaboration with the Mark Taper Forum, the nonprofit house in Los Angeles.
"Over here, this seems to be my year for nonprofit theater," said Mr. Mackintosh, still chubbily boyish at 52, explaining that the simultaneous arrival of the two shows is only a coincidence, and that his partnerships with nonprofits are nothing unusual for him; he has been working with state-subsidized theaters in England for more than two decades.
Asked why he has clung so tenaciously to "Martin Guerre," he responded with only a hint of exasperation. "My tenacity with this show is no different than my tenacity with any show," he said. "I'll keep going until I feel there's no more to be done. It's just that 'Martin Guerre' had to be developed in the public eye. The fact of the matter was the show I put on in London wasn't finished. It was still a work in progress, and at every stage it has gotten better. People forget that 'The Music Man' took 12 years to get together. 'Guys and Dolls' had 10 or 12 different librettos."
Though economy-size by comparison to "Ragtime" and "The Lion King," Broadway's current eight-figure extravaganzas, and even by Mr. Mackintosh's own long-running hits, "Martin Guerre," with a cast of 24 and a set designed by John Napier (who landed the helicopter onstage in "Miss Saigon"), cost $2.1 million to stage here. That is about two and a half times the budget of an average Guthrie show. Mr. Mackintosh paid for just over half.
"Martin Guerre," with Hugh Panaro in the title role, received a mostly positive review in The Minneapolis Star-Tribune ("Though the musical will engage the intellect only slightly, it speaks loudly, earnestly and passionately to the heart") and a more skeptical one in Variety. But in any case, ticket sales have been brisk for its seven-week run at the Guthrie, where the excitement of a Broadway-style production has seemingly justified the financial risk.
AND so, the argument goes, collaborations such as this one work to the benefit of both partners. The economics of mounting a musical for Broadway are so forbidding that for a commercial producer, trying out a show in a nonprofit house where costs are more modest is a way of preparing it for the make or break scrutiny of critics in New York and audiences who will judge it with their wallets.
"That seems to be the only way to go," said Hal Luftig, a producer working on a musical version of the film "Thoroughly Modern Millie." "We're going to try and do what Cameron is doing, start it in a regional house."
At the same time, the resources a commercial producer can provide for a nonprofit enable the theater to put on a more elaborate production, giving its local audience a taste of opulent show business that the theater could otherwise not afford. And bigger, it need be said, does sometimes mean better.
In addition, the participating theater generally shares in profits gleaned by the show after it moves on, a powerful inducement for institutions that are perennially scratching for funds. In the last decade or so, the new musicals "Big River" and "The Who's Tommy" and the revival of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" all had successful premieres at the La Jolla Playhouse in California, partly financed by commercial producers, before their turns on Broadway. The new musical "Jane Eyre" recently completed its run there, selling out 62 performances, and its producers are currently seeking additional financing -- and a theater -- to open it in New York.
On the other hand, such collaborations strike many as antithetical -- or at least threatening -- to the very nature of regional nonprofit theater, a movement that took hold nationally in the 1950's and 1960's largely as a revolt against the commercially driven enterprise that American theater art, as exemplified by Broadway, had become. (The Guthrie, founded by the director Tyrone Guthrie in 1963, was among the movement's seminal institutions.)
These days, few in the theater object to collaborations on principle (current economics make it difficult to support such rigid church-and-state separation), but the issue remains one of control. When a commercial producer with an eye on profit-making contributes to a production in a nonprofit house, who is making the artistic decisions? Whose interests are a priority? The theater, which is devoted to its local audience and which has a history and an artistic vision to uphold? Or the commercial producer, whose main concern is generating momentum for a long run elsewhere?
"The minute you get somebody else calling the shots about how the work evolves, somebody with an eye on the brass ring, you've molested the enterprise," said Zelda Fichandler, the founding director of Arena Stage in Washington and its artistic director from 1950 to 1991.
Control is always a difficult proposition to sort out, made more complicated recently as commercial partners have escalated their financial involvement. Five years ago, Lincoln Center Theater put on a revival of "Carousel" with Mr. Mackintosh; last year it staged the new musical "Parade," with Livent, the Canadian company then being run by Garth Drabinsky, Mr. Mackintosh's equal in showmanship if not financial acumen. (Livent went bankrupt just before the opening of "Parade," embroiling Mr. Drabinsky in allegations of fiscal misdeeds. "Carousel" was originally at the Royal National Theater in London, a nonprofit theater; Mr. Mackintosh maintained the commercial rights.)
Both shows were produced at Lincoln Center for about $5 million apiece, and the collaborators split the costs. Contractually, in both cases, said Bernard Gersten, the theater's executive producer, "we were in control of the production." But in both cases, the directors (Nicholas Hytner and Harold Prince, respectively) were chosen and the productions designed and developed by the commercial partner. None of those involved are known as shrinking violets.
"Who's in control on paper is clear and who's in control in fact is not so clear," Mr. Gersten said. "That's when the 400-pound gorillas come into play."
LAST year, when the Disney company opened its new musical, "Elaborate Lives: The Legend of Aida," at the Alliance Theater Company in Atlanta, Alliance's artistic director, Kenny Leon, in two separate interviews with The New York Times, said, first, that he had no influence over the production, and then that he did. Whatever the actual case, the initial production was a critical failure but, for Alliance, a financial success, and it maintains a share of the show, which, in a revised incarnation (it is now called simply "Aida"), is scheduled to open at a commercial theater in Chicago in December, before moving to Broadway in February.
For years, commercial theater and nonprofit theater existed in entirely separate orbits. That began to change in 1967, when Arena Stage in Washington put on "The Great White Hope" and the producer Herman Levin bought the rights from the playwright Howard Sackler and moved the production -- its stars James Earl Jones and Jane Alexander included -- to Broadway the following year. "It changed the American theater because it changed the flow of material," said Ms. Fichandler, who now heads the graduate acting department at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. "Up until that time," she said of regional theaters, "we were little outposts."
Indeed, Ms. Fichandler said, it was such a new and startling development that she neglected to maintain any rights to the show, the largest the Arena had ever put on up to that point. As a result, Arena lost money on its own production and received nothing from the show's long run on Broadway. In retrospect, she said, she was terribly naive. "My focus was so on the thing itself that I hadn't attended to the theater properly," she said.
Shortly after the move of "The Great White Hope," the New York Shakespeare Festival accepted $50,000 from the producer Michael Butler and moved its production of "Hair" to a disco near Times Square; Mr. Butler subsequently moved the show to Broadway. In 1971, the Shakespeare Festival entered the commercial arena on its own, moving its musical version of "Two Gentlemen of Verona" from Central Park to the St. James Theater on Broadway. Most famously, the festival produced "A Chorus Line," whose 15-year Broadway run, ending in 1990, poured a nearly $39 million bounty into the theater's coffers, supporting less commercially viable works on its downtown stages for years and providing a pot-of-gold model for nonprofit theaters across the country.
A recent example, "The Civil War," the Frank Wildhorn musical that flopped on Broadway last season, was developed by the Alley Theater in Houston (with financial help from Pace Theatricals, the tour-organizing company). Productions of the show in New York and on the road were already part of the plan during development.
In the last two decades, several varieties of theatrical partnerships have evolved; commercial producers keep close tabs on work being developed in regional theaters (as they do on shows in London), with an eye toward moving them. In recent years, such Tony-winning plays as "Angels in America," "The Kentucky Cycle" and "Death of a Salesman" were developed in one or more regional theaters before producers attempted to mount them commercially.
"That's the most rewarding way, and the most creative," said Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, which helped develop "Angels in America" and "The Kentucky Cycle."
But that has rarely happened with musicals because they are often too expensive for regional theaters to develop on their own. Musicals have also grown too expensive for commercial producers to finance alone; the old system of getting a show on its feet in Boston or New Haven in a pre-Broadway run has almost entirely disappeared. Instead, the most common strategy today makes use of what is known as "enhancement money"; that is, a commercial producer helps finance a musical in a regional house in exchange for the rights to produce it when the local run is complete.
The amount of influence exerted by the commercial partner over the theater's production is, at that point, up for grabs. Or, put more kindly, a matter for the partnership to work out. "It's not the dollar amount of the enhancement that determines the policies behind doing these productions," said Terrence Dwyer, the managing director of the La Jolla Playhouse, who said the enhancement money the theater had received ranged between $400,000 and $1 million, but was never more than half of a show's total cost. "Whether it's $50 or $2 million is irrelevant. The key thing is, are not-for-profits doing these things for the right reasons? Do they serve your audience and your mission? And do you maintain the character and the integrity of the institution during the process?"
IN the case of "Martin Guerre," both Mr. Mackintosh and the theater's artistic director, Joe Dowling, say the show and the theater are a good match. The Guthrie, which has an auditorium seating 1,300 and about 30,000 subscribers, is on the verge of a capital campaign for a new building that would house three different auditoriums and allow the theater to expand its mandate by developing new works and engaging more frequently in co-productions.
"We've been expanding our programming the last two or three years," said Mr. Dowling, the former head of the Abbey Theater in Dublin who took over in 1996 from the Guthrie's previous artistic director Garland Wright, who died last year. "I've been accused of being populist, and I say, 'Guilty as charged.' But no one's going to tell me that Cameron lacks esthetic values, and the notion that we're selling out to commerce is a faulty one. If Boublil and Schonberg had offered me their new musical, would I have taken it? Of course. Could we have afforded it on our own? No."
But that's not the entire story. At the show's last major opening in England, at the Yorkshire Playhouse, a nonprofit theater in Leeds ("If there's a British equivalent to the Guthrie, that's it," Mr. Dowling said), critics admired it as a triumphant turnaround from the show that many had judged bloated and confusing in London. Trimmed down, rewritten, its story clarified and songs replaced, it had also been completely restaged by two young Irishmen, Conall Morrison, the director, and David Bolger, the choreographer. Mr. Dowling had worked with Mr. Morrison in Dublin. "When I heard Cameron was going to do another 'Martin Guerre' with those two guys, I was very excited," Mr. Dowling said. "I immediately called him."
Mr. Mackintosh said he was attracted to the Guthrie because of its resemblance to the theater in Leeds and because he felt the Minneapolis audience would be appreciative; the Guthrie, after all, he said, attracts theatergoers from hundreds of miles around. And though staging the show in a nonprofit house keeps costs down (by union contract, actors are paid less in nonprofit houses than in commercial ones), it isn't exactly a money-saving venture for him. Before Broadway, the show will be moving from Minneapolis to engagements in Detroit, Washington, Seattle and Los Angeles, and it will have to be restaged, at a cost of some $2 million, Mr. Mackintosh estimated, for the proscenium houses there.
"Joe really wanted to do this," Mr. Mackintosh said. "Even before he saw it. He smelled it would be good for his theater. It's a cousin of 'The Crucible,' a cousin of Shakespeare. And it has the added bonus of a really terrific score. Why shouldn't it be on a stage like this?"
The most complicated hardware for the set -- which includes a steel wall resembling wood that seems, at one point, to be consumed by fire -- and the Broadway-style lighting and sound machinery were brought over from England. The Guthrie made the costumes and the props and participated in casting.
"There have been some tensions," Mr. Dowling said, "in terms of what we can afford. Their natural instinct is to add people and ours is to cut them. They think of the long-term life of the work and we're focused on the next seven weeks. There's a difference in culture there. But there's been no difference in how we approach the work."
Besides, Mr. Mackintosh added, the issue over whether such collaborations are appropriate is an artificial and particularly American one. "I just think there's so little good material out there anyway," he said, "that the best people, in whatever sphere, have to get together to put on a show in the best possible circumstances."

HEADLINE: The Arts Come Alive In School Programs

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
WHEN parents attend open house at the beginning of the school year at Hillside Elementary School, not all of them ask questions about the math curriculum or the language arts program. Instead, they seem more interested in which opera students in the second grade will be seeing, since a trip to a professional opera performance has become a tradition, said Linda Azif, a second-grade teacher here. The parents also fight over which parents will be asked to chaperone the trip.
Marilyn Wishnie, principal of Hillside, said: "Our district emphasizes the arts. We reflect the community's values. Arts education is a tradition here. We think arts are so much a part of life. How do you not permeate it throughout the curriculum? It's almost like cutting off your hand. How do you not do it?" 
 Such passion about the arts in Hastings, which is home to many actors, singers, musicians, dancers and writers, goes a long way toward explaining why Hillside not only received a Blue Ribbon school of excellence award from the United States Department of Education last spring but was also one of only two elementary schools in the United States cited for special recognition in arts education. The other is Mills Lawn Elementary School in Yellow Springs, Ohio. Both schools will receive their commendations at a ceremony Oct. 28 in Washington.
What impressed the Department of Education's panel, which also included members of the National Endowment for the Arts, was the total arts immersion available at Hillside. "Ninety of the schools that earned a Blue Ribbon applied for the arts commendation," Steve O'Brien, a team leader for the Federal Department of Education, said. "We were looking for a school that had to meet all the criteria: dance, music, fine arts and performance. We were looking for a total program. The idea is that the arts program had to be practically perfect, and a model for other schools. Arts are part of the national core curriculum."
Doug Herbert, director of arts education for the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, said of the Hillside program: "They have a clear commitment to teaching and learning in all of the arts."
Hillside's hallways could pass for a downtown art gallery, with artwork ranging from third graders' self-portraits or black-and-white studies in positive and negative imagery to kindergartners' interpretations of jazz music through Matisse-influenced cut-out art projects. In a third-grade art class, under the guidance of the teacher, Susan Larson, students studied black-and-white images of the gardens at Versailles so they could work on comparable designs in shades of gray and white.
Barbara Levine, a Hillside art teacher, said: "We have the philosophy that art is a natural, creative expression. Young kids do it on their own. They get inhibited later on. The idea with art is that they have to make decisions. It's creative problem solving and using critical thinking skills. However they do it, when we assess them, we want to know, 'Did you solve the problem?' and 'Did you learn anything in the process?' "
The visual arts program is not the only expression of arts education. In music classes, students regularly perform on a variety of instruments and discuss compositions, while the fourth grade performs a musical each year. Mark Ruhala, a Hastings dancer, teacher and choreographer, is a visiting artist each year, working with kindergartners. Artistic activities are seamlessly woven into other aspects of the curriculum.
Emily Meltzer, 9, a fourth grader at Hillside, composed the following poem as part of an autobiographical project, which also included an abstract art piece:
Energetic
Musician
Ice cream Eater
Limited Too Shopper
Yankees fan
Arts education has evolved considerably in the last several years, in part because of new Regents standards and in part because of consideration of the role the arts must play in a student's life. "The Regents recognize the emerging prominence of the arts in the economy and in the vocational field," Bill Hirschen, a spokesman for the state's Department of Education, said.
Jennifer Woodruff, assistant principal at Hillside, said, "We teach the children how to do something, like how to pinch clay so the handles won't fall off the pots they make." Mrs. Wishnie, the principal, added: "In a music class, the idea would be to explain to them how to listen to music. It's not a talent-based system, but a skills-based system."
The arts, which encompass theater, dance and movement and even poetry -- as well as art and music -- are rarely seen as frills. Instead, arts classes are seen as an extension of the curriculum, with projects aimed at offering skills and critical thinking experiences for all students regardless of talent.
Nor is Hastings alone in its pursuit of arts education.
In Lee F. Jackson school in the Greenburgh Central Seven School District, which serves kindergarteners and first graders, the students are taking part in a special 10-week arts education program this semester. First graders are working with a storyteller-singer using movement and music to explore multicultural stories, and then will be working with a visual artist to produce shadow puppets. The kindergarteners are spending time with the visual artist with textures, patterns and colors that relate to animal stories and science.
Sarah Schneider, director of cultural arts for the Ossining school district, said: "The standards that are driving curriculum development are saying that the arts are a basic, integral part of a student's education. It's not just listening to a piece of music and saying, 'I like it' -- they have to explain why they like it."
The revised state standards include a progressive exposure to and experience with art creation and performance, knowing how to use materials and resources in respective disciplines and ultimately responding to and analyzing a work of art, whether it is a piece of sculpture, a dramatic monologue or a symphony.
Dr. Frances Wills, Superintendent of the Briarcliff Union Free School District, said: "Arts are a highly significant part of a child's education. You don't have to be a great artist. You can be insightful and learn how to think about art."
In Briarcliff, 54 percent of the fourth and fifth graders learn to play a string instrument, and 83 percent of the students in those grades takes part in some form of musical instrument performance. At the high school level, where the school offers an advanced placement art course, 62 percent of the students are involved in an art program, with 32 percent taking part in some form of music.
Other aspects of arts education here include donations from the Briarcliff Manor Education Foundation, like grants to a high school art anthology and elementary school art and literary magazine, body microphones for performers at Todd Elementary School and a music keyboard and laser printer for the middle and high school music department. The middle and high school also have a new 500-seat auditorium. Fourth graders at Todd set up a museum in the classroom, reflecting their study of a particular era in art history.
In Ossining, a districtwide focus on the arts has been translated into a six-year initiative, begun this year, which provides classes in music, dance, theater and the visual arts. Under the plan, high school students can select a major in the arts that includes technology and the arts as well as performance.
"We want to create a mecca for the arts in the region," Dr. Phyllis Glassman, Deputy Superintendent of Ossining, said. "We want to be an exemplar as an area of serious and in-depth study. We consider arts basic to students' education." In the summer, the district sponsored an arts academy for high school students.
Work like that written by Vic Pathak, an 11th grader at Ossining High School, as part of an exercise to compose a response to music, reflects the program's objectives.
He wrote:
It's not ambiguous to visualize,
All the artistic rhymes
Fuse into your mind. Tune in
To the beautiful sound, which
As you can hear, is very profound.
 Music and Poetry make a powerful
Combination. When you hear them together
 They make a wonderful sensation, but the
Temptation is too strong if you don't hear it for long
And everything is rhythmic, just hear my song.
 
Grants Make the Arts More Than a Frill
One example of the renewed focus on arts education is the Empire State Partnership grants, an initiative from the State Department of Education and the State Council on the Arts.
Madeleine Holzer, director of Arts in Education for the Council for the Arts, said: "The idea is that the arts are integrated to a core curriculum, that they're not a frill, but worthwhile parts of the human experience. Through our grants, we want to improve learning and teaching through the arts. The idea is that arts are part of the fabric of a school and of the curriculum. It's no longer about exposing students to art, through a museum visit or concert, but about integrating arts into the curriculum."
Greenburgh and Yonkers earlier this year received a total of $157,000 in state grants to teach various subjects. Greenburgh received $92,000 for the district, while the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers is using its $65,000 grant to run literacy programs at the Yonkers Museum School of the Arts and Sciences and the Museum Middle School.
One current project in Greenburgh involves pairing an earth science teacher with a visual artist, who will help students refine their skills at detailed observation by doing landscape painting of the Woodlands campus. Last year, some fifth and sixth graders at the Richard Bailey Middle School worked with a visiting musician to learn about the science of sound..
The Council for the Arts sponsors Empire State partnership grants in conjunction with New York state's Department of Education.
As another partnership example, New Rochelle High School and Purchase College received a $100,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts to begin a pilot dance program.
Although the high school has run a dance program as part of its physical education program, the grant enables the school and the college to design a multicultural curriculum and also allows professional dance groups to work with students at the college and the high school. MERRI ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: THEATER;
The Garde Returns to Life, Again

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
EVEN though the theater originally opened in 1926 -- when movie palaces were movie palaces -- who's to argue with what management calls the "premiere season" of the Garde Arts Center in New London?
For the shows on this season's schedule, beginning Saturday with Patti LuPone in concert, are live and include five Broadway musicals for two performances each. 
 The reopening of the Garde -- the grand climax of a $15.75 million campaign begun in 1996 -- represents a contemporary take on an eternal story about the roles big businesses play in the revitalization of small cities.
When Internet initiatives, gambling casinos, videos, malls and multiplexes compete, at the same time devaluating the human spirit, what is live entertainment to do?
Easy. Steve Sigel, managing director of the Garde Arts Center, considers arts programming as a multitasking approach. "What we used to call audiences are now cultural consumers," Mr. Sigel continued. "Life in America is market driven, whatever your venture."
New London (population 26,000) has been identified as a whaling, then a military industry center. But there is New London's educational present: Connecticut College's downtown campus near the Garde and the storied cottage of Eugene O'Neill's doomed family, a short walk away. In 1977 the Garde was "destined for demolition," Mr. Sigel said, after Warner Brothers, which ran the theater from 1929 to 1977, gave up.
The Robertson Paper Company bought it as a for-profit operation, which Mr. Sigel said proved an "untenable economic set up." That lasted until 1985.
Then a nonprofit community organization, the Garde Arts Center, bought and reopened the building. (The Garde is part of a four-story commercial structure.) "Five historical buildings on the block were also purchased," Mr. Sigel said. Major restoration involved an up-to-date recapturing of the Moorish splendor of the past. Recent restoration included the conversion of a storefront into an expanded lobby.
The Broadway series, in the 1,460-seat theater beginning Oct. 30, consists of touring companies of the musicals, "Annie," "1776," (in the same production to be seen at the Bushnell in Hartford), "Camelot," "Victor/Victoria" and "Show Boat." Watch for "Porgy and Bess" in December, and "Late Night Catechism," an intimate Off Broadway revue in another space (seating 350). Even the special events programming has a theater connection: "Tap Dogs," which was produced Off Broadway two seasons ago.
The Garde Arts Center season includes international opera and ballet companies and shows for youngsters. Audiences are expected to be drawn from Waterford, Old Lyme, Stonington, Norwich and Groton.
But how do modern marketing strategies and an esthetic philosophy join up? It takes the vision of a culturally minded individual to discover what George Milne, an executive with Pfizer Incorporated, calls "the natural synergy between creativity in research and in the arts."
The choice of the pharmaceutical company to expand its global research headquarters, which are based in nearby Groton, to New London where 2,000 employees will be moved next year, is an effort to help a downtown area in decline. "That's how our employees can contribute to the transformation of the city," Mr. Milne said. The company has already contributed $150,000 to the Garde campaign.
"If we want to recruit the best brains from around the world, the community -- its quality of life for business and culture -- should be the key incentive for Ph.D.'s to come here," Mr. Milne added. "A rich diverse environment attracts outstanding thinkers and leaders to raise their families in such a setting."
"It's all in our interests," Mr. Milne continued. "This is not altruism. It's good business -- to penetrate the surroundings where you live. Research and development should be stimulated through music and dance and theater. We can spur the whole bio-medical industry like Silicon Valley did with computers."
"The dimensions of the arts are a necessary balance to sustain human creativity -- and that's the key to our involvement here," he added.
Pfizer, which has a day care center in Groton, is to build another in New London. "Your ultimate legacy is the people you work with," Mr. Milne continued. "And Steve has managed to make an effective bridge between the history of the theater and modern spaces. I'm very encouraged."

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Using Steel Frames For Homes

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI

 BODY:
THE vast majority of the houses built in the United States today are constructed with wood. About 85 percent of that wood is used for framing. Since wood has been the primary building material since Colonial times, it might seem that there is no reason for change, but wood has its drawbacks.
In the first place, the supplies of old-growth timber are diminishing. This has caused the price of construction lumber to rise dramatically over the last few years. It has also forced the lumber industry to harvest wood from young trees. This new wood has a greater tendency to warp and split as it ages. This results in cracks and warping appearing throughout the house soon after it is finished. 
 For this reason, some builders are looking for alternatives to wood as framing. One possible substitute is steel. Steel can be cold-rolled into pieces that are roughly the same size and shape as dimensional framing lumber, so they can be used for studs, joists or rafters. The pieces are rolled into a C cross section -- for that reason they are called structural-C members, C-members or simply C's -- and are coated with zinc to make them rust resistant. They are also available with prepunched slots so electrical wires and plumbing lines can be run through.
For load-bearing walls, structural members are available in 16- to 20-gauge thicknesses. Studs for nonbearing walls are available in thinner 25-gauge steel. These pieces are lighter in weight, easier to cut and less expensive than the heavier gauge pieces.
Unlike wood, steel is structurally stable and uniformly straight. That means that walls, floors and ceilings can be constructed so they are truly flat, plumb and level. Steel is moisture-resistant, so it will not dry out and warp nor will it expand in humid weather. Steel framing is also fireproof and free from rot and insect infestations.
Right now, steel framing is not significantly less expensive than traditional dimensional lumber, but representatives of the steel industry point out that prices are relatively stable, while lumber costs are rising. In the coming years, it may be more economical to purchase steel framing.
Does all this mean that wood-framed houses are a thing of the past? Probably not. Right now about 1 percent of the houses currently being constructed in the United States have steel framing. The iron and steel industry hopes to entice more builders into using steel framing, and they predict that by the end of the next decade, 25 percent of residential homes will be framed with steel.
Steel framing, however, has a downside. The biggest drawback to using steel is that steel is a good conductor of heat. A steel stud will conduct 10 times more heat than its wooden counterpart. This means that a warm house can quickly loose much of its heat through the outside walls if they have steel framing. Extra insulation will not prevent this, because the heat that enters into steel studs quickly travels laterally through the framing to the outside of the house.
Builders try to prevent heat loss by sheathing the outside of the house with high-density foam board instead of the usual plywood or particle board. This slows the heat transmission through the walls, but it has little effect on heat loss through the ceiling. Manufacturers are designing steel structural members with raised knobs along the edges that minimize the contact between the wallboard and the studs. This effectively creates a thin barrier of air that insulates the stud from interior heat. Other manufacturers are planning to introduce an insulation tape that can be applied to the stud before the wallboard is installed.
Another drawback to using steel for construction is that most professional carpenters are not used to working with it. It's true that working with steel does not require any arcane skills or even sophisticated tools; still many carpenters make no secret of the fact that they would rather work with wood.
With a circular saw, a profession carpenter can quickly cut a dozen wooden studs to length in less time than it would take to trim six steel studs with a reciprocating saw or a circular saw with an abrasive wheel. So the amount of money saved by buying structural steel may be lost in money spent for increased construction time, although this is not likely to remain a significant problem as more builders experiment with steel.

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
How East Windsor Stemmed a Route 571 Exodus

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WHEN Lockheed Martin closed its 120-acre space satellite complex off Route 571 in East Windsor last year, it was the latest in a series of moves of commercial tenants caused by mergers or consolidations over the last five years. Their actions threatened to leave about half of the mile-long Route 571 corporate corridor -- 1.9 million square feet of space in the buildings between Route 535 and Route 130 -- a ghost town of sorts.
Anticipating further moves, East Windsor officials began a campaign in 1996 to draw pharmaceutical and high-tech office users to the corridor in the western sector of the 15-square-mile Mercer County township. Their pitch was to offer a streamlined approval process, a skilled labor pool and a less expensive location than the nearby Princeton Route 1 corridor, about four miles to the west. 
 In addition, there was the promise of better access to the Route 571 corridor because of the state's plan to build the 2.8-mile, $65 million Route 133 Bypass to link it to Exit 8 of the New Jersey Turnpike.
"We identified the kinds of development and businesses that would be attracted to the community because of the good value we offer and we are going after them," said Janice S. Mironov, the mayor of East Windsor.
Over the last year six companies -- including Shiseido America, a cosmetics firm, and i-STAT, which produces a hand-held computerized blood testing instrument -- have moved into many of the empty buildings along Route 571, helping to stabilize the township's tax base, Mayor Mironov said. Now, with the bypass road set to open later this month, she added, the focus is on new construction and building on the foundation that has been put in place.
The current owner of the former Lockheed Martin site, GMH Associates of Wayne, Pa., has demolished all but 300,000 square feet of the 700,000-square-foot old complex, a collection of interconnecting buildings dating to the 1950's and including a 50-foot-high spherical concrete structure, where satellites were tested. The remaining space, in two now separated structures, is being renovated to modern offices as the first phase of a 1.1-million-square-foot project called Windsor Corporate Park.
GMH -- a major owner and manager of office and residential properties, particularly of off-campus student housing -- acquired the site 18 months ago, but leased it back to Lockheed Martin. Though Lockheed announced it would close the complex four years ago the company slowly reduced its operations there until it shut down late last December.
A month later GMH started the demolition and renovation work at the site, which is expected to cost $30 million to $35 million, including the purchase price of the land. Its equity partner is Urdang & Associates Real Estate Advisors, of Wayne, Pa., which invests in projects on behalf of pension funds. Ultimately, some 800,000 more square feet of space could be added to the site, including corporate office space and high-tech flex space. The latter offers space for offices as well as research and development, assembly and production in low-rise structures.
Location and timing were important factors, said Gary Holloway, president of GMH, of his company's decision to move ahead with the project. "Our game plan is to coincide the opening of the first phase of the project as closely as possible with that of the bypass road," Mr. Holloway said, noting that the renovation is to be completed by February. With the improved access and proximity to Princeton, "we feel the project is in an ideal location" to draw tenants from the Princeton Route 1 corridor, northern New Jersey and Manhattan, he added.
Mr. Holloway said the annual asking rents at the project -- starting at $19.99 a square foot a year, compared with $27 and more for Class A space in the Princeton Route 1 corridor -- would also draw tenants to the Route 571 corridor.
In addition to GMH's site there is a 100-acre parcel, called Windsor Corporate Center, as well as six smaller ones that township officials hope will draw developers. The Windsor Corporate Center contains a 66,000-square-foot single-story building that had been mostly occupied by Lockheed Martin until last year and has since drawn i-STAT as a new tenant.
The remaining land at the center, which can accommodate up to 1 million square feet of space, is owned by DKM, a holding company based in Manhattan and managed by Gale & Wentworth, of Florham Park.
The strong economy and employment gains in the state that have focused attention on the Route 571 corridor have spurred construction of new Class A office space nearby, notably in the Route 1 corridor.
NEARLY a million square feet of space in eight buildings are under construction along that corridor, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage. In its midyear survey, the brokerage reported that over the preceding year the new construction pushed up the Class A office vacancy rate along Route 1 to 13.9 percent from 5 percent, as well as average asking rents to $28.98 from $25.57.
It also said that by year's end leasing activity along the corridor should increase as the buildings under construction continue to attract tenants before they are completed.
Stephen Jenco, senior research analyst at Grubb & Ellis, another national commercial brokerage, is not so sure. "Yes, the new buildings are leasing but they still have available space and tenants have some choices now," he said. So the question is, he continued, "if we see any slowdown in the market can the momentum sustain itself?"
Not surprisingly, proponents of the Route 571 corridor side with the more optimistic forecast. They also say that the combination of limited choices of large available blocks of contiguous space and economic pressures will nudge companies that do not want or need to be on Route 1 to look at less expensive and nontraditional markets like Route 571.
That is what Buschman Partners, the Princeton-based commercial brokerage marketing Windsor Corporate Park for GMH, is banking on. "Because we have one of the few large blocks of space available, we think we have a good chance of landing an office tenant, and, in turn, creating a market," said John Buschman, managing partner at the brokerage. It is, he added, all about timing, pricing and a little luck.
Maybe so. Last year GMH, which has its own brokerage division, tried marketing the site before the demolition of the old complex was complete at an annual rental rate of $22 a square foot, with no results. "The project was still too much of a dream back then, and the initial pricing was incorrect," Mr. Buschman said.
Though he said the current $19.99 asking rent is a teaser rate, which will increase after the first few lease deals, rents at Windsor Corporate Park will always be about $5 lower than those along Route 1. "And," he added, "there will be enough tenants concerned about the bottom line and saving money that the project will snag its share of the market."
As part of the renovation, the two buildings at Windsor Corporate Park -- one with 240,000 square feet, the other with 60,000 square feet -- will be given new mechanical systems as well as high-tech wiring. The old brown-brick facade of the larger L-shaped structure, which dates to the 1950's, will also be replaced with stucco and ribbons of glass to complement the masonry exterior of the smaller building. The renovation architect is Thomas E. Hall Associates of Wayne, Pa.
Once two-thirds of the larger building is leased, said Brad A. Robertson, project manager for GHM Associates, his company will begin planning for the 800,000 square feet of space on the remaining 80 acres of the site. Construction of that space will be tied to the market and will include both build-to-suit and speculative office construction as well as one-story high-tech flex space, Mr. Robertson said.
Meanwhile, Kris Bauman, vice president of development at Gale & Wentworth, said his company's effort at Windsor Corporate Center was centered on marketing the site to users and developers for high-tech space. "It is the niche to compete in because we think there are enough opportunities right now for Class A offices," he said.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Flower District, A Crop of High-Rises

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
SEVEN years ago, Manuel Castedo moved his architectural practice into a 24-story loft building at 307 Seventh Avenue, near 27th Street, that was filled with furriers.
Ever since, he has been watching the fur flee. 
 "I was the first office tenant in this building," Mr. Castedo recalled. Now there are telecommunications and computer companies and other architects. Only a half dozen furriers remain.
Change is engulfing the old fur, fashion, flower and flea market districts along Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas in the West 20's. Mr. Castedo himself is contributing to the trend as the architect of a project at 291 Seventh Avenue, a block from his office, a loft building that is being turned into nine floor-through apartments by Houlihan-Parnes Realtors.
And that is one of the smaller undertakings.
In an area that has seen little new building since the Fashion Institute of Technology completed its Seventh Avenue megastructure in 1976, 2,100 housing units in seven projects, ranging from 10 to 37 stories and representing an investment of more than $600 million, are under construction or planned to begin within six months.
Spurring the transition are rezonings along Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas that permit residential development in what used to be manufacturing districts.
Developers like to say that they are expanding the boundaries of Chelsea northward, transforming unsightly parking lots into needed homes and amenities. But to those who live or work in the neighborhood, it feels more like the high-rise, high-rent contours of mid-Manhattan are being extended south, threatening daylight, small businesses and lower-income residents.
Beyond dispute is that another urban frontier, resistant to change even in the robust market of the 1980's, is at last being breached.
"There were these parking lot sites lying fallow on the avenues and there's clearly a great residential demand," said Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission. "The zoning changes to permit residential development on those avenue sites made sense. And now, after a long wait, it is under way."
At the same time, Mr. Rose said the commission would guard the side streets where so much small industry still exists. "The commission has been on record as vehemently opposing any zoning variances for the mid-blocks," he said.
Acknowledging that "one could engage in an interesting debate" on whether tall towers suited the area, Mr. Rose said their setbacks were meant to bring light and air to the mid-blocks.
What the planning chairman envisions is a mixed-use neighborhood in which apartment buildings, stores and light industry coexist.
Some local leaders are not nearly as sanguine.
Councilwoman Christine C. Quinn said she fears that "we've now taken 23d Street and, in our minds, decided that's where midtown begins, which means that it's O.K. to have really large buildings and it's not a place for small, family industries" like sewing-machine shops, printers, mannequin makers, furriers and flower dealers.
Not only will businesses be forced out but residents will see housing costs soar beyond their reach, said Kevin A. Finnegan, co-chairman of the land-use and zoning committee of Community Board 5 in mid-Manhattan.
"It's clear that what's under development is going to have significant impacts on nearby neighborhoods," he said. "Already in Chelsea, if you're not in a rent-stabilized apartment, you know you're going to have to move when the lease is up. This is going to accelerate the same pressure."
Housing costs are on the rise in the area from 22d to 28th Streets, Seventh Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas. According to the Corcoran Group, average sales prices to date this year were $282,000 for one-bedroom apartments, up 101 percent since 1996, and $525,000 for two-bedroom units, up 119 percent. The median rents were $1,650 for studios, up 34 percent since 1996; $2,800 for one-bedroom units, up 70 percent, and $3,650 for two-bedroom units, up 35 percent.
GIVEN the demand, the Rockrose Development Corporation has repeatedly raised prices at Chelsea Mercantile, an enormous loft building on Seventh Avenue, between 24th and 25th Streets, that it is converting into a 354-unit condominium. The architect is Avinash K. Malhotra, with public spaces designed by Gruzen Samton.
Penthouse C, a 2,246-square-foot, three-bedroom duplex that commands a view not unlike that in the photograph above, was offered in May for $1.56 million. In June, it was priced at $1.88 million; in July, $2.05 million. Today, the price is $2.15 million.
And Rockrose is having no trouble finding buyers. Last month, with the building still under construction, 205 units were under contract, said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president and general manager of Rockrose.
On the ground floor, Whole Foods Market Inc. of Austin, Tex., plans to open a 40,000-square-foot Fresh Fields Whole Foods Market next summer. The company calls itself the "largest purveyor of natural foods in the world" but does not have a New York City outlet. (It is not connected with Whole Foods of SoHo, 117 Prince Street, or Whole Foods-Uptown, 2421 Broadway, at 89th Street.)
"As we're developing a mini-neighborhood, this use is ground zero," Mr. Singleton said. Rockrose is poised to do for lower Seventh Avenue what it has already done in the West Village: transform the area with a mix of new and renovated buildings, condominiums and rental units, some of them subsidized for lower-income tenants.
It came on the scene last year by winning a sealed bid for what is now Chelsea Mercantile, a U-shaped structure built in four phases from 1906 to 1914. Long ago, the building housed the National Cloak and Suit Company and more recently the Federal Department of Veterans Affairs.
Rockrose also owns the lots between Chelsea Mercantile and the Fashion Institute of Technology, where it plans a 356-unit "80-20" rental project, designed by Costas Kondylis & Associates. K. Thomas Elghanayan, the president of Rockrose, said the project was made possible by the rezoning of a large swath of Chelsea earlier this year.
Essentially two buildings on an L-shaped parcel, the project will face the avenue with a bay-fronted structure of 10 stories, rising to 17 stories. An 11-story wing on 26th Street could be used as a dormitory, Mr. Elghanayan said. Rockrose will seek tax-exempt bond financing for one or both parts of the project, which would oblige it to set aside 20 percent of the units for lower-income tenants, with 80 percent at market rates.
Rockrose does not think small and Mr. Elghanayan allowed that he is pursuing other projects nearby. "I can't disclose what," he said, "but we're interested."
The Fashion Institute of Technology is similarly circumspect about its future. But Jacqueline L. Venable, the vice president for institutional advancement, said there is a master plan, within the existing boundaries of the campus, "to renovate, modernize and expand our facilities to respond to the growth in our student body and the changes in the industries we serve."
F.I.T. will offer weekend courses in decorating and refinishing next year. "I want to serve the people who want to live around here," said Prof. Elaine Stone, the acting dean for continuing education, "and make them feel that this is a community."
When Professor Stone began teaching at F.I.T. 22 years ago -- in a quonset hut -- furriers still filled numerous buildings along Seventh Avenue. No longer.
"We see a lot of consolidation in the fur industry," said Vincent Terranova, executive vice president of Bernstein Real Estate. "They are not occupying as much space as they used to." The company, which owns and manages lofts in the fur district and elsewhere, was founded by Sidney J. Bernstein, now 95, whose father was a furrier. The industry has not entirely vanished, however. For example, 150 West 30th Street is still "100 percent fur," Mr. Terranova said.
"The side streets are really remaining the same," Professor Stone said. "I think it will stay a mixed neighborhood."
Still, it is a different place than it was in the early 1970's when a self-described "neophyte broker" named Harry Macklowe of Wolf & Macklowe began selling property to a men's wear executive, Leonard Adell.
Mr. Adell had an office at the Avenue of the Americas and 31st Street. Where others saw a streetscape that had been badly stunted by decades under the Sixth Avenue el, Mr. Adell saw solid infrastructure, good transportation and high visibility.
Throughout the 1970's, Mr. Adell painstakingly assembled small parcels along the Avenue of the Americas into three sites, including the Coogan Building at 26th Street, which was built in 1875 as the Racquet Court Club but had long been used as loft space.
"This recent wave of activity is testimony that he was right," said Leonard's son, Matthew G. Adell, who is president of the Adell Corporation. "We were alone in our vision for many, many years."
The Adells failed in their efforts to obtain a rezoning in the late 70's and early 80's. Then, in 1989, the Coogan was designated a landmark as "one of the oldest surviving club buildings in Manhattan."
Two months later, the Board of Estimate overturned the designation. And a rezoning of the Avenue of the Americas was enacted in 1995. But the real estate market was not yet ready, Matthew Adell said.
Earlier this year, in partnership with Steven C. Witkoff, president of the Witkoff Group, the younger Mr. Adell bought the three sites assembled by his father. The parcels will be developed in phases, as the market warrants, Mr. Adell said. The working title of the project is "Center Six."
Construction is to begin early next year of the first "Center Six" building, between 26th and 27th Streets: a $120 million tower with 387 rental apartments. Because it will be conventionally financed, Mr. Adell said, all the units will be market rate, probably ranging from $1,700 to $4,000 a month.
There will be a mid-block plaza to the east of the building, which generated a 20 percent zoning bonus. The faceted facade steps up from a 4-story commercial base to a 37-story turret. Mr. Kondylis, the architect, said the turret would serve as an "urban signal," akin to the campaniles and domes of Europe, and that the rounded corners echoed older buildings in the area.
But the tower is also replacing the Coogan Building, which Councilwoman Quinn and others would like to save.
Jennifer J. Raab, the chairwoman of the landmarks commission, said her predecessors "did absolutely the right thing in designating the building" but that the "political process reversed the decision."
"Do you re-fight those battles?" she asked. "We decided not to do that. The political process has spoken and there is no reason to believe the politics would be any different" -- especially since the city subsequently rezoned the site to encourage the kind of development Mr. Adell envisions.
Landmarks and planning officials had more influence on the design of the Caroline, a 440-unit, "80-20" rental building on the Avenue of the Americas, between 22d and 23d Streets, in the Ladies' Mile Historic District. Fraydun Manocherian, who leads a partnership known as Whitehall Properties in the development of the site, said he hoped construction might begin in a month or two.
True to its setting in the historic shopping district, the building will have a lot of retail space -- almost 100,000 square feet.
Designed by Richard Cook & Associates and Mr. Kondylis to complement the old dry-goods stores nearby, the Caroline will rise 10 stories on the avenue, doubling in height along 23d Street. "It's completely counterintuitive to the standard statement as to how Manhattan blocks develop," Mr. Cook said, "but this was a very careful insertion into the urban fabric."
"That's such a critical site in terms of the character of the area that it deserved a building that paid attention to its obvious context," said Mr. Rose, the planning chairman. And Ms. Raab believes that "the materials and the design took a historic motif and turned it into 21st-century language."
Councilwoman Quinn is unpersuaded. "Sometimes in land use," she said, "we lull ourselves into thinking that what we've made better is in fact good."
For his part, Mr. Manocherian said the result of the long negotiations was a "very unique building." Having bought the site in 1984, he has been waiting almost as long as the Adells to begin development.
It is a couple of newcomers to the area, Albanese Development Corporation and Arbor National Commercial Mortgage, who have become the first to build on the Avenue of the Americas under the new zoning.
Their 30-story tower at 750 Avenue of the Americas, between 24th and 25th Streets, will have 300 studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom apartments, plus 15,000 square feet of retail space. It is an "80-20" project and is scheduled to open next May.
"Before we broke ground there was nothing going on" in the way of new construction, said Christopher V. Albanese, executive vice president of Albanese Development. "We're very excited that other residential projects will follow us."
Mr. Macklowe, who returned to the area a few years ago with a condominium conversion called the Chelsea Atelier, at Seventh Avenue and 24th Street, sees the neighborhood taking form. "This is a logical, sequential development from Houston Street straight up Sixth Avenue," he said. "You're going to have a concentration, which I think will really be beneficial in creating what they refer to as a critical mass."
The Macklowe Organization is planning a 31-story tower at 777 Avenue of the Americas, between 26th and 27th Streets. There are to be 291 rental apartments in this $80 million project, which will take advantage of a zoning bonus that rewards the construction of lower-income housing elsewhere in the community board district. Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron are the architects of the Albanese and Macklowe towers.
WITH the construction of these projects, Alan Boss's Annex Antiques Fair and Flea Market Inc. has lost two parking lots on which it conducts its well-attended weekend markets.
Mr. Boss expects to operate for the foreseeable future in the lot on the west side of the avenue, between 24th and 25th Streets; in the lot to the west and paralleling the avenue, between 25th to 26th Streets and in the lot on the east side, between 25th and 26th Streets. Ultimately, he might consolidate the market elsewhere.
Mr. Boss is less certain than the developers that luxury housing is the salvation of an area he has known for 23 years. "What happens when the cycle goes down?" he asked. "People can't pay $2,500 for a one-bedroom if they don't have a job."
But he also sounds resigned to the construction going on around him. "I always knew it would be developed," Mr. Boss said. "After all, it's New York."

HEADLINE: Polly Minifie, John Snyder

 BODY:
Margaret Chapin Minifie and John Michael Snyder, associates at Washington law firms, were married yesterday at King's Chapel in Boston. The Rev. Catherine S. Gibson, an Episcopal priest and the bridegroom's godmother, performed the ceremony.
The bride works at Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, the bridegroom at Collier, Shannon, Rill & Scott. 
 Mrs. Snyder, 28, is known as Polly. She graduated from Brown University and received a law degree magna cum laude from Georgetown University. She is a daughter of James M. Minifie of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Lola H. Minifie. Her father is an architect in Cambridge.
Mr. Snyder, also 28, graduated with honors from Stanford University and received a law degree from the University of Virginia. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Snyder of Falls Church, Va. His father retired as the regional contracting officer for Poland and Eastern Europe, in Warsaw, for the United States Agency for International Development.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 18; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 732 words

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Steel Instead of Wood for Homes

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI

 BODY:
THE vast majority of the houses built in the United States today are constructed with wood. About 85 percent of that wood is used for framing. Since wood has been the primary building material since Colonial times, it might seem that there is no reason for change, but wood has its drawbacks.
In the first place, the supplies of old-growth timber are diminishing. This has caused the price of construction lumber to rise dramatically over the last few years. It has also forced the lumber industry to harvest wood from young trees. This new wood has a greater tendency to warp and split as it ages. This results in cracks and warping appearing throughout the house soon after it is finished. 
 For this reason, some builders are looking for alternatives to wood as framing. One possible substitute is steel. Steel can be cold-rolled into pieces that are roughly the same size and shape as dimensional framing lumber, so they can be used for studs, joists or rafters. The pieces are rolled into a C cross section -- for that reason they are called structural-C members, C-members or simply C's -- and are coated with zinc to make them rust resistant. They are also available with prepunched slots so electrical wires and plumbing lines can be run through.
For load-bearing walls, structural members are available in 16- to 20-gauge thicknesses. Studs for nonbearing walls are available in thinner 25-gauge steel. These pieces are lighter in weight, easier to cut and less expensive than the heavier gauge pieces.
Unlike wood, steel is structurally stable and uniformly straight. That means that walls, floors and ceilings can be constructed so they are truly flat, plumb and level. Steel is moisture-resistant, so it will not dry out and warp nor will it expand in humid weather. Steel framing is also fireproof and free from rot and insect infestations.
Right now, steel framing is not significantly less expensive than traditional dimensional lumber, but representatives of the steel industry point out that prices are relatively stable, while lumber costs are rising. In the coming years, it may be more economical to purchase steel framing.
Does all this mean that wood-framed houses are a thing of the past? Probably not. Right now about 1 percent of the houses currently being constructed in the United States have steel framing. The iron and steel industry hopes to entice more builders into using steel framing, and they predict that by the end of the next decade, 25 percent of residential homes will be framed with steel.
Steel framing, however, has a downside. The biggest drawback to using steel is that steel is a good conductor of heat. A steel stud will conduct 10 times more heat than its wooden counterpart. This means that a warm house can quickly loose much of its heat through the outside walls if they have steel framing. Extra insulation will not prevent this, because the heat that enters into steel studs quickly travels laterally through the framing to the outside of the house.
Builders try to prevent heat loss by sheathing the outside of the house with high-density foam board instead of the usual plywood or particle board. This slows the heat transmission through the walls, but it has little effect on heat loss through the ceiling. Manufacturers are designing steel structural members with raised knobs along the edges that minimize the contact between the wallboard and the studs. This effectively creates a thin barrier of air that insulates the stud from interior heat. Other manufacturers are planning to introduce an insulation tape that can be applied to the stud before the wallboard is installed.
Another drawback to using steel for construction is that most professional carpenters are not used to working with it. It's true that working with steel does not require any arcane skills or even sophisticated tools; still many carpenters make no secret of the fact that they would rather work with wood.
With a circular saw, a profession carpenter can quickly cut a dozen wooden studs to length in less time than it would take to trim six steel studs with a reciprocating saw or a circular saw with an abrasive wheel. So the amount of money saved by buying structural steel may be lost in money spent for increased construction time, although this is not likely to remain a significant problem as more builders experiment with steel.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 3; Page 24; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1202 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Municipal Bonds Can Provide a Hedge, and Its Thorns Are Limited

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
YES, the headlines and the total return figures for municipal bonds the last 12 months have made for ugly reading. Do the math, though, and munis and muni bond funds come up a pretty attractive buy.
Municipal bond prices have been beaten down by a global flight to supersafe Treasury bonds, booming equity markets and the whiff of flat-tax talk in the Presidential election campaign, according to David W. Baldt, portfolio manager of Morgan Grenfell's municipal bond funds. (Proposals like those for a flat tax would generally strip municipals of their tax advantage over other bonds.) 
 As a result, yields on municipals are now very attractive for investors who want to limit risk in their portfolios, and they compare favorably with Treasuries. On Sept. 30, top-quality 30-year munis yielded 5.70 percent, on average, or 94.4 percent of the yield on a 30-year Treasury bond, before taking taxes into account. Historically, muni bond yields are only 82 to 85 percent of Treasury yields, said Steven D. Harrop, a portfolio manager at Strong Capital Management in Milwaukee.
Because municipal bond interest is not taxable for most investors, after-tax yields work out very much in the munis' favor: to beat that average yield on a 30-year triple-A rated muni after taxes, a taxable investment like a Treasury bond would have to yield 7.9 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket or 8.9 percent for those in the 36 percent bracket; the actual long bond yield that day was just 6.04 percent. (To find a taxable-equivalent yield, subtract your tax rate from 1 and divide the remainder into the yield.)
THE next question for investors is how best to buy municipals -- and the answer is not simple. Buying bonds directly, rather than investing through a bond mutual fund, makes sense for investors who want to hold the investment to maturity and recoup their principal on that date. Investors who want a more flexible vehicle might choose a fund instead.
"With a bond fund, there is no 'maturity,' " noted David P. Dresbach, a certified financial planner in St. Paul. Managers of open-end mutual funds trade securities almost every day as money flows in and out of the fund, and the portfolio is always being refreshed with new bonds.
Buying bonds directly also means a bigger commitment of money. Bonds generally cost at least $5,000 apiece and should be traded in lots of at least $20,000 to get better prices. Experts say an adequately diversified portfolio requires $100,000 or more. Bond funds, of course, provide such economies of scale -- and generally require small minimum investments.
Another consideration is credit risk. Muni bonds come in all credit ratings, from sterling to junk, and some are not even rated by independent agencies. Researching such bonds is possible for professional managers but impractical for many investors, Mr. Dresbach said.
So a bond fund may be the answer for someone who does not have $100,000 to commit to municipals or does not want exposure to unknown risks. A fund can also offer greater flexibility and opportunity to realize capital appreciation.
IF a bond fund is right for you, there is another fork in the road: Should you choose an open-end fund, one whose price reflects its net asset value, or a closed-end fund, which trades like a stock?
"For most investors, it makes sense to start off simple and work with the open-end fund," says Eric Jacobson, associate editor at Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. He said closed-end funds were more suitable for investors with sizable muni portfolios and plenty of time to study their quirks.
Open-end funds are often grouped by geography: funds that concentrate on bonds from a single state and national funds that buy munis from anywhere.
Single-state funds provide investors in that state with income that is free of Federal, state and any local income taxes. They are especially attractive for investors in high-tax states like New York and California; they offer no advantage over national funds for anyone not subject to that state's income tax.
But single-state funds can have two disadvantages. Trouble in that state's economy or politics, like the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., in 1994, can send them sinking. And because demand for municipal bonds is highest in states where taxes are highest, muni yields in those states tend to be lower than elsewhere, sometimes low enough to undo the benefit of the state-tax exemption, said Mr. Harrop at Strong, whose company offers only national funds.
Both state and national funds may be divided into categories based on the maturities of their bonds, from money market to long term. Yields are higher with longer maturities, but so are the risks that investors will be exposed to price volatility or locked into interest rates that do not keep pace with inflation.
An interesting offshoot of the national-fund category is the high-yield muni fund, so called because its portfolio tilts heavily toward bonds with low-credit ratings or none at all -- in other words, the least expensive and riskiest bonds. About 87 percent of the $98 million portfolio of Heartland High Yield Municipal Bond, for instance, is in nonrated securities, according to Morningstar.
Mr. Baldt at Morgan Grenfell said most investors should give these types of funds a wide berth because they de-emphasize a goal of most bond funds -- preservation of principal.
With a muni fund, he said, "you are really not looking to shoot the lights out with high returns." High-yield bonds are speculative but their historical returns are far below those of the stock market, he added, and they usually do not outpace higher-rated bonds by enough to be worth the added risk.
BUT Mr. Jacobson at Morningstar says some high-yield managers find good buys. "You want to try to identify a fund with a good record of managing its credit risk in the past," he said. One sign is whether a fund's net asset value has ever eroded sharply. If it has, find out from the fund if defaulted bonds were the reason, Mr. Jacobson said, though he added that such information is not the easiest to obtain.
Unlike their open-end cousins, closed-end funds trade on exchanges through brokers just as stocks do. That is where the quirks come in: most closed-end funds trade at a discount to their net asset value and are best bought in the secondary market, not when first issued. The discount bolsters the effective yield of the fund, just as buying a bond at a price below face value increases its yield.
Many closed-end funds are leveraged to further strengthen their yield, meaning that they borrow money at short-term rates, usually by selling shares of preferred stock, and use the proceeds to buy longer-term, higher-yielding investments. The difference between the two turns into added yield for fund shareholders, said Jeffrey Kratz, director of exchange-traded fund marketing at John Nuveen & Company in Chicago.
As a result, he said, closed-end funds typically yield a percentage point more than their open-end counterparts. But the leverage also amplifies the funds' vulnerability to interest rate risk compared with that of open-end funds.

Some experts think the battering has made them attractive buys. Investors can choose from single-state, national and closed-end funds, as well as high-yield offerings. HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
The Stock Market And Social Security

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Turning to Wall Street for help may not solve Social Security's potential problems, a group of researchers has found.
Investing some Social Security taxes in the stock market will not eliminate the program's projected deficit, they said. And under some circumstances, the analysis concluded, it may even accelerate it. 
 Economists from Goldman Sachs, Invesco, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and J. P. Morgan did the research for the Committee on Investment of Employee Benefit Assets, an association of corporate pension plans based in Washington.
The economists considered three environments in which 50 to 75 percent of the current surplus in Social Security taxes would be invested in stocks. They concluded that if the market performed in historical patterns, the year in which Social Security, without any other changes, would technically be out of money would be delayed from 2034, the current official projection, to between 2038 and 2046.
But if the stock market dropped 20 to 30 percent during the next five years, Social Security could run into a deficit as early as 2032, they said.
Workers, meanwhile, can expect annual letters from the Social Security Administration listing their earnings histories and projected benefits in retirement; the letters are similar to the annual benefits statements that companies must mail. The first letters were sent on Oct. 1. Half a million are to be mailed each business day, timed to arrive three months before the recipient's next birthday.
 DAVID CAY JOHNSTON
