SECTION: Section 3; Page 26; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1443 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: STRATEGIES;
Are Fund Managers Irrelevant? An 18th-Century Theory Suggests Not

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT 

 BODY:
THE debate over index funds has been exceedingly lopsided. Reason and common sense have been almost completely on the side of those who advocate investing all of a portfolio in index funds.
The statistics are familiar: Only a very small percentage of actively managed stock funds perform as well as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- just 6 percent, for example, over the last five years (although they've had more success in the last two quarters). And many people try to explain away those few funds that have beaten the market by saying they have done so by chance alone. After all, if several thousand monkeys threw darts at the stock pages of the newspaper, some of them would beat the market, too. 
 The debate is about to become a lot less lopsided. A new paper, available on the Internet but as yet unpublished, reveals that the case for indexing an entire portfolio -- tying all of it to funds that track major market indexes -- is a lot weaker than many people have thought. The study, titled "Should Investors Avoid All Actively Managed Mutual Funds? A Study in Bayesian Performance Evaluation," was written by Klaas Baks, Andrew Metrick and Jessica Wachter. Mr. Metrick is an assistant professor of finance at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, and Mr. Baks and Ms. Wachter are graduate students in economics at Brown University and Harvard, respectively.
Because it is waist-high in statistics, the paper probably won't prompt a stampede into actively managed mutual funds. But it should turn upside down a lot of people's thinking about indexing.
The first point that these academics make, if not particularly original, is nevertheless one that is not often appreciated: Just because the vast majority of managers fail to beat the market consistently doesn't mean that none have the talent to do so.
"Big deal," an indexing absolutist might say. "Even if the rare money manager has the stock-picking prowess necessary to beat the index, it doesn't alter the fact that he is in the extreme minority, and that rational investors therefore ought to put their whole portfolio into index funds."
That is where the absolutists are wrong, according to the paper, which can be read at http://finance.wharton.upenn.edu/metrick/nberap2.pdf.
The study's key assertion is that once it is conceded that even a very small percentage of managers have the ability to beat the market, it becomes irrational not to invest a big portion of an equity portfolio in the funds that have beaten the market, on a risk-adjusted basis, by the greatest amounts over the long term.
The study relies on a type of statistical analysis pioneered by the Rev. Thomas Bayes, an 18th-century mathematician, whose theory explains how probabilities should be updated in light of new information.
A nonfinancial example illustrates how Bayesian analysis works. Imagine that 10 percent of a coin dealer's inventory of identical-looking coins are special -- they are weighted so that when you toss them, they come up heads three-quarters of the time, instead of just half. Suppose, too, that before buying a coin, you are allowed to flip it to determine whether it is one of the trick coins.
Before flipping the first coin, you know that there's a 10 percent probability that it's one of the trick ones. That probability will grow slightly after the first flip comes up heads -- to 14.3 percent, according to the Bayes theorem. The probability will continue to grow after each successive flip that comes up heads. And though that probability will never reach 100 percent, after enough flips, the majority of which come up heads, it becomes a better than 50-50 proposition that the coin you're flipping is one of the trick coins.
THE researchers used a similar process to measure the probabilities that fund managers of 1,437 actively managed United States diversified equity funds would beat benchmarks in the future. It is a good analogy, because a superior fund manager won't necessarily beat his or her benchmark all the time, just most of the time.
Instead of flipping coins, of course, the researchers looked at a manager's performances in successive months relative to that of the relevant benchmark. And instead of the 10 percent initial probability, used in the trick-coin example, the researchers used a range of extremely conservative assumptions -- for example, that just 1 in 5,000 portfolio managers had the ability to outperform a benchmark. Remember, this initial assumption gives you the base upon which the subsequent probability data rest. In the coin example, it's a given, but in looking at manager ability, the authors started with extremely conservative probabilities in order to make a point.
The rest of the analogy holds up. The researchers repeatedly updated the probability that a given manager had the ability to beat his or benchmark in light of his performance in period after period. Even assuming that just two-hundredths of 1 percent of all managers had the talent to regularly beat the market, it turns out that there were a few managers who performed well enough to justify investing in their funds.
Unfortunately, though the study's extensive data base began with 1963, it ended with 1996. And its methodology is so complex that we cannot update the data easily ourselves, so we don't know which of today's fund managers have the highest probability of being market beaters. But as of the end of 1996, and under the assumption that 1 in 5,000 can outperform, just five such managers, or teams, had funds that beat their benchmarks by wide-enough margins to make them worth betting on.
Only one manager or team that made this cut through 1996 is still managing the same fund: Ralph Wanger and Charles P. McQuaid of the Acorn Fund, although Terance M. Hogan, who was also a co-manager at the time, has left the fund. Those who are no longer managing the funds cited in the study are Stephen A. Lieber, formerly of the Evergreen Fund, Charles Albers of Guardian Park Avenue, Shelby Davis of Davis New York Venture and Robert A. Lange of Lindner Growth.
As in the coin example, of course, we will never know with certainty that these few select managers really have market-beating ability -- no matter how many years they have been managing money and by how much they have outperformed the market. But the probabilities make it irrational not to bet on them, the study argues.
Deciding how much to invest with a particular manager depends, in part, on the margin by which he has beaten the index.
Before making that choice, consider what happens if you pick a manager who, despite a stellar track record, turns out to be unable to beat a relevant index going forward. It is not unreasonable to expect that his stock picks will be no better or worse than random. This means that his performance over time should match the market's before expenses, and lag behind it by an average of one and a half percentage points a year after expenses and transaction costs.
Contrast that with the potential advantage of investing with a manager who can beat the market by three percentage points or more a year. To simplify a large part of the authors' study, so long as there is greater than a 1-in-3 chance that she can do so, it makes sense to invest with her rather than with an index fund.
The authors, however, did not take taxes into account, so it is impossible to know whether any managers would "survive" their Bayesian analysis after accounting for the tax implications of trading. So it makes sense to use actively managed funds only for your tax-deferred accounts.
BUT how much of those tax-deferred assets should you invest with the best fund managers? It depends on how pessimistic you are about the probability that managers, in general, have the ability to beat their benchmarks. If you assume, for example, that only 1 in 5,000 fund managers can do so, you should invest at least two-thirds of your equity portfolio in the long-term, market-beating, actively managed winners, according to the study. If you assume that the ratio is 1 in 1,000, the case in favor of investing in the very top actively managed funds becomes so compelling that you should put all your equity position in them. Unfortunately, there are not enough statistical data to decide which assumption is more valid.
So score one for active fund management. But remember that this good news applies to very few managers -- those who can pass the rigorous testing, and who in most cases have been managing for a long time. The authors found that it makes no sense to invest in the vast majority of actively managed funds.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
NoLonger Also-Rans, Overseas Stocks Surpass U.S. Brethren

BYLINE: By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
SOME managers of international funds are beginning to remember what winning feels like. But just barely.
For the third quarter, international stock funds -- which have by and large lagged behind their domestic counterparts in recent years -- managed a relatively slim, 2.06 percent gain, on average, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. But that was more than enough to beat the average United States diversified stock fund, which was down 5.08 percent. 
 The success of the international equity funds stems largely from the resurgence of two sectors -- Japanese stocks and gold-mining issues -- that have been thrashed soundly for most of this decade. The stocks of Japanese companies have risen this year on perceptions that Japan's long-suffering economy has at least bottomed out. While the Nikkei 225 index rose just 2.8 percent in the quarter, the strengthening yen magnified the effect for United States funds that invest in Japan.
And shares of the gold-mining companies rallied in the last week of the quarter, after European central banks announced that they would limit their sales of the metal for the next five years. The price of gold rose 11 percent, to $299 an ounce, between the Sept. 26 announcement and the end of the quarter.
(Morningstar considers precious-metals funds to be international stock funds because of their high percentage of foreign gold stocks.)
Three managers of top-performing funds that invest abroad discussed the stocks that made their funds winners this quarter and -- in light of the heady run -- what they expect in the future.
 
A New Era for Japan
The Japan Fund, with 92 percent of its $840.9 million in assets in its namesake country, returned 29.5 percent for the quarter, earning it the No. 5 spot on the list of 712 international stock funds tracked by Morningstar. The fund, the oldest Japanese stock fund, returned 121.3 percent for the 12-month period, though just 7.2 percent annualized over five years.
Its lead manager, Seung K. Kwak, 38, says he tries to capture the extra return between other investors' short-term valuation of a stock and his own assessment of the value three to four years in the future.
NTT Mobile Communications Network, Japan's dominant cellular phone operator, was among the fund's biggest winners in the quarter. Mr. Kwak bought shares at their initial offering last October at 780,000 yen ($6,619) each. He said NTT Mobile, which has a leading proprietary system for the transmission of wireless data, has a lock on that market in Japan and huge potential to grow elsewhere in Asia. The shares closed at 2.1 million yen ($19,828), on Sept. 30, up 28 percent for the quarter.
Another winner in the portfolio was Fuji Bank, which rose 52.4 percent. Mr. Kwak said the company's planned merger with the Industrial Bank of Japan and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, announced in August, would bring economies of scale. "It was one of the loser banks," Mr. Kwak said, adding that the stock also received a lift from an infusion of Government funds in March and has reduced exposure to bad debts -- most of which were related to a weak company in its keiretsu, or business network.
Despite the market's run-up, Mr. Kwak said, Japanese stocks are still cheap relative to their underlying assets, sales and cash flow. The prevailing high price-to-earnings ratio -- 49 at the end of the quarter -- is a relic of management's historical fixation on revenue growth at the expense of profit margins, he said.
"Today, Japanese companies are being managed for the bottom line," he said. "We are in the early stages of a new era of modernization comparable to the Meiji era at the turn of the century."
 
Going for the Gold
The announcement by the central banks, along with their reiteration of the value of gold as a reserve asset, was music to the ears of Bill Martin, portfolio manager of the $275 million American Century Global Gold fund.
"New age investors view gold as a wasting asset that has no place in their portfolios," he said.
Mr. Martin, 35, said his fund, which ranked No. 6 among international funds in the quarter with a 28.9 percent return, is almost fully invested in gold stocks. But within the sector, he tries to keep the fund diversified along three lines. The portfolio is spread out geographically, with 60 percent in North American, 20 percent in South African and 20 percent in Australian stocks. It has a mix of low- and high-cost producers. And it includes companies with different strategies for hedging, which locks in future prices. (Such strategies tend to be very fluid.)
The fund gained 5.3 percent in the 12 months ended Sept. 30, though it has an annualized five-year loss of 11.8 percent.
Last quarter, its best performers were high-cost operators.
One of his holdings, Anglogold Ltd. of Johannesburg, rose 45.4 percent in the quarter. Mines in South Africa tend to be deep, so labor costs are high. Anglogold's average production cost is more than $200 an ounce, Mr. Martin said. So when the price of gold rose, its gross margins almost doubled.
He also invested in Battle Mountain Gold, based in Houston. The stock rose 30.8 percent in the quarter, to $3.1875. "The company has a lot of proven and probable reserves that become economic to mine with gold at $300" an ounce, Mr. Martin said. Such small gold stocks usually trade at a more modest premium to their net asset value than their larger-capitalization counterparts, but Mr. Martin said that the gap narrowed during the recent run-up in gold prices.
Another company in his portfolio, Newmont Mining, the global gold miner based in Denver, rose 30.4 percent last quarter. Also a high-cost producer, it should benefit from increasing output at a year-old Indonesian mine, Mr. Miller said.
Looking forward, he said that he was "neutral to bullish" on gold. Though he said that it was too early to guess where the price was headed, he thought it was unlikely to drop below $280 an ounce for at least the next year. He said he was keeping an eye on what he considered the two main near-term determinants of gold prices. First is the extent of "short covering," or the purchase of gold to pay back gold that was previously borrowed, either by producers as part of their hedging strategies or by speculators. The second is the demand for $300-an-ounce gold, especially among jewelers, during the pre-Christmas buying period.
 
Playing the Sector Game
"The way the world does business is changing," said Loretta Morris, 46, co-manager of the $99 million Nicholas-Applegate International Small Cap Growth fund, the No. 19 international fund for the quarter. "There are a lot of great growth stories outside the U.S."
Ms. Morris is mostly invested in Continental Europe and Britain (about 50 percent of the portfolio) and Asia (40 percent), the bulk of that in Japan. But she said she focuses more on sectors and industries than on country weightings. Her current emphasis is on service companies (about 27 percent of the portfolio), which are consolidating, and technology (23 percent).
The fund returned 19.1 percent last quarter, 73.2 percent for the 12 months ended Sept. 30 and 22.3 percent annualized over five years.
Among the retailers Ms. Morris likes are two Japanese category-killers: Kojima, which sells discounted consumer electronics and appliances, and Fast Retailing, an American-style apparel discounter. Both are benefiting from increased consumer attention to pricing, Ms. Morris said. Their stocks rose 42.9 percent and 62.3 percent, respectively, in the quarter.
Ms. Morris has also made money in Havas Advertising of France, Europe's second-largest advertising company. Its shares were up 7.7 percent in the quarter. She thinks the same forces that have powered the growth in ad spending in the United States are in place overseas: an increasing emphasis on product branding, rising expenditures by Internet and cellular telephone companies, and millennium-related promotions.
Those trends also helped lift another of her stocks, M6-Metropole Television, a French TV broadcaster, whose shares rose 14.8 percent in the quarter. Like the WB Network in the United States, M6 has the concentration of young viewers that advertisers love, Ms. Morris said.
She expects pending regulations that limit ad time on Government-owned stations to push ad rates higher for publicly held broadcasters.
Ms. Morris also bought the American depository receipts of Internet Initiative Japan, an Internet service company, at its August initial offering at $23 each. They were up 104.4 percent as of Sept. 30.
Still, Ms. Morris said she was paring holdings in Japan a bit, largely because of the price run-up, and adding more in Europe.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 20; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Swimming Against an Ebb Tide

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IT was a lackluster, disappointing third quarter for most mutual funds, but there were notable exceptions -- many of them helped by investments in innovative companies in the telecommunications, semiconductor and biotechnology industries. And smaller growth stocks in general outpaced bigger, value-oriented issues in the three months ended Sept. 30, helping those funds that tilted in that direction.
Here, stock-pickers of three top-performing funds for the quarter look back at what made their funds such standouts -- and offer a glance ahead. 

A Disciple of Growth
New technology created the winners in the $145.2 million Strong Enterprise fund, a mid-cap growth fund. It returned 19.5 percent for the quarter, taking the No. 1 place among domestic diversified equity funds. "We try to identify the leading companies in rapidly growing industries," said its manager, Andrew S. Cupps, 29, "companies that can capitalize on opportunities in a changing world."
One of his biggest winners was Sandisk of Sunnyvale, Calif., which makes what is in effect the film used in digital cameras -- the chips on which images are stored. Two million digital cameras have been sold since their commercial introduction in 1998, said Mr. Cupps, adding that sales of 28 million units are forecast for 2002 -- "and every one goes out with a Sandisk chip."
The company, he added, also makes chips that enable portable music players like the next-generation Sony Walkman -- due in January -- to play music downloaded from the Internet.
"There was no market at all for these several months ago," Mr. Cupps said, "and now they should sell several million units." Sandisk, whose stock rose 44.9 percent in the quarter, also makes chips that are built into personal digital assistants designed by Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard, he said.
Another winning stock was Broadvision, of Redwood City, Calif., a maker of software for companies doing business on the Internet. Its stock rose 80.4 percent in the quarter. Broadvision software lets companies like American Airlines offer personalized Web sites, Mr. Cupps said, by helping them identify individual customers and then offering special deals geared to their spending patterns.
He also made money in Millennium Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass., that specializes in genomics. Its stock rose 80.6 percent in the quarter. The company's research on human genes "can help pharmaceutical companies discover drugs more quickly and in a more targeted fashion," Mr. Cupps said. Millennium is currently focusing on the genetic roots of obesity.
Looking ahead, he remains optimistic. "A small group of big technology stocks and next-generation stocks have been very strong, but a whole generation of software stocks are down because of Y2K and other concerns." he said, adding that the market could resume its upward move "if the economy slows down, and there's some indication that this is happening."
 
A Monster Bet on Chips
How did the $265.1 million Northstar Special fund, a small growth fund, earn its No. 5 place among domestic diversified equity funds for the quarter? Through investments in semiconductor stocks, which made up 20 percent of the fund's portfolio, and contributed mightily to its 17.4 percent return.
"Semiconductor companies are secular growth vehicles that went through a slowdown last year, partly because of the Asian crisis and global recession, and began to come out of it this spring," said the fund's manager, Mary Lisanti, 43. "What's helping now is the strong demand for personal computers because of the Internet, cheap PC pricing and personal digital assistants."
One of her biggest winners was PMC-Sierra, a Burnaby, British Columbia, manufacturer of semiconductors used in telecommunications equipment; its stock rose 56.9 percent. The company is highly profitable and is "always considered one of the class acts in the business," Ms. Lisanti said, adding that it weathered the recent downturn better than most of its competitors did. "It's a value-added player as opposed to a commodity provider," she said, because of the specialized nature of its chips.
Another hit was Harmonic Inc., a Sunnyvale, Calif., company that makes fiber optic systems for delivering voice, data and video over cable satellites and wireless networks. The company, whose stock rose 127.7 percent in the quarter, uses a technology called wave division multiplexing that lets it expand fiber capacity by splitting light waves. "It allows you to make a 2-lane road into a 10-lane road," Ms. Lisanti said.
She also made money in Applied Micro Circuits, a San Diego designer and maker of semiconductors used in broadband communications. "It has leading-edge chip-manufacturing technology that it developed for the military, which always sent tons of data around the world," she said. "Now they're producing it commercially at a competitive cost."
The stock rose 38.6 percent in the quarter.
What's ahead for the market? "This year is the exact opposite of last year, when you wanted to own the big safe havens," Ms. Lisanti said. "Now you want the opposite -- more industrially oriented companies, to benefit from the economic recovery overseas."
She expects an inflation rate in the 2 to 3 percent range through year-end and long-term interest rates of 6 to 7 percent.
 
Thinking Small, Really Small
"We try to identify the most dynamic companies in the microcap universe that are also exhibiting above-average relative price strength," said Tom Callan, 39, co-manager with Bill Wykle, 62, of the $141.9 million Blackrock Microcap Equity Portfolio. In the third quarter, he found those stocks among emerging biotechnology and wireless communications companies.
The fund returned 17.7 percent in the quarter, earning it the No. 4 place among domestic diversified equity funds.
Among his biggest winners was United Therapeutics, a biotechnology company in Silver Spring, Md., that produces UT-15, a new version of a hypertension drug. UT-15 is administered intravenously, using a tiny portable pump instead of the awkward refrigeration unit that its predecessor required, Mr. Callan said. "It's a big step up in ease of delivery," he added. He originally bought shares in the June initial public offering. The stock was up 143.2 percent for the quarter.
He also made money in Trimeris, a Durham, N.C., company that is developing a new class of AIDS drug, called T-20, that blocks the H.I.V. virus from entering T-cells, Mr. Callan said, adding that it can be used when combination therapies and protease inhibitors are ineffective. The stock was up 15.1 percent for the quarter.
Another winner was Price Communications, a New York company that provides wireless service, mainly in Georgia and the rural South, and which benefited from accelerating growth in its number of subscribers. "The average revenue per user has remained stable, even though rates have dropped dramatically across the board," added Michael Carey, 30, a co-manager of the fund. The stock rose 75.4 percent in the quarter.
As for the future, "the market is trying to find a new level of equilibrium," Mr. Callan said. He is cautiously upbeat. "In the best-case scenario," he said, "third-quarter earnings, which should be strong, will dominate the news and that should lead a rally through year-end."

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Immigrants Build A Bridge of Barrels

BYLINE: By ABIGAIL BESHKIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Robert Peterkin finds himself with an extra $100, he spends it on two pairs of sneakers he'll never wear. Instead, he puts them aside until he gathers other household items -- rice, macaroni, underwear, combs, shoes. Then he packs it all in a four-foot-deep barrel to ship to the wife and four children he left in Haiti 10 years ago.
Like many of the Caribbean immigrants in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, Mr. Peterkin buys a little extra each time he goes shopping -- a few cans of soup when the supermarket has a special, some school dresses when the back-to-school sales start -- until he has a barrel filled. People from countries like Haiti, where the unemployment rate is 70 percent, or Jamaica, where inflation hit 10 percent in 1998, say their families and friends depend heavily on goods sent from Crown Heights, Richmond Hill and Jamaica in Queens, and other Caribbean communities in the city. 
 All along Nostrand Avenue in the heart of Crown Heights, small storefront companies specialize in shipping to countries in and around the Caribbean. They'll ship anything -- washing machines, refrigerators -- but the bulk of their business comes from "single-barrel customers," people who send life's everyday necessities to folks back home.
To the single-barrel customer, every piece of cargo is precious, said Lawrence Medas, treasurer of the Caribbean American Chamber of Commerce and Industry and owner of Medas Moving Overseas Shipping in Crown Heights.
"When you look at a barrel, sometimes you have a very sad feeling," Mr. Medas said. "It's not just a barrel that's being sent. It's the feelings, the sentiments. Sometimes a single parent comes here and they've left their family back home."
The barrels are filled with hard work, too. "People know that they're not a resident and they take advantage of them with the amount of hours and days they make them work," Mr. Medas continued. "When they hand you a barrel they say: 'This I'm sending to my children. Take good care of it.' "
The barrels, which are extremely durable, range in size. Those most commonly shipped are the super jumbos, which stand nearly four feet tall and two feet around and can hold up to 500 pounds.
The barrels cost $16 to $25, depending on size. The shipping cost is also relatively low. The storefront companies hire carriers to send the barrels by ship, and the carriers set their prices according to how many pieces they are transporting, rather than by weight. The shipping cost of a 500-pound barrel is no more than that of a 50-pound barrel, around $60. Both will make it to, say, Jamaica in two weeks.
United Parcel Service will send packages door-to-door to Jamaica in two business days, while most of the Crown Heights carriers require pickup at the receiving end. But U.P.S. will ship no more than 150 pounds to Jamaica, and the cost, $645, is prohibitive for many.
But, while the shipping and the barrels may be inexpensive, buying their contents may take a while.
"People I know, it takes them three or four months to fill a barrel," said Benfield Munroe, executive director of the Nostrand Avenue Merchants Association. "Every week they buy a little bit and a little bit until the barrel is filled." Mr. Munroe said many people start packing barrels in the summer in preparation for Christmas.
Mr. Peterkin happens to work at Medas Moving Overseas Shipping, so Mr. Medas lets him ship barrels home at a discount. Still, he combs the bargain stores on 14th Street in Manhattan. "I go shopping and I want that thing, but I buy something for them," Mr. Peterkin said. He says it takes him eight months to fill three barrels.
In late July, Milien Laurent had a barrel almost ready to go, standing in the corner of the cluttered ground floor of a building he owns on Nostrand Avenue. Visible on top were a package of pinto beans, a bag of rice and a can with a Polish ham. Deeper down, he said, were cans of condensed milk and packages of candy.
When he had enough money in mid-September, Mr. Laurent had one of the neighborhood storefront companies pick it up -- most will do so at no extra charge -- and send it on to his friends in Haiti.
"I don't have money to buy food, but I try to buy food to send to them," Mr. Laurent said. "When you tell me you're hungry and I don't have nothing to give you, it makes me sick." With inflation in Haiti still high, Mr. Laurent finds, he can stretch his dollar further by sending goods rather than cash.
There are tricks to filling the barrels. "I have an eye for bargains," said Vera Weekes, outreach coordinator at the Caribbean Research Center at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn. "For instance," she said, "the other day Pathmark had soap for 99 cents. They were three in a packet. All week long I'm in Pathmark buying up the soap."
Ms. Weekes is busy filling two barrels to send to residents of Montserrat, her native island in the Caribbean, which was devastated by a volcanic eruption in 1997.
In many cases, the barrels do not meet any dire need, but they are appreciated just the same. People often stock them with little niceties; one man said his relatives in Trinidad wanted Tommy Hilfiger perfume. Such luxuries may be affordable here but too expensive, or just unavailable, abroad.
Ms. Weekes said that when she was growing up in Montserrat, her aunt used to send just such gifts to her family in trunks from New York at Christmas.
She remembers getting processed foods; Uncle Ben's rice and refined flour were favorites, she said. But, she said, "I was more excited about the clothes and shoes than anything else."
Just like Ms. Weekes, many people who now ship barrels remember with pleasure being on the receiving end many years ago.
People who know the Caribbean well say that while sending goods back may be a hardship, it is largely expected of those living in the United States.
"They take it as second nature that you're supposed to send stuff back home," Mr. Munroe said.
Also, he said, Caribbean immigrants often do not want to admit to people back home that things are not as easy in New York as they thought they would be.
"Most people don't have a perception of America until they get here, regardless of how much they have their finger on the pulse of the U.S.," Mr. Munroe said. But however surprised they are, they want to be perceived as successful.
"You want people to know at home," Mr. Munroe said, "that you're doing better than you did when you were there."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS/INVESTING;
JunkBonds Are Quickly In a Crunch

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
SATURDAY mornings have become a little ho-hum for Tim O'Hara at the Golden Pear coffee shop in Bridgehampton, N.Y.
Mr. O'Hara, managing director and global head of the high-yield bond group at Credit Suisse First Boston, regularly runs into clients there who are picking up cups of coffee. But these days, his clients are glum. Money is getting harder for them to borrow, they tell him. And when they can get it, it is more expensive. 
 Such is the life these days of leveraged-buyout financiers -- that is, the group of Wall Street investors who borrow money to buy troubled companies with the hope of shoring them up and selling them later for a profit. The willingness of lenders to provide money for these deals at reasonable rates is dwindling. And that is affecting these financiers' ability to buy companies.
"They're waiting until next year," Mr. O'Hara said of the clients whose high-yield bond issues he underwrites. "They're not anxious to spend a lot of money."
Why the current crunch? For most leveraged-buyout specialists, trouble began last July when Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that the central bank would be willing to put the brakes on the economy by raising interest rates and tightening the supply of money available to borrowers. That sent a chill through mutual fund investors in high-yield, or junk, bonds. They began pulling their money out of the funds that specialize in such investments. As the pool of money to lend contracted, interest rates on junk bonds rose two to three percentage points, from roughly 9 to 11 percent to 12 to 14 percent, depending on the bond.
That is making it more expensive for leveraged-buyout financiers to borrow money. And to complicate matters, Mr. O'Hara said, some lenders are not only demanding higher interest rates, but are also asking for an equity stake of as much as 5 percent in smaller companies involved in buyout deals. That makes borrowing money an even more expensive proposition for the leveraged-buyout financiers, because it means sharing part of their ultimate profit with the lenders.
"Now they are forced to use money of their own, instead of borrowing it," said Kingman Penniman, president of KDP Investment Advisers in Montpelier, Vt. "They don't want to do that, or worse, give away a big piece of the company they are trying to buy."
What market watchers like Mr. Penniman have seen is the widening of the spread, or the difference between yields on high-yield bonds and on Treasury bonds. On April 30, Mr. Penniman said, 10-year Treasuries were yielding 5.35 percent, while an index of high-yield bonds averaged 9.11 percent -- a spread of 3.76 percentage points. By Friday, the spread had widened by nearly a full percentage point, to 4.67, with the high-yield index averaging 10.7 percent, compared with 6.03 percent on 10-year Treasuries.
"We've only seen spreads this wide for a short time, during the Russian default and the hedge fund debacle of last year," Mr. Penniman said. "It's way above what we've experienced historically."
Other concerns seem to be adding to the market nervousness, notably the fears that Year 2000 computer glitches will cause market disruptions that will play out detrimentally for bonds and bond holders. The validity of those fears remains unclear, though some lenders have warned customers that it will be difficult to finance highly leveraged transactions near the end of the year. "When people talk about Y2K, I look at the equity markets and I think, why aren't they concerned?" Mr. Penniman said.
To add to that, the default rate on junk bonds is climbing and is now running ahead of last year's rate, further dampening investor interest. As a result, bond investors are pouring their money primarily into the market for higher-quality bonds that offer more safety.
IN the short term, smaller buyout shops will suffer the most. Banks and other lenders have already put some of these customers on notice. One leveraged-buyout professional, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he got a call last week from an executive at a large lending institution, who told him that the bank was already winnowing its list of "preferred" clients. (His company was still on the preferred list, he said.)
By contrast, well-known and respected buyout financiers like Clayton, Dubilier & Rice are the least likely to be affected. "The situation six months ago was that you could have lesser-known companies get things done," said Bill Barbe, a partner at Clayton, Dubilier. "But now that is not as easy." As a result, Mr. Barbe added, "what will drive the market is quality transactions of size."

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
A Gloomy View of Immigration

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
FROM Mississippi to Minnesota these days, there's hardly a heartland city without a Peruvian restaurant, West African hair-braiding place or Korean green grocer. Asians are now the country's fastest-growing ethnic minority group. Hispanic people will soon be the biggest one, outnumbering African-Americans by a wide margin. Nearly one in five children born today has at least one foreign-born parent.
America's "second great migration" has prompted as much controversy as the first, which brought millions of Europeans to Ellis Island. Are immigrants one reason that America's economy has been the world's most vibrant for nearly two decades? Or are they to blame for the stagnant wages of America's unskilled workers and the growing gap between haves and have-nots? Are the newcomers models of hard work, thrift and old-fashioned family values, or deadbeats who evade taxes and collect welfare? Will their children and grandchildren join the economic mainstream or wind up in the underclass? 
 There are no cut and dried answers. But for an impressively researched, brightly written and tightly argued polemic against America's current liberal immigration policy, look at "Heaven's Door: Immigration Policy and the American Economy" (Princeton University Press, 1999) by George J. Borjas, one the nation's leading -- and certainly gloomiest -- experts on immigration.
Mr. Borjas himself is a shining example of the classic immigrant rags to riches story. A refugee from Cuba who grew up in a Miami ghetto, he wound up with an Ivy League education and today holds a Harvard professorship. But in "Heaven's Door," Professor Borjas calls for sharply restricting the number of future immigrants, especially those who, as his own family was in the early 60's, are poor, unskilled and uneducated. "My family would never have been able to pass the test that I think would best serve the interests of the United States," he writes. "There were no college graduates in my family, no wealth to prove that we would not become public charges, no particular skills that would seem urgently needed."
Since the 60's, as Professor Borjas tells it, family ties rather than education, skills or national origin have determined which foreigners get to pursue the American dream. As a result, two-thirds of the recent arrivals have come from Latin America and Asia. Four out of 10 wind up in the bottom one-fifth of the income distribution. And, by the late 1990's, the average new arrival had two fewer years of schooling than the average native-born American. In contrast, 30 years ago, most immigrants came from Europe, and the average newcomer was ahead in education.
Mr. Borjas acknowledges that, despite a "precipitous decline" in average skills, immigration is keeping an aging work force younger than it would otherwise be, and has, on the whole, been good for the economy. Unskilled immigrants provide employers with bargain-priced labor and provide middle-class consumers with bargain-priced services from baby-sitting to nursing-home care.
But, reflecting a growing unease among economists over inequality, he argues that while immigration has increased the total economic pie modestly, the far more significant effect has been to depress opportunity and pay for the most disadvantaged native-born workers, especially African-Americans. "The central issue in the debate therefore," he says, "is not whether immigration increases the size of the economic pie; it is about how the pie is split."
Perhaps. But immigration has not been a major reason that wages at the bottom have stagnated for more than two decades. Rather, the computer age has rewarded the college-educated and punished high school dropouts. Further, Mr. Borjas is overly jaundiced in his views. He scarcely acknowledges that unemployment is at a 30-year low, that poverty is at an all-time low while typical family income is at a record, or that bottom-rung wages have lately been rising briskly. True, the pay of low-wage native workers would no doubt have risen even sooner and faster absent immigration, but the extra supply of willing labor has also helped keep inflation at bay and therefore allowed the economic expansion to keep rolling.
FURTHER, Mr. Borjas argues that the sheer number and concentration of immigrants are creating the same ghetto effect that has marginalized inner-city blacks. But immigrants have lately been fanning out all over the country.
The education gap is real, and Mr. Borjas is probably right in concluding that it will take several generations to erase. But he plays down some of recent immigrants' strengths -- strong family ties and a super work ethic -- that augur well for upward mobility. Hispanics have employment rates nearly as high as whites, and, as a 1998 study showed, second-generation children have higher grades and lower dropout rates than other American children.
Few people, even the most ardent free marketeers, would argue that America should open its doors to every third-world citizen who wants to emigrate. Immigration confers permanent and scarce political and economic rights. But the case for cutting immigration in half and largely limiting it, as some countries do, to the well heeled and well educated is not nearly so economically -- much less morally or politically -- compelling as Mr. Borjas would have you believe.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Why Higher Interest Rates Haven't Fazed Auto Makers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
WHENEVER the Federal Reserve raises short-term interest rates or even hints that it might do so, as it did on Tuesday -- economists issue warnings about the consequences for rate-sensitive industries, notably automobiles and housing.
Yet, despite two quarter-point rate increases over the summer, the auto industry is thriving. August and September were among the best months ever for auto sales. The 1999 model year, which ended on Sept. 30, broke a sales record set in 1986. 
 Part of the industry's continued strength may indicate that rate increases are just slow to have an effect. But some economists are saying that the spread of retail incentives and leasing, and the aggressiveness with which manufacturers are using them, are allowing the industry to minimize the effects of interest rate increases -- at least for a while, and as long as the increases are fairly small.
"Car sales are not anywhere near as sensitive to interest rates as they once were," said Cynthia Latta, the principal United States economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, "because manufacturers will do anything to 'move the metal,' as they say in the industry."
Richard Curtin, the director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan, said the rate increases last summer have had no apparent effect on the public's interest in buying new cars and light trucks.
"It's clear from our data that the entire impact of the recent rate increases has been on the housing market," he said. "While we would normally say that interest rate changes affect rate-sensitive sectors of the economy, that has narrowed greatly."
Auto makers softened the blow from rising interest rates during the summer, mainly by using their auto financing subsidiaries to subsidize new car loans and leases, offering rates as low as zero percent for up to 36 months on some slow-selling car models.
According to the Fed, the average rate for four-year auto loans from banks rose to 8.44 percent in August, the most recent month for which data are available, from 8.30 percent in the second quarter. But the average rate charged by domestic and foreign auto makers for loans of similar maturity fell to 6.28 percent from 6.56 percent over the same period.
Auto makers are also charging about 8.5 percent now for loans on models with no incentives. But they have a much lower average than the banks because of the many subsidized loans.
Of course, subsidizing car loans is expensive for the auto makers. While auto industry profits are high, they would be far higher without them. The rising cost of sales incentives has pulled down the stocks of General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler by 20 to 30 percent since it became clear in early May that the Fed would raise rates.
Manufacturers can afford the incentives, because they are essentially passing along the considerable cost savings they are demanding, and getting, from parts suppliers, said David Bradley, an auto analyst at J. P. Morgan. "The auto makers have stepped in and have cushioned the impact" of rising rates, he added.
Van Bussman, an economist at DaimlerChrysler, said discounts were likely to remain widespread. Despite the auto market's overall strength, no company wants to be the first to accept lower sales and thereby lose market share, he said.
The lending arms of the big domestic and foreign auto makers are in particularly good financial shape right now for a rate war. They borrowed billions of dollars last winter, locking in low rates for long terms. That has left auto loan rates less closely linked than usual to the current rate for two-year Treasury notes, which leaped 11-hundredths of a percentage point last Tuesday, after the Fed's announcement.
The auto industry's rate resilience poses a potential problem for the Fed, which has long followed the industry carefully. The industry accounts for 4 percent of the nation's economic output, and a much higher share of what used to be considered the rate-sensitive portion of the economy. Diane C. Swonk, chief economist at the Bank One Corporation, said the industry's new ability to accept higher rates might require the Fed to raise rates slightly higher or faster than it would have previously to slow the economy.
ALMOST nobody questions that a large rate increase, perhaps a percentage point or more, would still hurt the industry. A big jump would slow growth in incomes and employment while damaging consumer confidence to the point that people would have less interest in buying new automobiles, even with incentives available.
Rate increases can also take as long as a year to affect the economy, so the recent small increases could eventually catch up with the auto industry. Higher rates have already slowed the pace of mortgage refinancings. In recent years, many Americans have been able to take out bigger auto loans because they have refinanced home mortgages, reducing their monthly payments.
Some auto executives, notably at DaimlerChrylser and Ford, have nonetheless been suggesting lately that their companies are no longer truly cyclical, and that they can remain profitable in an economic downturn. But even economists who think that the industry has begun moderating the effects of small rate increases say that such views require considerable optimism.
As Mr. Curtin put it, "It's always at this point in an expansion that an industry proclaims itself recession-proof."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Ina Rough Quarter, a Small Victory for Stock-Picking

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
SEISMIC shifts are often imperceptible in the stock market until well after they have taken hold. But 1999 is looking more and more like the year that index mutual funds lost their star quality.
In the third quarter, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.5 percent of its value, while the average United States diversified stock fund had a smaller loss -- 5.08 percent. Not much for active fund managers to crow about, but outperformance nevertheless. 
 And encouragingly, for the first time since the early 1990's, outperformance was the rule, not the exception, among the managers. According to Lipper Inc., more than half -- 57 percent -- beat their market benchmarks in the quarter. For all of 1998, only one-fourth of them did.
Could it be that actual stock-picking will make a comeback among fund managers, who for years made money simply by buying those stocks that had been rising the most? Perhaps. But temper that possibility with this fact: In the most recent quarter, successful stock-picking was confined to just two sectors, technology and precious metals -- a sign that the overall market has been an unrewarding place to invest of late.
Thanks to the desultory market, most stock funds closed out the quarter in negative territory. Specialized stock funds did better than their diversified brethren, losing only 2.28 percent over all in the quarter. But funds that invested in value stocks got hammered, some losing as much as 15 percent.
Only international equity funds managed to show a gain -- 2.06 percent, on average. This was largely attributable to the rebound in Japanese equities.
After years in which the same handful of stocks turned up in the top-performing mutual fund portfolios, the third quarter of 1999 gave investors fresh blood. Of the six stock funds that topped the performance list in the quarter, not one counted Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems, Lucent Technologies or America Online as major holdings.
Instead, the top-performing funds in the most recent quarter hold relatively obscure and smaller companies. The biggest holding of the Strong Enterprise fund, a mid-cap growth fund that returned 19.51 percent, the best of all diversified stock funds, is Applied Materials, a familiar name in semiconductors. But its other top stocks include less-known names like PRI Automation, a five-year-old company that helps semiconductor makers automate their factories, and Sandisk, a maker of data storage products. The No. 2 fund, Van Wagoner Emerging Growth, returned 18.46 percent in the quarter. Its largest holding is Com21, a cable modem company.
These holdings reflect the overall market's sole pocket of consistent strength in the quarter -- technology. Christine A. Callies, investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, pointed out that through Sept. 27, technology was the only sector in the S. & P. 500 that had increased in value during the previous 10 weeks. Eight other big sectors, including financial companies, utilities and basic materials makers, deteriorated during that period.
Rising stocks were in a distinct minority. According to Salomon Smith Barney, as of Sept. 28, Nasdaq stocks had declined almost 35 percent, on average, from their 52-week highs. New York Stock Exchange stocks had fallen almost 28 percent, on average, and shares in the S. & P. had dropped by 25 percent.
More alarming, 52.1 percent of Nasdaq stocks were down 30 percent or more from their 52-week highs by Sept. 28, compared with 37.5 percent of Big Board stocks and 33.2 percent of the S. & P. Investors who didn't happen to be in technology stocks felt a lot of this pain.
Only when the price of gold spiked late in September, bringing funds in that sector an average gain of 20.35 percent for the period, did technology stocks get some competition.
SEVERAL developments damaged the overall market during the quarter. The Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates twice over the summer, for a total of half a percentage point. And the weakening of the dollar, particularly against the Japanese yen, coupled with rising commodity prices, raised fears that inflation may recur.
But rather than buying on the market's dips, investors slowed their mutual fund investments as summer drew to a close. Investors put $9.2 billion into stock funds in August, a decline of 25.7 percent from July. And Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, said September's fund flows were still lower, at $5.5 billion. Mr. Adler said that most of the fresh money was still going into big-capitalization index funds and large-cap growth funds.
The slowdown in flows may indicate that investors are finally growing wary of stocks. Ms. Callies pointed out that in the postwar era, investors make broad shifts in their asset allocations once every 15 years or so. The asset allocation change that began in 1982, with the onset of a bull market in stocks, is now 17 years old. As a result, Ms. Callies speculated that the era of equity investments may be ending.
At the same time that money is flowing less freely into stock funds, mutual funds' cash holdings are low -- by Ms. Callies's reckoning, at 4.8 percent, which she puts at the extreme low end of the long-term range.
As the market indexes have skidded, it is somewhat surprising that managers are not building up cash to protect their portfolios from being hurt by a flood of redemptions. Instead, fund managers may be staying fully invested in stocks to try to jump-start their returns.
If the performance of well-known large-capitalization stocks is beginning to flag, it would fit a pattern -- identified by analysts at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company -- that typically afflicts growth stocks. In short, growth stocks do not remain growth stocks for long.
According to the firm's study, which looked at stocks between 1965 and 1998, only 42 percent of all growth stocks remained hot growers for more than five years, while only 19 percent stayed high-growth for more than 10 years. Over 20 years, only 5 percent of growth stocks kept up their steam.
The hurdles are even higher for technology companies. In that sector, less than one in three growth stocks will remain top-performers for more than five years. Looking out 10 years, the share drops to 11 percent As for 20 years, only 3 percent made the grade.
The firm concluded that technology stocks -- the ones now holding up the market -- were among the least reliable of growth companies.
Despite the pouring of money into technology funds, Mr. Adler of AMG Data Services sees a rising level of caution over all. He pointed to the activity in high-yield corporate bond funds as evidence. "There is an indication in the numbers that an aversion to risk is beginning to evolve among investors," he said.
LAST summer, after the Russian debt default, he added, "high-yield bond funds showed terrific inflows." Not today. In 10 of the last 11 weeks, there have been net redemptions from high-yield bond funds, reflecting investor concern about risk.
"That continuous type of negative activity," Mr. Adler recalled, "has only been experienced twice before" -- when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in 1994 and in the Russian default.
Of course, bond funds have been hurt by rising interest rates and inflation fears. Only those funds investing in international bonds did well, benefiting mightily from the weaker dollar.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
An Entrepreneur's Unlikely Mix

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

DATELINE: MCCOOK, Ill.

 BODY:
MIKE LYNCH would probably have stumped the panel on the old "What's My Line." His twinkly blue eyes, impishly salty language and well-cut suits would point to hard-driving real estate type, maybe, or brash young entrepreneur.
Actually, Michael W. Lynch has been both those things. But at 39, what he is -- incongruously to many, but logically in his mind -- is a metals man who loves playing David to corporate Goliaths. 
 He burst into the public consciousness in August, when his real estate investment company, Michigan Avenue Partners -- or, more accurately, its McCook Metals subsidiary -- offered to top a bid by Alcoa Inc. to buy Reynolds Metals. Neither Reynolds management nor its shareholders paid him much mind, and Reynolds has accepted Alcoa's offer. But anyone who thinks that is the end of McCook's bid has not met Mr. Lynch.
"I'm a street fighter, and if someone tells me I can't do something, I get an endorphin rush," Mr. Lynch said in his rapid-fire style. Neither Reynolds shareholders nor Justice Department regulators, who recently asked Alcoa and Reynolds for more information, have passed on the merger. So he has not abandoned "the dragon slayer" -- his nickname for his Reynolds project.
His tenacity does not surprise friends and colleagues. "Mike is very competitive, and capitalism gives him the biggest scoreboard," said Scott Miller, who was a Chi Psi fraternity brother of his at the University of Wisconsin.
Dominic Forte, one of Mr. Lynch's partners, agreed. "He gets an emotional charge from taking on the corporate giants," he said. "He's flamboyant, and he's not intimidated by anyone."
The oldest of seven children, Mr. Lynch grew up with "mixed messages all over the place," as he tells it. Money was ample, but his father kept the purse strings tight, and Mr. Lynch had to work odd jobs in college.
His parents split 11 years ago, and he has not spoken with his father in eight years. The only blood relative to whom he is really close is his maternal grandfather. "He loved my grandmother to the end -- he is the epitome of loyalty, he is my mentor," Mr. Lynch said. His grandfather turns 90 in February, and Mr. Lynch is chartering a jet to treat him to a weekend trip.
But none of this answers the obvious question: What is Michael Lynch, political science and economics major and real estate pro, doing in the grubby world of metals?
In one sense, it was a logical progression. He gravitated naturally toward real estate, an area in which competitive instincts and a gift of gab go far. After a stint as a broker for CB Commercial, he and a partner formed Michigan Avenue Partners to develop a property on that famous Chicago street.
It was 1991, the depth of the real estate depression, and Michigan Avenue picked up several plum properties at bargain prices. "I saw grown men cry in bankruptcy court, and I vowed I'd never live off debt," Mr. Lynch said.
He eventually bought out his partner, took on new ones and continued trawling for depressed real estate. Then, last year, he heard that Reynolds wanted to sell its McCook works, an old aluminum plant that sprawled across 265 acres just west of Chicago.
Most prospective buyers viewed the plant in terms of its products. But he saw a prime piece of real estate, ripe for an industrial park.
He bought it -- and realized almost immediately that McCook was overpaying for everything, from materials to electricity to insurance. "They had people negotiating contracts who should have been teaching school," he said.
Mr. Lynch convinced Reynolds's former suppliers to cut prices. He modernized the plant. And he successfully fought Alcoa in court, retaining the right to use technologies Alcoa had licensed to Reynolds. The results may give Mr. Lynch the best of both worlds: he is moving the aluminum operations onto half the site and may build an industrial park on the rest.
He has since bought Scottsboro Aluminum, Great Lakes Metals and various other metals plants, bringing the book value of McCook's metals asset base to nearly $1 billion.
"Mike Lynch is an old-time wheeler-dealer who knows how to buy cheap, cut costs, and make a whole lot of money," said Lloyd T. O'Carroll, a metals analyst at Scott & Stringfellow Inc.
Mr. Lynch is also spreading that cash around. A lapsed Catholic but a devout Christian -- "I believe in the Bible, but the church is run by dysfunctional men," he said -- he has designated $2 million for a McCook charitable foundation.
"As a little boy he dreamed of owning businesses, making millions, and using them to help others," said Kimberlee Lynch, his wife of seven years, who is expecting their third child, a son, later this month. "People say he's pompous, but he's not. He's incredibly focused, and he wants to do good in this world."
He puts in grueling days and rarely sleeps more than five hours. In August, after he became so distracted during a phone conversation that he nearly lost control of his car, he finally hired a driver. The driver picks him up at 5:30 A.M. and rarely delivers him back home until 7:30 P.M.
Still, Mr. Lynch finds time to read the Bible with his 7-year-old twin daughters, to garden at his home in Lake Forest, the Chicago suburb, and even to take some naps. That practically makes him the household sluggard. His wife, who never naps, gleaned her own seven-figure income last year as a part-time insurance agent and distributor for Starlight International's health food supplements -- many of which Mr. Lynch takes at her behest.
"He chills and winds down at home," she said. "When he's here, he's really all here."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Swept Away

BYLINE: By PETER DUFFY 

 BODY:
ELVIA SUTER was strolling down Bay 54th Street, a dead-end block in the tiny Brooklyn community of White Sands, when she stopped and gestured toward a 50-foot oak tree. An abandoned blue Chrysler filled with garbage was parked next to it.
"See this tree here?" asked Ms. Suter, a vigorous 82-year-old with salt-and-pepper hair. "When my son was 8, we went into the woods and picked it out. It was about three feet high. He came back here and planted it. The woman across the street, a German woman, said, 'Oh, it will never grow.' But he nourished it, and look at it: It's a sturdy tree." 
 She added, "My son is now 53 years old."
Although Ms. Suter, who moved to White Sands in 1924, did not mention it, the tree, like most of this six-block neighborhood nestled in the crook of Coney Island, will soon be history. Home Depot plans to demolish 41 of the community's 68 homes to make room for a 130,000-square-foot megastore that will be open 24 hours a day. The project was approved last month by the City Planning Commission and is being considered by the City Council, which is expected to give its nod by next month. A company spokesman said groundbreaking could begin in January.
The plan has generated some opposition, mostly from groups outside the neighborhood. But White Sands residents, who acknowledge that they willingly sold their homes, are already starting to pack their belongings and bid farewell. It is a bittersweet time for this tight-knit community, where neighbors know one another so well they often wander into one another's homes after a quick knock. Many go camping together in Ulster County in upstate New York.
"When I was growing up, I never had a key to my house," said John Davis, 42, an ebullient, barrel-chested city worker who has lived in White Sands his entire life, across the street from his 80-year-old aunt. "When I go to friends' houses in other parts of the city, they immediately bolt up the door, even when they leave for a short time. I couldn't live like that."
This is not a story of heroes and villains. But it is the story of the death of a neighborhood, one with its own distinctive history, traditions and characters.
"No matter how small, I don't think the loss of a community is ever insignificant," said Robert A. Caro, whose book "The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York" chronicles the destruction of East Tremont, Sunset Park and other neighborhoods that were devastated by urban development projects that Robert Moses masterminded. "Communities are things that make New York a home to its people. The values of community, of neighborhood, are things that cannot be replaced by anything else, even by the creation of jobs."
 
A Profusion of Cousins In Bright Bungalows
White Sands, a gritty, blue-collar enclave bounded by Coney Island Creek, the Shore Parkway, Dreier-Offerman Park and bustling Cropsey Avenue, is so small and insular that even Brooklyn experts know little about it.
John Manbeck, the borough historian and author of "The Neighborhoods of Brooklyn," was aware of its existence but unfamiliar with its name, which rarely appears on maps. A 1977 city study of Coney Island Creek says only that the area "is known to residents as White Sands."
The name derives from the white sand that used to cover the ground. It is believed that the bungalows that predominate, in a rainbow of colors and styles, were first built in the 1920's and set on stilts to elevate them above the sand. According to local lore, the sand was removed to restore the Coney Island beach, which had been depleted by the hurricane of 1938, and replaced by landfill.
The neighborhood is home to about 160 people, many of whom have lived there for decades. Although those early bungalows are small and ramshackle and the neighborhood itself has patches of deterioration, other, newer houses are proudly maintained, dressed up with gardens and smart additions. Since all the streets dead-end and there is no through traffic, it's a quiet place. It isn't uncommon for residents to drag lawn chairs into the middle of the road for a midnight card game.
White Sands families have stayed put for generations, and relatives abound. Eileen Tomaselli, 57, is typical; a smiling, chatty woman with feathered gray-blond hair, she is a lifelong resident. She and her husband, Anthony, and her son David live on the same block as her two other grown children, James and Danielle. A block over is her sister, Eleanor Barrack, who lives across the street from her sister-in-law, Lucille Gormely. Ms. Gormely, in turn, lives next door to her cousins, the Hamanns. Many older residents own several properties, which they rent to relatives.
"You get a lot of cousins that live around the corner from each other," said Harold Costino, 47, whose parents settled in White Sands when he was a toddler. "If somebody moves into the neighborhood, it is usually someone who is known. 'Oh, that's the Murphys, they are friends of. . . .' Very few cold strangers move in."
The neighborhood has traditionally been Irish and Italian, but it also includes Scandinavians, Germans and at least one Seneca Indian, Mr. Costino. Two years ago, a Chinese family and a Pakistani family moved onto one block. The men of the community usually have blue-collar jobs, as plumbers, carpenters, electricians and city employees.
Legend has it that the grandparents of the Brooklyn-born singer Connie Stevens once lived on Bay 54th Street and that young Connie would sometimes visit. Or was it Ms. Stevens who lived in White Sands? "The story always changes," one resident said.
Until recently, outsiders used White Sands as a dumping ground for stray dogs and stolen cars. The dogs became an integral part of the community, barking furiously at a stranger or a strange vehicle. Neighborhood youngsters built forts out of the cars. Recreation revolved around Coney Island Creek, where, despite the chronic pollution, children fished for fluke, bluefish, crabs and eels.
Perhaps the community's best-known resident is Jerry Bianco Sr., 78, a shipyard worker and patriarch of a large White Sands family, who attracted attention in 1971 when he built a yellow submarine. The 41-foot-long vessel, intended to salvage sunken ships, was launched into Coney Island Creek with great fanfare. Eventually, a storm dragged the sub toward Gravesend Bay, where the conning tower, no longer yellow, still juts out of the water. It is one of many stories in a neighborhood where residents easily fall into reminiscences.
Neighbors come together as often as any extended family would. At Christmas, a resident dresses up as Santa Claus and drops by each home. When a baby is born, everyone visits the newest arrival. The phrase "block party" is redundant in White Sands, because every party is a block party. If a few people are out barbecuing and drinking beer, it isn't long before a crowd has gathered.
 
The Coming of Home Depot, Benefactor and Destroyer
During the era of Robert Moses and the giant public works projects he spearheaded, it was government that destroyed neighborhoods, often against the wishes of the residents. Perhaps most famously, the Cross Bronx Expressway was built through the heart of East Tremont in the 1950's, displacing thousands and snuffing the life out of the community. Today, large-scale development is typically the work of private corporations, and the loss of a neighborhood becomes a matter of negotiation, as in White Sands.
Home Depot, which with 860 stores in North America is the country's largest retailer of home improvement products, began eyeing White Sands in 1993. According to John Simley, a company spokesman, Home Depot believed that southern Brooklyn could support another branch. The nearest Home Depot, three miles to the north on Hamilton Avenue in Red Hook, has done a brisk business. "Gangbusters is how I would characterize it," Mr. Simley said. The company also operates a store seven miles away in Ozone Park, Queens. In all, it has six stores in the city.
Plans in White Sands call for a big-box store with a garden center and a parking space for 580 cars. It will cost "several tens of millions of dollars," Mr. Simley said, and is scheduled to open early in 2001. In exchange for mapping and zoning changes that allowed the development to proceed, the company has promised to landscape the 13.75-acre site, build a walkway along the creek, improve sections of the park and upgrade local roads. The store will provide 150 to 200 permanent jobs, Mr. Simley said, 85 percent of which are earmarked for Brooklyn residents.
"Above all, we try to be a good neighbor," he said. "We don't want to disrupt or create problems when we locate."
As White Sands residents remember it, company representatives began making contact with them in 1994. Robert Barrack, who as full or part owner of 19 mostly vacant properties is one of the largest landholders, said he and his wife, Eleanor, were the first to be approached.
"They gave fair market price," Mr. Barrack said. "They are not stupid. They start low and you work your way up. They weren't hard-nosed about it. They were more than fair."
According to the latest tax assessment records, market values of homes in the neighborhood are $80,000 to $250,000. Although most residents were reluctant to disclose how much they would receive for their houses, Mr. Bianco said Home Depot has agreed to pay him "close to $200,000" for a home he bought in 1984 for $35,000 and improved extensively during the last 15 years.
Some residents were initially reluctant to strike a deal, among them Ms. Suter, who has lived in White Sands longer than any of her neighbors. Her home had been built by her father and moved to White Sands in 1924 from what is now the Belt Parkway. She still remembers the day the house arrived, pulled by a horse. "My father told my mother: 'Let her stay home from school. Maybe some day she will remember this.' " She can still picture the horse in her mind's eye.
Home Depot representatives telephoned Ms. Suter for two years before she agreed to talk. "One time they called and I asked, 'What are you going to do with my property?' They said, 'Oh, we are going to make a parking lot.' And I hung up."
Eventually she decided to sell, she said, because relatives encouraged her to do so and because all her neighbors were selling. She also worried that the city might condemn her property.
Other residents were less reluctant to sell, largely because of the deterioration of the neighborhood: the homeless people who live in Dreier-Offerman Park and the garbage that collects on the streets. They are troubled by other inconveniences. Since their homes were never connected to the city's sewage system, residents must maintain cesspools. Snowplows arrive only after servicing other neighborhoods, and street sweepers rarely come at all.
But even those residents who are not losing their homes are ambivalent. While Home Depot has promised to pay for double-glazed window and mechanical ventilating units to alleviate car noise and exhaust for the homes that will remain, those residents believe that the heart of their community has been cut out.
"Let's see," said Mr. Davis, whose home is among those that will survive the wrecker's ball, "I'm going to trade my neighbors for windows and an air-conditioner?"
The people of White Sands are not the only Brooklynites with mixed feelings about the project. Residents of the surrounding neighborhoods of Coney Island, Bath Beach and Gravesend have expressed fears about traffic congestion, and Community Board 13 voted against the project on the ground that too few traffic studies had been completed, although it has no power to stop the project.
In the eyes of the city government, however, the arrival of Home Depot will mean only good things for the neighborhood, the borough and the city.
Borough President Howard Golden cited the economic troubles of the area, noting that the immediately adjacent neighborhoods have the highest level of unemployment in Brooklyn. In a report to the City Planning Commission, he predicted that Home Depot would "contribute to the revitalization of Coney Island" and "expand employment opportunities and improve the city's tax base."
The commission agreed. "It is a well-planned economic development for the area," said Jennifer Chait, a spokeswoman for the commission.
The project is also in line with the Guiliani administration's position of encouraging megastores. Three years ago, the Mayor proposed that big-box stores be allowed in certain industrial areas without requiring public review. Legislation to that effect was defeated by the City Council.
Although the City Planning Commission could not provide statistics on how often single-family homes are displaced by megastores, Ms. Chait, the agency spokeswoman, said that between July 1998 and June 1999, 13 residential areas were rezoned to permit some form of commercial use.
One former city official has vigorously opposed the project. Irwin Fruchtman, a Gravesend resident who was the Commissioner of the Department of Buildings under Mayor Edward I. Koch, has spoken out against the new store at public meetings and in letters to community newspapers. He has attacked the city for "turning somersaults" for big developers, and has asserted that small businesses in southern Brooklyn will be hurt by this newest project.
"Home Depot wanted a location that would complete their triangle, and the city is giving them all the help they need," he said in an interview last week.
 
The Departure From Paradise
Every year, on the Fourth of July, the entire community gathers for the neighborhood's largest celebration. This year's event, held on an empty lot on Bay 53d Street, was billed as a bon voyage party and drew hundreds of revelers, many of whom had long since left the neighborhood. Prior to the day, David Tomaselli, an up-and-coming executive with a small record label who was the organizer of this year's event, had collected hundreds of family snapshots from his neighbors and transferred them onto a videotape, which he projected on a large screen during the party. Afterward, neighbors hugged one another and wiped away tears.
A few days ago, sitting on a sofa in his home, David Tomaselli, his mother and Ms. Barrack showed the video to a visitor and provided an informal narration. An anecdotal history of the neighborhood over seven decades, its images ranged from the sand-filled streets of the 1930's to last year's baby pictures. There were shots of dogs yapping in midair, people clowning around on camping trips and nearly every party held at the Ben Mc Chree Boat Club on Shore Parkway, the site of virtually every important White Sands celebration. One group of pictures was devoted to a neighborhood football team, called the Creek, which defeated local high school squads back in the 1970's and 1980's.
Although the residents have not yet received their checks from Home Depot and do not know exactly when they will have to move, they are already preparing to depart. Ms. Suter is thinking about Staten Island. The Barracks are relocating to Ulster County. James Rotollo, 70, who has lived in White Sands for 40 years, is heading to West Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Tomaselli plans to get an apartment in Bay Ridge. His parents aren't sure yet. "Everything is so expensive," Ms. Tomaselli complained.
Last weekend, several families held yard sales to begin the process of clearing out. Signs were put up on Cropsey Avenue and visitors drove into the small enclave looking for bargains amid the cracked china, mismatched silverware and rusted tools. Ms. Barrack, whose grandparents arrived in the 1920's, wandered around taking pictures of her neighbors. In front of her home, Ms. Tomaselli was leafing through a scrapbook of photographs.
The mood was wistful.
"There is a serious, serious emotional tie," David Tomaselli said. "It is impossible to replace this. Even people who decided to go amicably have an emotional tie."
His mother said, "People who don't live here probably think it is a dirty old slum."
But, she added: "We grew up here, and we had fun all our lives. This was our paradise."
