HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Bank Stocks and the Jinx of Fed Credit Tightening

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
"RISING interest rates are bad news for banks."
Every time the Federal Reserve starts to tighten credit conditions, that nostrum is trotted out to explain why bank stocks are suffering. But for the last two decades or so, the banks' big problems have not been caused by rising rates. 
 No matter. Bank stocks have been suffering this year, in part because investors have sold shares as the Fed has raised short-term rates. After peaking in late April, a time when most folks thought the Fed was friendly, the Keefe Bruyette & Woods Banks index has fallen 15.3 percent.
Unfortunately, it may be a while before Wall Street's attitude toward the sector sweetens. Lawrence W. Cohn, a bank stock analyst and director of research at Ryan Beck Southeast Rearch in Livingston, N.J., explained why last week. Here are excerpts from that discussion:
 
Q. Why is this perception about rising interest rates being bad for banks misplaced?
 
A. That universally held misconception drives bank analysts around the bend. And it goes back to the early 1970's, when after roughly four decades of stable interest rates, this country went through the first of several bouts of inflation.
In the postwar context the banking industry had never had to defend itself against that, and banks got their clocks cleaned. Traditionally, banks had never paid attention to looking at the sensitivity of their balance sheets to rising rates. The experience was very painful.
In every succeeding rate cycle since then, and there have been five, banks have gotten increasingly sophisticated in managing risks by doing a variety of things, from repricing assets, changing the mix of their liabilities to inventing various kinds of derivative instruments that allow them to shift risk to someone else.
All of that has given the industry an ability to manage rate risk.
 
Q. But doesn't that perception explain why bank stocks have come down this year?
 
A. A rise in interest rates is a big chunk of the reason, but not all of it. There has been a real shift in attitude about where we are in the economic cycle.
Last year's problems in the capital markets, coupled with the Long-Term Capital crisis, began a view that the cycle couldn't go on forever. And that has led to increasing concerns about asset quality.
 
Q. Economic data don't support the thesis that the expansion is nearing an end. And isn't the Fed raising rates to cool off the economy?
 
A. We don't see any signs the economic cycle is coming to an end. But we have gone through this before.
Back in 1988, when the economy was quite strong, bank stocks acted quite poorly. The issue then was worry about the end of the cycle when nothing indicated it was here.
At some point this cycle will end, and when the market is worried about that, things are tough. The thing that makes this such an extraordinarily frustrating period for people in my profession is that the stocks stay very cheap for a long period of time.
 
Q. You mentioned concerns about asset quality. Are there areas where banks are overextended?
 
A. We have already seen some of the excesses in the system. Subprime consumer lending has gone through a terrible period, as has credit card quality. But that has been improving now for more than a year.
Over all, though, we don't see anything that would make the next recession comparable to what the late 1980's was for the banks. When it comes, the next recession will be sufficiently modest for the industry that you will see a decline in earnings, but not much else. If the market sees that modest effect, then you are finally going to get a multiple on bank earnings that better reflects the underlying growth of the industry.
 
Q. Absent a recession, can you see anything on the horizon that would prompt investors to take a second look at the group?
 
A. A recession is the only thing that will cause the market to reassess this situation. We had hoped that as the market saw the better capital and reserve position of the industry, it would recognize that banks were in better shape than during the last recession, which for banks was the worst since the 1930's. But it has not come to pass.
At some point yields on these stocks will reach a point where they start to create a floor.
 
Q. For the past couple of years a good number of bank stocks had a takeover premium built into their stock price. Merger activity has slowed this year. Why?
 
A. The primary reason is the drop in stock prices. But it was not possible that 1999 was going to be as active in the merger area as 1998 was, because by any measure that was an exceptional year of merger activity.
Merger activity has picked up a little recently, and we still expect a rush of activity as banks try and beat the 2001 deadline, when pooling-of-interests accounting gets eliminated.
 
Q. Are there any stocks you like at this point, given the market's sour mood on the group?
 
A. We think the place to be is those kinds of companies that are less exposed to movements in interest rates from a perception standpoint and from a business standpoint.
That brings us to companies with big processing or money management businesses, like Bank of New York, Northern Trust, U. S. Trust and Mellon Bank.
We also like companies with solid dividends and the capacity to grow those dividends. In that area, we like People's Bank of Connecticut, which has been growing their dividend at a 20 percent compound annual rate for the last five years. We think they can do that for the next several years.
 
Q. So people should stay away from the big money center banks?
 
A. The money centers are stocks that will have the hardest time making progress. At some point they will get so cheap they will drag in value investors. But they are stocks that have had substantial asset quality problems at the end of the economic cycle. When they move out of institutional favor, as they are now, it is hard for them to move higher.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
In E-Commerce Frenzy, Brave New World Meets Old

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
WHEN Amazon.com declared two weeks ago that it was beginning a bold campaign to become an Internet shopping bazaar, Wall Street applauded. And why not? Amazon, a corporate poster child of the New Economy and pioneer of on-line retailing, would be collecting money from any business, large or small, that wanted to set up shop under its cyber-tent.
Besides, Amazon really needs the cash. Its losses are mounting, as they are for most Internet merchants. But, Amazon explains, the red ink merely underlines the scale of its ambitious investment for future growth. 
 And what is Amazon spending so lavishly on these days? Building a high-tech bunker of supercomputers or hiring battalions of software wizards? No, Amazon is spending much of its money on a half-dozen huge warehouses across the country.
The New Economy is increasingly coming face-to-face with the old: Net code hackers and money hustlers meet the members of Bricklayers Local 247. The hot, new fields of the Internet economy suddenly include distribution and logistics, the humdrum backstage of business. Indeed, as electronic commerce moves into the mainstream -- an estimated 17 million American households will purchase on line this year -- it has prompted a new appreciation for the business skills of the old bricks-and-mortar world.
Customers, it seems, still have decidedly off-line standards of service. They demand timely delivery of goods and the ability to easily return merchandise that proves disappointing, for example.
The on-line retailers who come up short on those fronts, industry analysts predict, will be casualties in the coming consolidation among on-line retailers -- a Darwinian winnowing expected to begin during this year's Christmas shopping season as winners are sorted from losers.
"A lot of the dot-com retailers are going to fold after their venture capital money runs out," observed David Pecaut, a senior vice president of the Boston Consulting Group.
Curiously, the biggest winners in on-line retailing could well be today's department stores, discount chains and specialty stores. In fact, 62 percent of E-commerce sales are accounted for by bricks-and-mortar and catalog companies that also have begun on-line ventures. Within five years, Mr. Pecaut expects that share to rise to 85 percent as companies like Wal-Mart, Nordstrom and Sears improve their performance on the World Wide Web.
THE reason, he says, is that their assets from the "legacy world" -- well-known brands, distribution networks, stores and purchasing power -- will prove to be advantages, and increasingly so in electronic commerce. The leading on-line brands like Amazon and Ebay, for example, came onto the marketplace a few years ago as innovative newcomers, when cyberspace was far less crowded and Internet brand-building was far less costly. The chance of an Internet start-up gaining that kind of brand recognition today, Mr. Pecaut says, is slim.
"For marketers, the superior economics in the future are going to come from the old standards of business -- and not just being on line," he said.
The new catch phrases of modern retailing have embraced that notion: multi-channel retailers, integrated shopping and 360-degree marketing. All are meant to convey the concept of servicing -- or assaulting -- the consumer on many fronts, on line and off.
Some Internet companies are even using their high-priced shares as currency to buy bricks-and-mortar counterparts. For example, the on-line auctioneer Ebay purchased Butterfield & Butterfield, a San Francisco-based auction house founded in 1865, for $260 million in stock earlier this year.
The statistics for on-line retail sales, and projections of future revenue, show meteoric growth. Yet a closer look at the numbers suggests how much traditional retailing retains its hold, despite the rapid, up-from-zero growth of E-commerce. On-line sales in the United States will rise sharply this year to $20 billion and jump to $185 billion by 2004, according to Forrester Research Inc., a technology research firm in Cambridge, Mass. Still, the $185 billion figure, even if it proves accurate, would represent only 7 percent of the nation's retail sales in 2004, the firm maintains.
The rise of the Internet has clearly created not only new wealth but a new sense of economic opportunity.
"The essence of the new Internet economy is its ferocious speed, the faith that this is a big deal and the uncertainty that it will pay off," said Thomas Eisenmann, an E-commerce expert at the Harvard Business School.
The economic payoff from Internet technology will almost surely come first in an area that gets the least attention: its use as a low-cost communications technology to automate all kinds of business transactions. "The Amazons of the world get all the press, but the real growth in electronic commerce in the next five years is going to be in the business-to-business market," said Peter Schwartz, chairman of the Global Business Network, a consulting firm.
FUELING that growth will be companies using the Web instead of faxes, telephones and face-to-face meetings to handle the "back office" tasks involved in trading with their corporate customers and suppliers. Forrester Research projects that the business-to-business market could reach $1.5 trillion by 2003.
But even the Internet-assisted overhaul of dealings among businesses in the next few years represents an evolutionary instead of a revolutionary step. Much of the anticipated transformation amounts to doing the same chores more efficiently because of new technology -- as was true with the telephone and, before that, the telegraph, which has been called "The Victorian Internet," in a book published last year (Walker & Company) by Tom Standage.
And if the past is any guide, the surest corporate winners in the E-commerce business may be the suppliers of basic tools and services for the Internet: computers, software and technical know-how. That, at least, seemed to be the lesson of the last great gold rush in California. It was the general stores and saloons, not the miners, that pocketed the steady money.

LENGTH: 3364 words

HEADLINE: Tearing Down The Facade of 'Vitamins Inc.'

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
THE scope of the conspiracy boggles the mind. For a full decade, top executives at some of the world's largest drug companies met secretly in hotel suites and at conferences. When Federal investigators were closing in, they moved to the homes of high-level European executives.
Working together in a coalition they brazenly called "Vitamins Inc.," they carved up world markets and carefully orchestrated price increases, in the process defrauding some of the world's biggest food companies, including Kellogg, Coca-Cola and Nestle. 
 It was, in the words of Joel I. Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, "the most pervasive and harmful criminal antitrust conspiracy ever uncovered."
In May, after the conspiracy collapsed, those involved agreed to pay nearly $1 billion to settle Federal antitrust charges, by far the largest criminal fines in American history. And further penalties could come in Europe and elsewhere. The companies involved have pleaded guilty to the Government's charges, but they have refused to discuss details of the case beyond what the authorities originally charged.
Now, virtually every big vitamin maker in the world is on the brink of agreeing to pay an additional $1.1 billion to resolve a consolidated class-action suit brought by purchasers of bulk vitamins -- the raw vitamin ingredients that go into everything from cereal and orange juice to vitamin pills and chicken feed. The suit alleges a wide variety of anti-competitive practices.
How could a conspiracy on this scale ever be born, much less survive a decade? How, in a global marketplace filled with sophisticated buyers and sellers, could a group of multinational corporations, largely from Europe and Asia, avoid detection for so long?
They did it, interviews with investigators and a review of court documents show, with a sly mixture of corporate panache and tight discipline -- nourished by a European tradition that actually encouraged such anti-competitive practices. The big vitamin makers aren't talking, except to say that they regret fixing prices and are working to keep it from happening again.
"We can't dispute the facts and we've decided it is of no value to unravel it. The situation is behind us," said Carolyn R. Glynn, a spokeswoman at Roche A. G., which is based in Basel, Switzerland. "We've paid dearly for it."
But even lacking chapter-and-verse corporate confessions, it is still possible to piece together the outlines of this historic swindle.
 
The Origins
2 Giant Companies In Secret Talks
It all began in 1989, when executives at Roche and BASF A. G. of Germany began holding secret talks about price-fixing, Government investigators said. At the time, both companies faced pressure from rivals and from the prospect of falling prices.
Their solution was to agree, in secret, to carve up the vitamin market and to recruit other big vitamin makers to come in on the arrangement, like Rhone-Poulenc of France and Takeda Chemical Industries, Japan's largest pharmaceutical company. Because these companies have operations in the United States, this was a blatant violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
"These companies seemed to be indifferent to the possibility that the antitrust laws would be enforced," said Robert Silver, a lawyer at Boies & Schiller, of Armonk, N.Y., who filed the first class-action suit against the vitamin makers in 1998.
Roche was the ringleader. Its executives, Federal investigators say, organized the meetings, coordinated the price-fixing and ordered documents destroyed. And it wasn't just one Roche officer but a succession of high-level executives who carried out the details of the plot.
The company had gone this route before. Roche's antitrust problems date to the early 1970's, when it was fined by antitrust officials in Europe for engaging in anticompetitive behavior in the sale of two tranquilizers, Librium and Valium.
Roche also faced litigation over the vitamin market in 1973 after Stanley Adams, a high-level executive in its vitamins and fine chemicals division, sent a confidential letter to antitrust officials at the European Commission in Brussels detailing what he said was Roche's violation of European law in its dominance of the bulk vitamin market.
In "Roche Versus Adams," his 1984 book, Mr. Adams said the company regularly fixed prices. Roche would "get together the major vitamin and chemical producers and talk prices with them," he wrote. "Meetings were held, often in Basel. The manufacturers discussed world prices for different vitamins and chemicals and set a price which they all agreed to keep."
Although the vitamin price-fixing accusations were never proved, and Mr. Adams himself turned out to be less than a savory character -- he was jailed in 1994 for plotting to murder his wife for the insurance payoff -- the story he outlined turned out to be eerily similar to the one Government investigators described in the more recent vitamin case.
In both cases, there were said to be meetings in Basel, coordinated price increases and threats to smaller competitors. By the 1990's, Roche, BASF and Rhone-Poulenc, which together controlled more than 60 percent of the world's vitamin supply, formed a giant price-fixing phalanx, the Government said in court documents.
Roche alone had revenues of $3.3 billion in the United States while the conspiracy was running, and during that time, Justice Department investigators say the conspirators gradually and artfully raised the prices of raw vitamins, so as not to attract notice. They also rigged the bidding process. The average price of bulk vitamin A was $11.59 a pound in February 1990; in November 1998, it was $19.84 a pound, according to a study by the lawyers. The Justice Department says that $5 billion to $6 billion in United States commerce was affected.
The vitamin conspiracy wouldn't be just a European operation for long. In 1991, three Japanese vitamin makers -- Takeda, Eisai and Daiichi Pharmaceutical -- joined in. And a year later, prosecutors say, the cartel included Lonza A. G. of Switzerland, Chinook of Canada and as many as 10 other vitamin makers, including Ducoa. There are few American companies involved in the production of vitamins.
As the operation went global, there were regular meetings in Switzerland, Germany and elsewhere with a varying circle of participants, investigators said. The companies exchanged sales and market-share data, illegally coordinated price increases and decided, region by region, who would get what share of the market, right down to the half percentage point, and even the penny, the Government said.
There were also efforts to prevent cheating and regular "budget meetings" to make sure everyone was on the same page, according to the Government's court documents. "This was a very elaborate and effective conspiracy," one high-level Justice Department official said. "The companies operated as if they were a single entity. And they were very precise. It was greed, pure greed."
 
The Environment
Raising Suspicions Of Wider Price-Fixing
The vitamin business, to be sure, is not unique. Even as some of the largest chemical and pharmaceutical companies atone for the sin of cornering the vitamin market, antitrust experts say the very length and existence of the vitamin cartel raises troubling questions about the possibility of price tampering throughout the food industry.
In the last few years, Federal prosecutors have broken up three international food and agriculture cartels that lasted for more than a decade. The Justice Department says there are now 35 Federal grand juries hearing evidence about the possibility of other global cartels operating in this country, affecting billions of dollars in commerce.
And in the wake of a number of large mergers in food and agriculture, as well as criminal price-fixing convictions earlier this year against executives at the Archer Daniels Midland Company, some of the nation's leading antitrust lawyers say the legal remedies now available may not be enough to thwart price-fixing cartels.
"This is not a one-time thing that has been rooted out," said Kenneth J. Adams, an antitrust lawyer who joined the class-action suit against most of the large vitamin makers. "There's no reason to believe this won't happen again."
Although Justice Department officials say they have successfully smashed the cartel, even Government prosecutors say they are astonished at what took place over the past decade.
Not since the reign of I. G. Farben, the German chemical giant that operated as a state-sponsored conglomerate in the 1930's and 1940's, has an international cartel so effectively and systematically manipulated a world market.
In a sense, such collusion can be seen as part of an age-old tradition. Some experts say the secret vitamin pact may have grown out of a corporate culture that encouraged collusion, and legal systems in Europe and Asia that were then far more accommodating to price-fixing than the American legal environment.
"Until recent times, European countries didn't have laws that stopped cartels; in fact, they had laws that encouraged cartels," said George L. Priest, a professor of law and economics at Yale University. "But today, virtually every country is coming around to the view that the more competition, the better the economy."
What the vitamin conspirators controlled was most of the world's bulk vitamin production -- vitamins A, C and E, niacin and other B-complex vitamins -- a $1 billion-a-year industry in raw vitamin ingredients.
The big companies sell the raw vitamins to animal feed operations, food and beverage makers, and pharmaceutical and cosmetics companies, which turn the raw products into off-the-shelf vitamin tablets and even skin cream.
 
The Warnings
Animal-Feed Mixers Fight Back Early
America's largest food companies, which blend raw vitamins into things like bread, rice and juice, said they were unaware of any unusual pricing practices.
"They saw the price increases and inquired about them," said Jonathan D. Schiller, another lawyer at Boies & Schiller, which sued vitamin makers on behalf of big food companies like Land o' Lakes, the butter maker.
"But the vitamin makers justified the increases by saying that it was exchange rates or production cost increases," Mr. Schiller said.
But the animal feed industry, which bought huge amounts of bulk vitamins and used them to produce healthier and faster-growing livestock, was more alert to the conspiracy.
Vitamin producers shipped raw vitamins, often in powder form, to a vitamin blender, or pre-mix operator, who then created a special blend of vitamins that was sold to large farms and animal feed operations, like the huge chicken farms of Tyson Foods, the world's largest poultry producer.
It had worked that way for decades, until the 1980's, when vitamin makers saw the American pre-mix industry as a source of additional revenue -- a way, some lawyers said, for the companies to strengthen their hold on the world's biggest market for bulk vitamins.
BASF entered the blender market in 1986. According to lawyers for the independent blenders, BASF and Roche later tried to destroy small mixers with what the lawyers called predatory pricing.
BASF executives declined to comment, but small pre-mix blenders say BASF charged them high prices for raw vitamins while selling blended vitamins directly to animal feed operators below cost, in the hope of snuffing out their independent rivals.
"They threatened us," said Eugene E. Reed, a former vitamin blender in Little Rock, Ark., who told investigators that in 1997 he sat in on a meeting in Atlanta with a BASF executive who made threats against an American blender.
"They told a friend of mine: 'You need to remove yourself or you'll be forced out of the business.' "
There were logical reasons for combining production and blending, like getting to market faster. But lawyers involved in the class action say the larger economic reason was simple: eliminating competition.
"You squeeze out the guy in the middle," said Mr. Adams, the lawyer for the pre-mix blenders. "You vertically integrate, and then you control both ends."
By the mid-1990's, blenders and animal feed producers had grown increasingly suspicious.
Among themselves, they repeated tales of threats to small blenders, and some vitamin customers complained about a lack of competitive bidding.
"We did notice that the bids seemed to be unusually consistent," said Les Baledge at Tyson in Springdale, Ark.
"And if you went to a competing company they said the supply wasn't available."
 
The Trail
One Cartel's Collapse Fuels New Inquiries
For the vitamin cartel, the beginning of the end may have been signaled by the scandal at Archer Daniels Midland. In 1996, the company agreed to pay $100 million to settle Federal charges that in the early 1990's executives had conspired with European and Japanese companies to fix the prices of feed additives.
At the time, it was the biggest international cartel ever uncovered by Federal prosecutors. One key Archer partner was Roche, which agreed in 1997 to pay $14 million to settle criminal charges that it helped fix prices for one additive, citric acid.
The Archer case cracked open because of Mark E. Whitacre, an Archer executive who secretly tape-recorded company executives discussing price-fixing with rivals. Then came confessions from other executives. During the investigation, Justice Department officials heard Roche might have also been fixing prices in the vitamin market.
But there was no immediate confession on vitamins, partly because there was no tape and no mole. When Kuno Sommer, head of marketing in the vitamins and fine chemicals division of Roche, a key participant in the meetings on citric acid, was questioned by Federal agents in March 1997, he denied that there was any price-fixing in vitamins.
Federal agents later discovered, according to the Government's settlement documents, that before the 1997 interview, Mr. Sommer had "met separately with at least two other high-level Roche executives. At the end of those meetings, it was understood by the individuals that if Sommer was asked about Roche's participation in a vitamins cartel, Sommer would lie and deny that such a cartel existed."
By that time, private antitrust lawyers had already begun their own investigation in hopes of winning a huge settlement. Among their findings was a memo Mr. Sommer had written in September 1993 that suggested a continuing price-fixing scheme. "Good experience with citric acid," Mr. Sommer wrote before a meeting with Archer executives. "Next opportunity B2. We think it's worth that we explore all possibilities of cooperation. Let's explore cooperation product-by-product."
By 1998, some of the nation's leading law fims joined the fray. Cohen, Milstein, Hausfeld & Toll was investigating the case. And lawyers at Boise & Schiller -- headed by David Boies, who is prosecuting Microsoft for the Government -- filed suit on behalf of J & R Feed Services in Cullman, Ala., accusing large vitamin makers of conspiring to fix prices. A year later, the Justice Department brought its first price-fixing charges against Lonza of Switzerland. Then the department turned to the biggest players.
Initially, the big three vitamin makers -- Roche, BASF and Rhone-Poulenc -- denied the charges. Even when lawyers working at Roche first learned about the conspiracy in late 1997 or early 1998 and directed that it be stopped, according to other lawyers involved in the case, the cartel continued to operate. Meetings were moved to executives' homes to avoid detection.
 
The Turning Point
One Big Player Comes Forward
 But earlier this year, Rhone-Poulenc broke ranks. It came forward as part of an amnesty program, begun in 1994, that offers leniency to the first company to cooperate in a Federal antitrust investigation. Some lawyers involved in the case say Rhone-Poulenc was eager to appease regulators scrutinizing its pending merger with Hoechst A. G., the German pharmaceutical giant, which earlier this year paid $36 million to settle Federal charges that it had conspired to fix prices on food preservatives.
After Rhone-Poulenc's confession, the cartel's wall of silence crumbled.
Roche and BASF stepped forward. So did a large group of Japanese companies, which agreed last month to pay $137 million to settle vitamin price-fixing charges. Roche was hit the hardest, though, agreeing to pay $500 million to settle charges, equivalent to about one year's revenue from its vitamin business in the United States. Two Roche executives have been sentenced by Federal courts to prison terms of a few months. BASF paid $225 million and Rhone-Poulenc avoided any fine.
Partly as a result of those payments, the Justice Department's antitrust division has already recovered $1 billion in all cases this year, more than in the previous 30 years combined.
Archer Daniels Midland "was not the iceberg; it was the tip," said Mr. Klein, of the Justice Department, in an interview.
 
The Future
Will a Settlement Prevent Repetition?
What was it about vitamins that nourished a conspiracy?
Antitrust experts say international cartels develop because the right dynamics are in place. Most operate in concentrated markets with few players, making it easy to coordinate pricing. They also operate in businesses that require a big investment to enter. And price-fixing commonly involves commodities, like paper or chemicals, because generic products are harder to differentiate, allowing conspirators to price uniformly. Vitamins were a perfect fit.
Even though there have been huge sanctions against the conspirators, some experts worry that the penalties may not be enough to prevent cartels from reappearing. Mr. Adams, the lawyer, said the Justice Department ought to compel the breakup of the cartel's American subsidiaries, because they have already killed off many of their competitors. "The Justice Department could have imposed structural relief to inject competition," Mr. Adams said.
The vitamin cartel made billions of dollars, he said, often with price mark-ups of 20 percent, far more than the cartel will repay in criminal fines. "That made it worthwhile," he said. "Their thinking was, A: You might not get caught. B: If you get caught, you pay the ticket. Is this simply an expensive license to keep stealing?"
The Justice Department doesn't think so. Officials say the agency has fulfilled its legal duty. They add that the antitrust division does not have the authority to restructure foreign companies and does not want to force them to break up American subsidiaries. "The penalties coupled with the jail time I think is a far greater deterrent than structural relief," Mr. Klein said. "I'm confident that we've nuked this cartel."
Still, questions remain about whether the big vitamin makers, which still dominate the world market, will try again to raise profits artificially. Even after the Archer Daniels Midland scandal and government investigations into the vitamin market, investigators say Roche continued to operate at the head of the cartel. "They basically kept perpetuating it, basically saying it's worth it," one Justice Department official said.
And though Roche was hit with big fines for being a repeat offender, Roche executives say the conspiracy was carried out by a small group of rogue executives.
"You will understand that this was not part of our responsibility," Franz Humer, the chief executive, said at a news conference in Basel after the settlement. "It is certainly not easy to understand the reasons for actions of employees who in secrecy organized a conspiracy of this kind."
BASF executives said something similar, arguing that there is no foolproof way to prevent another cartel from developing. "There will be no 100 percent guarantee that even with audits, everything will be legal," Eggert Voscherau, a BASF board member, said in an interview with The Chemical Markets Reporter in July. "We cannot set up a police state."

Chart: "The Vitamin Fix"
Last May, some of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies confessed to taking part in what Federal investigators now say was a huge, decade-long conspiracy to fix prices of bulk vitamins around the world.
 
THE BIG PLAYERS -- Estimated current United States market share for all bulk vitamins, a $1 billion market:
 
ROCHE -- 60%
BASF -- 28%
RHONE-POULENC -- 7%
OTHERS -- 5%
 
1989
 
LATE 1989 -- Roche of Switzerland and BASF of Germany begin to conspire to fix prices and divide up world vitamin markets, according to Federal prosecutors.
 
1991
 
LATE 1990 AND 1991 -- Rhone-Poulenc and several large Japanese vitamin makers join the price-fixing conspiracy, Government officials say.
 
1993
 
1993 OR 1994 -- A BASF business plan spells out its intent to end competition among vitamin blenders and control 90 percent of the market, according to a class-action lawsuit filed against BASF and other vitamin makers.
 
1996
 
OCTOBER 1996 -- Archer Daniels Midland agrees to pay $100 million to settle Federal charges of price-fixing in the lysine and citric acid markets. As part of the investigation, the Government questions Barrie R. Cox, an Archer Daniels executive, who describes his company's plot to fix prices. He also gives details of Roche's key role in the conspiracy.
 
1997
 
JANUARY 1997 -- At a meeting in Atlanta, BASF executives threaten one of the company's small competitors, according to lawyers for the class-action suit.
 
MARCH 12, 1997 -- Kuno Sommer, a high-level executive at Roche, admits that the company engaged in price-fixing in the citric acid market but denies that price-fixing occurred in vitamins. Government investi 2/3gators later learn that Mr. Sommer was coached by other Roche executives to lie.
 
MARCH 26, 1997 -- Roche pleads guilty and agrees to pay $14 million to settle charges that the company fixed prices and allocated markets for citric acid with Archer Daniels and others.
 
1999
 
EARLY 1999 -- Rhone-Poulenc tells investigators that it took part in the cartel. (Because of its early cooperation, Rhone-Poulenc is not fined.)
 
FEBRUARY 1999 -- The vitamin conspiracy ends, according to Government documents.
 
MARCH 2, 1999 -- Lonza of Switzerland, along with five executives of other companies, pleads guilty to price-fixing in vitamins.
 
MAY 20, 1999 -- Roche and BASF agree to pay a record $725 million fine to settle Federal charges. The next day, the chairman and the chief executive of Roche attribute the conspiracy to a small group of rogue executives.

HEADLINE: A Leader's-Eye View Of Leadership

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
LAWRENCE A. BOSSIDY spoke of the value of hiring those who have failed. L. Dennis Kozlowski shook his head at the "absurd" valuations of Internet companies, while Charles B. Wang talked about having dot-com envy. Shelly Lazarus defended the $80-million-plus pay package that Hewlett-Packard recently awarded its new leader.
Early one Monday morning in late September, these four chief executives -- Mr. Bossidy of Allied Signal, Mr. Kozlowski of Tyco International, Mr. Wang of Computer Associates International and Ms. Lazarus of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide -- gathered over coffee at The New York Times to talk about leadership and how they do their jobs. All are featured in a recent book, "Lessons from the Top: The Search for America's Best Business Leaders," (Doubleday/Currency, 1999) written by Thomas J. Neff and James M. Citrin, two executive recruiting consultants from Spencer Stuart in New York. Mr. Neff and Mr. Citrin also joined the discussion, as did Reed Abelson, Alison Leigh Cowan and Patrick J. Lyons of The Times. 
 The four chief executives brought different perspectives to the two-hour discussion. Mr. Bossidy, who has more than four decades of business experience, helped turn around Allied Signal and is currently merging it with Honeywell to create a company with $25 billion in sales. Mr. Kozlowski has guided Tyco through the purchase of more than 100 companies since he took over as chief executive in 1992. At Computer Associates, one of the world's largest independent software concerns, Mr. Wang managed the transition from founder to the leader of a company with more than $5 billion in annual sales. And while the agency that Ms. Lazarus runs is not an independent or public company -- the London-based WPP Group acquired it in 1989 -- it has long been one of the most successful advertising agencies in the world.
Much of the discussion focused on the challenge of managing people: the fierce competition for talented employees, the need to communicate effectively, the growing demand for a healthier balance between work and life outside the workplace. The four also frankly discussed compensation, and all noted the importance of their own actions in conveying the values of the companies they lead.
Following are excerpts of the conversation.
 REED ABELSON
 
Making Their Mark
 
Q. What kind of thoughts do you have about the legacy you're going to leave behind? Is it just to have the biggest company?
BOSSIDY -- It isn't size that is as important to me as to have the employee base be convinced that we were always willing to change a lot of things, that the company had some edge.
KOZLOWSKI -- We went out and did a reverse acquisition of ADT a couple of years ago where we had to charge our shareholders capital gains on the deal. It was a pretty unpopular decision with shareholders and even with my board. I hope to exemplify leadership in a way that we're willing to do things that are unpopular.
WANG -- I don't know if legacy is defined only in business. If I could be remembered for something, it's probably how I raised my kids and what else I did. As much as we think we're very important, I think we forget there's probably somebody in our ranks who thinks they can do it better and probably can do it better. Our job probably is to make sure that they have the right values.
LAZARUS -- I inherited a legacy, which came home very much to me when David Ogilvy died. We had a memorial service, and thousands of employees returned who hadn't worked for the company in 20 and 30 years because the emotional connection to what David founded was so remarkable. So I see my job much more is to keep that alive.
WANG -- Why wouldn't you make your own legacy?
LAZARUS -- Well, because it's marvelous, because it's founded on a set of values. It's not founded on a personality, on an individual. And it's a set of values that are all about excellent people and excellent work and all about recognizing individual contribution. I've stayed for 28 years because I believe in all those things.
 
Success and Succession
 
Q. The book "Lessons from the Top" is clearly a reflection in time. As we approach 2000, what qualities and skills will your successors need?
BOSSIDY Trying to stay ahead of the game, trying to work with a work force which is far more independent than it was when I started and trying to be responsive and keep those organizations at the leading edge will be the challenge.
I mean, you could be a C.E.O. 10 years ago and never have talked to your employees. You talk to them every day now.
This notion of C.E.O. and C.O.O. chief operating officer , which I think is awful, will go in the next 10 years. It's a bad thing under a set of circumstances that doesn't envision transition immediately, because it separates two jobs that should be joined.
KOZLOWSKI -- I agree that the C.O.O. concept is a dangerous one in most companies, because it really separates the C.E.O. from the operating groups.
WANG -- You know, maybe by the traditional definition of what the C.E.O. or C.O.O. does, what their job function is, perhaps you can say that. But maybe I'm fortunate. I know who the next C.E.O. is: He's my C.O.O. But he doesn't really operate in that traditional sense. We do things together. He happens to have the unfortunate task of doing everything I don't like to do.
If you asked him, he'd probably tell you he can run the company better than I can. And I hope he feels that way, because that's what makes somebody who should be the C.E.O.
LAZARUS -- The thing that keeps me up at night is the scarcity of talent. In my industry, we keep recycling the same eight people. There's so much opportunity for young people now -- the world of the Internet and start-ups and dot-coms, and 28-year-olds making $50 million overnight. The challenge for us is to figure out how to keep those people long enough that they are ready to become C.E.O.'s.
BOSSIDY -- I think there's more talent than ever before. The trouble is, it migrates to narrower places. A few years ago, if you didn't go to a consulting firm, you weren't essentially in the main. Now if you're not with a dot-com you're basically not allowed to the party.
KOZLOWSKI -- There are 20-year-olds coming out of college now, and out of graduate school, that are far brighter and have a far greater perspective of the world than anybody did in my class. But there's another thing that's happening, too: Really talented, bright people are starting to question the life styles that are involved in this kind of work.
LAZARUS -- Absolutely. I think we're going to have to get much more flexible and open-minded about how we -- I don't even say employ people -- but how we source resources. Because there are people who are now saying, "I'll give you X number of hours a week but I am not signing up as a full-time employee."
Q. Can you give us an example of the flexible arrangements you find yourself making?
LAZARUS -- Well, we have a man who wants to live in Penelope, Tex., where he has a ranch. I'd make him a creative leader in my agency; he doesn't want to do that. He said: "I will sell you 40 percent of my time. And I will also retain the right to refuse an assignment if I don't want to do it."
He has done a brilliant job for us, absolutely brilliant. If I can get five more of him, if I get a hundred more of him, I would take them.
BOSSIDY -- You've also got to be careful that the only people you retain aren't those who are risk-averse and don't want to do the dot-com situation. So I say to our people: "Let's go get some people from the dot-coms right now. They're failing every day. But at least they showed the interest and the courage to take some risks."
Q. So failure can be a good thing?
BOSSIDY -- I used to hire real estate people. I always hired ones that had failures. I wanted the person who had lost a lot of money for somebody else to come work for me. You don't reward -- you don't praise -- failure. But it can be a wonderful thing in terms of what you learn.
Q. Even if the failure is very public?
BOSSIDY -- I think every failure needs to be analyzed. Why? What happened? And sometimes you've got to stand up, yourself, and say, "I was a part of that and I have as much responsibility for it as anybody does. Now, let's make sure we don't make that same mistake again when we develop another product."
WANG -- I think what you've got to do is take the blame. I mean, ultimately you give all the credit to your people and you take all the blame.
We tell our people we're no smarter than any other company in the world. The problem with all the other companies seems to be, they may spend five times the amount of time to make decisions, spinning about what went wrong: "It's really not my fault." And all of that time could have been used to make decisions. So if we could just cut out all the spinning, then we'd have that much more time.
KOZLOWSKI -- Any time you're going to try something, at whatever level, there's always a risk of failure.
BOSSIDY -- And if you study it for three months, or study it for a day, probably the percentages are about the same.

Embracing the Internet
 
Q. These days, one primary reason that chief executives seem to fail and are shown the door is the Internet.
KOZLOWSKI -- I don't see the Internet as being the demise of C.E.O.'s. There are a couple of examples, maybe, but C.E.O.'s usually trip over themselves. They make slow decisions or bad decisions or invest the money in the wrong way or don't have a focus -- aren't quick out of the box.
LAZARUS -- I think the healthiest thing that's coming out of this whole Internet phenomenon is that the good C.E.O.'s are rethinking the whole way they go to the market.
So it's not the Internet per se. I think that becomes sort of like a distraction. But because you have this new capability -- this new way to distribute, inform, communicate -- the good companies are stepping back and saying, "What does this mean about the whole way we go to market?"
BOSSIDY -- One of the things I try to do is get everybody in the company involved on the Net in some way -- manufacturing people, more outsourcing; purchasing people, more global sourcing. And you can use it as a way to reinvent the company. You get a whole new set of excitement; some new people come to the fore. You do some things experimentally that you would never do otherwise.
 
E-Communicating Pros and Cons
 
Q. You all lead large organizations. How do you stay in touch with your employees?
WANG -- Get a good C.O.O.!
BOSSIDY -- There's such a thing as the E-mail now. And you have an easier time communicating with anybody than ever. You can issue E-mails, you can get E-mails, all the time. And I think it's essential that you do.
LAZARUS -- But I also think there's no substitute for face-to-face.
BOSSIDY -- I agree.
LAZARUS -- Something happens when you are in the room with people with whom you work, trying to solve a problem together or just listening to them. And the E-mail becomes more meaningful after the trip with the face-to-face.
KOZLOWSKI -- We have 140,000 employees in 80 countries. And it takes a lot of face-to-face time, a lot of travel on my part, to be able to articulate our goals and where we're going.
But I really like showing up. You know, I really like being there and being able to have a dialogue like this.
BOSSIDY -- If you aren't willing to communicate and if you're not good at it, you're at a disadvantage. You have to do even more than you've ever done before in whatever way you do it, but it's something that you ought to do every day, someplace.
KOZLOWSKI -- Employees are far more willing to critique -- openly critique -- the C.E.O. than ever before.
BOSSIDY -- That's better than having it only in chat rooms.
LAZARUS -- I agree.
WANG -- I don't have E-mail. I force my people to get in touch with me. And it takes an effort. And it must be important, then, too.
And I travel a lot. Once a year we also bring all our field people together for what we call a kickoff. We spend a week of basically bringing them all up to date on what's happened. But as you get bigger, you still have to force the issue of thinking small, because otherwise you end up in a bureaucracy that can choke you.
 
Fair Play in the Numbers Game
 
Q. What about that other constituency: the institutional investors, the analysts?
WANG -- My C.O.O. deals with Wall Street.
KOZLOWSKI -- I spend 10 percent of my time communicating with investors.
BOSSIDY -- One of the things I think C.E.O.'s do is understand who your constituents are, and one of them is share owners. You've got customers, you've got employees, you've got suppliers, you've got share owners, you've got communities in which you live. You've got to spend time with all of them.
 
Q. Does paying attention to the share owners make you too short-term at times?
KOZLOWSKI -- You absolutely have got to deliver what you promised in the short term. And you've got to have a strategy in place worrying about two years from now. I pretty much know what the next year and a half will look like and have a forecast in place that I'm very confident in.
LAZARUS -- I'm actually sitting here thinking this is probably the only benefit of having been acquired hostilely by an English company.
 
Q. We have seen very good managements run into trouble when they surprise analysts. But then, maybe truly good managements never surprise analysts.
BOSSIDY -- You're better off to run it on the basis that you avoid those surprises to the fullest possible extent.
NEFF -- You could probably get away with one surprise.
KOZLOWSKI -- I don't agree.
BOSSIDY -- No. The price is immediate.
KOZLOWSKI -- Yeah. You miss earnings by a penny and you can lose $3 billion of market value the same day.
 
Q. Doesn't that increase the temptation to have a little bit in the back pocket to make sure you're going to make your numbers?
KOZLOWSKI -- It increases the temptation of making sure you give appropriate guidance to Wall Street as to where you think you're coming out.
You can't manage earnings. There are very specific accounting rules and S.E.C. rules now that preclude one from going that route. But it really is terribly important to have good communication and good visibility of your own businesses, so that you can become, and are, and continue to be a predictable company.
WANG -- I don't know if you really can be that predictable. There are a lot of things beyond your control. We do so many deals a year. Some of them can slip by a few days. You don't know until almost the -- actually, till the last day of the quarter, many times.
Q. You see a company that makes its numbers for 15 years in a row. Do you suspect they're just lucky enough to be in a very predictable business, or do you suspect that the chief executive is good at making the numbers?
KOZLOWSKI -- I think they're good. I think companies like G.E. are good. They're well-run companies.
 
That Urge to Merge
 
Q. This is a golden age for mergers. Do you see that changing?
BOSSIDY -- I think it depends on two things: What's the interest rate environment and what's the stock market going to be?
I think there's benefit to being big. To Charles's point, I think you want to be as big as you can and run it as small as you can, as a way to be quick.
KOZLOWSKI -- When interest rates fluctuate, pricing usually comes down on companies to be acquired and you're more inclined to use some combination of stock and cash in those deals. I would expect, for any horizon I can see, a Tyco that would continue to be quite active.
BOSSIDY -- Dennis, let me ask you a question. What's going to happen to your view if pooling of interests, a method of accounting for mergers is eliminated?
KOZLOWSKI -- I think what we attempted to do with Raychem -- where we could have pooled Raychem and shown another penny or two a share but where we used half stock and half equity -- is the kind of deal that you're going to see going forward. However, part of the proposal is showing earnings before the amortization of goodwill. Then you have the best of all worlds. And there are so many unintended consequences of poolings, limitations that the S.E.C. puts on you -- not being able to sell off things that you don't want to have, on the purchase of your own stock -- I think it's almost a good thing that poolings will be eliminated. It will protect us from ourselves.
BOSSIDY -- I agree. I think there's going to be a lot of furor expressed on the potential elimination, but I don't think at the end of the day it's going to have much impact.
 
A Brave New World?
 
Q. Does this unprecedented period of prosperity herald a "new economy," or are you afraid that it's got to end pretty soon?
WANG -- I think we are in a new economy. I think we've gone through this kind of industrial age, the marketing age, and now we're really in an information age. And I think the people we call the knowledge workers are expected to have more information and make decisions faster.
KOZLOWSKI -- It's a true global economy now, too, that just didn't exist five years ago, where you're buying and selling on a worldwide basis, and your competitor now may be in Indiana, or your competitor may be in Brazil, or your competitor may be in Germany.
Plus, the information technology that you have available to you now allows you to see a lot of things on a real-time basis that you weren't able to see five years ago.
Q. Is the business cycle gone?
KOZLOWSKI -- No, probably not. In business, as far as I know it, the good times get bad and bad times get good. Maybe there are longer cycles now.
BOSSIDY -- I think, too, there's another factor, which doesn't mean that markets won't, over time, change.
I think the U.S. has a big competitive edge now. We have taken a lead in the information technology. We've taken the lead in Internet. I don't say that we're destined to always have that advantage, but I do think in the last number of years we've moved faster than the Europeans, we've moved faster than the people in the Far East.
Q. So higher price-to-earnings ratios are justified?
BOSSIDY -- I think on a global basis, yes. You know, markets are smart.
Q. What about the Internet valuations? Do you all wish you had dot-com at the end of your company's name?
KOZLOWSKI -- No. Some of it is absolutely absurd.
WANG -- I wish we had dot.com.
We do so much business on the Internet, but traditionally, the perception has been that we are a plumbing company, what's behind it. Our software manages the largest Web sites in the world, and we have more security software than any other independent software company. And yet our valuation is not a dot-com.
LAZARUS -- Once you relax the profit requirement, you know, it's very different. And we have clients coming in who are new dot-com companies who say, "We have an advertising budget of $70 million, $80 million," and you sort of press them on the economics.
I just saw where Etoys today is going to invest 70 percent of their sales last year in advertising in the next three months. I mean, it's madness.
BOSSIDY -- But you know, therefore, that's going to stop.
LAZARUS -- It's got to stop.
BOSSIDY -- But I do think that the medium will continue.
Tom, what percentage of your placements have been Internet placements in the last 12 months?
NEFF -- In terms of current assignments in the U.S., it's into the double digits. It's probably approaching 15 percent, currently. So we've had over 100 active search assignments for Internet C.E.O.'s.
 
Q. Many a brilliant marketing campaign aims to familiarize the public with these new Internet names. What about the companies that possess the old great names?
LAZARUS -- Well, I think they have an advantage if they use it. Sears, which is one of our clients, as a name for the old catalogue company, as a place that you trust to get merchandise, is brilliant. But they've got to get onto it or Amazon.com is going to become the retailer of the year 2000. I mean, because I don't think they're stopping at books.
WANG -- I really believe that an established business should look at a hybrid type model instead of thinking of this as a separate, distinct silo. Imagine if you could get on line, buy books and at the end of your whole order, you have a choice: send it to me or go drive through a drive-through window at Barnes & Noble and pick up my package.
BOSSIDY -- And yet, it's ironic that because of Amazon.com, Barnes & Noble's got a better household recognition than ever before. So the question is: Can you capitalize on that?
 
The Chief as Superstar
 
Q. Last week George Shaheen surprised all of us by jumping from Andersen Consulting, which he ran with an iron fist, to the Webvan Group, the Internet grocery vendor. Out of his mind?
KOZLOWSKI -- He has the opportunity to make a whole lot of money over there, from what I've read. So, you know, it's like the risk somebody pointed out before: if he has a shot at $100 million or thereabouts, it's probably a reasonable place to go. And he's probably a pretty capable executive, so it's a risk worth taking.
 
Q. Do the media exaggerate the extent to which the C.E.O. is the company and the company is the C.E.O.?
KOZLOWSKI -- I've thought about that a lot, and I think the difficulty you have is it's hard to talk about a company -- that Allied Signal did this or Tyco did that.
BOSSIDY -- I think you ascribe brilliance too soon. I mean, you take a Jack Welch of General Electric for 20 years -- he deserves it. He's come through good and bad times and always has done well. But I don't think you should do it in terms of a year or two. I mean, you might want to see them season a little.
 
Q. What about C.E.O. compensation? There is some concern that while the market's been doing wonderfully, C.E.O.'s have made out more than handsomely.
BOSSIDY -- The press had something to do with that. They didn't like salaries and bonuses, so they said, "You ought to put more of your income at risk." And so the corporations did, and now they're complaining about that.
But when I get asked in my own audiences, I say: "I make a lot of money. And take on a lot of risk."
And then I say, "Our savings plan is up $2.5 billion since I came." That doesn't mean just me -- the whole company has made a lot. And the people who own the stock in the company make a lot of money.
KOZLOWSKI -- I do not receive one single penny of bonus unless my earnings per share grow over 20 percent a year. However, I do start accruing restricted shares of stock, and I make an awful lot of money in the stock. We pay taxes on that, and our compensation is totally in line with the shareholders. And one could look at it and say, yeah, we truly are overpaid, but a lot of it's been the appreciation of the stock market.
WANG -- It's been noted that I got a $600-and-some million grant. But people don't realize this was a plan that was approved by 86 or 87 percent of the shareholders. If we brought a value of $18 billion to shareholders, I would think then we'd earned a bonus. It was a five-year plan with a seven-year tail.
KOZLOWSKI -- You got a $600 million grant? I'm glad I'm not your shareholder.
BOSSIDY -- I wouldn't mind being your adopted kid.
LAZARUS -- I had a fascinating conversation last week with someone who was absolutely outraged by Carly Fiorina's pay package when she recently signed on at Hewlett-Packard . And I said, "Yes, but why would she have come otherwise?"
 
Q. It's often said that at a certain level it no longer matters how much any of you make, that you would be doing just as good a job for $100 million less or $20 million less.
KOZLOWSKI -- Yeah, all my meals are paid for, for as long as I'm around. So, I'm not working for that any longer.
But it does make a difference in the charities I ultimately leave monies behind to, and it's a way of keeping score.
BOSSIDY -- Hewlett-Packard doesn't have a habit of going out and paying exorbitant salaries, so they wanted her Ms. Fiorina to run the company, and that's what the market was, and she got the market price. How can you be critical of that?
LAZARUS -- I don't even know her, but I think she would have considered herself foolish if she left all that money on the table. Why would she do that?
 
Setting an Example
 
Q. Do employees and other stakeholders in the companies look to activities outside the executive suite as signals about the chief executive's leadership and values?
WANG -- I think charity is a personal thing. We also recognize the company is also a member of the community and the world at large. What I try to do is encourage my people to give. If you're an employee of C.A., if you give $1, C.A. will match $2 for it. So this way we really push them to give more.
BOSSIDY -- I think, though, there is an issue as to how much time a C.E.O. should spend doing other things.
I think you're hired to run the company. That doesn't mean you should be ignorant of what's going on in Washington, but you ought to go down there selectively as opposed to weekly.
I don't think you can get involved in a whole bunch of charities. I think you can get involved in a charity and then spend some time, and influence it, and try to make it better. But the more I see C.E.O.'s fragment their time doing a lot of other things, I think, the less successful they're going to be.
LAZARUS -- I'd like to answer your question in a somewhat different way, because I think I'm always asked these questions about balance and how do you retain women.
How I spend my time and how I communicate my own values and my own priorities does have a very significant impact on the employees in my company. So that when I stay out for three months for maternity leave, I am well aware that that makes it all right to take maternity leave.
And if the C.E.O. isn't going to the school play, and the C.E.O. is canceling his vacation, and the C.E.O. is not coming home to be at his 6-year-old's birthday party, well then, the rest of the company knows how they're supposed to behave.
 
Q. We still haven't seen too many cases of women with small children running large organizations.
WANG -- Why is it different for women? I raised my three kids. One of them is 28 years old. And I raised them while I was building Computer Associates. Now I have two more kids. One's 6 and one's 1 year old. I go to the school play. I'm the one that goes to the parent-teacher conference.
 
Q. There is a widely cited statistic that two-thirds of the men who work, are married and have children, have wives who stay at home, but hardly any working wives with children have stay-at-home husbands.
WANG -- My wife works. She works for C.A. She has 4,000 people reporting to her.
KOZLOWSKI -- So she is your successor?
WANG -- No, she's not. She's too nerdy!
BOSSIDY -- I've had nine children. There's no reason why you can't be president and do a lot of the things as the kids grow up. I did.
And I do think the hardest deal in the world is for a woman to have two or three young kids, to work when their spouse works. That is just physically exhausting. That takes a toll after a while. And I don't know what we in business have done yet to be able to resolve that.
KOZLOWSKI -- We've tackled it a little differently in the last couple of years, where we've put about 8,000 of our managers through diversity training, approaching all types of issues, from creating a culture where a man or a woman can work from the home, to being much more flexible in their abilities to make contributions to a company, to being supportive of maternity leaves before Congress mandated them. And I think you really need to do that, because if not, you're going to eliminate an awful lot of talented people out of your pool of resources.
LAZARUS -- The smart C.E.O. has to do that. Why would you give up 50 percent of the population when talent's a scarce resource?
BOSSIDY -- I tell people: "Don't come in here on Saturday and Sunday unless something special is going on, because all you're going to do is become a bore. I mean, do something, music or whatever you like, but for heaven's sake, grow." They'll say, "How many Sundays do you work?" I work a couple of Sundays a year, only because something special is happening.
 
Q. What is the one thing about being a chief executive that you would change with a wave of your hand, if you could?
KOZLOWSKI -- I'd probably eliminate the jet plane, so that we wouldn't be expected to be in so many different places so often. Jets have really destroyed civilization.
WANG -- One thing is, don't perceive us C.E.O.'s as some kind of higher order of human beings. I really want to work with people and not have a meeting where everybody is, "He's here, so I've got to be on a different kind of behavior." I wish they would just relax.

HEADLINE: Hard Times in the 90's

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Boom Generation" (Op-Ed, Oct. 8):
T. H. Watkins doesn't need to hearken back to the Great Depression to teach his Generation Y students a cautionary tale about economic downturns. When I graduated from Columbia in 1991, the school canceled a jobs fair because companies weren't interested in attending. The highest salary listed on the university's jobs board was $8 per hour. Contrary to what the economic revisionists say, the last recession lasted from 1988 to 1994. 
 Things have changed dramatically. Now hundreds of companies compete for my alma mater's newly minted graduates. Thoughout the 80's and early 90's, Gen Xers, who were then under 30, faced underemployment, hopelessness and staggering student loan debt. And for today's young people, optimistic as they may be, that last part hasn't changed.
 
TED RALL
New York, Oct. 8, 1999 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 967 words

HEADLINE: Correspondence/Vienna, Rightward;
Something's Afoot in Austria, But It Isn't Goose-Stepping

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: VIENNA

 BODY:
WEDGED inside a crowd in Vienna's central square, listening to a politician harangue the throng while 200 student demonstrators behind you scream "Nazis, raus! Nazis, raus!" at him, it's important to quell those waves of memory and remind yourself: You don't speak German, stupid. Forget all those black-and-white films you watched as a kid. This isn't "Triumph of the Will" even if you're getting the guttural aural cues. It was your father who was in on the Normandy landing; you only caught the flick.
Outsiders often think they spot Naziism on the march in German-speaking countries. It's a conditioned reflex, the same way African newspapers love to run big pictures of tiny Ku Klux Klan rallies, leaving the impression that every third American is a Klansman. 
 One American TV report on the 27 percent showing by Jorg Haider's right-wing Freedom Party in voting here last week worked in old clips of goose-stepping soldiers and a fulminating Hitler. An Israeli headline said: "One Out of Every Four Austrians Chose a Neo-Nazi Chancellor."
That offended even Austrians who detest Mr. Haider (whose party tied for second and is highly unlikely to become Chancellor).
In fact, my translator said, the speaker was criticizing the gap between the pay of Austrian bank presidents and working stiffs. It's true that when Mr. Haider complains about "Uberfremdung," or over-foreignization, even Austrians say the word has a certain "Deutschland Uber Alles" ring to it. But the overtly racial element of Naziism is lacking. It's similar to the sentiment expressed in Ross Perot's "giant sucking sound" from south of the border -- nativist populism.
Even here, it isn't necessarily racial. An Egyptian taxi driver, Hassan Ramy, told me he was a Haider voter. What about his anti-immigrant feelings? I asked. He's against the ones who don't have papers, he answered.
True, Austria was long criticized for failing to deal with its Nazi past; for years, while Germany apologized, it portrayed itself as Germany's first victim. And Mr. Haider has made what a Jewish leader in his party called "a couple of stupid remarks that are constantly quoted."
In one, he retorted in the heat of debate that the Third Reich had a sounder employment policy than the governing Social Democrats, and in another he told a veterans' reunion that included some Waffen SS soldiers that they were "decent people who stuck to their belief through the strongest headwinds."
Neither at the Vienna gathering I attended nor at a noisy beer-tent rally in Mr. Haider's home area, near the Slovenian and Italian borders, did his supporters harp on race. "Sixty percent of the people here, I think, are protest votes," said Hans Hechenleitner, 53, explaining that people felt the ruling Social Democratic-conservative coalition in Vienna left them feeling powerless. "There's not racism, except maybe among some of the uneducated ones, and you have also this difference in the U.S., is it not so?"
I asked Mr. Hechenleitner about something Mr. Haider has said in Vienna, complaining about the "extremist" tag: "People say I'll declare war on Slovenia if I'm elected. But that's not true. In my area, we have good relations with the Italians and Slovenians."
The reaction suggested Mr. Haider had gone a bit bleeding heart in pandering to the urbane Viennese. Mr. Hechenleitner and his friend, Horst Assam, 62, looked at each other. Mr. Hechenleitner finally spoke, betraying the Austrian mistrust of outsiders: "No, you can't say we like them. But we work together."
THERE is definitely something creepy about Mr. Haider's xenophobia and how many Austrians it appeals to. Austria is in the middle of Europe and has been overrun by a lot of peoples -- and Austrians themselves are often eager to enumerate their diverse ethnic backgrounds for you. But there's something in at least 27 percent of the country that wants to shut the door, and it lives even in the breasts of Egypto-Austrian cabbies. Andreas Rudas, a senior tactitian for the Social Democratic Party, called it "the omnibus effect," as in, "Once I'm on the bus, I want the doors to close so it doesn't get crowded."
What liberal leaders find disturbing is less Mr. Haider's rhetoric on race than his oratory on crime -- which, by extension, whips up fear of foreigners. Prodded by his claims that it is coddling drug dealers, the Government launched a series of drug raids. "But the subtext becomes anti-black, anti-Nigerian," said Georg Hoffman-Ostenhof, a political columnist for the weekly Profil, even though the black population is minuscule.
WITH 4 percent unemployment, health care for all and a negligible murder rate here, it's a mystery why a lot of Austrians are convinced that their tiny nation is a hotbed of crime.
"What drug dealers?" my translator, who weighs about 100 pounds and feels safe bicycling anywhere in Vienna at night, asked Horst Thaler, a 66-year-old in a Tyrolean jacket at a rally for Mr. Haidar's party.
"Look in the Karlsplatz," he said.
It was a subway station a few blocks away, so we did. By Times Square standards, it's an Alpine village. By Austrian standards, it's littered, and there were several unwashed guys begging for "Zigaretten."
On election night, coming home from watching the late returns, I passed the Karlsplatz again. The beggar who approached me was, I presume, Austrian; he was polite and completely bilingual.
Then a music event nearby let out, and a crowd came surging toward the tram. They climbed on, loud and obnoxious, practically shouting at each other. They were from North Carolina and California, they were in black tie and had hearing aids. They were ticked: They didn't know the opera in Vienna begins at 6, and they had missed the whole first act.
Uberfremdung.

LENGTH: 1409 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Now, State of Siege, Colombian Style

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A Latin American country slides toward chaos. Leftist guerrillas attack the government, right-wing death squads attack guerrilla sympathizers, peace talks falter. The economy spirals downward, scattering thousands of refugees, and fears of instability sweep through the region. The United States hurries to the rescue with hundreds of millions of dollars in aid.
With the Colombian Government facing its most serious crisis in years, Clinton Administration officials confirmed last week that they are putting together a package of military and economic assistance that could reach dimensions not seen in the hemisphere since the cold war. They are also trying to reassure anyone who will listen that Colombia today really looks nothing like El Salvador once did. 
 The United States will not be giving Colombia lots of sophisticated weapons and aircraft, the officials say, nor will legions of Colombian soldiers be training at Ft. Bragg. American military advisers in Colombia are to help troops there fight the drug trade rather than insurgents, except where the insurgents protect the trade. "There are, in my view, few if any really logical, easy comparisons to make between El Salvador 10 years ago and Colombia now," said the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Thomas R. Pickering, who once presided over the military build-up in El Salvador as the United States Ambassador there.
Still, there are many in the Administration and many more outside it who see quicksand in Colombia. The government that Washington is supporting in Bogota is weak and increasingly unpopular. The army it trains has been ineffective on the battlefield and frequently complicit in the massacres of civilians by rightist paramilitary groups. The rebel armies it hopes to bend have held out in the jungles for decades. The Administration is also on unsteady ground at home: For domestic political reasons, it has proclaimed a central goal in Colombia -- curtailing the drug trade -- that will likely mislead Americans about what it hopes to achieve there.
What has panicked both the Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans is not so much the latest turn in Colombia's cocaine problem as the growing troubles of its new President, Andres Pastrana. Little more than a year after Mr. Pastrana came to power with bold concessions intended to bring the biggest rebel army to the negotiating table, the talks are stalled in the earliest stages, the guerrillas appear stronger and more recalcitrant and the President is widely criticized as naive. Unrest within the armed forces has surged and paramilitary killings have continued. The country's long-buoyant economy, having made it through the regional debt crisis of the 1980's relatively unscathed, is suffering its most severe recession in decades.
Whether the United States sinks deeper into Colombia's troubles or helps to solve them may ultimately depend a good deal on how it defines its objectives there. Over the last three months, officials have gone to unusual lengths to reconsider those aims: Working groups have been set up, strategy papers have been prepared and assistant secretaries of all sorts have shuttled back and forth to Bogota. Yet even as that review got under way, senior officials seemed to limit its parameters: The center of American policy, they insisted -- "the spear point," as Mr. Pickering put it -- will remain the illicit drug trade.
Colombia's drug problem has taken a significant turn for the worse. Over the last several years, as the authorities in Bolivia and Peru have made headway in intercepting drug planes and helping poor farmers supplant crops of coca, the raw material of cocaine, drug producers have sharply expanded their fields in remote, sparsely populated areas of southern Colombia. That shift has strengthened both the Colombian producers and their guerrilla allies, who profit by taxing the coca fields and hiring out to guard jungle air strips and drug-processing labs.
Nonetheless, the drug "emergency" that some senior United States officials have begun to describe does not necessarily threaten new waves of cocaine washing onto American streets. It is not clear how or even whether the shifting of coca crops around the region will affect the availability or price of cocaine abroad. Nor, despite technological advances in tracking drug shipments through the Caribbean, can the Administration promise that better-funded interdiction efforts will seriously reduce the flows of cocaine and heroin into the United States.
According to several officials, most of the aid proposals being circulated internally would give relatively short shrift to such basic (and comparatively inexpensive) solutions as the training of Colombia's judges and the strengthening of its notoriously porous prisons. Instead, American "counternarcotics" aid will aim to help the security forces beat back the guerrillas in southern Colombia so that crop-spraying and lab raids can proceed. As illogical as the assurance increasingly sounds, Administration officials continue to insist that the United States will stay out of the civil war.
In private, at least, such officials are more candid about acknowledging that a decade after the cold war's end, the drug fight is the only policy objective likely to win political support for the $1 billion to $2 billion in aid that they have talked of putting forward over the next three years. (Even then, a Colombia package will have to compete in the weeks ahead with foreign-aid proposals ranging from help for peacekeeping in Africa to support for the Israeli-Palestinian peace accords.)
It is hardly disputed that the United States has other significant interests in Colombia, from oil fields to radar stations to the stability of a democratic ally. In recent months, State Department and National Security Council officials, in particular, have pressed for what they call a more "integrated" approach -- one that might include trade benefits, development aid and human rights programs as well as military support. But as Colombia's military leaders showed their wish lists around Washington last week, it appeared that some central issues remained unresolved: how the beleaguered military might best be strengthened, how the guerrillas might be drawn into serious talks, and how those two goals interlock.
IN a July 20 letter to Mr. Pastrana, President Clinton suggested a new point of departure for American policy, saying, "The hardest step may be the first: convincing all sides in Colombia that a military solution is not possible and that all will gain from a negotiated settlement." But neither Mr. Clinton nor his senior aides have explained clearly how this might be achieved. Administration officials have begun trying to recruit other Latin American countries and United Nations mediators to bring pressure on both sides. In the meantime, the search for a comprehensive strategy in Colombia continues to resemble a free-for-all in which different factions of the Administration have put forward different aid proposals -- many of them with different implications for how to wage peace.
Some United States officials, including the commander of American military forces in Latin America, Gen. Charles E. Wilhelm, argue that only significant reverses on the battlefield will bring the rebels to the bargaining table. But at the pace at which the United States is now training and re-equipping the Colombian military, officials say it could take years to start changing the military balance. Critics of the policy also ask what might happen if Colombia's generals gain unexpected ground against the guerrillas -- and decide to continue fighting in order to press for a better deal.
"So far, the thinking has not gone much beyond, 'Let's get some helicopters in there,' " said Michael Shifter, a senior fellow at the Inter-American Dialogue, a policy research group based in Washington.
Viewed from Washington, the greatest difference between Colombia in 1999 and El Salvador in 1979 may be that virtually no one in the White House now believes Colombia's Government is in any immediate danger of falling to the rebels. That consensus may make it harder for officials to argue for a huge "emergency" infusion of American aid. It could, however, be the basis for an approach to Colombia's problems that might be sustained even when the flow of illicit drugs fails to miraculously end.
