LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Rx Redux;
Fevered Issue, Second Opinion

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE signs are unmistakable: Washington is rediscovering the health care crisis. It did not, after all, go away with the failure of the Clinton Administration's attempt at universal coverage in 1994.
New Census data show the number of uninsured Americans is climbing, in the face of an extraordinary economic boom. The cost of health insurance, after a few years of stability, is rising as well. The House of Representatives spent last week in angry, anguished debate over the state of the nation's health care, then passed a sweeping new bill to rein in the managed care industry and protect patients' rights. And out on the Presidential campaign trail, candidates are beginning to offer their solutions -- with much political forethought -- to the increasingly apparent problems of access, cost and coverage. 
 President Clinton all but snapped an "I told you so" when confronted with the Census numbers last week. "We told you in 1994 that if this were voted down, the insurance companies would continue to drop people, or employers would, because of the system we had," he said, clearly stung by the notion that 44.3 million uninsured Americans would be part of his legacy.
The new politics of health care is, not surprisingly, framed by the failure of the Clinton plan. Even as the uninsured return to the political agenda, nobody is out campaigning for a plan on the scale of Mr. Clinton's -- or, for that matter, for anything like what was routinely discussed by several Democratic Presidential candidates in 1992 with what now seems breathtaking naivete.
Even as some experts bemoan the shortcomings of piecemeal, incremental steps to expand health care coverage, much of the political class seems committed to the approach; witness the package of tax breaks intended to encourage coverage that Republicans in the House passed to much fanfare last week.
Still, the past seven years have in some ways profoundly changed the lay of the land: Managed care is no longer a theory but a reality for most Americans. The Clinton Administration did not restructure the health care system, but the private sector did. As Bob Blendon, an expert on public opinion and health at Harvard, put it, it was a "top-down" revolution that people never got to vote on.
Hence the backlash: The most popular enemy on Capitol Hill last week was not the bureaucrats in "big government," as it was during the struggle over Mr. Clinton's 1,342-page health plan, but the bureaucrats in health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care. Government regulation, in fact, was presented as a necessary check on out-of-control H.M.O.'s; Representative Charlie Norwood, a conservative Republican dentist from Georgia who was elected to Congress in 1994 as a fierce opponent of the Clinton plan, was now standing shoulder to shoulder with the Democrats and Mr. Clinton, leading the charge against H.M.O.'s.
Andrew Kohut, the director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press, says this concern about the power of H.M.O.'s has made health care more of an issue for middle-class working people with coverage. The percentage of people polled by the Pew Center who say "reforming health care" should be a top priority rose from 56 percent in January 1997 to 69 percent in January 1999. A particularly big jump occurred among men aged 30 to 49, Mr. Kohut said. This helps explain why a Republican-controlled House, much of whose leadership is deeply uncomfortable with government regulation, passed the managed care reform bill by such a lopsided vote last week.
THE managed care backlash is only one piece of the health care puzzle, although perhaps the easiest piece politically. To many health care planners and lawmakers on Capitol Hill, the primary concern is the steady rise in the uninsured, many of whom are low- and moderate-income workers.
"I worry what will happen when there's a recession," said Dr. Judith Feder, dean of policy studies at Georgetown University and a former top health adviser to the Clinton Administration. "If low-wage workers are in trouble in good times, where will they be in bad?"
Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, says voters raise similar concerns in focus groups, something she calls the Jack Nicholson effect: "What if this is as good as it gets?"
Still, politicians have only recently begun to venture near the issue again; there are no easy fixes for the uninsured, big solutions carry big price tags and the cost, complexity and political ham-handedness of the Clinton plan are painful, lingering memories.
It is no coincidence that Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are leading the way; concern about the uninsured tends to be higher among Democratic primary voters, according to Ms. Lake.
Deborah Steelman, who is advising Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on health care, said the issue is "really on his radar screen," particularly the plight of low-income workers who lack insurance, but she also indicated that his health care proposal was not imminent.
Still, while concern may be rising, even many voters who worry about the uninsured are wary of big solutions, some analysts say. "I just don't think there's a mood out there for some big government program that involves big intervention," Mr. Blendon said.
Mr. Bradley's plan, which won praise for its boldness because it set a goal of universal "access" to health insurance, was a careful political document that avoided the new governmental structures and mandates of the Clinton plan. (Even so, its estimated $65 billion a year cost may eventually prove a tempting target.)
In fact, the constituency for "health care reform" is divided and complicated, several experts said. Some voters are insured but angry at their H.M.O.'s. Some voters are motivated by the plight of the uninsured, and others are mostly concerned about Medicare and coverage for prescription drugs. "I just don't think this health care issue is a cohesive issue the way it was in 1992," said Mr. Blendon.
MOREOVER, what some experts see as the most worrisome trend in health care -- rising costs -- is the most difficult to discuss politically. Managed care leaders have tried hard to make the case that putting new mandates on the industry -- particularly opening it up to lawsuits -- would raise costs that would ultimately be passed on to employers and consumers. And industry officials seem stunned at times at how little credit they get for making care more efficient and, at least for a while, for controlling costs.
But cost-control in health care is a risky business: the cost-containment provisions in the Clinton plan led to fears of rationing. And the gatekeepers and referral requirements of managed care led to one horrific anecdote after another on the floor of the House last week about dying children and heedless bureaucrats on the other end of the phone.
Some experts worry that the managed care revolution has already squeezed out the easy savings. "I've thought for many years that there was an underlying upward trend in medical spending because of the increase in new capabilities in medicine, which we're now seeing fairly dramatically in pharmaceuticals," said Joseph Newhouse, a professor of health policy and management at Harvard. He suggested that after "some one-time gains from the managed care revolution" that upward trend may be reasserting itself.
Rising health care costs, of course, can have a direct effect on the number of uninsured. And higher costs can raise profound questions of equity; for example, Congress is currently struggling with the fairness of a Medicare program that lacks prescription drug coverage, just when the pharmaceutical revolution offers immense promise for many of the ills of old age.
The complex, interlocking nature of these issues pushed the Clinton Administration -- and many other health planners, for that matter -- to go for a grand, comprehensive plan. Working on these problems with incremental measures, step by step, is harder, some health planners say, but is probably all the political system can handle.
Families USA, a consumer group, and the Health Insurance Association of America plan to convene a conference of past combatants to try to seek common ground on the uninsured. Ms. Steelman, a lobbyist and longtime Republican adviser, said of the larger struggle: "This isn't about one big-bang theory. This is about trying to balance costs and needs and rights. It's the crucible of American politics. It's where it all comes together."
Advocates for the uninsured take heart from the fact that, at the very least, the eerie political silence around 44.3 million Americans is breaking.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1132 words

HEADLINE: When the Stars Come Out to Play Politics

BYLINE: By Michael Beschloss; Michael Beschloss, author of "Taking Charge," the first of a trilogy on the Lyndon Johnson tapes, is writing a history of the Lincoln assassination.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It looks as if Mad magazine is scripting Presidential politics. Donald Trump has announced his Presidential exploratory committee. He is dreaming of Vice President Oprah Winfrey, insisting that if the talk show host runs with him, they will win. The actress Cybill Shepherd is said to be pondering her own chances for the White House. Can Rob Lowe, star of the new NBC drama "The West Wing," be far behind?
No one can imagine that any of these candidates -- including more serious yet unconventional aspirants like Jesse Ventura and Warren Beatty -- will succeed Bill Clinton. Some have said that Mr. Trump's motive is to flog the latest volume in his life story, remembering what the whispers about a Presidential bid did for Colin Powell's book sales in 1995. With the economy zooming along and no war on the horizon, Americans may feel that politics is less directly connected to their lives and that they may as well indulge themselves in some harmless entertainment. 
 But there is more to the phenomenon of celebrity politics than that. The rise of the celebrity candidate alerts us to certain aspects of Presidential politics at the turn of the century, just as the rise of Prohibition party candidates 100 years ago (including the aptly named Silas Swallow) was a harbinger of a grand and frustrating national experiment.
At one level, this is merely the inevitable, absurd consequence of a system that is no longer about working your way up the ladder. By creating a system of front-loaded primaries to choose their nominees, the Democrats and Republicans unwittingly placed a high premium on exactly what many celebrities have: instant national name recognition, money (or access to it) and the ability to play to the cameras. Although his chances of winning are slight, Mr. Beatty could win a significant portion of the vote in early Democratic primaries, especially if he presented himself as the avatar of the party's disenfranchised left.
In the past, candidates for major party nominations who get lavish attention have usually been officeholders or generals. If the spotlight fell on a private citizen, it was usually some grave figure like Wendell Willkie, the New York utilities sachem nominated by the Republicans to oppose Franklin Roosevelt's third term.
These candidates did not simply plunge into the contest and pour their own money into television. They were vetted by the political establishment. Although a political neophyte, Willkie had to withstand the scrutiny of the Northeastern junto of lawyers, bankers and publishers who in those days could throw their weight around within the Republican Party and who rammed the Wall Street millionaire through on the sixth ballot.
Were Mr. Beatty to seek the Democratic nomination under the old system, he would have had to go with hat in hand to the bosses, governors, members of Congress and other party leaders who chose delegations. Although the actor has been a player in Democratic politics for more than 30 years, the Old Guard would almost certainly have sent him packing.
Nowadays, insurgent candidates outside the two parties have a much better ability than ever before to get themselves and their messages across to the voters. Had Donald Trump run in, say, 1932, he would have had to depend on Walter Lippmann and other political journalists to tell Americans what they thought of him and his ideas. (It is not hard to imagine the reaction of Lippmann, who with his delicate sensibilities refused to accept money from his father because it came from tenement rents, to the candidate Trump.)
But Mr. Trump does not need to pay court to today's gatekeepers. He can go on "Larry King Live" and the Internet to reach exactly the voters who might find his candidacy appealing. Television and the Web have become the great equalizers between professional politicians and those famous people who think it might be cool to be President. At a time when a sitting President can no longer command automatic attention from all networks when he gives a speech, a real estate developer can make himself one more face on the screen, right alongside an incumbent Vice President, a Governor and a former Senator.
Just as in 1952 and 1976, when Dwight Eisenhower and then Jimmy Carter were elected, this is a moment in which nonpoliticians can have the upper hand. Even though the anti-government frenzy of the early 1990's has faded, no candidate in 2000 would dream of reviving the slogan that Vice President Richard Nixon used in 1960: "It's Experience That Counts."
Instead Al Gore moves to Nashville, Bill Bradley gives short shrift to his 18 years in the Senate and George W. Bush stresses that he lives in Austin, Tex., not Washington.
All three may have more in common with Donald Trump and Warren Beatty than they care to admit: fame, money and access to the airwaves. And, paradoxically, they may be able to get away with demonstrating less substance on the issues than the third party hopefuls can.
History shows that the most successful third party candidates in this century got a large number of votes not because of their technique, money or entertainment value -- which in some ways was as considerable at the start of the century as it is at the end -- but because they fought for issues that the major parties were ignoring.
As the Bull Moose nominee in 1912, former President Theodore Roosevelt won 27 percent of the vote because he argued that his handpicked Republican successor, President William Howard Taft, had dropped the ball on Progressive reform.
George Wallace captured 13 percent in 1968 by appealing to white Southerners and urban ethnic voters who felt left behind by Lyndon Johnson's Great Society and who were fuming about civil rights and "the breakdown of law and order."
Ross Perot won 19 percent of the popular vote in 1992, not because of his homespun quips about his large ears and his business acumen, but because he convinced voters that deficits were ruining the country and that, if elected, he would seek a balanced budget far more strenuously than his opponents.
If Republicans and Democrats settle early on nominees who seem to agree on the preponderance of issues, a celebrity insurgent could make a contribution as the champion of a cause that is going unaddressed.
But if the economy starts to collapse or if the country faces a foreign crisis, the threshold for leadership is likely to magically rise once again. After all, when the United States became a world power a century ago, the voters put a stop to the age of journeymen Presidents like Rutherford B. Hayes and Benjamin Harrison.
When that new seriousness arrives, as it will, this flukish moment in our politics will evaporate -- a luxury that we could no longer afford.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Rara Avisat G.M.: A Director From Japan

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
When Nobuyuki Idei, Sony's chief executive, was named to the board of General Motors last week, he joined only a handful of other Asian executives who are directors of United States companies. Among the few are Goro Watanabe, vice chairman of Mitsui Chemicals, who serves on DuPont's board, and Minoru Makihara, chairman of Mitsubishi, who is on I.B.M.'s.
Despite all the corporate talk of globalization, big business often leaves its multinationalism at the board-room door. 
 John T. W. Hawkins, a managing director at Russell Reynolds Associates, a headhunting firm in New York, says very few executives are willing to cross the Pacific to attend frequent board meetings. And given the turmoil in Asian economies, he added, American companies have become even less willing to try recruiting directors in Asia.
But companies are more likely to look to Europe, he said. European directors can make a day trip out of a board meeting by hopping on the Concorde, particularly if the company is based in New York. No such snappy commutes are possible from Tokyo or Seoul.
 REED ABELSON

HEADLINE: Gambling Faces Two Big Tests in South

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: ROCK HILL, S.C., Oct. 6

 BODY:
It has been more than 50 years since any state banned an existing form of gambling, but a drive around the border roads of York County helps explain why South Carolina is poised to do just that.
Video poker is everywhere. Its robotic musical signature drones from gambling machines in virtually every gas station and convenience store as mesmerized players feed in dollar after dollar to play five-card stud and blackjack. Gaudy windowless parlors with five machines to a room greet visitors who cross the state line from North Carolina. The industry crept up on the state through a series of back-door legal moves, but 34,000 of the machines have now taken root across South Carolina, far more than in any other state, and many people have had enough. 
 On Nov. 2, voters will have a choice to either ban the machines beginning next summer or regulate them more closely. The latest newspaper poll shows that a sizable majority of likely voters -- more than 60 percent, in one poll -- want the machines permanently unplugged.
That vote, and another one on Tuesday in which Alabama will decide whether to institute a state lottery, will be among the most important tests in years of whether gambling's steady growth in the Southern Bible Belt has finally reached its limit. Although the lottery is more accepted and far less intrusive than video gambling, several polls show that its popularity in Alabama has dropped in recent months. The outcome of next week's lottery vote, which once seemed certain to pass, is now considered a tossup.
"These are very big symbolic votes coming up," said William N. Thompson, a gambling industry expert and public administration professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. "The last time a state voted out gambling was in 1948, when Idaho banned slot machines. It will be a very big victory for the anti-gambling side if it's thrown out in South Carolina."
Alabama's Governor, Donald Siegelman, campaigned almost exclusively on a promise to create a lottery, and is selling it as the only way to create a pre-kindergarten program and a college scholarship program similar to that in neighboring Georgia and other states. Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina, who also ran on a pro-lottery platform and accepted about $3 million from video poker interests, now says he is opposed to video poker. His state's lottery will be on the ballot in November of 2000.
In both of the coming votes, gambling proponents have encountered large and potent coalitions of religious groups, but the size of the opposition in South Carolina has been particularly remarkable. Virtually every denomination in the state -- including Southern Baptists, Presbyterians and Jews -- has joined in well-organized coalitions to get anti-poker voters registered and to the polls. They have been joined by the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce and most large businesses, which are worried about the state's image, and most editorial pages. The state election commission has reported a noticeable burst in voter registrations in the last two months.
"The social cost and the implications for our citizens were already huge," said Paula Harper Bethea, chairwoman of the South Carolina chamber. "But we also think it has a negative economic impact on the state, because it greatly affects our image. We're struggling to get ahead in a lot of areas, and we have a good quality of life, and we think we deserve better than video poker."
The 2,300-member chamber, the state's largest business organization, is running television and radio advertisements against the machines, while an anti-gambling group, Legacy Alliance, is putting up billboards. Meanwhile, religious groups are distributing yard signs and building grass-roots support. A recent rally in Rock Hill, a hotbed of anti-poker sentiment, drew a crowd of 3,500 to protest the effects of video gambling.
Opponents have an endless sheaf of stories about middle-class parents who lost their life savings to a video poker addiction, or poor families who spend their food money in the parlors. But they have been careful not to make the vote a referendum on the merits of gambling itself. The Rev. Steve Hogg, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Rock Hill and a prominent leader of the anti-poker forces, said many people in his coalition approved of lotteries or horse racing, though he does not, and so they decided to focus on the one issue that united them.
"We couldn't have put this coalition together if the lottery was on the table, but we all agree that video poker is the most destructive and addictive form of gambling there is," said Mr. Hogg, a conservative Southern Baptist who wore a blue Vote No button on his shirt pocket. "I'm not one of those Christians who believes in outlawing everything I think is sinful or immoral. I'm part of the community, and we have to be pragmatic about what we consider to be life-or-death issues."
Most of the support for the machines has come from the state's video poker industry, which has revenue of about $2.8 billion a year and has raised about $2 million on the campaign to keep the machines, more than twice as much as its opponents. Supporters say the state will lose $200 million to $300 million in yearly tax revenue if the machines are banned, and predict that 28,000 people will lose their jobs. Many video parlors and gas stations are plastered with fliers that cast the issue in terms of personal freedom, saying that the next step is to ban the Internet or rock music.
Since the poll was published by The State, in Columbia, and five other newspapers last month, the pro-poker forces have intensified their broadcast advertising and direct mailings, and are building a get-out-the-vote effort among poker employees and players to rival that of the churches. But many who have watched the issue say the industry may have grown too large to stay alive.
"I think it's tightened up since the poll," said John Cavanaugh, a political science professor at the University of South Carolina. "But there's still a strong anti-gambling feeling that's catching hold in the state. Everyone sees the machines when they go to the gas station, and many people know someone with an addiction problem. The tide seems to be turning."
There is a considerable sentiment against the lottery in Alabama, as well, again led by church groups, but the intensity of the opposition is less than in South Carolina because of the nature of the game. Many people consider the lottery less addictive and less harmful than video poker, and are jealous of the lottery-financed college scholarships offered to Georgia students.
"If this fails, there is no Plan B," said Rick Dent, a spokesman for the Alabama Education Lottery Foundation, which is running the pro-lottery campaign. "This is our one chance to ever have college scholarships, pre-K and computers in the schools. If there were another way to pay for them, surely we would already have them."
But lottery opponents have also repeated a frequent criticism of the numbers game: most tickets are purchased by poorer residents, a large number of whom are black, while the scholarships tend to go to middle-class white students. Church leaders said they were particularly angered by a statement from Governor Siegelman several weeks ago that opponents of the lottery should be ashamed of themselves, and they said no other issue had brought different denominations so closely together.
"We simply believe that government should not fund itself with money from the people who can least afford it," said Michael Anderson, executive director of the Mobile Baptist Association, which represents about 100 churches.
Mr. Siegelman later said he respected those who disagree with him on religious or moral grounds, but pollsters say the intense church-by-church mobilization has significantly eroded support for the lottery. A poll conducted by three newspapers and published this week showed that 51 percent of likely voters said they supported the lottery, down from 61 percent in August.
"Remember, every church in Alabama has a bus," said Eric Johnston, a Birmingham lawyer who is treasurer of the largest anti-lottery coalition. "And on Tuesday, they're all heading for the polls."

HEADLINE: Clinton Jolts Canadians With a Plea On Federalism

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Canadians on both sides of the nation's deep linguistic divide say they were stunned by President Clinton's unexpectedly passionate appeal here for national unity and federalism.
President Clinton traveled to the flashpoint of separatism in North America and without once mentioning Quebec nationalism argued on Friday that "the United States and Canada are among the most fortunate countries in the world because we have such diversity." 
 If every major "racial and ethnic and religious group" won independence, "we might have 800 countries in the world and have a very difficult time having a functioning economy," Mr. Clinton said, addressing a forum on federalism that earlier in the week had become a platform for complaints by Quebec separatists. "Maybe we would have 8,000 -- how low can you go?"
"The great irony of the turning of the millennium is that we have more modern options for technology and economic advance than ever before, but our major threat is the most primitive human failing -- the fear of the other," he said at Mont Tremblant, north of Montreal.
"We must think of how we will live after the shooting stops, after the smoke clears, over the long run," the President said. National independence, he warned, is often "a questionable assertion in a global economy where cooperation pays greater benefits in every area than destructive competition."
American leaders traditionally sidestep the hornet's nest of the separatist aspirations of many Quebecers, the central political quandary of Canada for the last three decades. In turn, Canadians put extraordinary weight on the words of the President of the United States, the nation that dominates Canada's foreign trade and investment.
Canada's widely read weekend papers, English and French, viewed the speech as a strong argument for Quebec's remaining inside Canada.
President Clinton made "a powerful argument in favor of federalism, which he describes as the political regime of the future," Vincent Marissal wrote in La Presse, a Montreal daily that bills itself as the largest-circulation French newspaper of the Americas. "But his message on the merits of federalism went much further, questioning even the usefulness of the nationalist projects in the era of globalization."
The English-speaking media were less restrained.
"Clinton Sings Praises of United Canada," read a banner headline in The Montreal Gazette, one of only two surviving English language daily newspapers in Quebec.
The National Post, a conservative newspaper, hailed Mr. Clinton's "historic speech" with a banner headline, "Clinton Takes a Swing at Separatists."
The Globe and Mail, Canada's other nationally circulated newspaper, declared, "Mr. Clinton's speech was the most powerful and subtle argument in favor of the federal idea heard in Quebec in years."
Quebec separatists sought to make the best of the speech, noting that Mr. Clinton had praised the European Union, a relationship they see as a model for future ties between an independent Quebec and "English Canada."
Separatists also noted that after the speech Mr. Clinton met with Quebec's Premier, Lucien Bouchard, the first such meeting between an American President and a separatist Premier.
But Mr. Clinton did not allow photographs, kept the meeting to 15 minutes, and then rushed off to a photo opportunity and golf with Canada's Prime Minister, Jean Chretien.
On Oct. 30, 1995, Quebec voters came within a whisker of approving a third nation for North America. In a referendum with a huge turnout, the yes vote for an independent Quebec was 49.4 percent.
But austerity policies adopted by Mr. Bouchard's government seem to have contributed to a fall in separatist support, currently said in opinion polls to be around 40 percent. Consequently, Mr. Bouchard has been vague about holding what would be a third referendum on the issue since 1980.

HEADLINE: Clinton Faults Senate Over Hispanic Judicial Nominees

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton told a national Hispanic group today that the Senate was a black hole of delay, unwilling to vote for his Hispanic nominees for Federal judgeships but afraid to vote against them.
"Now I don't know about you, but if I took three and a half years to make a decision, you wouldn't think I was a very good President," Mr. Clinton said. 
 The President was warmly received today at the annual conference of the Hispanic Leadership Institute, a nonpartisan organization that promotes voter registration and training of Hispanic officials.
He credited the Clinton-Gore Administration for a growing economy, particularly this week's report that household incomes of Hispanic Americans are growing faster than those of other Americans.
But he devoted much of his address to the judicial nominees.
He said it was not an isolated incident this week when the Senate rejected his nominee for the Federal District Court in Missouri, an African-American, after the seat has sat empty for two years. The Senate voted 54 to 45 on Tuesday to reject the nomination of Justice Ronnie White of the Missouri Supreme Court. Republicans say they have approved hundreds of Clinton nominees, including two on the day that Judge White was rejected.
That nomination was rejected, Republicans said, because Judge White had an extremely pro-criminal record in hearing appeals of death penalty cases. The President criticized the vote as "a disgraceful act of partisan politics."
And while many Republicans said they were not aware of Judge White's race when they voted against him, the White House, in its reaction, emphasized what it called unfair treatment of minority nominees.
Mr. Clinton continued that theme today, turning the focus on Hispanic judges.
"They just disappear somewhere in the dark recesses of the calendar of the Senate," Mr. Clinton said. "Why? Well, they don't want to vote him down because they hope that you will vote with them in the next election, but they don't want to vote for him."
He said the Senate was dragging its feet on the nominations of Richard A. Paez of California, the first Mexican American to serve on the Federal bench in Los Angeles, for a vacancy on the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit; Marsha Berzon, an appellate lawyer, also in the Ninth Circuit; Judge Julio Fuentes in the Third Circuit; Enrique Moreno, a lawyer, in the Fifth Circuit, and Judge Ronald Guzman for the Northern District of Illinois.
"Now I think the treatment of Richard Paez and Marsha Berzon is shameless," the President said.
"I am pleased to announce that Judge Guzman finally received his Judiciary Committee hearing last week for a vacancy here," the President said. "But the Senate's treatment of Judge White and its failure to vote on the outstanding Hispanic nominees that are pending creates a real doubt" about the abilities of the nominees and about the Senate's willingness to perform its "constitutional duties to advise and consent."
Hispanic Americans have become the fastest-growing group of voters, according to a study released here by the Leadership Institute. From 1976 to 1996, Latinos increased their voter registration by 164 percent, compared with 31 percent for the nation. In votes cast, Latinos have increased to five million in the 1996 Presidential election, up from two million in the 1976 election. The number of Hispanic elected officials has not risen so fast.
"I have always wanted an administration that looks like America," the President said. "You've heard me say that a dozen times, I bet. More and more, America will look like you."

HEADLINE: As Benefits Expire, the Experts Worry

SERIES: LIFE AFTER WELFARE -- Out of Time.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
Wisconsin, of all places, suddenly has the jitters about cutting families off welfare.
Since 1996, the state's famously tough work rules have swept more than 57,000 families from the rolls and turned a war on welfare into a social experiment commanding international attention. Almost 90 percent of the families that were getting welfare checks three years ago no longer receive them, and envious bureaucrats from around the globe visit the state to hear officials boast of the disappearing dole. 
 But Wisconsin is now grappling with the ultimate symbol of the new welfare age: time limits. Virtually everyone on welfare in the state is required to join a work program, and there are two-year limits on those jobs. This month, for the first time, a handful of Wisconsin families have hit the deadline. As a result, they could lose their checks not for refusing to work for their aid, but simply for staying in the program too long.
The question of what to do with these families has everyone in the welfare system on edge, with the revealing exception of the poor themselves. In theory, time limits are supposed to push the needy down the path to self-reliance. In practice, most poor people are too tangled in the chaos of daily life to give them much thought. Instead, the limits have had an impact far more complex and indirect than the political slogans behind them.
What they have set into motion are waves of worry along bureaucratic fronts. Competing approaches to the deadlines' enforcement are in play as requests for extensions arrive. The state officials who oversee the program are quarreling with the private agencies that help run it. And all are looking to avoid blame when families stay mired in problems that are sometimes decades in the making.
Amid the proliferating subplots, the deadlines have had at least one clearly positive effect: afraid of being called to task or even fined for their clients' slow progress, welfare agencies are revisiting old cases with new intensity. But it remains unclear how much even the best social work can accomplish, especially as troubled lives compete with expiring clocks. And the heightened concern about these few families implicitly raises questions about the tens of thousands dropped from welfare before them without nearly as much thought.
Though the program, Wisconsin Works, or W-2, prides itself on being tough, so far the forces of caution have prevailed. Forty-eight recipients have sought extensions to the two-year limit and all have received them, putting off the day of reckoning by three to six months.
Among them was Robin Edwards, a 38-year-old mother of six who works as a janitor at a Milwaukee parochial school in exchange for a monthly welfare check of $673. A painfully shy woman who stares at the ground when she talks, she reads at the third-grade level and is unclear about such basics as what year her deadline expires. "I'm really not too sure," she said.
In fact, her time expired this month. As it did, it added to the concern up the bureaucratic ladder.
At Y-W Works, a private agency in Milwaukee that handles her case, social workers redoubled a two-year effort to help Ms. Edwards find a regular wage-paying job. Sabrina Lee returned to Ms. Edwards's problems with child care. Pepita Johnson gave weekly lessons on talking to employers. Mark Miller lined up interviews at a hospital and a grocery.
The challenges before them were considerable. In the past 10 years, Ms. Edwards had held just one private job, for a few weeks. Among the skills she is trying to acquire are the rudiments of workplace grooming. "They tell me, 'Don't go in there with body odor on you,' " she said.
As the social workers attended to Ms. Edwards, the head of Y-W Works, Julia Taylor, asked the state for more time.
J. Jean Rogers, the state official who oversees W-2, personally sifted through two years of case notes to review the agency's work. Ms. Rogers, a strict critic of welfare, gave Ms. Edwards three more months, but only after urging Y-W Works to follow a seven-point plan.
"Contact employers with whom she has interviewed to determine for certain why she is not being hired," she wrote. "Engage her in family planning." Ms. Rogers's decisions, in turn, are reviewed by aides to her boss, Linda Stewart, the Secretary of the Department of Workforce Development, who is considered more of a moderate.
The entire process is buffeted by competing political concerns. Saying many families have not received enough help, critics of W-2 have threatened to sue on behalf of the first recipients who lose their aid. "The state should extend the deadline for everyone, given the disarray the program was in," said Pat DeLessio, a welfare rights lawyer.
But others are warning against retreat. "We have to make sure that time limits have teeth," said State Representative John Gard, a Republican who sponsored the legislation creating W-2. If extensions become the rule, he said, "we'll need to scrutinize this closely."
As for Ms. Edwards, though she is getting a remarkable amount of attention, her circumstances are not particularly remarkable. Officials often describe the last cases as the hardest, but that is not necessarily so. Work programs like W-2 sometimes affect the most troubled families first: addicted, depressed or disturbed clients often just disappear. For every client now getting a second look, there may well be two or three others with similar problems who vanished into the post-welfare world.
Ms. Edwards herself had a spotty history in the program, sometimes missing weeks of work. But Y-W Works continued to pursue her. And its efforts just produced a result that took her by surprise: She got a job. On Oct. 1 she began working three days a week as a janitor at a Toys 'R' Us.
No one pretends her problems are solved. With only a part-time job, Ms. Edwards is still on welfare -- she now sweeps the school two days a week -- and her clock is still ticking. Supporters of time limits would call her breakthrough a testament to the power of deadlines. Critics would describe her as a vulnerable woman whose safety net is shrinking.
Her supervisor at the school, Venus McMurry, sounds a pessimistic note. "I don't care what anybody says, the girl's not ready to work," Ms. McMurry said.
Ms. Edwards offers no predictions about where this experiment is heading. "Hopefully, I'll have some luck," she said.
 
The Country
Clinton's Proposal Seized by Republicans
Though they swept the country appearing inevitable, time limits on welfare were anything but. Until Bill Clinton ran for President in 1992, few welfare experts had pondered them and no states had tried them.
Although time limits are now hailed by conservatives, they were first proposed by a liberal, Prof. David T. Ellwood, an economist at Harvard. He wanted to give the poor two or three years of training and then require those still on the rolls to work for their checks. But they would remain eligible for aid, with the Government providing the jobs, if necessary, along with other services.
President Clinton used that plan as a template for his 1992 pledge to "end welfare as we know it." Like Professor Ellwood, Mr. Clinton merely proposed sending the poor to a work site after a few years. He never suggested dropping them from the rolls.
But conservatives seized on his bold rhetoric and called for doing just that. "Ending welfare," they argued, meant enforcing finite periods of eligibility, period. Otherwise, they said, the poor would lack the motivation to leave welfare.
Soon, this new definition prevailed: not time limits followed by work assignments, but time limits followed by nothing. Under attack for failing to keep his "end welfare" pledge, President Clinton accepted a Republican plan in 1996, signing a law that placed a five-year lifetime limit on eligibility for Federal benefits.
The law permits states to set shorter limits, and Wisconsin is one of 20 to do so. It also allows states to exempt 20 percent of their welfare families from the deadline. Wisconsin has no outright exemptions, though there is no limit on the number of extensions a recipient can seek.
At first, time limits appeared to be one of the most consequential features of the new welfare law. The Urban Institute, a Washington research group, predicted that of the 5 million families then on welfare, 1.4 million would suddenly be dropped in 2001 when their five-year limit expired. But a good economy and tough work rules have already cut the country's welfare rolls nearly in half, and as a result, the impact that time limits will come to have is now less clear. Many of the 2.7 million families still receiving aid are expected to leave the rolls before their deadlines expire. And after such precipitous reductions, states may approach the deadlines more permissively than once expected.
So far, the state evidence is mixed. Some of the largest have rejected the strict limits envisioned by Federal law. California and New York, which account for a third of the nation's recipients, have said that after five years they will reduce, but not eliminate, a family's cash aid. If necessary, they will finance the continued payments themselves.
Massachusetts, by contrast, is rigorously enforcing a two-year limit. Of the first 5,000 families to reach the limit, about 70 percent lost their cash assistance. (Time limits do not affect food stamps or Medicaid.) Similarly, Louisiana dropped 4,200 families this year, about 10 percent of its caseload, after they reached a two-year limit. Time limits in Connecticut have cut the most families, about 19,000, but the vast majority were working families who would have been ineligible for welfare in most states.
For evidence about how the limits work, most analysts turn to Pensacola, Fla., which began experimenting with them in 1994. As in Wisconsin, the poor seemed to pay the deadlines little mind. Families given limits of two or three years left the rolls no quicker than a control group of other families.
But researchers found that the Pensacola program, like Wisconsin's, did motivate caseworkers. "They felt like they really had to pay attention to people as they approached the time limit," said Dan Bloom of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a New York City group that evaluated the program. Likening time limits to shock therapy, Mr. Bloom said creative managers might be able to find other ways to motivate caseworkers. But, he added, "it's harder."
 
The State
Conflicting Visions About Time Limits
Wisconsin would seem the last place to fret about families losing welfare. When Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, took office in 1987 after an anti-welfare campaign, there were nearly 100,000 families on the rolls. Now there are 7,700.
But as a few dozen families now seek extensions, tensions are running high. Consider the jousting around Simona Alva, a Mexican immigrant who went on welfare seven years ago after her husband fell ill with epileptic seizures.
An outgoing woman with 11 children and 10 cockatiels, Ms. Alva insists that her ability to work is limited. She speaks no English. She gets lost on city buses. Though seven of her children are grown, she worries that a mentally ill son, who is 24, will burn down the house without her supervision. And like many Hispanic women, who are leaving welfare more slowly than blacks or whites, she feels her place is in her home, watching over her troubled family. "The woman is supposed to take care of the man," she said.
Since joining W-2, Ms. Alva has held the least demanding of two major types of jobs in the program, called a "transitions" job. She spends four hours a day, under close supervision, packing books and calendars. But with eligibility at each job level limited to two years, she is now expected to move up to a more demanding "community service" job, with longer hours, or leave welfare. The combined eligibility for all work levels is five years. Because clients are generally required to move up the ladder, those who start in community service, as most do, are typically expected to leave the program for regular jobs after two years. They are the ones most affected by the current deadline.
In Ms. Alva's case, Y-W Works, the private agency, requested an extension, arguing that her ability to work is "complicated by her husband's and her son's disabilities." State officials were skeptical. "This seems to be a person who is ready to move up," they wrote.
The agency resisted. ("Her illiteracy renders her vulnerable in the workplace.") The state pushed back. ("She can communicate functionally.") In the end, the state gave Ms. Alva six more months to study English and to find care for her husband and son.
These first decisions have been shaped by at least three layers of bureaucratic politics. One involves tensions between the private welfare agencies and advocacy groups for the poor. Eager to avoid a lawsuit, some agencies are seeking extensions for any client who wants one, shifting the burden to the state. "It's a game of chicken to see who's going to be the first to make a denial," said an official at one agency.
To circumvent the limits, some agencies are also quietly shifting clients to an easier level of work -- buying them two more years of eligibility. As the deadlines approached, the number of Milwaukee clients placed in the least-taxing "transitions" jobs grew 11 percent as the overall rolls declined.
A second level of tension pits the agencies against the state. Under state contract, agencies can be fined $5,000 for any "failure to serve" a client. So far, no fines have been issued, but Ms. Rogers, the presiding state official, has sometimes criticized the Milwaukee agencies. With Ms. Rogers examining every request for an extension herself, a flurry of social work is sometimes intended as a defense.
A third level of tension exists among state officials, as suggested by the contrasting tenor of their remarks in recent interviews. Ms. Rogers is a firm believer in time limits who has longtime ties to the Governor. "If time limits are serious, you have to treat them seriously," she said. "You don't just look for some external reason" for extensions. Her boss, Ms. Stewart, sounded less stern. "I don't think our legislators expect us to be punitive toward people," she said.
 
The Agency
Limits Produce More Social Work
Amid the tensions, families that might have been left to languish are getting a second look. At Y-W Works, a weekly brainstorming session shows the personalized attention that the system can muster at its best. Client by client, a roomful of social workers revisited the struggles of people approaching the deadline.
Here is one: "She's a schizophrenic who refuses to take her medication."
And another: "She finds it hard to stop using marijuana."
And another: "She just plain flat out doesn't have the emotional energy to do anything about where she is in life."
While such personal attention was missing from the old welfare system, its achievements remain unclear.
Teams of workers were sent to the homes of the schizophrenic woman and the woman on marijuana. But that was just a start. The depressed woman had the group stumped. Her Medicaid plan will pay for only six visits with a therapist. "We've got to find something better than that," her caseworker said.
If the meeting shows the system at its most conscientious, it also shows that clients can -- indeed, often do -- still fall through the cracks. After all, these are families who have made little progress in nearly two years.
Sometimes caseworkers miss problems. Often clients hide problems. Turnover among caseworkers is high. And families that move must often start at a new agency, as cases are apportioned geographically. The schizophrenic woman, for instance, had had been seen by three other agencies.
While Ms. DeLessio, the welfare rights lawyer, called Y-W Works one of the more attentive agencies, she said the system as a whole had failed to live up to the promises behind time limits. "The whole idea is we were going to do these individualized assessments and get people the services they need," she said. "That did not happen."
Ms. Taylor, the agency head, says the issue is less the casework than the difficulty of the cases. Of the first 10 Y-W Works clients to reach their limit, 5 were physically disabled or caring for disabled relatives. Five spoke little or no English. On average, they had a fifth-grade reading level and had been on welfare for the last seven years.
Time limits "do help create a sense of urgency, and sometimes that's helpful," Ms. Taylor said. "But we're dealing with really difficult problems. It's not something that's going to necessarily get solved in two years."
In mulling extensions, sometimes the hardest cases are easiest, because the need for more time seems most obvious. Such is the case with Elise Moore, another schizophrenic woman. She often refuses medication and will attend her work assignment only if her housemate comes with her. Even then, she often flees. "If I hear voices, I'm gone," she says. "I don't want to be around people when I start to scream."
Her case generated no dissent: state officials quickly agreed to an additional six months. Y-W Works plans to use the time to help Ms. Moore reapply for Federal disability benefits. A more difficult challenge, in Wisconsin and beyond, involves people with less obvious but perhaps no less disabling, problems. On the surface, Loretta Triplett, 48, seems, if anything, overdue to leave welfare for work. She has a high school diploma. . Three of her four children are grown.
And she insists she could find work if she had to. "It needs to be a position I'm going to enjoy," she said.
In a program that promotes entry-level work, statements like that, if taken alone, could disqualify her from an extension.
But inside, Ms. Triplett is stalked by more than finicky standards. She has battled depression for 35 years and tried medication without success. Tensions at home add to her worries. She says her son drinks heavily, and with her daughter susceptible to depression, Ms. Triplett must often care for three young grandchildren. She is self-conscious about her missing front teeth, and she conducts job interviews -- indeed, most conversations -- through clenched lips. "I don't like to smile," she said.
Tight-lipped about her problems as well, Ms. Triplett began opening up to a counselor at Y-W Works only recently, shortly before her benefits were scheduled to expire.
If they do, she will join legions of Wisconsin women in the post-welfare world, many with similar problems. About two-thirds find at least sporadic work, according to most surveys. Others turn to family or boyfriends. Relatively few have wound up on the streets. But relatively few have escaped poverty. Most simply find new ways to get by. Ms. Triplett said that if she lost welfare she would move in with her mother.
In June, Ms. Triplett began a new work assignment, at the electric company. Arguing she could gain new clerical skills, Y-W Works asked for another six months. The state gave her three. "We don't want to cut her off," said Anne Paczesny, her counselor. "We see her as making progress. It's just not as fast as W-2 wants."
 
Life After Welfare
With the nation's welfare rolls down by 47 percent, President Clinton, as well as his Republican critics, count the 1996 welfare law as the cornerstone of their respective legacies. The law replaced a 60-year-old cash safety net with time limits and work requirements.
No place has come closer than Wisconsin to the goal of "ending welfare." A decade ago, 100,000 families relied on public aid. Now 7,700 do. The changes taking place in the state, particularly in Milwaukee, its largest city, continue to reverberate in broad and unpredictable ways. Throughout the year, The New York Times is returning to Milwaukee to plot the pattern of change.
The articles and related coverage of welfare issues are available on The New York Times on the Web at www.nytimes.com/politics.

HEADLINE: A Scramble for Office Space in Jersey City, Manhattan's 'West Bank'

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The hottest address for investment bankers today is the former home of a toothpaste and detergent factory.
It is not on Fifth Avenue, the Avenue of the Americas or Wall Street, but across the Hudson River in Jersey City. 
 Merrill Lynch & Company is about to close on the purchase of a waterfront parcel for a million-square-foot office tower where 1,300 workers once churned out Colgate toothpaste, according to real estate executives and Jersey City officials. And Goldman Sachs & Company, the investment bank, is negotiating with the Colgate-Palmolive Company to buy as many as four other parcels for what could be 3.9 million square feet of office space.
Lord, Abbett & Company will move its entire operations there from the General Motors building. And, real estate brokers said, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is looking for space for its Internet business at the 20-acre site, where Colgate's landmark 55-foot octagonal clock still illuminates the Jersey City waterfront at night.
"It's the hottest address in town," said Leonard Boxer, a real estate lawyer with Stroock & Stroock & Lavan who has many Wall Street clients and a residential project at the Colgate site. "Jersey City is benefiting from its proximity to where the action is: New York."
Last week, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced that it would move 3,500 back-office jobs to Florida and Texas, while continuing to expand in Manhattan. But most financial companies are looking closer to home.
This is not a repeat of the late 1970's or early 90's, when some Manhattan companies fled a recession- and crime-racked city. Wall Street is increasingly looking to what New Jersey developers like to call the West Bank of Manhattan for back office space, and occasionally, a new headquarters, because financial companies are booming and large blocks of office space are virtually nonexistent in New York.
Jersey City is less expensive and only minutes away by PATH train or ferry. State and local governments there are willing to provide enormous tax breaks and other incentives.
"All these financial services firms are bursting at the seams," said Richard B. Clark, president of Brookfield Financial Properties, a major Manhattan landlord. "They're moving nonessential functions across the river so they can expand the front office in Manhattan."
Fearful of losing large segments of the financial industry, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has provided $2 billion in tax breaks to 50 large corporations threatening to leave Manhattan. But his administration has failed, urban planners say, to create back office space in Brooklyn or Queens that might stem some of the defections to Jersey City, where office rents are $10 to $30 a square foot cheaper than in Manhattan.
In the last real estate boom, in the 1980's, Mayor Edward I. Koch oversaw the development of office buildings in Long Island City, Queens, as well as the Metrotech complex in downtown Brooklyn, which serves as back office space for Chase Manhattan Bank and other companies. But those projects have been full for years.
H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a nongovernmental planning group, said the city should have provided land and incentives to developers to build additional office space on waterfront sites outside Manhattan, rather than giving corporate giants like Time Warner, Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley billions in tax breaks.
"There is no economic development policy," Mr. Shostal said. "They've thrown all the incentives at the big guys and they don't have anything left for the development of back office space or the small- and medium-sized firms that generate a lot of job growth."
Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for economic development, disagreed sharply with Mr. Shostal.
"Due to our success in retaining and attracting companies, there is a shortage of space in Manhattan," Mr. Levine said. "We are trying to find, and in some cases have succeeded, in finding back office space in Staten Island and College Point, Queens."
But developers say no Wall Street company would go to College Point or Staten Island, the psychological equivalent of the other side of the moon. It is the Colgate site that is suddenly in the corporate searchlight.
Unlike the developers of other Jersey City office parks, Colgate wants to sell the land rather than lease it. The company's Jersey City factory closed in 1986 after more than a century of operation. Colgate sought to turn the site into an office park, and in 1992, a developer completed what is now called 101 Hudson Street, offices for both Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers. But not much else happened for years.
Now, Hartz Mountain Industries is completing one office building at 90 Hudson Street, which will be a home for Lord, Abbett and the National Discount Brokers Group, and is starting a second on another Colgate site.
SJP Properties, one of the largest commercial developers in New Jersey, recently bought the only remaining factory building at Colgate and plans to transform it into modern office space, which has attracted Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, as well as other potential tenants.
Real estate executives on both sides of the river said Merrill Lynch would soon complete the acquisition of another parcel for a large office tower at Colgate. Merrill will almost certainly enjoy a number of tax breaks, just as it has in Manhattan. Peter Riguardi, the real estate broker representing Merrill Lynch, declined to discuss the deal.
"Jersey City affords large companies the ability to get large blocks of office space at competitive prices," Mr. Riguardi said. "The Colgate sites, in particular, provide them the ability to control the development."
On Tuesday, the developer Lester Fisher won approval from the Jersey City planning board for a twin-towered complex with 650 apartments that would rise nearly 30 stories over a garage on the Colgate property.
But it is the prospect of Goldman Sachs's buying all the remaining land at Colgate that has Jersey City buzzing. The investment bank has doubled in size (to 3.5 million square feet) and the number of employees (10,180) in lower Manhattan over the last four years. Goldman anticipates that it will need an additional two million square feet by 2004, which brought the bank to the Colgate site, where it would own the land.
New York City officials say that Goldman has talked to them about a vacant lot at the north end of the World Financial Center, or the office tower over a new trading complex for the New York Stock Exchange, if and when it is built. But many brokers are betting on Colgate, where, they said, Goldman is negotiating a contract to buy two parcels and an option on two others.
"Goldman Sachs is interested in tying up all the remaining office sites on the river," said Joseph Barry, chairman of the Applied Companies, a residential developer on the Jersey coastline.
Certainly the number of companies landing on the Jersey City beachfront is mounting.
"I think the focus on the waterfront will become even more intense over the next 18 months" as the economy slows and corporations become more interested in reducing costs, said Josh N. Kurilofs, executive director of Cushman and Wakefield, a real estate broker.
Last month, the Insurance Services Office, an information clearinghouse, announced that it would move its headquarters from Manhattan to an office building under construction at Samuel J. LeFrak's vast Newport complex on the water in Jersey City. Mr. LeFrak is just finishing a separate building in Newport that will have offices for PaineWebber, U.S. Trust and Cigna.
Robert Murray, a spokesman for Colgate, declined to discuss any pending deals. But, he added, "If everything were to happen, it would be the culmination of a dream we set out for that site 13 years ago."

HEADLINE: Political Puzzle of 2 Texans: Candidate and House Leader

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER and FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
There are a couple of leading theories about the relationship between the Texas Republicans who may soon be running the country:
A.) That the party's Presidential front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush, and the House majority whip, Tom DeLay, are closer than we know, ideological kindred spirits who like to play good cop/bad cop but then share the double-secret conservative handshake when nobody is looking. 
 B.) That these two guys from opposite sides of the tracks have little to nothing in common and if Governor Bush were elected President, would enjoy roughly as easy a relationship as the Governor's father did with Newt Gingrich, the firebrand who later became Speaker.
Those close to both men suggest yet another possibility: While they are not unfriendly and are at least somewhat like-minded, both are tough and competitive enough to be willing to win at each other's expense, if need be. And smart enough to recognize that they need each other, at least for now.
In the last two weeks, Mr. Bush certainly seemed to go out of his way to poke Mr. DeLay and all House Republicans in the eye a couple of times. First, he accused them of trying to "balance their budget on the backs of the poor." Then, in a speech on education, he portrayed his party as fixated on affluence -- "focused on the national economy, to the exclusion of all else." But aides to Bush insist that his later remarks, which had been written before the first flap occurred, were not intended to cut Congressional Republicans a second time, and seemed harsher in light of the earlier criticism.
After initially lashing out that the Governor "does not know how Congress works," Mr. DeLay is said to be over his pique (or facsimile of pique, in the alternative view). Though Mr. DeLay, who is commonly viewed as the real power in the House, volunteers that he and the Governor have "never had dinner; we aren't social friends," his comments do advance the theory that the two are ideologically much closer than their stylistic differences might suggest. And, of course, no one in the Bush campaign has ever hinted that their candidate is anything other than a credentialed conservative.
"I'm not sure there's a whole lot of difference between us," Mr. DeLay said in a recent interview, before Governor Bush's unflattering remarks. "I'm not sure there's a dime's worth of difference between us, philosophically. I don't know of any moderate Texas Republicans, if you really want to know. It's conservative and more conservative."
In his quest to put a friendlier face on the Republican Party, Mr. Bush has more reason to put some distance between himself, the majority leader, Dick Armey, another fellow Texan, and Mr. DeLay, also known as "the Hammer," who Democrats are trying to make his de facto running mate. ("Just remember B-A-D," said a spokesman for Vice President Al Gore, Chris Lehane. "Bush-Armey-DeLay: Bad policy, bad politics, bad for America.")
One Republican strategist said that because Governor Bush would be jettisoning the House Republicans' confrontational style, the members of Congress hurrying to board the Bush bandwagon seemed to be catching on only belatedly to the fact that their instant affection for the Governor might not be reciprocal. Most House Republicans rushing to support him "never calculated that it was an act of self-immolation," the strategist said, adding that most were still "as oblivious to what this means for them over the next two to four years as a 6-year-old is to the workings of a jet engine."
But not so Mr. DeLay, who seems both reconciled to the fact that some distancing is probably inevitable and willing to return the favor and speak out against the Governor if necessary. "Bush has to do what he has to do to win his Presidency," he said at week's end. After making the critical remarks about fellow Republicans in last week's education speech, one adviser to the Governor said Mr. Bush had acknowledged that House leaders know the score, saying, "Those guys understand."
And the Governor, in turn, understands that he needs Congressional support -- 152 House members have endorsed him so far, along with 25 Senators -- and so must keep Mr. DeLay at least relatively happy. "For House Republicans, DeLay is the most important figure, and within the campaign there's a recognition that we need to be working with him," the Bush adviser said.
Many in Congress have already pitched in with fund-raisers back home, and will help turn out the Republican vote in their districts, where many of them are quite popular. If Governor Bush is elected, a working relationship with House Republicans would certainly make life easier, even if they fail to hold on to their majority. But it is also generally understood that if he has to sacrifice the House to get elected, he will.
Meanwhile, relations do not seem to have been permanently chilled by the recent criticism. Aides to the two men socialize, and a couple of people in Mr. DeLay's office have been under serious consideration for senior positions in the Bush campaign, which already includes plenty of Capitol Hill veterans. The Governor's official liaison on the Hill, Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, who says he talks to the Governor's staff nearly every day, is also Mr. DeLay's chief deputy whip.
Even before Governor Bush formally announced his candidacy, he and some House Republicans had begun meeting informally to discuss an agenda for 2000; Mr. Bush needed their early support, and House Republicans needed a strong Presidential candidate, one with the potential to help them preserve their slim majority despite some pretty iffy poll ratings.
"Frankly," Mr. Blunt said recently, "a lot of our members endorsed him before they met him," but have only become more enthusiastic as they have gotten to know him, he added. When asked to name Governor Bush's closest friends on Capitol Hill, he thought for a while and then said, "I think he and Tom DeLay are friends" -- again, not golfing buddies, but political allies with an understanding.
In background, bearing and basic style, the two men are obviously worlds apart: Mr. Bush is an Ivy League-educated former owner of a professional baseball team who was born into a political dynasty -- a sunny, big-picture guy's guy who likes to get along and seemed to enjoy governing Texas alongside his good friend, the late Democratic Lieut. Gov. Bob Bullock.
Mr. DeLay, on the other hand, is the son of an alcoholic wildcatter, a man Mr. DeLay describes as "like something straight out of 'Giant.' " The House whip is a former pest exterminator who made his own way, got into politics to cut red tape and became a true believing, i-dotting and t-crossing, fight-to-the-finish conservative, the ultimate partisan, and proud of it.
"Bush does the forest, DeLay does the trees," said Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist, with a laugh. "Bush is passive-aggressive, DeLay is aggressive-aggressive."
Governor Bush, by all accounts, seems to regard Mr. DeLay with a respect exactly commensurate with the power he wields in the Congress.
They met in 1980, "When I was first starting," Mr. DeLay remembers, "and his Daddy was running with Ronald Reagan." Their first encounter was at a fund-raiser in Houston, near Mr. Delay's Sugar Land home. "He was, what's the word I want? Passionate is too feminine, but he was gung ho for his Daddy. He was kind of oil field trash -- that's an endearing term, by the way. And when I first met him he was trying to find himself."
Since then, "He's certainly smoothed over the edges. Probably the best thing that ever happened to him was getting involved with the Texas Rangers, because he focused and learned from that."
In 1990, when President Bush abandoned his no-new-taxes pledge, Mr. DeLay was front and center among House Republicans who opposed him. And the younger Bush did not enlist Mr. DeLay into his gubernatorial campaign against the incumbent, Ann Richards, a Democrat. "I don't recall him relying on Congressional Republicans at all," said Representative Henry Bonilla, a Texas Republican who knows both men well.
But Mr. DeLay does seem to get along better with the Governor than he ever did with President Bush, referring to the younger Bush as a fellow Christian and "much more of a people person" than his father. Typically, he likes to position himself as the benefactor, rather than the supplicant, in the relationship. "When he needs something, he calls, and we try to take care of him," Mr. DeLay said.
But even if in truth the balance of power is probably in Mr. Bush's favor, Mr. DeLay does have the power to hurt the Governor, and those who know Mr. Bush say that means he will try to keep him as close as possible.
As one Bush supporter who knows them both put it, "They're different guys, but at the end of the day, they're both just a couple of pols. And I can see them now, on the Truman balcony with their boots up, trading war stories."

HEADLINE: Ford and Auto Workers Avert Strike With Tentative Agreement

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 9

 BODY:
After round-the-clock negotiations lasting nearly 30 hours, the United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement today with the Ford Motor Company on a new contract for its 101,000 unionized workers.
"The U.A.W. has reached a tentative agreement with Ford on a new contract covering hourly workers at Ford facilities in the United States," the union and the company announced in a joint statement at 1:30 this afternoon. Both the union and the company refused to discuss any details of the contract until they had a chance to discuss the contract with the workers. 
 Because the Ford contract is expected to have terms nearly identical to those in contracts the union has already negotiated with other auto companies, it is expected to cover four years and call for hefty raises.
Ford's unionized workers would get annual raises of 3 percent on top of increases that nearly compensate for inflation. In addition, they would get a $1,350 signing bonus and sweetened pension benefits.
Unionized workers were awaiting details of the contract, but were pleased that a threatened strike at midnight Friday did not materialize, despite negotiations that continued past the midnight strike deadline. Workers are expected to ratify the contract later this month.
The agreement today ends the union's drive this autumn to negotiate new labor contracts covering the nation's 400,000 unionized auto workers, whose contracts were due to expire Sept. 14 but were extended during the negotiations.
On Sept. 16, the union reached a deal with the DaimlerChrysler Corporation covering its 75,000 factory workers in the United States. On Sept. 28, the union reached a deal with the General Motors Corporation covering its 143,200 blue-collar workers and 48,000 workers at Delphi Automotive Systems, the auto parts unit that G.M. spun off to shareholders in May.
This week, the union told Ford it would end the current contract at 11:59 P.M. on Friday and would call a strike if no agreement had been reached by then.
With auto companies earning record profits, the union was able to force them to share the wealth with blue-collar workers, who now earn $50,000 to $100,000.
"This is the fattest contract in decades," said John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The auto industry has been in continuous restructuring since the early 70's, so this was a rare opportunity to get a piece of meat."
The union had threatened to strike to show dissatisfaction with Ford's plan to spin off its giant Visteon Automotive Systems unit to shareholders.
Nearly a quarter of Ford's unionized workers toil in Visteon factories, and they feared that their jobs and pensions would be less secure if Visteon were an independent company.
As negotiations continued past the midnight Friday deadline, thousands of workers at four Ford factories walked off the job, causing Ford to lose about 13 and a half hours of production. However, the company said this morning that workers had reported to work today.
Though neither the union nor the company released details today, Ford was expected to have promised wage and job protection for its 23,500 Visteon workers in the event of a spinoff.
It has been 23 years since there has been a strike at Ford, which has basked in sunny labor relations as its rival, General Motors, suffered 17 strikes in the last six years, including one last year that cost it $2 billion.
