HEADLINE: In Troubled Roosevelt, A Takeover Still Awaits A Makeover

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

DATELINE: ROOSEVELT

 BODY:
LILLIAN COGGINS-WATSON is an elementary school principal who gives everything to the delicate and daunting mission of educating some of Nassau County's neediest children. She has stayed for a generation and often stops to hug pupils whose parents attended the same school. The children wear uniforms with colorful ties made from African fabric. Trained storytellers visit. Sixth graders spend a week visiting Washington, D.C.
She insists that education at the Ulysses Byas School in the Roosevelt school district be an intricate, meticulously planned process. For instance, the very first reading mistakes of kindergartners are systematically corrected before they can become habitual. It seems to be paying off: last year's fourth graders ranked in the top 10th of readers in the state. 
 "What are you?" Ms. Coggins-Watson demands as she leads a visitor from classroom to classroom. The smiling children thunder back, "First in the universe!"
The tragedy of the Roosevelt district, which contains four elementary schools and a combined middle and high school, is that these so-far successful children face a rough road in an exceptionally troubled school system. Four years after the state seized control of the 2,900-student district, the only one Albany has taken over, it remains in turmoil. Each step forward seems threatened by the same old, deeply intractable problems.
The consensus is that state intervention has brought few new ideas and even less new money, the district's greatest need by virtually everyone's estimation.
Michelle Smith is pleased to have two sons, 6 and 10, at Ulysses Byas School, but sees all the positive energy in that school as solely the result of Ms. Coggins-Williams's drive and inspiration.
"Where are the funds to have more things for these children?" she asked. "I mean Ulysses Byas is a great school, but they don't have a playground."
Ms. Smith is scouting private prep schools that might give her older son, a straight-A student, a scholarship. Another parent, Anastasia Mayo, already sends her 17-year-old son to a Catholic school in Manhassett, St. Mary's, for a barely affordable $5,000 a year. She does not know what she will do with two younger children still in the Roosevelt system.
"The Roosevelt district has really failed me," she said. Just two weeks ago, she found out that none of her son's seventh-grade teachers had been told that he had severe reading problems that need special attention.
The state takeover is an educational experiment that remains, at best, unfinished. And in two more years, law requires that the state leave Roosevelt, which all in all might not be a bad thing.
"I wouldn't support this model again," said James A. Kadamus, the state's deputy commissioner of education, who wrote a recent report on Roosevelt that, among other things, advocated hiring a private consultant to sort through the mess and make recommendations.
Michael Mostow, the district superintendent who also headed the state's staff at Roosevelt immediately after the takeover, is downright dismissive of the critics. He points to current initiatives from computer education to teacher training to corporate fund-raising. But he insists that he is more than competent to run things without kibitzers from Albany.
What's even worse, he complains, is Albany's latest decision to put one of nine new charter schools in Roosevelt -- a decision he is fighting ferociously. If the charter school begins next year as planned with 200 pupils from kindergarten through second grade, he says, it will cost his district $1.7 million and grow each year as more classes are added.
"This should never have happened in a suburban school district that's poor," he said. "It's a travesty."
Others see a charter school as the only solution. "All of us have failed so far," said Bob Francis, who leads a Roosevelt advisory committee authorized by state law and is on the charter school's board. "I don't have any problem recognizing that we failed."
Most telling, the principal who bragged about her fourth-grade winners said several minutes later that their best teacher had been hired by a nearby district for more money. So had two exceptional third-grade teachers. In the entire district, 16 percent of teachers leave each year, compared with a Nassau County average of 9 percent. The reason is that the district pays at least $10,000 less for an experienced teacher. Its salary schedule is the lowest in downstate New York outside of New York City.
Administrators twirl through their own revolving door. So, too, do state overseers brought in from outside. (New ones, who will be paid for the first time, have just been appointed. They are the third such group since the state takeover.)
It might not be cause and effect, but critics say it all wears on the students. Junior and senior high school students do considerably worse than their elementary counterparts. Last year's 11th graders were Nassau County's lowest achievers on standardized tests, a result of what one school board member calls "a menu for failure." Although the graduation rate rose last year to 97 percent, a record high for the district, only 4 of the 120 high school graduates received Regents diplomas, compared with 5 in 1996, the academic year of the takeover.
Seretta McKnight, who was president of the Roosevelt school board when the state fired the panel and who remains a fierce critic of both state and local officials, puts it more graphically. "A systematic retardation process has been going on," she said. "Slowly, our children fall apart."
A striking response is the number of local parents scrambling to send their children to private school. At Ms. Shelley's Upward Prep school, which serves grades kindergarten through 4 and has two buildings, one on Nassau Road and the other on Centennial Avenue just a few blocks from the Roosevelt district's Centennial Avenue Elementary School, an official said that 90 percent of 500 students are from the Roosevelt district. That comes to around a quarter of the district's enrollment for the same grades.
Kevin Hagans, a heavy equipment operator for New York City, strains financially to send two children to Ms. Shelley's. He cites smaller class size, an excellent after-school program and what he thinks is better security. "You have a better chance to really prepare your child," he said.
Maybe this is what it means to be a poor, nearly 100 percent African-American and Latino school district in the midst of more affluent suburbia. But this is no war zone. Lawns in Roosevelt are well tended, and every so often appears the sort of wonderful garden that makes people smile on a sunny morning. The scene varies little from Baldwin and other nearby neighborhoods.
Still, the one-square-mile Roosevelt district has the highest poverty index of any district in Nassau County, the highest unemployment rate and the largest population receiving public assistance. Nearly three-quarters of Roosevelt students are eligible for free or reduced-price school lunches, compared with 17 percent in the rest of Nassau county.
A bitter irony for the strivers who escaped the Bronx and Brooklyn to seek the suburban dream is that Roosevelt also has Nassau County's second-highest residential property tax rates.
Much of the tax burden is caused by the district's small size and the virtual absence of businesses to tax. But the United States Justice Department is suing Nassau County, accusing it of assessing minorities exorbitantly high property taxes. Roosevelt residential property is taxed at $55 per $100 of assessed value, compared with less than $40 in neighboring Freeport. The average value of a home in Freeport, a more integrated community, is $225,000, compared with $160,000 in Roosevelt.
"Roosevelt is like a part of inner-city Brooklyn that grew up on Long Island," said Alan Singer, an associate professor of secondary education at Hofstra University.
Dr. Singer works regularly with teachers at Roosevelt's junior-senior high school. He said that Roosevelt exists only because surrounding districts "don't want their kids," and that Roosevelt and a similar district in Suffolk County, Wyandanch, continue to exist only to maintain segregated patterns.
His view that they were never economically or educationally viable was expressed as early as the late 1960's by the state Education Department. By 1989, when the state compiled its first list of schools in danger of imminent failure, Roosevelt and Wyandanch were on it.
But no move was ever made to close the Roosevelt district, or at least its most troubled school, the junior and senior high. This would have required sending the students to nearby districts. Mr. Kadamus, state deputy commissioner, explained that such a step would have had to be approved by the state Legislature and probably by the voters in nearby districts -- Hempstead, Uniondale, Freeport and Bellmore-Merrick.
"Certainly, our neighbors were not going to go for that," Ms. McKnight said. "We're a black district that was defenseless."
But it would be hard for anyone to argue things were not in a deplorable state.
"If a community could be charged with child neglect, possibly with abuse, Roosevelt would be a strong candidate," wrote Daniel Domenech, who at the time was the Boces superintendent for western Suffolk County and was asked by the state in 1995 to lead an investigation of the reports from Roosevelt.
"Although each member of the visiting team is an experienced, veteran administrator," he wrote in his report, "few could recall ever visiting a school with conditions as deplorable as what exists at Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School."
The report mentioned a lack of books in classes, fires in lockers, calcified chemicals in laboratories and poor sanitation in the cafeteria. It said that no district buildings had certificates of occupancy and that all had numerous fire-code violations. Security problems, including students freely tossing firecrackers in the halls, were particularly noted. Students entered and left the building at will despite the presence of security guards at doors.
Dr. Domenech, who is now superintendent of the Fairfax, Va., school district, said his most poignant memory was student after student approaching him to say: "Help us. Can you do something about our school?"
The result was a bill in Albany sponsored by local legislators and supported by the state Regents. The bill permitted but did not require removal of the local school board. So the state began with more moderate steps than kicking out incumbent boards. In part, this was a matter of philosophy. "I believe in local control," Gov. George E. Pataki said when he signed the law in July 1995.
Among the 22 states that have taken over school districts, there is a mix of actions, ranging from very intrusive, such as New Jersey's, to West Virginia's, which kept local boards. Todd Ziebarth, a policy analyst at the Education Commission of the States, a Denver-based study group, said that both approaches had usually helped with finances and in some cases with needed capital construction. But the impact on education itself is more uncertain, he said.
"There hasn't been a compelling pool of evidence suggesting that takeovers consistently improve student achievement," Mr. Ziebarth said.
But the Roosevelt takeover was particularly timid, even tentative, many players say. And some think the result was a squandered opportunity. Mr. Mostow said the state should have been allowed to dissolve the elected school board, fire all teachers and administrators and totally restructure the district. Mr. Domenech agreed, saying, "It would have been wonderful for us to have the powers to clean house."
But he said the powers permitted by the legislation were not always employed. "After the legislation was passed, there wasn't the political will to follow through and do what had to be done," he said.
Then, over the first months of what was discreetly termed "the intervention," tensions escalated. The local board moved to assert its independence by changing superintendents, a move the state considered disruptive. There were also disagreements about the pace of school repair and curriculum reform. The result: a real state takeover. On Jan. 3, 1996, the Regents ordered the board removed.
For five months, progress was rapid. New computers and working toilets became the order of the day. A deficit of more than $1 million was erased by extra state aid. Every child received a textbook in every subject.
But in May 1996, a new board was elected. All were totally inexperienced, and the New York State School Board Association has said it takes members three to five years to get the hang of the job, even under smooth circumstances. Tensions developed with the state over how to manage the large physical reconstruction effort required. As the board scurried to interview dozens of architects, not to mention teachers, some new members seethed over being second-guessed by the state at every turn.
"It seemed they were bolstering their own egos more than working with the board in the district," said Mark Davis, a board member since 1996.
Another factor that residents believe has definitely tested the grace of political discourse is that members of the school board are the unincorporated hamlet's only elected officials.
Mr. Mostow was offered a job in as a superintendent in Bethpage. He wanted to stay at Roosevelt, but the district would not match the $135,000 offer. So he left, only to return in the fall of 1998. Progress slowed, and Dr. Domenech left the district in November 1997. Principals and acting principals came and went, four of them since the takeover. Anthony Pecorale, who succeeded Dr. Domenech and resigned just last month, said that attaining consensus within the local board was difficult, much less reaching common ground with the state. "The board is at best a 3-2 board, and that community can't afford that," he said.
Underlying the debate has been the prickly issue of money. The community voted down two property tax increases this year, the first a mild one of 0.5 percent, based on getting $3 million in extra state aid. The second, with no expectation of state help, would have meant a 21.8 percent increase.
The defeat of that budget forced a mandatory "austerity budget," but even that meant a tax increase of 9.8 percent and the cancellation of numerous budget items, including $670,000 in teacher salary increases, $394,000 for teacher aide positions and $283,000 to hire five new reading teachers.
When last-minute state aid came through, the district cut the tax increase to 4.7 percent. The state criticized the tax cut in a report late last month, suggesting it will make it very difficult to increase teachers' salaries, and said the state needed to spend $32 million to repair and upgrade schools and recommended a bond issue. The state estimates taxes must go up 11 to 12 percent annually each of the next three years.
The predicted increases include nothing to improve school quality. Instead, they are necessary to make up for state advances of aid, which have been running $4 million a year. The state is requiring that these advances be stopped, and by June 2002 will have phased them out completely.
"The ultimate issue here is finances," Mr. Kadamus said. But it is not the only issue.
As he enters his second year as boss, Mr. Mostow says he is relishing the challenge. He has greatly expanded teacher training and preparation, gotten grants to give every third grader in one of the four elementary schools school computers both at school and home, and hired two more foreign-language teachers for the high school. The language instructors are critical because the school has lacked sufficient courses to prepare students for foreign-language Regents exams, which is a requirement for a Regents diploma and perhaps the biggest reason that so few in Roosevelt have received one.
Mr. Mostow used state grants to decrease student-teacher ratios and to mix special-education students into regular classrooms. The district last year revived dormant after-school programs and added summer school. The superintendent has also attended to such details as building two tennis courts, in addition to the two it has, so the tennis team can play interscholastic matches at home for the first time. The P.T.A. has been reorganized, the football field resodded and the libraries remodeled. He has thrilled junior and high school students by buying a pizzeria-quality pizza oven for the cafeteria.
"I've never had as hard a job as this job," Mr. Mostow said. "There are so many things to juggle simultaneously."
Indisputably, there are positive signs as one wanders through the schools. Mary Deutch, a fifth-grade teacher who formerly taught in Far Rockaway, Queens, said Roosevelt kids are simply nicer. In her old school, she said "the kids knew every gun, every type of drug." Here, she said, "There's not a tough kid in the whole class."
Lynda Sarnoff, who is director of special and alternative education, said she came to Roosevelt after 25 years in the New York City system, where she supervised 45,000 children at the end. "I wanted to get closer to kids," she said. "You can work child by child."
One of her progams is a new alternative school for disruptive high schoolers. Jamal Griffin, 17, a junior in the alternative school, located in a separate building away from other schools, said he appreciated the extra attention. "Without this, I would have got lost," he said. "I would have been out of school or something."
Edwina Williams, who as P.T.A. president last year revived the moribund organization, said parents were getting more and more involved. Last year's initiatives began with a potluck supper and crescendoed into a variety of activities. Most important is encouraging parents to visit the high school, and a new parents' room was recently established through the P.T.A.
"We're working to be supportive and they're listening," Ms. Williams said. "I'm determined not to give up hope."
At the center of the storm is Shelton Wilder, the new high school principal. He came from Mississippi, where he specialized in improving reading test scores of flagging schools. Though the state report suggested he may need help adjusting to New York, particularly the move from Mississippi's tests of academic competency to the higher standards being imposed in New York, Mr. Wilder sounded quite confident.
"Desire is the ingredient that makes a district jump," Mr. Wilder said.
One of his plans is to replace study halls with classes where students learn something. Another is to take classes to visit a penitentiary as inspiration to stay in school.
Not that anything will be easy. Ronald Musson, the third assistant superintendent for business in less than a year, said he had found the district's financial coordination worse than he had suspected. "It's very challenging," he said. "Challenging and overwhelming."
Perletter Wright, the principal of the Washington Rose elementary school for the 10th year, acknowledged the difficulties. But she said she always feels a sense of purpose when a child pulls at her skirt and says he needs her.
"We don't sit on our hands and cry because we don't have something," she said. "It's not a crying time, it's a doing time."

HEADLINE: The Next Big Thing

BYLINE: By David S. Reynolds; David S. Reynolds is a Distinguished Professor of English at Baruch College and the City University of New York Graduate School. His books include "Walt Whitman's America" and "Beneath the American Renaissance."

 BODY:

STILL THE NEW WORLD
 American Literature in a Culture
 of Creative Destruction.
 By Philip Fisher.
 Illustrated. 290 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 IN computers, today's sleek cheetah is tomorrow's plodding turtle, ready for the basement or the recycling bin. Philip Fisher claims in "Still the New World" that American history has been a prolonged exercise in creative destruction. He points out that every new technological advance and pop culture fad obliterates a host of others: "All that now exists is equally half-real, half-unreal because it exists under the threat that it might soon become obsolete or be discarded."
The idea of creative destruction is rooted in the work of the economist Joseph Schumpeter and the social historian Stanley Kutler. While acknowledging his debt to these scholars, Fisher, who teaches English and American literature at Harvard, offers applications of the notion that are fresh and provocative. He suggests that creative destruction is at the very heart of the American social experiment, permeating the economy and mass culture. At the same time, he sees versions of it in American writings from Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass" through Mark Twain's "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" to the fiction of Ernest Hemingway and William Faulkner. Tracing simultaneously the social and literary ramifications of the idea, he veers between sweeping generalizations about American society and detailed literary analyses that are illuminating but often linked only indirectly to his theme.
Challenging the pessimistic thesis, anticipated in the late 19th century by Frederick Jackson Turner, that American frontiers (literal and figurative) are closed, Fisher, citing the ever-present "newness and nextness" of American life, turns to Emerson's 1839 essay "Circles" for a different view, highlighting innovation and renewal. Paraphrasing Emerson, he writes that most people are satisfied with the "apparent completeness and perfection of the world just as it is now" until "a new idea or invention surrounds and dissolves the earlier fixed places for these limited facts," creating a "new circle" that opens into "a new world." For Emerson, the new idea was steam. For later generations, new ideas would include the telephone, the airplane, the personal computer and the Internet. With bravura, Fisher declares that "the whole of American culture and economic life is a, so far, successful attempt to live up to this Emersonian manifesto" about newness.
Along with newness has come homogenization. Every new American idea or product becomes instantly replicable, producing cultural sameness from point to point. The examples Fisher gives include the Kellogg's cornflakes box on the kitchen table and the same 10 songs on every car radio on a given summer day. From such examples, he leaps to large statements about what he calls "democratic social space" in the United States, which he argues is identical from place to place, open to entry and mobility, transparent and intelligible, and devoid of outside observers who might make possible self-awareness or negative criticism.
This last claim points up a weakness in his reasoning. Although his comments about the homogeneity of American culture are shrewd, his insistence on an absence of meaningful critiques of mainstream values overlooks powerful figures of dissent and radical individualism in American history, including several Fisher presents as progenitors of conformist mass culture. In his treatment, Jefferson, having once mapped out a grid for equal-sized farms, becomes a kind of ancestral spirit behind Levittown-like suburbs, not the father of revolutionary fervor revealed in his more radical writings. Thoreau's retreat to a cabin by Walden Pond, an act of cranky protest against conformity and materialism, is improbably said to have set a "repeatable pattern for a nation of self-sufficient poet-farmers," so that "an entire earth could be carpeted from end to end with reduplications of Thoreau's experiment." The Whitman he emphasizes is the all-equalizing, ultrademocratic poet, not the bohemian rebel who could sneer at the "corruption, bribery, falsehood" he thought saturated American institutions and who could write, "Vive, the attack -- the perennial assault!"
Fisher does recognize an exception to the rule of what he calls America's "common ground of citizenship or democratic personality" -- regionalism. One of his most original points is that regionalism, sometimes viewed as blandly conventional, actually goes against the cultural grain by affirming the uniqueness of the local group. But regionalism, in Fisher's view, has no permanence in American society, as is exemplified by the bygone cultures of cowboys, jazz or hotel ballrooms. Besides a few tenaciously independent groups, like the Amish, regional cultures are absorbed into "a new common identity" and "a common way of life created around democratically available mass-produced goods." Fisher thus gives a fresh take on the melting-pot thesis, by which national and ethnic differences are said to dissolve into an American identity. Without becoming polemical, Fisher challenges multiculturalists, with their emphasis on ethnic and national differences, by arguing that these differences inevitably diminish in the fluid culture of creative destruction.
Fisher insists that American literature alternates between abstraction, concentrating on "minimal, widely shared traits," and realism, dedicated to "concrete detail" and "specific experience." His discussions of American writers, interspersed with analyses of painters like Thomas Eakins and Winslow Homer, give off many intellectual sparks but do not cohere around a clear thesis. It is typical of the rambling nature of his criticism that "Leaves of Grass" is called a masterpiece of abstraction but later is offered as a prime example of realism. His analysis of William Dean Howells as a novelist of manners whose fiction typically ignores social matters slights novels like "A Traveler From Altruria" or "A Hazard of New Fortunes," in which Howells boldly tackled public issues. Fisher's declaration that "the novel has an almost fated relation to realism, to concrete detail" neglects an important body of experimental European and American fiction featuring surrealistic imagery and distortion of time and space.
There is something self-descriptive about Fisher's discussion of the "easy, light-fitting American personality" that he says is captured in Whitman's line about "the loose drift of character, the inkling through random types." "Still the New World" itself drifts loosely over the American landscape, illuminating major cultural currents and dipping into literary and artistic thickets that make for fascinating, if random, exploration.

HEADLINE: Memo to Gore: Express Yourself!

 BODY:
He's moved his headquarters to Nashville from Washington. He's hired a new campaign manager and fired his pollsters. What else can Vice President Al Gore do to rejuvenate his flagging campaign? The Op-Ed page asked political veterans and others for their suggestions.
 
Bill Hillsman, president and creative director of North Woods Advertising, which created campaign commercials for Senator Paul Wellstone and Gov. Jesse Ventura, both of Minnesota. 
 In Jesse Ventura's gubernatorial campaign last fall, we realized that despite the Democratic front-runner's high poll ratings, the front-runner would inevitably be brought down as voters became more familiar with the candidate's dull campaign style. Therein lies a lesson.
First, Al Gore should stop speaking in manufactured sound bites. He's the sitting Vice President -- we don't believe he's the underdog. Remember, the American people can sniff out a phony on TV at 50 yards. And hearing him quote Janis Joplin sets our teeth on edge.
Second, he should get rid of Tony Coelho. We just got finished with a President mired in scandal. We aren't interested in voting for another one quite yet.
Third, he should get rid of Carter Eskew, his political consultant, who also helped create commercials for tobacco companies during the Congressional fight over Federal anti-tobacco legislation. The morally vacuous proclivity of political consultants to work any side of an issue (usually for the highest bidder), drives normal people nuts, undermines the credibility of the campaign and is at the very heart of what is destructive to our political system.
Fourth, he should stop overreacting to insider negative press and stop paying attention to every conflicting opinion. James Carville did campaigns and consultants no favors with his insistence on rapid response. Al Gore should pursue one vision and speak with one voice.
 
Mario Cuomo, former Governor of New York.
Few people challenge Vice President Gore's intelligence, personal rectitude and substantive command. Instead, his opponents point to polls that say he is behind. No surprise: Vice Presidents are almost always treated as a neglected positive -- like the word "inept." No one ever uses the word "ept," and few think of a Vice President as a powerful, positive force, especially if they have grievances with the President he serves.
Add Gore's relentless solemnity in public appearances, and you have a candidate too heavy to rise in the polls. It's different when he steps out of the role of Vice President and slugs it out on the issues, baring his soul instead of carrying someone else's water.
Remember his debates with Ross Perot and Jack Kemp? Heartfelt debate is more apt to produce spontaneity and reveal the candidate as an individual. That's perfect for Gore. Trading issues head to head with any of his opponents -- or just on the stump -- Al Gore will be charming, compelling and much stronger than he is as President Clinton's "Mr. Vice President."
 
George McGovern, 1972 Democratic Presidential candidate.
Bill Bradley has taken the initiative on issues like health care and campaign finance reform. In response, I would like to hear Mr. Gore acknowledge that the large number of uninsured Americans is part of a larger problem -- to say that it is unacceptable for the greatest nation on earth to permit one out of five children to live in poverty.
And I would like to see him commit himself to the full public financing of Presidential and Congressional elections. This is the most practical way to end special-interest contributions and to allow the candidates with the most innovative ideas -- always Mr. Gore's strong point -- to reach the public.
 
Charles Rangel, Democratic Congressman from New York.
I really believe that Al Gore will ultimately receive the nomination, but I never thought that he was so popular that he could wrap it up. In fact, I'm surprised that Bill Bradley is the only other candidate.
In any case, Mr. Bradley is not a serious threat; there's no substance there. He's just a pleasant alternative to those Democrats who want change. But this primary race is a healthy thing. It will rev Al Gore up and test him for the main event.
 
Howard J. Rubenstein, president of Rubenstein Associates, a public relations firm.
Al Gore should stick to the issues he feels most passionately about and speak about them from the heart. He must emphasize that we have a strong economy and a content public and that we remain the world's leader. Then he must take credit for it. After all, he helped get us there.
 
Deborah Tannen, professor of linguistics at Georgetown University.
Being a great communicator in the age of television does not mean being an orator -- filling a hall with the force of a booming voice and florid turns of phrase. Oratory in our age is conversational, because television has toppled the wall between public and private: public figures sit down to dinner with the family and keep them company in the evening.
President Clinton thrives in televised town hall meetings because he can talk to hundreds of people and sound like a friend who just pulled out a chair at your kitchen table to have a chat.
Al Gore's talents are different: He is warm and personable in private and articulate but formal in public. That's why he excels at debates, because his public style is just right for that setting.
But he also needs to find a way to bring his private strengths into the public sphere. That means fewer press conferences and speeches in front of large audiences, and more one-on-one interviews. Successful communication often means not changing your style, but finding the right context in which you can express who you really are.
 
Al Franken, comedian and author of "Why Not Me?"
My advice to Al Gore is simple: Don't panic. A few bold moves can get your campaign back on track.
1. Move your campaign headquarters to Nashville. This will allow you to run as a "Beltway Outsider."
2. Start calling yourself the underdog. This will better position you to win the "expectations game."
3. Challenge Bill Bradley to a series of debates. This is a win-win. If Bradley refuses to debate, he looks scared. If he does debate, simply appearing on the same platform with him will establish you as a serious contender.
Now is the time to prove that you are the only viable alternative to Bill Bradley. If Bradley stumbles between now and the spring, you'll be in position to step in and take the nomination.

HEADLINE: When Jobs Move Away

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The news that Chase Manhattan is moving 3,500 of its jobs out of New York has tragic meaning for many of the families involved (news article, Oct. 8).
Although these employees cannot be compelled to go to Florida, Texas or Massachusetts, the reality is that with all of our prosperity, it is not so easy to get a new job. 
 What Chase's action means to some is breaking up families, relationships with close friends and church affiliations. To people whose ambition has been to live in what many consider the world's greatest city, it also has meaning that defies evaluation. More and more, we are seeing the tremendous power of corporations to affect the lives of people who work for them.
 
HARRIS L. PRESENT
New York, Oct. 8, 1999

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce;
How can technology investors move into areas like Africa? One entrepreneur sees the answer in satellites.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
THE technology sector's financial success the last three years has been largely a North American phenomenon.
But some forward-thinking investors have been moving offshore toward untapped markets and investments, often pushing communication technologies into underdeveloped countries in Latin America and Asia. 
 On foreign soil, American investment often looks -- and acts -- remarkably like invasion. And it is sometimes treated accordingly, as cellular telephone providers discovered last year when the Chinese Government abruptly terminated a number of successful joint ventures with vendors like Motorola and Ericsson in favor of its own technologies.
So how will American investors, particularly those drunk on their recent good fortune and feeling perhaps a little invincible, henceforth enter these raw new markets? The answer to that question may determine which nations are pulled into the global market and which are left behind.
Some areas, notably much of Africa, might even welcome an invasion of foreign technology investment.
With nearly 800 million people in nearly 50 countries speaking hundreds of dialects and often in conflict with one another, Africa has attracted almost no technology investment. Add to those problems the continent's relatively high levels of poverty and illiteracy, and the risk-reward ratio is not exactly compelling.
And yet, people like Noah Samara are willing, and even eager, to take the risk.
After 10 years of planning and development, Mr. Samara, the Ethiopian-born founder and chairman of the Worldspace Corporation in Washington, began broadcasting digital radio programming from his company's Afristar satellite on Oct. 1.
Afristar, the first of three Worldspace satellites (two more serving Asia and Latin America are to be launched in 2000), is the first satellite to deliver simultaneous programming to the entire African continent.
If all three satellites are in orbit by the end of next year, Worldspace's potential audience will be more than 4.8 billion people.
Worldspace was conceived when, while practicing law in Washington, Mr. Samara saw the AIDS epidemic ravaging Africa. People needed information desperately to stem the spread of the virus, he realized, but distributing printed materials was expensive and impractical in a continent with so many remote areas and such illiteracy, and televisions were too few and too expensive for most Africans to operate.
Mr. Samara's answer was the world's first portable satellite media receiver: a digital radio that connects with various power sources, including solar panels for poor, rural areas, as well as to PC's and printers.
The receivers, manufactured by Matsushita's Panasonic and JVC subsidiaries, Hitachi and Sanyo, cost about $250 today, Mr. Samara said. That seems prohibitively expensive, but he said that "once you start introducing new products and services, people start working harder to make sure they can benefit from the conveniences."
"We've calculated the number of families in our coverage area that can afford receivers at these prices," he added. "We designed the African satellite's footprint to cover the more affluent Middle East, as well."
Why radios and not the Internet? Digital radio was the only solution that made sense, he insisted, because it was the cheapest, most efficient way to reach the widest population, from poor, illiterate rural villages to more affluent urban areas.
It was also the most adaptable, he said, because the digital radios could also receive data, like documents and static Web pages.
Worldspace, with $1.2 billion of investments, primarily from Saudi backers, hopes to make money by selling time on the satellites to various broadcasters, and by offering pay services of its own. Today, these include Time Warner's CNN International and Bloomberg Financial News as well as national and indigenous broadcasts from countries like Egypt, Ghana, Senegal and South Africa. But more interesting than its commercial services is its goal of creating markets by fighting poverty.
A central part of Mr. Samara's strategy was setting aside 5 percent of his satellites' capacity for a nonprofit organization called Equal Access, which Worldspace started with Solaria, a solar-energy equipment provider and the State of the World Forum (www.worldforum.org), a nonprofit global leadership and education organization formed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1995.
Equal Access aspires to provide free digital radios and a rich flow of basic information, including educational and health programming, to the poorest African villages, at a net cost of $10 a user.
Its strategy is to get money directly from organizations like UNESCO and the World Bank, which have millions of dollars earmarked for poverty-eradication programs.
An early project will be a Pan-African, noncommercial news program, in the tradition of National Public Radio. Mr. Samara calls it "the voice of Africa talking to the people of Africa."
And because the Worldspace radio receiver can also connect with a PC and a printer, even remote villages would be able to receive multimedia data for distance learning and health programs as well as school curriculums in multiple languages.
Perhaps the most critical project for Equal Access, says Tom Rautenberg, director of strategy and program development for State of the World Forum, is a broadcasting service for women and families.
"We've learned from World Bank studies that the education of women and girls is probably the most critical variable in sustainable development," Mr. Rautenberg says. "Their status and economic potential is a leading indicator of how that community is doing and its potential for the future."
Although Mr. Samara is dedicated to changing the lives of Africans and others in developing countries, he argues that the strategy makes business sense.
"We thought a lot about how to subsidize the development of the poorest part of the market," he said. "People need so many things in these areas -- information on hygiene, how to be better entrepreneurs, a whole range of issues. If we can do that, we will help them break through some of the hardest barriers."

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report;
Turning small businesses' Internet dreams into reality.

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
COMPANIES hoping to do business on the Web are being bombarded with more solutions than ever -- all promising to provide services that address the problem of how to set up shop on line.
And within the E-commerce sphere, the segment that "solutions providers" seem to think needs the most help is the small business category. In fact, they may be right. According to the United States Small Business Administration, only 30 percent of the nation's 24 million small businesses accept orders on the Web, and far fewer can process credit card transactions. 
 But as more of those companies develop a full-scale Internet presence -- and as everyone who ever had a lemonade stand decides to sell something on the Web -- E-commerce software and service providers are competing more furiously for market share.
One increasingly popular approach is to offer "all-in-one" E-commerce packages, in which merchants pay a nominal monthly fee for software that enables them to build a site that is then hosted by a third party -- sparing the client the cost of Web servers and fast Internet connections.
Analysts say such services generally fall short of providing everything businesses need to succeed on the Web, which is, of course, what many promise to do. Still, all-in-one packages have proven to be a good way to test the Internet waters, according to many business people who have used them. And as more competitors enter the market, analysts say, the quality of low-priced E-commerce services should improve.
Rosa Simon, for one, can attest to the wide array of low-cost E-commerce packages available. Last year, Ms. Simon decided to build a Web site, www.blindsdepot.com, to extend the reach of her window treatments business, which she had previously run by herself selling door to door.
A technology neophyte, Ms. Simon looked first at one of the market leaders in one-stop E-commerce setup, Yahoo Stores. As with other companies, Yahoo enables users to build a Web site in minutes by filling out a series of forms on line. For $100 a month, digital entrepreneurs can post their store on Yahoo's site and offer as many as 50 products for sale. The more products offered for sale, the higher Yahoo's monthly fee.
Like its competitors, which range from established companies like I.B.M. to Internet service providers like Hiway Technologies and other portal sites, Yahoo offers a host of additional features. It aggregates orders and sends them via fax to the store owner for processing, encrypts credit card numbers during processing and offers a shopping cart feature, so customers can pay for multiple products at once.
What Ms. Simon could not get from Yahoo -- or any E-commerce provider, for that matter -- was placement high up on the results pages of search engines. Seeking more shoppers, Ms. Simon opted for an all-in-one package provided by iMall, which guarantees placement on its shopping site, www.imall.com. When that also failed to generate sales, she built a store using software provided by Concentric Network, an Internet service provider that hosted the site for $50 a month, and she set about learning how to manipulate the search engines for better placement.
However, the Concentric software tools were somewhat limited for her purposes, Ms. Simon said, so she spent about $500 to build a more sophisticated site with Shopsite software, from Open Market. With the help of a consultant, she also learned how to increase her site's visibility on search engines. The payoff, at last, came in March, when sales started to roll. "I'm making much more than before," Ms. Simon said, though she would not disclose specific numbers. "And I'm working much less."
Jack Staff, chief economist with Zona Research, a unit of Intelliquest, said "there are literally dozens of features that are needed to make an E-commerce site work well" beyond those offered by the one-stop E-commerce companies. Among other things, Mr. Staff said, small businesses need technologies to analyze customer activity on the site, gauge the effectiveness of advertisements, personalize the site for each visitor, build incentive programs, offer coupons and instant discounts, confirm orders and returns and automate E-mail responses. "And then the real issue becomes how to get well known with consumers," Mr. Staff said.
In this regard at least, E-commerce service providers feel their customers' pain. According to Andrew Beebe, chief executive of Bigstep.com, which provides E-commerce services to businesses, profitability and visibility are difficult to achieve in this category. "There are a lot of people doing this," he said, "and they're making a lot of noise."
As for profitability, Mr. Beebe said his company, which began operations last month, "is not making any money at all right now." The plan, at least, is to provide free help to small businesses starting E-commerce sites, then sell them more advanced technology services along the lines of what Mr. Staff, of Zona, described. With 20,000 small businesses currently signed up and hundreds more being added daily, Mr. Beebe said he can negotiate discounts from E-commerce technology providers and extract a margin with every sale to his customers. "But this really is going to be a tight margin game," he said.
That is especially likely if his competitors keep driving the price of services down. "Every time someone else thinks they're going to sell something, we're going to give it away," said Serge Wilson, chief executive of Freemerchant.com, which provides E-commerce services completely free of charge. Mr. Wilson, whose company has signed up 20,000 merchants, earns money by offering suppliers like the Office Max retail chain access to Freemerchant store owners.
Mr. Wilson sees his service as an ideal entree for people who are not sure they want to commit thousands of dollars to an Internet business. "A certain percentage of our merchants will never sell successfully," he said. "It takes the right product, and time and effort."
It also takes more expertise in a given category than many E-commerce newbies are willing to develop, said Larry Erlich, founder of Domainregistry.com, who provides consulting services to small businesses. "Almost without fail, the people who try to start an E-commerce site try something they have absolutely no expertise in," he said. "They're usually involved in a business they could probably make some money with on the Web, but they want to do something else. It's clicks and wishes."

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
The Stars Give a Party For a Global Web Site

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
When is a benefit not a benefit? When it's a start-up party for a Web site. Three all-star concerts were given on Saturday for www.netaid.org, a Web site intended to take on not just one cause on one occasion but long-term work on five major global issues: poverty, the environment, human rights, refugees and poor countries' debt. It was a way for stars to demonstrate concern about everything from malnutrition in Bolivia to toxic oil-refinery waste in Lake Charles, La.
Net Aid was modeled on Live Aid, the shows in England and the United States that raised $200 million for African famine relief in 1985. While donations were accepted (to be used for refugee relief efforts in Kosovo and in Africa), the goal of Net Aid was primarily to publicize the Web site. Net Aid, supervised by the United Nations Development Program, is a clearinghouse for volunteer efforts, donations, information on agriculture and business development and Internet-style organizing, including an E-mail petition urging developed countries to forgive $371 billion in third-world debt. 
 The United States concert, Net Aid New York, took place at Giants Stadium (which is in New Jersey, in East Rutherford). The nearly eight-hour show began and ended with Wyclef Jean and Bono. They had collaborated on a song for Net Aid, "New Day," which touches on problems from unemployment to crime to homelessness but promises, "Sun got the darkness on the run." The lineup also included Puff Daddy, Sting, Jewel, Mary J. Blige, Busta Rhymes, Sheryl Crow, the Black Crowes, Counting Crows, Jimmy Page, the Algerian singer Cheb Mami and the Italian rocker Zucchero. Although nearly all the performers have sold at least a million albums each, the scattered lineup didn't fill the stadium; the top tier was empty, as were expanses of the lower tiers and the field.
Between sets, the audience at Giants Stadium saw video clips from the two other Net Aid concerts: a packed performance at Wembley Stadium near London, with a lineup including David Bowie, the reunited Eurythmics, George Michael, Bush, Bryan Adams, the Corrs and Robbie Williams, and an invitation-only event at the Palais des Nations in Geneva with Bryan Ferry and Des'ree, which was attended by Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations. The concerts were broadcast on radio stations in 132 countries and shown on VH1 and MTV in the United States and on the BBC. A two-hour show of excerpts is scheduled for Wednesday night at 8 on the TNT cable network.
With television cameras transmitting to an international audience, the musicians didn't stint on production values. They brought full bands, choirs, string orchestras and, for Puff Daddy, pyrotechnics. They also refrained from profanity.
Some stars brought out their most earnest, idealistic anthems. Bono -- dressed in a quasi-military uniform and wearing a cap from Jubilee 2000, an organization pressing for debt forgiveness -- sang "One" with a string orchestra conducted by Quincy Jones, insisting, "We got to carry each other." Jewel declaimed like a gospel preacher in "Life Uncommon," which grows militant: "There is a new army coming and we are armed with faith/To live, we must give."
Others just treated their short sets as condensed versions of a regular show. The guitarist Jimmy Page rocked the stadium with time-tested arena fare when he played his old Led Zeppelin songs while Chris Robinson, of the Black Crowes, sang as much as he could like Robert Plant; Mr. Robinson, a Southerner, was imitating an Englishman who emulated Southern blues singers. Mary J. Blige lavished her voice on songs about romantic strife, as her vows and pleas gave way to wordless, virtuosic swoops, blending the cutting tone of Dinah Washington with the gutsiness of Gladys Knight. Busta Rhymes set off one party chant after another, machine-gunning syllables and racing around the stage.
Net Aid is touted as the largest Web site to date, showing off technology from Cisco Systems, which contributed more than $10 million to the site; it claims the ability to handle one million connections a minute. The concerts were shown on the Internet, through an electronic network 10 times larger than the previous largest Webcasts (for Victoria's Secret and the opening of the 1998 Olympics), able to send out 125,000 video streams simultaneously. But on a home computer with a 56K modem, sound and video quality were still murky, and network traffic made connections difficult in some areas. Douglas Graham, who oversaw the design and software of the Web site for KPMG, ascribed the problems to local Internet providers and high Internet use on Saturday.
Even more than Live Aid, the Net Aid concert drove home stark contrasts between the haves, onstage and in the audience, and the have-nots. Puff Daddy's songs celebrated material success -- the Mercedes, the cell phones -- but then, in a burst of piousness, insisted there's more to life than a platinum Rolex. He was the concert's prime showman, with a white piano, a white-robed gospel choir, puffs of flame and two guest hard-rock guitarists to show he's keeping up with the metal-rap trend: Slash of Guns 'n' Roses and Mr. Page, who let Puff Daddy turn Led Zeppelin's "Kashmir" into a wounded lover's rant.
Video clips, shown during equipment changes, detailed harrowing situations and statistics: arms hacked off during Sierra Leone's civil war, 22 million refugees, 800 million people chronically undernourished, 1.3 billion people in extreme poverty. They made for some bizarre juxtapositions. Immediately after a segment on teen-age prostitution and drug addiction in Russia, a video clip of the Corrs at Wembley was shown. "It really doesn't matter if we don't eat/It really doesn't matter if we never sleep," they sang, " 'Cause we are so young now."
Nearly absent from the concerts was any music from the countries that Net Aid is intended to help most. Sting made an effort by turning over a song (and his band) to Cheb Mami, an Algerian rai singer with an expressive, fine-pointed voice. And Mr. Jean, over-reaching his limited skills on guitar, tried to cover the United States (with rap, rockabilly and blues) and the Caribbean (with "Guantanamera" and a version of "Hot, Hot, Hot" that turned the original soca into a Haitian compas). As cyberspace is now, Net Aid was a sphere of the affluent, but one that envisions affecting the whole world.

HEADLINE: Ford's Deal With Auto Workers Has an Unusual Twist

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 10

 BODY:
In difficult labor talks with the Ford Motor Company, the United Automobile Workers union finally agreed to an unusual compromise: it would allow the company to spin off its giant auto parts unit as long as Ford did not spin off workers with it, people briefed on the deal said today.
After nearly 30 consecutive hours of negotiations, the union and the company reached a tentative agreement Saturday afternoon on a four-year contract for Ford's 101,000 unionized workers, averting a potential strike. Under the deal, workers, who are expected to ratify the agreement later this month, would receive annual raises of 3 percent on top of adjustments for inflation, plus a signing bonus of $1,350. 
 To clinch the deal, Ford was forced to agree that the 23,500 workers at its Visteon Automotive Systems unit would remain Ford employees -- with pensions and even paychecks from Ford -- even after the company was spun off, the people said.
"It is like the janitors working in a commercial building -- they work for you but are paid by a different company," one of those briefed on the terms of the labor agreement said.
Stephen Girsky, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said the quirky compromise was necessary to prevent Ford's historically strong labor relations from disintegrating into strife that could cause costly strikes. "Is it a perfect solution?" he said. "No, but it is probably the best solution they could've come up with. Effectively, Visteon will be renting employees from Ford."
Ford has been eager to follow in the footsteps of the General Motors Corporation, which spun off its Delphi Automotive Systems unit in May. Ford had explored selling Visteon to Delphi or to another parts maker, the Lear Corporation, but is leaning toward spinning it off.
Under the terms of the labor accord, a Visteon spinoff would create a giant manufacturing company -- Visteon has about $17.8 billion in revenue and more than two dozen factories in the United States alone -- with almost no blue-collar employees.
While details remained unavailable today, and neither the union nor Ford would discuss them, those briefed on the contract terms said that new workers hired for Visteon factories would most likely be on Visteon's payroll, although they would have the same pay and benefits of current Ford workers. It is unclear whether Visteon would simply reimburse Ford for its payroll costs, or whether Ford might win price breaks on Visteon auto parts purchases that would offset the labor costs, or whether there might be some other arrangement.
Ford wants to spin off its in-house supplier, in part because it thinks that Visteon could win more work from rival auto makers as an independent company.
The terms of the agreement have left both sides frustrated. Ford executives are grumbling because they expected the union to allow them to spin off Visteon under the same terms that G.M. got after spinning off Delphi without consulting the union.
Under a contract reached on Sept. 28, the 48,000 former G.M. workers who now receive paychecks from Delphi are paid the same rates and receive the same benefits and pensions as G.M. workers. They are allowed to switch back to G.M. jobs when such jobs become available, and are promised layoff pay and other benefits from G.M. in the event that Delphi fails or runs into financial trouble before 2007.
But Ford could not get the same deal. The union found unexpectedly strong, emotional opposition to a Visteon spinoff from rank-and-file members and from some members of its bargaining team. Talks with Ford took longer than expected, and were clearly more difficult than either side had bargained on. Last week, the negotiations became so heated that they dissolved into shouting matches on several occasions, according to one person briefed on the negotiations.
While local union officials had not been briefed today on the details of the agreement, some said they had heard that the deal would allow Ford to spin off Visteon, with workers remaining Ford employees.
"That is still not acceptable to me," said Roger Caldwell, president of U.A.W. Local 845 in Plymouth, Mich., whose workers build heaters and radiators for the Visteon unit.
Because the contract includes big raises, and because less than one-quarter of Ford's unionized employees work at Visteon, the union's rank-and-file is expected to approve the contract when it comes to a vote later this month.
The agreement effectively completes the U.A.W's drive this autumn to negotiate fresh labor contracts for the nation's 400,000 unionized auto workers. On Sept. 16, the U.A.W. reached a deal with DaimlerChrysler A.G. DaimlerChrysler and G.M. workers won the same big raises as Ford's workers.
The Canadian Auto Workers union has also been negotiating new contracts this fall. It has already reached an agreement with Ford and DaimlerChrysler, and will begin negotiations with G.M. this week.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. to Take Part in Alliance With Other Computer Giants To Better E-Commerce Security

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ARMONK, N.Y., Oct. 10

 BODY:
I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, said today that it would become part of an industry alliance to create better security for electronic-commerce transactions.
In addition to I.B.M., the Trusted Computing Platform Alliance includes the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Hewlett-Packard Company, the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation. 
 The alliance's purpose is to develop a universal standard for equipment and software so that technology companies can make personal computers more secure, I.B.M. said.
"It's good that there's that many vendors involved," said Roger Kay of the International Data Corporation. "The agreement favors the average PC user in terms of giving them control over distribution of their information and greater comfort in doing E-business."
Business-to-business trade on the Internet is expected to increase to $1.3 trillion in 2003 from $43 billion last year, according to Forrester Research. Alliance members said the agreement makes sense as more consumers buy goods and services on the Internet.
"We see E-business expanding, and PC's are a critical piece of that expansion," said Alan Hodel, a Compaq spokesman. "As PC's evolve, the standards for security need to evolve with them."
PC users will benefit most directly from the alliance's efforts, Mr. Kay said.
"This gives the user a greater degree of assurance that the transaction they were doing wasn't being snooped, and they'll be more comfortable moving their business to the Internet," he said.
Mr. Kay predicts that other companies, like the Dell Computer Corporation, may join the alliance. "Dell sounded like they'd go along with it," he said.
A spokesman for Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., was not immediately available to comment.

HEADLINE: Milt Jackson, 76, Jazz Vibraphonist, Dies

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
Milt Jackson, the jazz vibraphonist who was a member of the Modern Jazz Quartet for 40 years and was one of the premier improvisers in jazz with a special brilliance at playing blues, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Teaneck, N.J.
The cause was liver cancer, said his daughter, Chyrise Jackson. 
 All the best jazz musicians know how to take their time, and Mr. Jackson was no different. Originally a singer in a Detroit gospel quartet, he created a new sound in the 1940's by slowing down the motor on his Deagan Vibraharp's oscillator to a third of the speed of Lionel Hampton's; a result, when he chose to let a sustained note ring, was a rich, warm, smoky sound, with a vibrato that approximated his own singing.
"He came closer than anyone else on the instrument to making it sound like the human voice," said the young vibraphonist Stefon Harris yesterday. "It's a collection of metal and iron, and we don't have the ability to bend notes and make vocal inflections like a saxophone. But Milt played the instrument in the most organic way possible -- with a warm, rich sound. He set a precedent that this instrument can speak beautiful things, and that it's not just percussive."
Mr. Jackson, who was born in Detroit, had become an impressively broad musician by the middle of his teen-age years. He had perfect pitch, and he began teaching himself guitar at the age of 7, started piano lessons at 11 and in high school played five instruments: drums, tympani, violin, guitar and xylophone; he also sang in the choir. By the age of 16, he had picked up the vibraphone as well, encouraged by a music teacher, and sang tenor in a popular gospel quartet called the Evangelist Singers as well as beginning his jazz career, playing vibraphone with Clarence Ringo and the George E. Lee band.
Out of high school, he almost joined Earl Hines's big band, but his draft notice intervened. In 1944, back in Detroit after two years of overseas military service, he set up a jazz quartet called the Four Sharps. (He admitted that he got his nickname, Bags, from the temporary furrows under his eyes incurred by a drinking binge after his release from the Army.) Dizzy Gillespie saw the quartet at a Detroit bar on a swing through the Midwest, and called upon Mr. Jackson in 1945 to join his band in New York.
Mr. Jackson's style, then and later, came from Charlie Parker, rather than Mr. Hampton, his most prominent precursor on the instrument; he not only tried to achieve a hornlike legato with his mallets, but he adopted many of Parker's rhythmic traits as well. He was the first bona fide bebop musician on the vibraphone, and became one of the prides of Gillespie's own band. Gillespie also brought him to Los Angeles to fill out his sextet at Billy Berg's club, hedging against the probability that Parker, who was in the band and at the low point of his heroin addiction, would fail to show up.
Back in New York in 1946, Mr. Jackson recorded some of bebop's classics with Gillespie's orchestra -- "A Night in Tunisia," "Anthropology" and "Two Bass Hit." Mr. Jackson, the pianist John Lewis, the bassist Ray Brown and the drummer Kenny Clarke were the rhythm section of Gillespie's band. "Dizzy had a lot of high parts for the brass in that group," remembered Mr. Brown. "So he said, 'I have to give these guys' lips a little rest during concerts, and while they're resting, you should play something.' " The development of this rhythm section's relationship led to some recordings for Gillespie's own label, Dee Gee, by a new band known as the Milt Jackson Quartet.
Mr. Jackson left Gillespie and came back to him again for a period in the early 1950's. And in 1951, with Thelonious Monk, he made recordings that would further the idiom again, weaving his linear improvisations around Monk's abrupt, jagged gestures on pieces including "Criss Cross" and "Straight, No Chaser."
Mr. Lewis, the pianist, began to have ideas about forming a new group, one that would go beyond the notion of soloists with a rhythm section. He had an extensive knowledge of classical music, had been involved in the sessions with Miles Davis and Gerry Mulligan that would become known as "Birth of the Cool," and he envisioned a more deliberately formal feeling for a small band. In 1952 the Modern Jazz Quartet began, with Clarke as drummer and Percy Heath as bassist. Connie Kay replaced Clarke in 1955. After a while, Mr. Lewis became the group's musical director.
The group wore tailored suits and practiced every aspect of their public presentation, from walking on stage to making introductions to the powerfully subdued arrangements in their playing. They wanted to bring back to jazz the sense of high bearing it had been losing as the popularity of the big bands was slipping and jazz became more of a music predicated on the casual jam-session. Through two decades of immaculately conceived and recorded albums on Atlantic Records, beginning in 1956, their vision was borne out. Initially, they found that audiences were somewhat startled by the authority of their quietness; eventually the group would be one of the few jazz bands embraced by an audience much wider than jazz fans.
Mr. Lewis economized, playing small chords and creating a light but sturdy framework for the music, and Mr. Jackson was the expansive foil, letting his tempos crest and fall, luxuriating in the passing tones and quick, curled runs of bebop. It was often supposed that he grew frustrated with his role in the band; in a recent interview Mr. Jackson said he felt that Mr. Lewis suppressed the group's sense of swing. In 1974 he left, dissolving the band until it reunited for the first of several tours in the 1980's. Mr. Kay died in 1994, and the Modern Jazz Quartet, with Mickey Roker sitting in for him, gave its last performance the following year.
Besides being widely acknowledged as one of the music's greatest improvisers, Mr. Jackson wrote a lot of music -- most famously the blues pieces "Bags' Groove," "Bluesology" and "The Cylinder." He recorded widely. He made small-group and orchestral records in the early 1960's, collaboration albums with John Coltrane and Ray Charles, and a large number of records on the Pablo label during the 1970's and 1980's with Mr. Brown on bass, as well as Gillespie, Count Basie, Oscar Peterson and others. In 1992 he began a series of albums produced by Quincy Jones for the Qwest label; the most recent, from this year, was "Explosive!," recorded with the Clayton-Hamilton Jazz Orchestra. The last collaboration with Mr. Brown and Mr. Peterson, "The Very Tall Band," was issued this year by Telarc.
In addition to his daughter, of Fort Lee, N.J., he is survived by his wife, Sandra, of Teaneck, and three brothers: Alvin, of Queens, and Wilbur and James, both of Detroit.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Clinton's Consumer Rip-Off

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
"You want to buy this new cable service that's much faster than your old modem," my son the information architect told me. Not wanting to become the slowpoke pundit, I called my local cable company and ordered ExpressNet. A new black box cost $150 and the monthly fee was $25.
Two weeks later, a disembodied voice called to say that the superspeed Internet connecting service had merged with a Texas conglomerate and if I didn't agree to the doubling of the monthly rate, my service would end and I would be stuck with a useless $150 receiver. 
 I again called my local cable monopoly. Although I never reached a human being, its complaint software signaled that I could continue for six months at the original rate, after which it was double or nothing.
This minor outrage came to mind in watching the gee-whiz, ain't-these-big-numbers-fun accounts on television news of the latest combinations of corporate colossi.
Worldcom, which last year bought MCI, was now swallowing up Sprint for $115 billion. This, analysts assure us, will allow the new supergiant to compete with AT&T, which already is plunking down $58 billion for Mediaone with the smiling approval of roundheeled Clintonites at the Federal Communications Commission.
Why are we going from four giants in telecommunications down to two? Because, the voice with the corporate-government smile tells us, that will help competition. Now each giant will be able to hedge its bets in cable, phone line and wireless, not knowing which form will win out. The merger-manic mantra: In conglomeration there is strength.
That's what they said a long generation ago when business empire-builders boosted their egos by boosting their stock to buy the earnings of unrelated companies. A good manager could manage anything, they said, achieving vast economies of scale. As stockholders discovered to their loss, that turned out to be baloney.
Ah, but now, say the biggest-is-best philosophers, we're merging within the field we know best. And if we don't combine quickly, the Europeans and Asians will, stealing world business domination from us. The urgency of "globalization," say today's mergermaniacs, destroys all notions of diverse competition, and only the huge, heavily capitalized multinational can survive.
That's why we see the old Seven Sisters of oil working their way down toward two big sisters having fun with fungibility, and why our former Big Seven accounting firms are headed to a Big Two. Unchecked international combines can crush unions, water down professional ethics, circumvent national regulation and stick it to consumers.
Here are two startling, counterintuitive thoughts: The fewer companies there are to compete, the less competition there is. And as competition shrinks, prices go up and service declines for the consumer. (Say these reactionary words at the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, and listen to the global wheeler-dealers guffaw.)
Who is supposed to protect business and the consumer from the power of trusts? Republican Teddy Roosevelt believed it to be the Federal Government, but the antitrust division of Janet Reno's Justice Department is so transfixed by its cases against Microsoft and overseas vitamin companies that it has little time to enforce antitrust law in dozens of other combinations that restrain free trade.
Our other great protector of the public interest in diverse sources is supposed to be the F.C.C. When MCI merged with Worldcom last year, the chairman appointed by President Clinton, William Kennard, took no action but direly warned that the industry was "just a merger away from undue concentration." Now that is happening.
Why will the F.C.C., after asking for some minor divestiture, ultimately welcome a two-giant waltz? For the same reason that the broadcasters' lobby was able to steal tens of billions in the public's bandwidth assets over the past few years: Mr. Clinton wants no part of a communication consumer's "bill of rights."
Candidates Bradley, Bush and Gore look shyly away lest trust-luster contributions dry up. Only John McCain dares to say: "Anybody who glances at increases in cable rates, phone rates, mergers and lack of competition clearly knows that the special interests are protected in Washington and the public interest is submerged."
Today's populist message comes to you by my old, slow modem.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 637 words

HEADLINE: The Senate Confronts Soft Money

 BODY:
When campaign finance reform comes before the Senate this week, Trent Lott and other enemies of cleaning up the system will make the usual predictions that reform cannot win. In fact, the Republican leadership's barricade against change is crumbling. Under pressure from a growing number of business leaders, and rising outrage over a projected $3 billion to be spent in the current campaign, some important Republicans are thinking about supporting the McCain-Feingold "soft money" ban. Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska is planning to offer amendments, a welcome sign that he and others might be showing up to help pass the bill, not block it.
A solid bipartisan majority passed campaign reform in the House last month. In the Senate it is backed by a majority consisting of all 45 Democrats and 7 Republicans. But eight more Republicans are needed to break the filibuster to be engineered by Mr. Lott and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky. 
 Mr. McConnell, an energetic fund-raiser and ardent proponent of the present system, is telling colleagues that changing the campaign laws is a liberal plot to destroy the Republican Party. In fact, Democratic Party professionals also fear that banning soft money -- the unlimited money that corporations, unions and rich individuals give to the parties -- would cripple the Democrats. What the bill will really do is curb each party's ability to haul in vast corrupting sums from special interests looking for favors.
The core bill to be introduced by Senators John McCain of Arizona and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin is a simple ban on soft money, without an earlier provision regulating contributions to independent groups for their campaign ads. Their aim in pushing this stripped-down version was to lure Republicans genuinely worried about regulating the rights of such groups. We support the restrictions on these groups' fund-raising but also accept the tactic of dropping that part of the bill. Democrats pushing to re-attach the regulation of independent groups should realize that they are probably reducing the chances of winning enough votes to get the entire bill passed in the Senate. One alternative might be to widen disclosure requirements for money donated to independent groups that run campaign ads before an election.
Amendments to be offered by Mr. Hagel or other Republicans should be aimed at attracting more supporters without opening loopholes to corrupt money. The Senate can consider raising ceilings on donations to candidates, but only if the soft-money ban for the parties remains intact. Among the senators whose constituents should press them to join this process are Spencer Abraham of Michigan and William Roth of Delaware. Both are in tough re-election fights in states where voters care about campaign reform. They must know that they would receive tremendous credit at home for standing up for principle, not campaign money.
This is a signal moment for Mr. McCain, whose poll numbers in New Hampshire are starting to move upward in his drive for the Republican Presidential nomination. But other Republicans, notably Susan Collins of Maine, have been working hard to corral support within their party. Mr. McConnell's bullying tactics have not worked. After his threatening letter to the Committee for Economic Development, telling it to stop recruiting among businesses for support for the soft-money ban, the committee doubled its membership to more than 200 leaders.
Mr. McConnell likes to define campaign donations as free speech. But everyone knows that money does more than talk in Washington. It buys influence. The only way to stop that practice is to limit the money that sloshes through the system. Most Americans, most House members and most senators agree. The only question now is whether the majority or cash will rule.
