HEADLINE: One Wide-Reaching Slash Could Settle Budget Battle

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Running out of weapons in their politically charged fight to finance the Government without using Social Security money, Republicans in Congress are turning to the crudest of fiscal tools, an across-the-board cut in spending.
That blunt instrument would be a last-ditch choice for Republican leaders. The political risks are such that analysts are skeptical that Congress will use it. But party leaders say they support the idea, and 54 Republican senators passed a nonbinding resolution in favor of it last week. 
 "We are drawing the line," said Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, the majority whip. "If necessary, and hopefully it will not be necessary, we will implement across-the-board reductions."
That would avoid the difficulty of cutting specific programs by spreading the pain. And Republicans say they will do whatever is necessary not to reach the point at which Government spending for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1 dips into excess Social Security revenue.
The Republicans are well aware that the cuts could generate widespread public opposition and draw intense attacks from President Clinton and Democrats in Congress. And because Republicans are talking about exempting the military and veterans' programs from the cuts, the reductions could fall even harder on domestic and social programs.
"This approach is a sign of desperation," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee.
The cuts would be so painful that many Republican lawmakers have no stomach for them. But they say they have few alternatives.
The Republican spending bills increase money for the Pentagon, while freezing or cutting some domestic programs. So an across-the-board cut would mean some real reductions in social spending.
"Who wants to cut 6 percent out of education, health care, medical research?" asked Representative C. W. Bill Young, the Florida Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee. "But if the leadership directs us to do it, we'll do it."
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, say the cuts must be made if the alternative is tapping Social Security funds.
"It's an indication of how desperate they are up on Capitol Hill for a way out of their appropriations problem," said Stanley E. Collender, head of the Federal budget consulting group at Fleischman Hillard, a public relations firm.
The cuts could also aid the Democrats' argument that the Republican majority in Congress cannot meet its most basic responsibility of setting priorities and passing spending bills.
"An across-the-board cut is the ultimate confession of policy failure," said Robert L. Bixby, policy director of the Concord Coalition, a nonpartisan fiscal watchdog group. "It's the meat cleaver approach."
One difficulty would be the pressure to exempt the military, veterans and other favorites. "As soon as you talk about across-the-board cuts, everybody jumps up and salutes it, and then their second point is, 'But I have this very special program,' " said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader.
Conservatives outside Congress said the approach was not ideal, but better than raising tobacco taxes, as Mr. Clinton has proposed, or breaking the Republicans' pledge not to use Social Security revenue for general Government operations.
"It looks like the least bad of several bad choices," said Peter Sperry, a budget analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization.
Spending some Social Security money would have no direct effect on the retirement system's long-term financial condition and little or no economic impact. But it has immense political significance for Republicans.
Congress has still not finished work on 6 of the 13 spending bills needed to finance the Government, now operating under spending authority that expires on Oct. 21.
The Republicans are trying to limit overall spending outlays for Government agencies to $592 billion for fiscal 2000 -- roughly the same as fiscal 1999 -- and they are using every accounting device available.
For example, the Pentagon spending bill delays payments to military contractors from late September 2000 to early October 2000, shifting $1.25 billion of spending into fiscal 2001, Congressional aides said.
Similarly, Republicans are weighing whether to delay Federal workers' paychecks for late September until early October 2000, shifting about $3.6 billion in spending into the next year, those aides said.
The Republicans' only alternatives to this kind of creative bookkeeping are cutting their spending bills or tapping the Social Security funds.
It is possible that the Republicans will achieve their goal on time and on budget. But it will be hard. Congress is on track to use at least $8 billion of the Social Security surplus, House Republican estimates show.
To bring outlays down by $8 billion in fiscal 2000, Congress would have to pass and Mr. Clinton would have to sign into law across-the-board cuts of 2.7 percent, or $15.2 billion in budget authority, the Republicans estimate.
Budget authority, which pays for one or more years of spending, must be cut deeper to yield savings in outlays, which cover only one year.
Under a 2.7 percent cut, the military would have to furlough close to 100,000 personnel, disband an Army division and a Navy carrier battle group and deny health care to many veterans, House Democrats say. If military and veterans programs were exempted, the cuts on all other programs would be 6.3 percent, Republicans and Democrats say.
But the cuts might have to be even deeper. The Congressional Budget Office and the White House have both judged the Republicans to be on track to spend at least $19.2 billion of the Social Security surplus.
To avoid that, the cuts would have to be 6.9 percent if the military and veterans are included and 16.1 percent if not, Democrats on the House Budget Committee say.
The precise effect across-the-board cuts would have on specific programs is hard to predict. But the cuts would almost certainly shake every branch of the Government, from national parks to national security, and force thousands of layoffs.
They would cut off funds for food and education to hundreds of thousands of poor children, cancel millions of home-delivered meals for the elderly and hobble Federal law enforcement, the White House says.
The White House budget director, Jacob J. Lew, said in an interview that in many ways a 2.7 percent cut would be the worst of both worlds, failing to protect the Social Security surplus while hurting the needy.
"This idea hasn't been floated lightly, and we're taking it seriously," he said. "But it's a silly way to make policy."

HEADLINE: CLINTON OPPOSES A PLAN BY ALLIES TO GIVE SERBS AID

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
With winter fast approaching, the United States and its allies are deeply divided over whether to increase the isolation of Yugoslavia and its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, or to offer some aid to ease the hardship of Serbs in the hope of encouraging a more vital opposition.
On the eve of a meeting on Monday of the 15 European Union foreign ministers in Luxembourg, the Clinton Administration has outlined its strong opposition to plans by the group to provide heating oil and other aid to certain Yugoslav cites controlled by opposition parties, American and European officials said. 
 Under the program, the European Union would initially supply two cities with about $5 million in heating oil to help cope with shortages caused by destruction of Yugoslavia's petroleum refineries during NATO's air war over Kosovo. That aid would be the first part of a broader package that would eventually include food, medicine and even small-scale public works projects, European officials said.
But American officials have said they fear that the assistance could shore up Mr. Milosevic by alleviating public discontent, which they hope could lead to protests in Yugoslavia, early elections, or even Mr. Milosevic's ouster or resignation.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has laid out the Clinton Administration's objections in a series of discussions with her European counterparts, including Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain and Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany. "We're concerned about proposals that may have appropriate humanitarian goals but may lead to developments that directly or indirectly support the regime," said the State Department's chief spokesman, James P. Rubin.
The dispute over providing aid highlights the dilemma facing the United States in the wake of NATO's air war over Kosovo last spring, which left Mr. Milosevic politically battered but still clinging to power. The quarrel also underscores Washington's philosophical differences with the Europeans over how to further isolate and weaken Mr. Milosevic's Government.
While the United States has said it supports aid to relieve the suffering of ordinary Serbs, it has ruled out any aid for reconstruction in Yugoslavia as long as Mr. Milosevic remains in power.
Many American allies in Europe, however, view things differently.
"The Europeans don't necessarily see isolation as the only way to do away with Milosevic," said Ivo Daalder, a former National Security Council aide who now studies the Balkans for the Brookings Institution.
"The Administration wants to keep the pressure on," he added. "They're afraid, one, that if you divide the allies from us Milosevic will exploit these divisions and, secondly, that the allies are weaker than we are, as on Iraq and Iran, and will undermine the sanctions."
Since the war ended, Yugoslavia has remained under strict sanctions that prohibit trade, even as millions of dollars of aid has poured into Kosovo, which is technically still a province of Serbia, but increasingly is being administered by the United Nations as a separate entity.
The sanctions against Yugoslavia, coupled with NATO's destruction of bridges, refineries and factories, have caused the country's already feeble economy to collapse. There are shortages of foods, and spiraling inflation is making even basic items unaffordable for many.
In a report on Sept. 20, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said that as winter sets in, Serbia faces severe shortages of electricity, heating oil and coal. Electricity supplies, it warned, could fall 40 to 50 percent below its requirements as winter progresses.
"The overall impact of such shortages is expected to be increased morbidity and mortality, particularly in urban areas," the report said. "The most vulnerable will be the elderly, the very young, the sick and the urban poor."
Mr. Rubin said the United States, based on its own analysis, did not believe that the energy shortage would be substantial, but the Europeans have shown more willingness to consider ways to respond to the warnings.
The European Union has been trying to tailor a relief program that would not directly support Mr. Milosevic, who has been charged with war crimes by the international tribunal in The Hague. During a meeting last month, the group's relief office pledged roughly $40 million in aid.
European officials said they planned to provide aid only if they could guarantee that it would not end up in the hands of Mr. Milosevic's Government. The $5 million worth of heating oil being considered under the initial plan would, for example, go to two cities in southeastern Serbia -- Nis and Pirot , which are governed by opponents of Mr. Milosevic's ruling Socialist party.
Mr. Daalder said such plans had potential downsides, especially since energy, like money, can be easily diverted to the central Government. "These localities don't have real power other than political power," he said. "They don't have police or security power. How do you assure it doesn't get stolen or simply taken away?"
At their meeting in Luxembourg, the foreign ministers are expected to discuss ways to insure that Mr. Milosevic's central Government could not redirect the assistance -- something that Dr. Albright demanded in her discussions with them.
"They have to prove they are democratic forces," one European diplomat said of potential aid recipients, "and we have to be sure these funds are not siphoned off to the Government of Slobodan Milosevic."
The diplomat said that directing aid to cities, rather than denying it, could shore up the opposition leaders by showing the people of Serbia that the international community is prepared to help those committed to democracy. Otherwise, European officials have argued, the democratic opposition is left looking as if it is in partnership only with Western countries that first bombed Yugoslavia and now want to make Serbs suffer still more.
"If you give them some glimmer of hope if they chose another path, they might chose the other," the official said. "It is a carrot-and-stick question. The E.U. sees more profit in the carrot than the stick."

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Hardship Aid for Serbs Divides U.S. and Allies
The United States and its allies are deeply divided over whether to increase the isolation of Yugoslavia and its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, or to offer some aid to ease the hardship of Serbs in the hope of encouraging a more vital opposition as winter fast approaches. A1
 
Blame for Mexican Floods
Opposition politicians in Mexico have fanned citizen anger over eastern Mexico's worst flooding in decades, saying the disaster was caused by Government negligence. A statement issued by the Federal Government put the official death toll at 314, while unofficial tallies compiled by Mexican news agencies said more than 400 died. A8 

Timor-Indonesia Border Buildup
The United Nations-backed peacekeeping mission in Dili, East Timor, said it would triple the number of its troops along the border with the Indonesian-controlled half of the island in an effort to thwart attacks by anti-independence militias. A4
 
Leftists Gain in Berlin
The successor to East Germany's Communist Party drew on a ground swell of disillusionment about the transition to capitalism to surge to its best showing yet in Berlin city elections. The former Communists, once discredited, are still ranked third behind the center-right Christian Democrats and the center-left Social Democrats, and the election will leave Berlin's local Parliament essentially unchanged. A9
 
Europe Defense Worries U.S.
A plan to create a defense arm for the 15-nation European Union is stirring fears among American civilian and military officials in NATO about unnecessary replication that the allies can ill afford. A9
 
Two Sides of Chechnya War
As Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia contends that his military operation is going well, the Chechens insist that they have beaten back the Russian advance. The Chechens say they have regrouped and retaken a number of villages. A3
 
Malaysia Frees Reporter
Murray Hiebert of the Far Eastern Economic Review was freed today from a prison on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur after serving four weeks of a six-week sentence for contempt of court. Mr. Hiebert, 50, of Steinbach, Manitoba, lost an appeal of a 1997 conviction for an article he wrote about the growing number of defamation suits in Malaysia. The imprisonment drew widespread condemnation and focused attention on press restrictions. (AP)
 
New Prime Minister in Peru
President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru appointed Alberto Bustamante Belaunde, a lawyer who defended Peru before the Inter-American Human Rights Court, as the new Prime Minister. Mr. Bustamante replaces Victor Joy Way, who resigned on Friday to run for Congress. (Reuters)

A.F.L.-C.I.O. to Endorse Gore, Its Leader Says
The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney, said that Vice President Al Gore would receive the endorsement of the powerful labor federation at its convention this week because a two-thirds majority of delegates had committed to Mr. Gore's Presidential campaign. A1
 
G.O.P. Weighs Spending Cuts
Running out of weapons in their politically charged fight to finance the Government without using Social Security funds, Republicans in Congress are turning to the crudest of fiscal tools, an across-the-board cut in spending. A10
 
2d Trial in Wyoming Slaying
Jury selection begins today in the trial of Aaron James McKinney, left, the second of two men charged with kidnapping, aggravated robbery and murder in the death of Matthew Shepard, a student at the University of Wyoming. Mr. Shepard was beaten, tied to a fence and left to die, perhaps because he was gay. A10
 
Satellite Launching From Sea
A multinational company has launched a communications satellite into space from a platform in the Pacific Ocean, the first such launching from sea rather than from land. A15
 
Bush Warned on G.O.P. Attacks
Continued attacks on Republicans in Congress by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas could hurt him on Capitol Hill should he become President, said a Republican lawmaker, Representative Ray LaHood. A12
 
Wildfires Nearly Contained
Firefighters were gaining yesterday on two wildfires in the Los Padres National Forest in California that were started by a lightning storm a month ago along the central coast. One fire had burned about 48,815 acres, and the other nearly 34,850 acres. The fires have forced the evacuations of dozens of people, including the monks of the New Camaldoli Hermitage monastery. (AP)
 
Gasoline Prices Decline
Gasoline prices dipped about half a cent nationwide over the past two weeks as crude oil prices fell, said Trilby Lundberg, director of the Lundberg survey, which covers 10,000 gasoline stations across the nation. The weighted average nationwide as of Friday was $1.33, down .53 cents per gallon from a survey on Sept. 24. The drop in gas prices follows an increase of more than 14 cents per gallon that started in early June. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Colt's Curtails Gun Making In Effort to Limit Liability
Colt's Manufacturing, which invented the six-shooter, the companion of cowboys and Texas Rangers, is abandoning much of its 144-year-old retail gun business in an effort to limit its liability in lawsuits. Colt's plans to make far fewer weapons and sell them mainly to law enforcement agencies and the military. It will effectively stop selling handguns to civilians, except to gun collectors. A1
 
Concerns Over Virus Diagnosis
The sudden switch in the diagnosis of a mosquito-borne virus in New York has caused concern among many of the scientists and Government officials who are working to strengthen the nation's defenses against biological warfare. HEADLINE: After Paying Pataki's Fare, A Free Office

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
When the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce of New York and New Jersey paid for two trips by Gov. George E. Pataki to Hungary a few years ago, the group was based in suburban New Jersey and listed its official address as its president's home.
These days, it has more distinctive quarters: a small office on the 63d floor of 1 World Trade Center. 
 The chamber pays no rent to the building's owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The authority's executive director, Robert E. Boyle, who was appointed by Mr. Pataki and is his longtime friend, gave the furnished office to the chamber at no charge. A similar space elsewhere in the trade center complex would rent for roughly $6,000 a year without furniture.
The authority also contributed $2,500 to help sponsor a trade conference held by the chamber at the World Trade Center in 1997. And it was not the only government agency connected to Mr. Pataki to lend its name. The Pataki administration's economic development arm also was a sponsor.
When the Governor accepted the trips in 1995 and 1996, his aides said the chamber was a nonprofit outfit that promoted trade with Hungary and had nothing to gain from the Pataki administration in return.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Governor, said Friday that the Governor had played no role in Mr. Boyle's decision to give the chamber the office and the help with the conference. Asked whether this assistance was linked to the trips, Mr. McKeon said, "We are pleased that we and the Port Authority have a good working relationship with the chamber."
Monika Szarka-Elling, the chamber's president, did not respond to two messages on Friday seeking comment.
Until recently, the World Trade Center address was listed on the chamber's Web site (www.haccusa.org) as its primary office. After The New York Times reported last month that three large corporations with interests before the Governor had made sizable donations to the chamber and had been involved with the Hungary trips, the address was removed from the Web site. The only address that now appears is a post office box in Far Hills, N.J.
Allen Morrison, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said the authority had not offered free office space to other nonprofit trade groups. He said Mr. Boyle gave the chamber the office, which is about 200 square feet, because the chamber did valuable work, not because it had paid for the Governor's trips.
He said Ms. Szarka-Elling approached Mr. Boyle in February 1998 and asked for an office, and Mr. Boyle agreed. Mr. Morrison noted that the office, which has no window, was in an area occupied by the Port Authority staff, so even if the chamber did not use it, the authority would not customarily rent it out. As such, the authority did not lose money on the office, he said.
"We would entertain similar requests from other nonprofit trade development groups," Mr. Morrison said, "as long as the request is in keeping with the Port Authority's mission to promote trade in the Port of New York."
The State Ethics Commission, which permitted the chamber to pay for Mr. Pataki's trips to Hungary after determining that the chamber had no business before the Governor, is now considering whether to investigate the financing of the trips.
Of the three corporations that contributed to the chamber, the tobacco giant Philip Morris gave the most -- $10,000 shortly before the first trip, $10,000 a few weeks before the second and another $10,000 a year later. The other two corporations are Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceuticals conglomerate, and Pepsico.
Mr. Pataki's aides have said that he and others in the administration were not aware of the donations.
If it can be determined that the corporate donations were intended to pay for the trips, that could be a violation of state ethics rules barring the Governor and other administration officials from accepting gifts of $75 or more from companies doing business with the state, even through a third party.
It is unclear whether the chamber's use of the World Trade Center office would fall under the ethics rules.
The Port Authority is not technically part of the Pataki administration and the state government. It is a bi-state agency that Mr. Pataki controls jointly with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey.
The authority would not allow photographs of the office, which has a desk, a circular table with four chairs and a bookcase adorned with a large photograph of Mr. Pataki.
Mr. Morrison said there was nothing unusual about the authority's decision to support the chamber's trade conference, which was called "Trade 2000: Developing Hungarian Business Partnerships." In previous years, the chamber had held the event in New Jersey. Mr. Morrison said the authority had contributed to a few similar trade conferences held by other groups in recent years.
The Empire State Development Corporation, the Pataki administration's economic development arm, also sponsored the event, but Maura Gallucci, an agency spokeswoman, said it had not contributed money.
She defended the administration's ties to the chamber, which is now known as the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce U.S.A. She said the Governor's first trip to Hungary, which was both a family vacation and a trade mission, had helped lead to the construction of a glass factory in upstate New York that had created 300 jobs.

HEADLINE: These Aren't the Days, My Friends;
Russian Singers See Young Snub Brighton Beach Clubs

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
Misha Gulko sat in a dinner club on Brighton Beach Avenue in Brooklyn, tripping excitedly on his words as he tried to recount the decades of his fame, from Khrushchev to Yeltsin, in just a few minutes.
Mr. Gulko, an icon of Russian lounge singing, flipped through dozens of posters and photo albums, with picture after picture of him in his signature Cossack hat with an accordion slung around his beefy middle. He fingered the tapes of his greatest hits -- songs of war's pain, love's loss, the cold of Siberia, the trials of immigration. 
 But what he really wanted to do was sing, not reminisce. So as the floor above thumped with the oompah beat of synthesizers and the wail of other Russian musicians, the man who says his age is a professional secret packed up nearly 40 years of memories and walked up the sweeping staircase to the stage of the National Restaurant.
Dressed in black, he was Perry Como with Wayne Newton moves. And the other musicians, whether middle-aged or barely in their 30's, rose in cheers when he finished belting out a brassy Russian love song. He had played everywhere, from Australia to Jerusalem, but sliding into a chair next to a smiling young woman, he pulled down the brim of his leather hat, still wanting to bask in this small moment.
"What do you think about that?" he asked, pushing every word through a thick accent. "Pretty darn good."
None of the other musicians contradicted him, although he had just crashed their party, a practice session for a music festival aimed at younger Russians. Instead, they crowded around to shake the hand of a man who had inspired so many of them, a living legend of the music scene in Little Odessa by the Sea, as this community is known because so many here emigrated from that city in Ukraine.
But Mr. Gulko also illustrates why the dinner clubs and cafes of Brighton Beach find themselves confronting a generation gap. He and other popular performers still draw an older crowd, but younger Russian-Americans generally shun the clubs, with their towering platters of sliced beef, bottomless glasses of vodka and schmaltzy Russian standards. Nor have they been stirred by modern Russian pop, which is still mired in the Western styles of one or two decades ago.
"The Russian culture here is just bad; it's plastic and tacky," said Alisa Nevmark, 15, whose parents brought her to this country when she was 5. "I would rather go to a museum than one of these places. It's just too bizarre."
Ms. Nevmark, who was standing one night outside the Odessa, another famous dinner club just off the strip, at first even refused to admit that her parents were Russian, choosing to note instead that her father was "a chemist."
Her generation's indifference and, in some cases, outright loathing, are not the only reasons for worry in the traditional music scene in Brighton Beach.
While Russians continue to move to New York in record numbers, many are settling in other parts of the city. Some older Brighton Beach residents are doing the same as they gain economic stature and feel more at ease.
And the recent immigrants are more diverse. While many of their predecessors were Russian Jews escaping persecution, they tend to be more splintered by religion, education and economic class, with different tastes in entertainment.
But those who hope to keep the Russian lounge scene alive see the biggest difficulty in attracting teen-agers like Ms. Nevmark and their older siblings, who came here as children and feel little attraction to the culture. Older performers lament that many young Russians even refuse to speak their native tongue.
The bittersweet times evoked in the sentimental songs of Mr. Gulko mean little to young Russians. To them, "Gulko is like a dinosaur," said Anatoly Aleshin, 45. And Mr. Aleshin's pop style, while newer, is still stuck in the 1970's and 1980's, he said.
"The people coming to these shows now are my age and older," Mr. Aleshin added, noting that his son, now a 20-year-old college student, stopped coming to his shows once the family moved from Russia to Brighton Beach.
"There aren't a lot of young musicians coming up in the clubs anymore," Mr. Aleshin said, "and the youngsters just are not interested in this stuff. They would all rather go to discos."
Making matters worse, some performers said, is that some of the area's most popular Sinatra-style crooners have returned to Russia, while younger stars of the hit parade in Russia come to New York only to buy vacation homes. They said there is little reason for these musicians to perform in Brighton Beach for less money, and often with less artistic freedom.
Some of the club singers, especially those few in their 20's and 30's, say they have notebooks full of original compositions -- from rhythm and blues to songs in the angry-girl style of L7 and the funky blend of a Luscious Jackson. But the Brighton Beach club crowd expects mostly golden folk oldies, with an occasional late-night English rendition of "Fools Rush In" or "That's Amore."
For the jam session Mr. Gulko crashed, the acts had been carefully picked to represent the diversity of Russian music and attract younger people. Alla Samoilova, the manager of Brighton Beach's Interesting Gazette Newspaper, a sponsor of the event, said there was even an age cutoff, which left Mr. Gulko and his songs of the Czar and the cold war out of the spotlight. Two similar festivals are planned for next month, she said, the first on Nov. 4 at Restaurant Tatiana.
"We need to let people know that these great musicians exist," she said. " Who knows, maybe an American producer will come."
But if the Sept. 23 festival at the National Restaurant was any evidence, a vast divide remains between what club owners consider hip and what young Russians think is cutting edge.
Mr. Aleshin was there, his hair feathered and his black shirt slightly open, inciting the crowd to clap along between courses of pickled herring, chicken Kiev and caviar. Misha Botsman sauntered around under sparkling disco balls, singing Russian and Italian love songs in the style of Burt Bacharach, reducing the audience to a weepy silence. And Anatoly Kireev let it all hang out in the Tom Jones tradition, sending the crowd home humming "Delilah."
Some of the singers had been warned not to perform anything too biting, original or bawdy, so as not to offend the older fans. Few did, although Lera Max performed an edgy tune as she swept about the stage tossing a shock of red hair. And Veronica, who goes by the single name, pushed the dress code as she sang coolly of love in a platinum page-boy haircut and a tight pink miniskirt with a low-cut top.
The festival was a compilation of what young Russians have come to expect: out-of-date songs and unsettling kitsch no more likely to appeal to them than a Catskills comic or a Las Vegas crooner.
Ms. Nevmark said that the only reason she had come to the Odessa, a palace of cruise ship opulence with a mirrored ceiling, was to celebrate a sweet-16 birthday party sponsored by a friend's parent. She and her friends grimaced when asked about the clubs and the festival.
In Manhattan and elsewhere, they said, there are clubs with Russian-language music more to their tastes -- techno, rap and pop not unlike the music on MTV.
But little of that can be found in Brighton Beach. Even though the cafes serve food and welcome all ages, the teen-agers clearly had no interest in spending any time at places like Club Arbat, Rasputin or Pastorale, where a woman in a black-and-white-striped top hat was likely to be singing "Lean on Me" or pirouetting around a man juggling silver propellers.
"I barely even speak Russian," said Neil Spitkov, 16. His friend Richard Batelman, 15, added that the clubs play "this old Russian music" for young people "who are basically American."
As the teen-age partygoers loitered in their high-cut evening dresses and black Gucci-style suits, the faint echo of a synthesizer came from inside the Odessa. The familiar blippy beat caused the teen-agers and people in their 20's to flee the dance floor as middle-aged men jumped up to dance.
"It's just not our generation," Ross Knopov, 16, exclaimed in frustration. "I mean, a lot of it's just so cheesy."
It is doubtful that Mr. Gulko would agree. He said the old Russian tunes he lays out every few nights in Brighton Beach remain the richest in the world. The younger generation likes "music without soul," he said, but he holds out hope that they will come around as they grow older.
"People hunger for bread, vodka and music, that is all," he said. "But people want understanding from music about broken life, broken love."
Mr. Gulko held up a small, yellowed picture of his parents, taken before the Communist revolution. "Only the old music is meaning over money," he said. "Only it comes from the gut and the soul."

HEADLINE: A Mystery in Louisiana Governor's Race

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Ever since he began running for a second term, Gov. Mike Foster of Louisiana has been dogged by one political embarrassment and mix-up after another.
At times, he says, he wonders whether running for office is worth all the grief, especially when he could be down on some bayou in Cajun country, where he grew up, hunting birds instead of votes. 
 "A lot of people want me out of office," he said this week while campaigning in New Orleans. "A lot of them enjoy all this grief I'm taking."
It is no exaggeration to say that the Governor is taking some political grief. What is perhaps more interesting is that despite it, he remains a heavy favorite to win on Election Day, Oct. 23.
That probably says as much about how the political game is played in Louisiana as anything.
The more curious and outlandish twists a contest takes here, the more voters seem to like it, especially if there is a whiff of corruption or dark dealing, real or imagined. As they say in Southern Louisiana, that's lagniappe, a little something extra added to the recipe or moment at hand.
Mr. Foster's grief began with an incident in which the Governor, a Republican, ended up acknowledging that in his first run for office, in 1995, he secretly bought the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke's list of contributors and supporters for a whopping $150,000.
Then, just as the furor seemed to be dying down, along came a Federal grand jury and the state Ethics Board, asking a lot of questions about the deal.
The Ethics Board ordered the Governor to pay a $20,000 fine for not reporting the purchase as a campaign expenditure, but chose to ignore accusations, denied by the Governor, that what the $150,000 really bought was not access to supporters of a racist who is still politically powerful but a promise by that racist not to jump into the governor's race.
The grand jury wanted to know, and apparently still is pondering, whether Mr. Duke ducked paying taxes on the $150,000.
Now, with Election Day just two weeks off, comes the strangest and most curious campaign incident yet.
A few days ago, several news organizations in Louisiana received copies of an audio tape of a conversation the Governor recently held with a private investigator from New Orleans, Dwayne Alexander. Who recorded the conversation and who distributed copies of it remain a mystery, but neither the Governor nor Mr. Alexander questions the tape's authenticity.
In the conversation, the Governor, who has summoned Mr. Alexander to his office, says he has learned that the investigator is "spying" on him. He demands to know who hired Mr. Alexander and why.
"I was hired to do a job," the investigator replies elliptically.
Mr. Foster tells Mr. Alexander that spying on a Governor is unwise and warns, "If you're doing it, I don't think it's to either one of our best interests." He says he will turn the tables on anyone who tries to "mess" with him and will have "a lot of fun messing back."
Then he suggests that Mr. Alexander become a "double agent."
The tape ends there. But Mr. Alexander has since said he refused to become a double agent, considers the incident over and has gone about other work.
Federal, state and local investigators have said they see no reason to become involved in the dispute, that it is strictly an issue between the Governor and Mr. Alexander.
As the Governor tells it, he was "just talking with Alexander, no threats, just fooling around with him, feeling him out, trying to figure out what he was up to."
"You always have to keep in mind that I've got a lot of political enemies out there," Mr. Foster said on Wednesday while talking to reporters on a visit to The Gambit Weekly, a local tabloid.
But probably he has nowhere near enough enemies to turn him out of office on Oct. 23.
Despite all his problems, the Governor has a lot going for him besides the forgiving nature of Louisiana voters. As a result, his challengers -- there are 11 in all -- are having big trouble finding political traction, including the strongest of the candidates, Representative William J. Jefferson, a five-term Democrat from Louisiana's Second Congressional District, which includes most of New Orleans.
Like the rest of the country, Louisiana, long beset by economic difficulties, is now booming, and Governor Foster is riding that boom. The state's schools, among the nation's worst for many years, are now beginning to improve, thanks in part to overhauls pushed by the Foster Administration. And the state's business and property owners, once among the easiest targets in the land for personal injury lawsuits, now enjoy extra safeguards, thanks to changes pushed through by the Governor.
Also, this being Louisiana, the race is not being run like most races for governor.
There are no primaries, only an initial contest in which all Democrats, Republicans and independents run together. If no candidate emerges from that with a clear majority, there will be a runoff on Nov. 20 between the top two finishers.
Few polls have been taken and those that have carry the usual caveat that they were conducted for candidates. But, significantly, not one released thus far shows the Governor with less than 50 percent of the vote.
Mr. Foster says he has "high hopes" he can win it all the first time around.
Mr. Jefferson is banking on a runoff.
A black candidate in a state whose population is 30 percent black, Mr. Jefferson expects to get all of the black vote in the first contest. He also predicts that he will pull enough white votes to end up with 45 percent of the ballots cast, and he says he is confident that the 10 other candidates together, even though little known and short of money, will take 10 percent to 15 percent.
"The math on that leaves the Governor with only 45 percent of the vote at best, and that means a runoff," Mr. Jefferson said this week after a campaign swing through the city. "Come that runoff, if I can hold my original vote and pick up roughly half of the white vote that went to the 10 other guys, who will then be out of the running, then I've got a real shot at being Governor."
If Mr. Jefferson pulls it off, he will be the first black to win statewide office in Louisiana since Reconstruction. If he falls short, he can run again for Congress in 2000 or for mayor of New Orleans -- his ultimate goal, many of his friends suggest.
The big issues in the governor's race, as Mr. Jefferson sees them, are the "fiction" that the Governor has significantly improved the state's schools and economy.
Mr. Jefferson said that he had much of the labor and teacher vote sewed up and that that would not be the case if the Governor had achieved all he said he had.
Mr. Jefferson says he expects to spend almost $1.5 million on his campaign, about $1 million of it raised two weeks ago when President Clinton came to town for a fund-raiser.
The Governor says he will spend about $3 million.
Most of the state's political professionals and political scientists foresee an easy Foster victory, maybe not a clean-cut win on Oct. 23, but a victory eventually, probably a big one.
Edward F. Renwick, who follows state political developments as director of the Loyola University Institute of Politics in New Orleans, says that while a reasonable mathematical case can be made that the Governor will fall short of winning 50 percent of the vote in a crowded field on Oct. 23 he is as certain to win a runoff as anything can be certain in Louisiana politics.
"Bet on it," Mr. Renwick says.

HEADLINE: Improbably, The Tiger Survives

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
In an old Vietnamese myth about how the tiger got its stripes, a man tries to show the great cat who's boss by lashing it to a tree and setting the tree on fire. But the tiger is so powerful and so inured to pain that it strains against the flaming rope until it breaks free, its brush with extinction evident only in the black marks seared on its fur.
So, too, it turns out, with the real tiger. As recently as the early 1990's, researchers were convinced that the largest and most sumptuously pelted of the world's cats, an animal more feared, revered, fetishized and lionized than the lion itself, was about to go up in smoke. Once the tiger abounded throughout Asia, from eastern Turkey to the Sea of Japan, from Siberia in the north to Indonesia in the south. But humanity's expanding numbers, and its lust for land, tiger body parts and the prey on which the tiger feeds, had taken such a huge toll that by 2000, many biologists gloomily predicted, the wild tiger would effectively be extinct. 
 But now, like a furred phoenix rising or a creature cognizant of its nine-lifetime warranty, the cat has come back. Far from disappearing, the tiger in some parts of its range is practically thriving, its numbers measurably greater today than just a few years ago. Though conservationists who have long battled to save the tiger warn against complacency and emphasize that the tiger is still endangered, they admit to an unusual sensation these days: optimism.
"We're all encouraged, which is very different from how we felt five or six years ago," said Ginette Hemley, vice president for species conservation at the World Wildlife Fund. "We won't be able to save the tiger everywhere, and we've learned that we cannot ever drop our guard again, but in some areas there's been some real progress."
Researchers and conservationists from around the world gathered last month in New York for a three-day conference called "Saving the Tiger: Assessing our Success," held under the aegis of the Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs the Bronx Zoo.
At the meeting, researchers presented data indicating that tiger populations are better off now than they were earlier this decade in eastern Siberia, Nepal and some areas of India.
For example, in the Ranthambhore forest south of Delhi, popular among ecotourists eager for a glimpse of tiger, a 1993 census found at most 20 tigers left in the region's 318 square miles. The latest tally, which has yet to be officially released, suggests that the figure has doubled and is still rising.
Even in countries where biologists feared that the tiger was doomed, including Sumatra, Burma, Thailand and Cambodia, scientists at the meeting reported encouraging signs of resilience.
"We had such a surprise," said Dr. John Seidensticker, the curator of mammals at the Smithsonian Institution's National Zoological Park in Washington. "We thought Sumatra was a loss, but it turns out that even with its enormous political turmoil, which is often accompanied by increased poaching, there are pockets where survey data show there are good levels of tigers, more than we expected to be found."
The tiger is by no means faring well everywhere. In the mangrove swamps of Bangladesh, where biologists had thought tiger populations were relatively healthy, new survey results indicate fewer than the predicted number of cats. And across its entire range, the tiger is still quite scarce. Dr. Peter Jackson, the chairman of the Cat Specialist Group of the World Conservation Union in Switzerland, estimates that there are 5,000 to 7,000 tigers left in Asia. Nobody knows how many tigers dwelt on the continent originally, for there were no efforts to track tiger populations until about 1972, but the number a century ago was probably at least 10 times greater than today.
Nevertheless, that the mighty tiger is holding its own in many pockets heartens biologists and offers a refreshing counterpoint to the dirges in conservation circles, with their bleak refrains of a world peopled solely by weedy species like squirrels, crows, roaches, rats and people.
The biologists attribute the tiger's recovery to several factors. For one, many Asian countries have begun cracking down harshly on poachers, who in the early 1990's were killing tigers willy-nilly, mostly to obtain tiger bone, a popular ingredient in traditional Chinese medicine.
For another, conservationists have succeeded in gathering critical information about tiger biology, hunting practices and reproduction rates to advise governments on how best to save the great cats. That advice varies from region to region, but one theme predominates: the best way to save the tiger is to save the tiger's prey: the deer, wild cattle and wild pigs that tigers eat, said Dr. K. Ullas Karanth, "like hamburgers."
"If you manage the prey species well, the tigers will take care of themselves." said Dr. Karanth, a conservation zoologist for the Wildlife Conservation Society, who is based in Bangalore, India.
To guarantee that there will be enough prey to support tigers, he added, a country must set aside some places where humans are not allowed to hunt, and hence where prey animals can always find haven to breed.
"For a while, it was very popular to talk about 'sustainable use,' the idea that you could have human use of a tiger habitat and still have tigers," Dr. Karanth said. "But our prey data have shown that we need to have nested within these sustainable use areas some truly protected places."
Asked if it was likely that protected areas could be set aside for the long term in countries as populous as India, Dr. Karanth said: "I'm 51 now. When I first started going into the Indian forest, at age 18 or 19, I thought soon there would be no more forests. But there are more protected areas and more tigers now than when I had given up hope as a young man."
"If you can do it in India," he said, "you can do it anywhere in the world."
Nor do people living in the tiger's range need to be convinced of the cat's worth, Dr. Seidensticker said, or told why saving the tiger is the right thing to do, morally, ecologically and economically.
"I remember talking to a Government official in Bangladesh a number of years ago, who said to me: 'You don't have to tell me that we should save the tiger. Of course we should save the tiger. Just tell me how we can do it,' " Dr. Seidensticker recalled.
In India, he said, the tiger is considered a national treasure, and not for nothing do other countries in the tiger's domain call themselves, sometimes wistfully, "Asian tigers."
That the tiger hangs on suits its metaphorical heft, which, like the fortissimo timber of its roar, has carried far, wide and deep. The powerful Hindu goddess Durga rode a tiger mount, while Siva, the god of destruction and reproduction, sat on a tiger skin. In the Chinese calendar, every 12th year is the year of the tiger, and it is considered a lucky, powerful year to be born (that means you, 1998 babies). The Romans loved the tiger, identifying with its deadly might, and brought them from Turkey as mascots. The Emperor Nero kept an entire stable of them, and Bacchus, the god of wine, was depicted in mosaics as riding a chariot drawn by tigers. William Blake mused in a seditious nursery rhyme about the "tyger, tyger, burning bright, in the forests of the night." Many other tigers have infiltrated children's consciousness, as Winnie the Pooh's strong, foolish friend Tigger; cartoon Calvin's stuffed animal, Hobbes, and a well-known spokesbeast for Sugar Frosted Flakes.
The symbolic value of the tiger is flamboyant enough that, several years ago, a shareholder stood up at a corporate meeting for Exxon, which long urged drivers to put a tiger in their tank. The tiger has been so accommodating as logo and sound bite, the shareholder said, that it's time to give something back to the tiger. As a result, Exxon, with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, began a Save the Tiger fund in 1995 that will dispense $9 million over eight years to various tiger preservation programs, to which conservationists, ever strapped for cash, responded "Gr-r-eat!"
For all the tiger's cultural presence, the animal proper is devilishly difficult to find in the wild. It lives largely in dense forest underbrush, where its striped pattern keeps it well camouflaged, so well that at least one renowned tiger researcher admits he has never seen a tiger in the wild. Other tiger biologists have spotted their subjects repeatedly, yet they say it always feels as good as the first time. "Even finding their tracks is exciting," Dr. Jackson of the Cat Specialist Group said. "And when you see the tiger itself, it's an awesome sight."
Only in the Sunderbans, a swampy forest that straddles India and Bangladesh on the Bay of Bengal, do people hope not to see tigers. Living in the Sunderbans are about 250 tigers notorious for being man-eaters, and every year they kill a dozen or so people who venture into the forest to collect wood or fruit. Recently, people have had some success in preventing attacks by wearing hats with eyes painted on the back, for tigers rely on the tactic of surprise, ambushing their prey from behind.
Apart from the Sunderbans, though, tigers have learned, after centuries of being hunted, to shy away from human beings. They prefer meatier meals in any event, the better to support their massive bodies. Tigers vary in size depending on where they live and what subspecies they are. The largest tigers are the Siberian males, which may be nine feet long and weigh more than 500 pounds. The smallest tigers are the Sumatrans, with males of 250 pounds and females 50 pounds lighter.
Coats also vary from one subspecies to the next. Siberian and Himalayan tigers live in cold climates and relatively open spaces, and so they have long, thick, relatively light-colored fur, while the tigers that live in the tropics have short, dark fur. Every so often a Bengal tiger is born with almost white fur, the result of a recessive genetic trait. These rare specimens have an otherworldly glow and a magician's reputation.
Whatever the hue, all tigers have an almost magical capacity for hunting. An adult can pull down a wild bull two or three times its size, puncturing the prey's throat with canine teeth bigger than your index fingers. Tigers, which have extraordinarily keen vision, can hunt by sunlight or darkness, and researchers have been surprised to find tigers hard on the trail in the heat of midafternoon, when many creatures are taking siestas.
A tiger is a semisolitary cat, living and hunting alone most of the time, but not averse to occasional congregations. Young males disperse at adolescence, but a daughter will often continue to live near her mother for much of her life, inheriting the mother's territory when she dies.
Females are not the only doting parents. Recently, males have been observed eating, playing and traveling with their cubs. They have reason to look after their young: an interloping male will often try to kill the resident cubs, his hope being that, by doing so, he will put the mother tiger back into heat and have a chance to mate with her. And tigers do mate and breed readily, which is why, scientists say, they can rebound from near-extermination when given half a chance.
In seeking to allow tigers to take care of themselves, conservationists have joined forces lately with purveyors of traditional Chinese medicine. One reason tigers hit bottom in the early 1990's, researchers said, is that the explosive growth of the Chinese economy led to an equally strong demand for products used in traditional Chinese medicine. Tiger bone has long been a staple item in preparations to treat arthritis, rheumatism and other muscular aches and pains. Rather than excoriate traditional Chinese medicine as superstitious hogwash -- an approach doomed to fail, given the enormous popularity of Chinese medicine -- conservationists have approached experts in the discipline to see if there were alternatives to tiger bone that could be promoted. They have discovered, through examining traditional texts, that one option is to substitute the bones of an Asian rodent called a sailong, which is common in China.
One way to make sailong bone desirable might be to charge more for it than tiger bone ever commanded. It worked for fake fur, didn't it?

HEADLINE: What Is a Minority-Owned Business?

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Long united in the struggle to maintain special breaks for nonwhite entrepreneurs, some civil rights leaders and minority business groups have become divided over a basic concept: what is a minority-owned company.
Many black and Hispanic owners of large businesses are arguing that the traditional definition -- a company in which members of minority groups own 51 percent -- limits their ability to raise capital by selling stock. But leaders of large civil rights groups and minority small-business owners say that changing the definition will further erode the whole idea of affirmative action. 
 At issue is a proposal by the National Minority Supplier Development Council to relax the definition of what would be considered a minority company. The council, based in New York, is a private organization that certifies whether companies can be considered owned by minorities. Many large corporations rely on the council's evaluation process to determine whether companies they are contracting with are, in fact, owned by African-American, Hispanic or Asian-American entrepreneurs.
On Oct. 26 in Phoenix the council's 80-member board will vote on a resolution that would allow minority companies to sell stock and, in some cases, retain the council's certification, even if the stock sale results in minorities owning as little as 30 percent of the company.
Supporters of the change say it is needed to allow minority companies to grow and to compete against larger white-owned companies.
"Our commitment is to assist the development of minority business," said Harriet Michel, president of the council, which is made up of Fortune 500 corporations. "Minority firms must be allowed the same opportunity to grow in this global economy, to be competitive and not to be continually defeated because they don't have access to capital."
Larger minority-owned companies say they need access to capital without losing the council's certification, without which they might not be eligible for a company's minority contracting program.
"It gives you an introduction," said Joe Arriola, who is Cuban-American and chairman and chief executive of Avanti-Case Hoyt, a graphics arts company that does nearly $160 million worth of business and has offices in Miami, Chicago and Rochester.
Mr. Arriola said he would like to expand his business by buying a small graphics arts company. But while his competitors could do that by selling stock, "I got to pay with cash and, for me, cash only comes from borrowing."
Leaders of some civil rights groups, including the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the National Urban League and the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, say the change will open the door to so-called front companies, in which minority executives have prominent positions but the companies are really owned and controlled by whites.
"For as long as there has been black enterprise, when you said black ownership that has always meant 51 percent," said Earl G. Graves Sr., publisher of Black Enterprise Magazine, who has led the opposition to the proposal. "If you have 51 percent, you have control; less than 51 percent, it is not control, you have an ownership stake."
Opponents worry that any increase in front companies would discredit the concept of special breaks for minority companies at a time when affirmative action programs are under assault. They are also concerned that a change by the council might prompt the Government to re-examine its definition of what constitutes a small "disadvantaged" company -- currently 51 percent ownership by minorities or some whites -- that are given breaks in bidding for Government contracts.
Proponents of the change say they understand the concerns of civil rights leaders given the setbacks in the courts and the passage of ballot initiatives like Proposition 209 in California, which outlawed government programs that extend "preferences" based on race and sex in employment, college admissions and contracting. But they say the proposal has a number of safeguards built in.
For example, companies must already be 51 percent owned by minorities and have a stock deal with a venture capitalist worked out before they can apply for a waiver of the 51 percent rule. The council will also examine the future makeup of the board, the issue of who holds voting stock as opposed to common stock, and who will be in charge day to day.
The change is being pushed by several large corporations, particularly the Big Three auto makers. In recent years, General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler have been consolidating their supply operations, buying more from larger and larger suppliers and scaling back contracts with small suppliers. In the process, the car companies and several minority suppliers say that unless minority suppliers grow, they will soon be shut out of the industry.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Railroad May Enter Telecommunications

BYLINE: Bloomberg 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 11

 BODY:
The Norfolk Southern Corporation, the fourth-largest United States railroad, is forming a unit to lease its telecommunications system to phone, Internet and cable service providers and may eventually enter that business.
The railroad's new Thoroughbred Technology and Telecommunications Inc. unit is negotiating with long-distance and local telephone companies and cable providers to lease the rights of way along its 21,600 miles of railroad tracks for cables as well as its microwave network and other assets. 
 "We have one of the largest private telecommunications systems in the world already set up and running and doing a good job of serving our needs, with plenty of capacity to handle others," said Bob Fort, spokesman for the railroad, based in Norfolk, Va.
Cable-based Internet providers are expected to have 13.6 million subscribers by 2002, up from 700,000 last year, according to Forrester Research.
Norfolk Southern stock fell 31.25 cents, to $22.1875.

HEADLINE: U.S. Study Finds Lack of Control In U.N. Food Aid to North Korea

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
A report prepared for Congress by the General Accounting Office in Washington has found that the United Nations World Food Program is not able to monitor adequately what happens to food aid donated by the United States to North Korea.
"U.S. policy is that no food aid will be provided to North Korea if it cannot be adequately monitored," the report, to the House Committee on International Relations, said. The report, issued last week, contends that the World Food Program itself estimates that 90 percent of North Korean institutions that receive food aid, including hospitals, orphanages and schools, have not been visited and says its own monitors had "rarely been allowed to observe the actual distribution of food to beneficiaries." 
 A renewed debate over whether food donations, most of which are from the United States, are siphoned off by officials or the military in the world's most isolated and totalitarian nation occurs as Congress begins hearings on the Clinton Administration policy of easing some sanctions against North Korea in the hopes of deterring its nuclear and missile programs. The policy has met strong Republican criticism.
Malnutrition and starvation have been a cause for concern in North Korea for more than five years, as the effects of the country's complete economic collapse have been worsened by floods and other disasters. Experts disagree on the death toll from the years of famine, but estimates range from 500,000 to two million or more. North Korea has 24 million people, and most famine victims were the youngest and oldest citizens, international experts say.
A spokesman for the World Food Program, Trevor Rowe, said in an interview from Washington that "for us, there is nothing new in this report." He said there had always been questions about access to North Korean people and institutions. The G.A.O. team was itself denied visas.
Mr. Rowe said access for his program had in fact expanded considerably in North Korea in recent years.

HEADLINE: Humanitarian Aid in Serbia

 BODY:
European foreign ministers yesterday approved the shipment of heating oil to two cities in Serbia controlled by the opposition to Slobodan Milosevic. While the Clinton Administration is concerned that the fuel might indirectly help the Milosevic regime, the planned shipments actually do not go far enough. Heat is a basic humanitarian necessity during the cold Balkan winters, and should go to all Serbs who need it.
Since the war in Kosovo ended in June, Washington and European nations have struggled with how to provide humanitarian aid to Serbia without helping to prop up Mr. Milosevic. The West's obligations are particularly hard to sort out because Serbia's infrastructure and economy have been crippled not only by NATO bombing, but by years of Mr. Milosevic's ruinous policies. 
 The Clinton Administration is concerned that European nations will seek to provide aid on such a broad scale that it could end up benefiting the Serbian regime. The fear is legitimate, as many nations in Europe have been relaxed about aid and trade with Mr. Milosevic. Washington is right to oppose anything beyond humanitarian aid until Mr. Milosevic is out of power. There should be no restoration of air links to Belgrade, shipments of gasoline or help to rebuild bridges and buildings.
The European Union has approved a very limited plan -- a small shipment of heating oil to two cities, Nis and Pirot, with opposition governments. If it is properly used -- not hijacked by the central Government or sold by corrupt officials -- the E.U. would then begin sending fuel oil and perhaps other forms of humanitarian aid to opposition-controlled areas elsewhere in Serbia.
Help for Nis and Pirot could, in fact, damage Mr. Milosevic because it would send a message to Serbs that the opposition can deliver a higher standard of living than their leader can. Such aid will also help people realize that sanctions are targeting Mr. Milosevic, not ordinary Serbs. But if the aid program expands beyond humanitarian goals to anything not necessary for saving lives, the aid must be sent only to the opposition areas and in well-designed programs, or wait until Serbia is a democratic nation.

HEADLINE: Princeton Considers Abolishing the A-Plus

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11

 BODY:
Princeton University officials want to do away with the A-plus grade, saying they are concerned that high marks have become commonplace.
A faculty committee has proposed that A-plus be replaced by a grade called "A with distinction," for truly outstanding work. 
 The "A with distinction" would be worth 4.0 grade points, the same as an A, instead of the 4.3 points that an A-plus is worth. In addition, faculty members would have to file written explanations with each "A with distinction" they give.
One idea is to assign a different symbol to the A, like an asterisk.
"The problem we've got with A-pluses is that there's too many of them to suggest that the students getting them are really doing exceptional work," said Justin Harmon, a university spokesman. "And they're not evenly distributed across the subjects. It's easier to get an A-plus in science and engineering than it is in the humanities. We want a common standard, and we want it to mean something."
The grade recommendation, which awaits a decision by the university's faculty members, was suggested last week by an eight-member faculty committee that was asked to come up with possible solutions to the problem of grade inflation, in which too many students get A's and B's.
If approved, the change would take effect for the 4,500 undergraduates in the 2000-2001 academic year.
The committee was formed in 1998 after a study of grading patterns from 1973 to 1997 showed a trend toward a growing number of A's and B's and fewer C's and D's.
Though the College Board scores of incoming Princeton freshmen are on the rise, the study said the grade inflation was due more to lenient professors and students who badger them for higher marks.
But some students say they worry that the change, while well-intended, could make them look bad to graduate schools or potential employers by reducing their grade point averages.
"I'm not sure if it will accomplish all they say," said Robbie Adler, 20, of Scottsdale, Ariz., a junior electrical engineering major.
Students are being asked for their opinions on the proposal, but ultimately the decision will be the faculty's, Mr. Harmon said.
Princeton officials said several prestigious universities do not use A-plus, including Brown, Dartmouth, Harvard and Yale. But Columbia, Cornell, Stanford and the University of Pennsylvania use A-plus.
In a report on the Princeton proposal, the dean of the college, Nancy Weiss Malkiel, said: "Such a change would preserve the capacity of the faculty to recognize truly outstanding work, while not disadvantaging students in the contest for academic honors, awards and prizes which depend significantly on grade point averages."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Giant Banks Will Face New Regulations

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told bankers today that regulators were considering ways to deal with the huge banks being formed by mergers and the possible harm to the economy should the institutions fail.
Mr. Greenspan said "significant changes are in the pipeline" in banking supervision by domestic and foreign regulators. 
 The changes point to a "multitrack approach" to oversight of banks, since the institutions vary significantly in size, business strategy and penchant for risk, he said.
"Even among the largest banks, no two institutions have exactly the same risk profiles, risk controls or organizational and management structure," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to the American Bankers Association's annual convention, held this year in Phoenix. Copies of his speech to the association, the banking industry's biggest trade group, were released in Washington.
Because banks vary so widely, he said, Government oversight needs to be "customized for each financial institution: the more complex an institution's business activities, the more sophisticated must be our approach to prudential oversight."
Mr. Greenspan said that such flexibility is especially needed in the case of "megabanks" resulting from mergers that, he said, "create the potential for unusually large systemic risks in the national and international economy should they fail."
Regulators like the Fed must walk a line between exercising adequate oversight of big banks and regulating them excessively in a way that smothers innovation and competition, he suggested.
"Such a heavier hand would also blunt the ability of U.S. banks to respond to crisis events," Mr. Greenspan said. "Increased government regulation is inconsistent with a banking system that can respond to the kinds of changes that have characterized recent years."
An outline of the changes being considered by United States and foreign regulators was released for public comment in June by an international group of bank supervisors based in Basel, Switzerland.
But Jim McLaughlin, director of regulatory affairs for the bankers' group, said that Mr. Greenspan's speech put the issue in clearer perspective.
Mr. McLaughlin also said that American bankers support Mr. Greenspan's push to have Federal regulators consult with the industry on developing new standards for banks to disclose details of their assets.
Big bank mergers have been occurring at a rapid pace, with recent multibillion-dollar consolidations including the combination of Citicorp and Travelers Group; NationsBank with BankAmerica, and Banc One with First Chicago.
Critics, including consumer advocates like Ralph Nader and some lawmakers, have said that the mergers have raised the likelihood of future taxpayer bailouts for big financial institutions that fail.
Beyond responding to the rise of huge banks, Mr. Greenspan said, "few changes" are needed to the current system of regulation for the vast majority of banks.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russian Court Ruling Is New Blow to Foreign Investment

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Russia's shaky foreign-investment reputation weakened further today when a court in St. Petersburg ruled that the 255-year-old Lomonosov porcelain factory be renationalized, annulling a majority stake held by executives of a prominent Wall Street buyout firm and an American-financed investment fund.
Alistair Stobie, vice president of the $440 million United States-Russia Investment Fund, said it planned to appeal the ruling that voided the ownership interests of his organization and those of executives in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. 
 The court's decision on a case brought by the Russian Ministry of State Property against the porcelain factory is the latest in a series of disputes over the last year that have eroded foreigners' investments in Russian companies.
The Dart Group, for example, is struggling to prevent a share issue by the Russian oil conglomerate Yukos that would dilute Dart's stake in a Yukos subsidiary. BP Amoco P.L.C. is trying to save a half-billion-dollar investment in a Russian oil company, Sidanko, which is now bankrupt.
These and other smaller deals gone awry have supported the widely held view abroad that Russia's market is a volatile one unworthy of significant investment because most major Russian companies, and perhaps even the Government itself, flout shareholder rights. "We work with start-ups who understand the importance of sound corporate governance," Mr. Stobie said. "But 90 percent of the factories that existed under the Soviets still don't understand it. They think an equity investment is a no-interest loan."
The fund was capitalized by Congress in the early 1990's to encourage direct investment in the Russian economy, and so far, it has invested about $240 million. The fund has spent about $4.25 million since September 1998 to buy slightly more than 25 percent of the Lomonosov plant.
The Kohlberg Kravis executives, through a holding company called the International Porcelain Company, invested about $4 million of their money and acquired a similar holding. The rest of Lomonosov is owned by current and retired employees and by two offshore companies.
The factory, Russia's oldest and most famous porcelain works, was purveyor to the imperial court and, in modern times, the maker of china praising the achievements of the Soviet state. During its heyday, Lomonosov was regarded highly enough that museums all over the world carried its porcelain sets. "We invested because of the brand name," Mr. Stobie said. "There are very few high-quality porcelain brands in the world, and this is one of them."
Under the Soviets, however, and recent ragged years of reform, the quality of Lomonosov china had steadily declined, Mr. Stobie said, and the factory today is unprofitable. The investment fund had planned to invest in new equipment, he said, to improve the quality of the porcelain being turned out.
But since their initial investment late in 1998, the fund and the International Porcelain Company have had severely limited access to the plant and its books, mainly, they say, because of a hostile management that like many from the Soviet era views outsiders as a threat.
Then, in June, the Ministry of State Property filed suit against the Lomonosov plant to annul the privatization, based on what it called an error in the factory's original incorporation in 1993. Fund officials have said they suspect the suit was initiated at the request of Lomonosov management to fend off the foreign investors. Officials at Lomonosov and the property ministry could not be reached for comment tonight.
According to Mr. Stobie, the three judges hearing the case deliberated for 15 minutes before repealing the privatization.

HEADLINE: Cuts in Commissions Sting Travel Agents

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Three more airlines cut travel agent commissions to 5 percent from 8 percent yesterday, making the latest reduction in commissions all but a fait accompli for most of the industry.
The cuts by Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, following the lead last week of United Airlines and American Airlines, left agents shaken. "It's going to be devastating for lots and lots of travel agencies," said Mary Berry Murphy, the owner of Berry World Travel in Omaha, echoing a widespread concern among agents. 
 The airlines' success with electronic ticketing and Internet booking capability has periodically emboldened them to reduce commissions, but most travel agents have demonstrated surprisingly strong survival skills. For one thing, 49 percent of travel agencies now have World Wide Web sites of their own, compared with 37 percent last year, according to the American Society of Travel Agents, and 76 percent of the trade group's members have access to rates on the Internet, up from 61 percent a year ago.
"Clearly, these figures show that travel agents are using the Internet to get the best deals for their clients," said James Ashurst, a spokesman for the trade group.
Studies also suggest that many people who surf the Internet for deals then turn to travel agents to make the bookings. For example, a study this summer by NPD Online Research, which tracks consumer purchasing and behavior, found that while more individuals are booking travel on line, "56 percent of on-line travelers reported having completed travel reservations with a traditional travel agent after visiting a travel-related Web site."
The reason, NPD found, was "the need for human contact and assurances that reservations are correct."
Thus, Joe Galloway, the society's president, said, "Despite the doomsday forecasts by many industry 'experts,' the Internet is not carving away at travel agency profitability -- in fact, the exact opposite is occurring."
Still, it is likely that some of the almost 1,800 retail travel locations that went out of business in the first seven months of this year did so at least in part because of the drop in revenue from lower commissions.
In addition to lowering the rate, United, a unit of the UAL Corporation; American, owned by the AMR Corporation; Delta; Northwest and KLM -- like most of the industry -- have a $50 maximum commission on round-trip domestic tickets and $100 on round-trip international tickets.
"We recently wrote a $3,000 ticket for a corporate client who likes to travel first class," said Joy Wittmann, the owner of the Joy In Travel agency in Metairie, La. "A few years ago we would have made at least $300 on that ticket. Now it's $100."
Consequently, travel agents have turned to other sources of income -- in particular cruises, which, with commissions averaging about 15 percent, are the second-biggest source of agent revenue and the fastest growing.
In addition, many travel agencies now charge fees averaging $10 to $15 for writing or rewriting tickets, booking hotels or rental cars and processing refunds. Already 75 percent of agencies charge fees, compared with 64 percent in 1998.
Mrs. Murphy's agency, for example, charges $10 fees and has managed to reduce its reliance on the sale of airline tickets from 90 percent of the business to about 55 percent. To pick up the slack, she sells more cruises and tours.
Even with fees, a recent survey of 450 travel agencies found that 90 percent of agencies that charge them say they have retained at least 81 percent of their clients; three-quarters say they hung on to at least 91 percent.
Still, many travel agents say that the combination of commission cuts and direct on-line bookings have cut into their revenue and profits -- and would have cut even deeper if the strong economy of the last nine years had not emboldened people to keep traveling.
Mrs. Murphy said she had been aided by participating with about 375 other Midwestern travel agencies in a consortium. The group's collective strength helps independent agencies receive favorable rates on business items like computer rentals and marketing programs.
The airlines hope to reduce their costs by cutting commissions. United, for example, said that its commission cut is expected to save about $150 million a year.
American and Delta are not saying how much they expect to save. Indeed, the releases announcing the cuts said that the carriers would not offer any public comment about them.
