HEADLINE: Hudson Towns Wary of Rail's Reach;
Commuter Line Extension Faces Hostility in Bucolic North Dutchess

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

DATELINE: TIVOLI, N.Y.

 BODY:
With its luminous views of the Hudson River and the Catskill Mountains beyond, the terrain surrounding this Dutchess County hamlet helped inspire the Hudson River School of painting, which for more than a century helped define the American wilderness.
Now a proposed extension of the Metro-North Railroad's Hudson commuter line is leading people here and in nearby towns to define something else: how much they value the virtues of isolation and repose and how much they want the economic benefits that would come from better access to New York City, 100 miles downstream. 
 Since last year, Metro-North has been exploring the feasibility of extending service from its current northern terminus at Poughkeepsie to a station near the border of Dutchess and Columbia Counties.
The preliminary proposal includes constructing three new platforms and parking areas, and possibly a rail yard and remote commuter parking lots. Such an expansion would extend commuter service 25 miles north, linking Tivoli, Staatsburg and Hyde Park to Grand Central Terminal. It would also provide Metro-North service to Rhinecliff, several miles south of Tivoli, which is now served by Amtrak trains that go to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.
The proposal has been met with intense official resistance. Even as the railroad examines its options, public officials are warning of an unwise trade: convenience to Manhattan in exchange for new residents, developers and, eventually, the intrusion of suburbia and sprawl.
"Bringing Metro-North in here would probably make the real estate market go through the roof," said Thomas L. Cordier, Tivoli's deputy mayor. "But it would throw the quality of life out the window."
Energized by these and similar concerns, seven Dutchess County communities have passed resolutions since August opposing expansion of Metro-North's commuter lines, or even the railroad's study of the issue. The communities are the towns of Rhinebeck, Red Hook, Milan, Stanford and Clinton, as well as the villages of Rhinebeck and Tivoli. Officials say they are merely formally stating the overwhelming sentiment of their constituents.
Opposition is not unanimous, however, and measured support comes from potential foes. In Hyde Park, a town with more traffic lights and strip malls than its neighbors to the north, local attitude "has been more of a wait-and-see mode," said Town Supervisor Thomas M. Spence. "I personally am very interested in what the M.T.A. study shows."
But resistance is easy to find in Tivoli, population 1,024. This river hamlet is not quite the wilderness outpost it was in the 19th century, when the painters Thomas Cole and Frederic E. Church captured the valley's forest-draped slopes and airy vistas with oil and canvas. But modern times have treated the area gently, and Tivoli still sits in a region of solitude and soft light. Tourists find only one stop sign on Broadway, its main street, and no gas station or franchise stores. The idea of commuter service has villagers alarmed.
"I'm totally against it," said Marilyn Rivera, who moved to Tivoli from Inwood, in upper Manhattan, in June. Ms. Rivera, a social worker, commutes to the East Village, usually by bus from Kingston, at least once each week. While a railroad extension would simplify her trips, she fears it would also bring in rush-hour traffic and noise. "One of the reasons we moved here is that it is a quiet little town," she said.
Ms. Rivera's husband, Leslie D. Gabriel, took care to emphasize that local opposition was not an upstate-downstate tiff. "This is not an anti-New York City frame of mind," he said. "I love New York. I lived there most of my life.
"But if you start bringing in all of this transportation infrastructure, you're going to have everything in the Hudson Valley looking like one huge strip mall. You go down that slippery slope of ruining an awesome piece of planet."
As Mr. Gabriel points out, Tivoli and the communities that extend south to Poughkeepsie are in a geographic belt where it is difficult to commute either to Albany, which is 45 miles north of Tivoli and on the other side of the Hudson River, or to Manhattan. A common feeling is that this isolation is a fortunate circumstance, because the local way of life is fine as it is.
"It's not an easy commute by any means, and maybe that's been our saving grace," said Gary DiMauro, who owns a real estate firm in Tivoli. "If we eliminate that, we eliminate the very thing that is attractive about this area."
The trip from Grand Central to Poughkeepsie is 74 miles by train, and takes roughly an hour and 45 minutes on Metro-North. The peak fare costs $26 round-trip. Commuters also have the option of riding round-trip on Amtrak between Penn Station and Rhinecliff, for $46, on trains whose cars have reclining seats, snacks and electrical outlets for laptop computers. Most of the Dutchess communities' resolutions say that their residents are satisfied with just Amtrak service.
But Metro-North says its study, which will cost $3 million, is necessary because the northern section of its Hudson Line is the fastest growing on the railroad, with ridership having climbed from 1.37 million fares in 1984 to 3.6 million fares projected this year. Moreover, Dutchess County's population is projected to climb to 314,000 in 2020, from 259,000 in 1990, a 21 percent increase.
The railroad expects to issue a report next year on the ways existing track -- owned by Amtrak -- that passes through Hyde Park and Staatsburg might be put to wider use. Still, it insists it has no firm plans, and has not decided precisely where to put any new stations. "The main thing to know is that it's a study -- it's only a study," said Marjorie Anders, a Metro-North spokeswoman.
Ms. Anders said that any recommendations that Metro-North makes must be approved by the Poughkeepsie-Dutchess County Transportation Council, a regional transit planning agency, and then by the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The project would also require state and Federal money, and the M.T.A.'s proposed five-year capital budget, released in late September, showed no money for the project through 2004.
Given these facts, the degree and scope of the official resistance is striking. In Red Hook, Town Manager John J. Gilfeather said Metro-North was caught off guard by "the negativism they got."
In Rhinebeck, Town Supervisor William W. Dowden voiced long-range concerns. "If you go back and do the reading, Yonkers used to be the outskirts of the metropolitan area, then Tarrytown, Ossining, Croton-on-Hudson, and on up," Mr. Dowden said. "Now they all blend together. In 20 or 25 years, it may not be impossible to see sprawl all the way to Rhinebeck."
Although this feeling is widespread, some see the transportation authority's study as a useful planning tool. For instance, Scenic Hudson Inc., a nonprofit environmental organization based in Poughkeepsie, has withheld judgment. "We think good transit also means good land-use policies, and a recognition that not all transit projects are appropriate," Deborah Meyer DeWan, a director of the organization, said. "Having said that, we welcome a study that will really evaluate the possibilities for transportation alternatives, but in the context of managing future growth."
And some residents' opinions are clearly at odds with those of their elected officials. Benjamin T. Deford, a musician, said he would welcome local growth and the access to Manhattan that a rail extension would provide.
"A lot of my friends and I would like to commercialize the place to where we could make a real living, and not have to live in the dog-eat-dog of the city," he said.
The dueling sentiments were played out in a good-natured argument between Laura D. Ciancanelli, a painter, and Michael Gonnella, a baker. Sitting in the Santa Fe Mexican restaurant, Ms. Ciancanelli spoke of the destruction of the area's quiet character she feels a rail expansion would mean. Mr. Gonnella merely chuckled. "More people who come and eat and spend money in the restaurants and bars? More people who keep the town alive?" he said. "That's a terrible thing."
Then he grew serious. "A train is a conveyor belt that carries people with disposable income to this town," he said. "Who can be against that?"
Down Broadway, in the village offices, Deputy Mayor Cordier's opinion was firm. He said he would rather use the public money and energy that would go into extending rail service to instead revive Tivoli's waterfront with a park and pier, a project with an eye to the old days, when the town was served by a ferry that plied the Hudson, and the river's platinum light inspired painters to romanticize the entire valley.
"It's a decision the community has to make," Mr. Cordier said. "But I think we've spoken -- loud and clear."

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA TO SET LEVEL OF STAFFING FOR NURSING CARE

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Over the objections of the state's health care industry, Gov. Gray Davis has signed a bill that will make California the first state to require hospitals to meet fixed nurse-to-patient ratios, in an effort to force higher quality care and combat cost-cutting measures in the place where managed care was born.
Mr. Davis signed the new law, backed by the state nurses' union, over the weekend as part of a last batch of bills from this year's legislative session. The session also produced a package of measures that the Democratic Governor signed last month, expanding patients' access to mental health care and their rights to sue their health insurers for punitive damages and seek outside reviews of decisions denying coverage. 
 Heath care has been a major political issue in California, given the prominence of health maintenance organizations and for-profit hospitals here. And the hospital industry and business groups had lobbied hard against the nurses staffing bill. Mr. Davis's Republican predecessor, former Gov. Pete Wilson, vetoed a similar measure two years ago.
At times this year, Mr. Davis himself has complained that the Legislature was sending him too many bills on health care, and he has generally taken a cautious approach to this and other issues since his election last year. Even as he signed the nurses staffing bill, he vetoed another measure intended to overhaul the state's nursing home system, saying it was too costly.
The new bill on nurse staffing levels -- which covers all "licensed nurses," including both registered and licensed practical nurses -- does not specify minimum nurse-to-patient ratios, but instead requires the State Department of Health Services to set such standards for general, psychiatric and special hospitals. To secure Mr. Davis's support, the measure's sponsor, Assemblywoman Sheila James Kuehl, Democrat of Santa Monica, agreed to sponsor a follow-up bill next year, delaying the implementation by at least a year, until 2002, to allow the state time to work out the desired ratios.
Nurse staffing has been a hot-button issue among health care consumers nationwide in recent years as hospitals have sought to save money by laying off registered nurses and consolidating a range of typical nursing functions in the hands of less-qualified aides. Ms. Kuehl first sponsored the bill at the urging of the nurses' union two years ago, and it passed the Legislature but was vetoed.
"This is one of the most significant days in the history of nursing," Kay McVay, the president of the California Nurses Association, said after Mr. Davis signed the bill.
The measure will also bar hospitals from assigning unlicensed workers to perform certain medical procedures, including administering drugs and assessing a patient's condition, and it will prohibit hospitals from shifting nurses trained in one unit to duty in another without adequate preparation.
The state's health care industry had opposed the measure on the grounds that it would impose overly specific requirements on hospitals and increase costs.
"Hospitals are being put under tremendous pressure to lower costs by the managed care companies, which are under pressure from the government and employers, and ultimately, the public," said Walter Zelman, president of the California Association of Health Plans, which represents H.M.O.'s statewide. "If they can avoid it, they would prefer not to have the government mandate a certain rigid standard. Not that the government is always wrong, but rigidity is rigidity. It's easier for the industry to function if it has to meet outcome goals, rather than specific means of achieving them."
But Rose Ann DeMaro, executive director of the California Nurses Association, which represents 200,000 nurses, said the new rules were necessary to address severe gaps in care resulting from cutbacks in nursing staffs and the fact that hospital patients in general are sicker than in the past, because H.M.O.'s resist putting patients in the hospital if they can avoid it, to save money.
A new research report commissioned by the nurses' union, analyzing 18.2 million patient discharge records and other data from 1994 through 1997, found a nearly 9 percent increase in the average number of patients for which each full-time registered nurse was responsible. The ratio rose from one nurse for every 56.87 patients to one for every 62.33. At the same time, patient acuity levels, which measure the severity of illness of patients at the point of discharge from the hospital, increased by more than 3 percent for the categories of "major acuity" and "extreme acuity."
"There has been significant downsizing in the nursing staff of virtually every private hospital in the state," Ms. Kuehl said. "And because of managed care, patients are much more seriously ill before they're even checked in. The dreadful result of the intersection of these two things is that nurses were caring for more and sicker patients."
California regulations require hospitals to assess the illness of patients for every shift, on every floor in every hospital, and then set nurse staffing levels accordingly, Ms. Kuehl said. But she said that made it effectively impossible for the state to enforce any uniform standard.
Allan Zaremberg, president of the California Chamber of Commerce, said it had opposed the bill "because we thought it would add to health care costs and be costly to the overall economy." But he expressed relief that Mr. Davis had gone out of his way to find a flexible approach that would not unduly increase costs or require nurses to perform tasks that could be done by others. He also expressed satisfaction that the bill was the only one among those that the chamber had most opposed that Mr. Davis had not vetoed.
By contrast, consumer groups and the American Association of Retired Persons expressed dismay that Mr. Davis vetoed the nursing home measure, which would have gradually increased the training, number and pay of certified nurse assistants, and doubled fines for violating state nursing home law to a maximum of $50,000 for a patient's death.
In his veto message, Mr. Davis said the bill contained "many well-intentioned, commendable features," but placed too great a burden on the state budget, with a five-year cost of more than $500 million. He noted that he had already supported including $72 million in the budget passed this summer to increase the minimum nursing home staff-to-patient ratio and provide a wage increase to patient-care staff.
"Let's let that happen first," said the Governor's press secretary, Michael Bustamante. "Let's let those positions be filled and then let's take a look at what's going on. This bill would have cost taxpayers a half a billion dollars. And the Governor has made clear throughout this entire year that he is hard-pressed to spend money today that we may not have tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Highflying Generic Drug Stocks Now SharplyLower

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
A year ago, the chief executives of the nation's largest generic drug makers seemed almost giddy.
Generic versions of popular drugs were coming to market with ease, and investors clamored for shares of the tiny companies. The stocks of two prominent ones, Watson Pharmaceuticals, best known for its estrogen-replacement therapies, and Forest Laboratories, a maker of the antidepressant Celexa, each roughly doubled in value in 1998. 
 But the group has had a rapid descent recently. A raft of legal troubles from lawsuits to inquiries by the Federal Government have scared away investors, while the number of drug introductions has stalled.
Though the Standard & Poor's Drug index has slipped 6 percent this year, the stocks of the generic companies have in some cases lost a third or half of their value.
The chief executives are hard pressed to explain the sudden reversals of fortunes. "Not a lot of drugs have come off patent this year," said Fred Wilkinson, chief operating officer of Watson Pharmaceuticals. "Everybody is just hunkering down. But within the next two years, more drugs will come off patent. That may change the business cycle."
William A. Fletcher, chief executive of Teva Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., one of the largest makers of generic drugs, said, "Everybody is suffering from a lot of lawsuits."
After Mylan Laboratories struck exclusive deals last year with suppliers of raw materials necessary to make two anti-anxiety drugs, the Federal Trade Commission accused the company of trying to monopolize the market. The company asked a Federal court to dismiss the case but got nowhere. Analysts now worry that Mylan's mounting legal bills could dent the company's earnings.
Other generic makers face some serious court challenges over the deals they have made with the drug giants. At issue is the practice of accepting a payment from a branded drug company to delay the introduction of a competing generic or to avoid patent litigation.
People with knowledge of its investigations say the F.T.C. is considering filing a complaint against Hoechst Marion Roussel and the Andrx Corporation, a maker of specialty pharmaceuticals and generic drugs, over a deal they made to delay a generic version of Hoechst's Cardizem CD, a treatment for high blood pressure, from entering the market.
The commission is investigating similar agreements between Zeneca Pharmaceuticals, part of the giant Astra-Zeneca global drug concern, and Barr Laboratories, a generic company, over the breast cancer drug tamoxifen, and between Eli Lilly & Company and Sepracor, a specialty pharmaceuticals company, to develop an improved version of Prozac, according to people close to the investigation.
"Certainly, Mylan's case with the F.T.C. has put the company's shares under pressure," said David Saks, a managing director of Gruntal & Company. "But I don't think the F.T.C. investigations will change anything. This may be more for a warning."
Shares of Mylan Pharmaceuticals are off 41 percent this year, closing yesterday at $18.50. For the quarter ended in June, Mylan's earnings fell 6 percent from a year earlier, and analysts have forecast a slide of more than 6 percent in the next quarterly report.
Since the F.T.C.'s investigation of Andrx was disclosed late last month, the company's stock has tumbled 23 percent, to $46.0625, well off its $78 high in June. Even the stock of Watson Pharmaceuticals, which has not been reported to be the subject of an F.T.C. investigation, fell 54 percent this year, to $28.9375.
Litigation has long been a cornerstone of the generic industry. To get a generic drug to market, companies must sometimes fend off a patent infringement suit.
Such courtroom quarrels sometimes amount to David vs. Goliath battles. Andrx has been sued by Glaxo Wellcome and Hoechst, among others. Andrx had $8 million in earnings last year; Glaxo, $1.8 billion.
Mr. Fletcher and Mr. Wilkinson complained in recent interviews that their annual legal expenses had swelled to about $4 million each. For Watson, that amounts to a 200 percent increase from two years ago.
With litigation fears depressing the stocks, some stock pickers now consider them undervalued. Analysts expect Andrx earnings, for example, to jump 221 percent from the period a year earlier, to 45 cents a share in the third quarter.
At the least, generic drug companies point to a better pipeline of new products. Drugs worth some $13 billion in sales over the next three years are coming off patent in that period. Last year, drugs with just $1.4 billion in sales came off patent, virtually the same as is expected this year, according to Gruntal & Company. The generic drug companies will record a combined $9 billion in sales this year, up 9 percent from last year, by Gruntal's estimates.
Some expect the F.T.C. investigation to eliminate exclusivity deals and ultimately open the market wider for more generics. Even if it does, it will crimp some companies' revenues along the way.
Andrx, for example, was to receive $100 million a year from Hoechst to keep its generic version of Cardizem CD off the market. The deal was scrapped in June, but only after Andrx had earned most of that amount, when the companies settled their patent dispute.
A wider open market could put more pressure on the generic companies to continue merging in hopes of better economies of scale.
"When it comes to drug volume, the generic makers are going to do quite well," said Sergio Traversa, a pharmaceutical analyst at Mehta Partners. "But there is so much competition within the generic industry, that it is always going to be difficult to make money."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Officials Accuse Port Authority of Skirting Law

 BODY:
Elected officials in New Jersey yesterday denounced a land deal between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and Continental Airlines as an attempt to circumvent local authority to redevelop an industrial area in Elizabeth.
The deal calls for creation of a 2,000-space parking lot for Continental employees on 177 acres next to the Jersey Gardens Mall and a proposed office complex in a redevelopment area that was once the site of a landfill, said Michael J. Lapolla, the Union County Manager. 
 Continental bought the land recently for $17 million from the Allied Signal Corporation, and will lease it to the Port Authority, making it exempt from local development oversight.
Mr. Lapolla said a vast parking lot would conflict with plans to remake the area as a retail and office center.
"This is just such a bad use for the site," he said.
The elected officials are angered by what they say is an attempt by the powerful bistate agency and the big airline to skirt state law that allows municipalities to impose wide-ranging redevelopment plans on blighted areas. Under the law, Mr. Lapolla said, mayors have the authority to designate developers of sites within redevelopment areas on the basis of their proposals and to condemn private property if necessary to insure the preferred plan is carried out.
As private property, the site would ordinarily be subject to condemnation by the Mayor of Elizabeth, J. Christian Bollwage, if Continental refused to develop it as the city would like.
But property owned or leased by the Port Authority is exempt from such condemnation, and Mr. Lapolla said the five-year deal in which the Port Authority would lease the property from Continental and operate it as a parking lot for the airline's employees was intended to circumvent the law. The agency also has an option to buy the property.
"It's a sham deal," Mr. Lapolla said.
Mr. Lapolla also said the agency's executive director, Robert E. Boyle, had improperly entered into the lease this month without the Port Authority board's approval. The Union County Board of Freeholders yesterday called for Mr. Boyle's dismissal and said it would sue the agency.
Mayor Bollwage joined United States Representatives Robert Menendez and Donald Payne, who both represent parts of Elizabeth, in calling for a Federal audit of the deal. United States Senator Robert G. Torricelli sent a letter dated Oct. 8 to Mr. Boyle questioning the fairness of the situation. The State Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, wrote to Lewis M. Eisenberg, the Port Authority chairman, seeking a special board meeting "to reverse and rescind the action of the executive director."
A spokesman for the agency declined to talk about the deal other than to provide a statement that the agency believed that it was important to the economic development of the region. The agency later issued a statement, attributed to its general counsel, Hugh Welsch, asserting that Mr. Boyle had acted within his authority.
Michelle Treacy, a spokeswoman for Continental, declined to comment.
The dispute is the latest in a longstanding feud pairing the city of Elizabeth and Union County against the bistate agency, which owns large tracts of city land occupied by Newark Airport and the Elizabeth shipping terminal. However, the agency is exempt from standard property taxation, and Mr. Lapolla said Elizabeth received just $67,000 last year in payments in lieu of taxes on 2,000 acres of property.

HEADLINE: Montredon Journal;
French See a Hero in War on 'McDomination'

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: MONTREDON, France

 BODY:
At home here in his 500-year-old stone farmhouse, Jose Bove seems pretty relaxed for someone out on $17,000 bail.
He moves around in his slippers and turns off his cell phone so he can answer questions without being interrupted. His antique dining-room table is covered with stacks of paper, mostly faxes and printouts from Internet sites. Outside his windows, tucked among the trees, are the other five houses of this village and, beyond them, hundreds of Mr. Bove's sheep leisurely picking over the grass. 
 Since he was arrested in August on charges of vandalizing a nearby McDonald's restaurant under construction -- though his principal complaint is about American tariffs on luxury food -- this wiry, 46-year-old union leader and sheep farmer has become something of a national hero.
Hardly a day goes by that French newspapers fail to mention Mr. Bove, lauding him for his refusal to bow to globalization, publishing photographs of him with his hands clenched above his head and his wrists cuffed, and suggesting that he may be the only man left in France willing to go to jail for the republic.
He has been praised by France's highest officials, including President Jacques Chirac, who has declared that he, too, detests McDonald's food. Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has also weighed in, comparing Mr. Bove with other noted leaders who have emerged from grass-roots movements in recent years.
Mr. Bove, who lives in Larzac, an area of southwest France that is one of the country's best-known gastronomic regions, organized the destruction of the McDonald's in nearby Millau -- using tractors to tear down half the roof -- to highlight what he sees as the unfairness of the United States's decision to levy high tariffs on Roquefort cheese, pate de foie gras and other luxury imported food. Washington acted in retaliation for the European Union's decision to ban America's hormone-treated beef. He attacked McDonald's because it was a symbol of industrialized agriculture, "where quality doesn't matter anymore," he said.
"There have been three totalitarian forces in our lifetime," said Mr. Bove, who supplies sheep's milk to makers of Roquefort cheese. "The totalitarianism of fascism, of communism and now of capitalism. How can people try and tell us that we must import hormone-enhanced beef? What is that?"
Mr. Bove hardly looks militant. His eyes twinkle over his handlebar mustache when he is asked about all the attention he is getting. "There was some luck in it," he confides. "The judge threw me into jail. People didn't like that."
But some say Mr. Bove's crusade -- only the most conspicuous of a rash of protests against McDonald's -- has tapped into far larger issues gnawing at the French lately, including a general annoyance with the power of the American economy and a nostalgia for a way of life, including long lunches, that is disappearing yet still held in high regard. Every year, new McDonald's franchises open and flourish in France.
However, few people admit to indulging in those quarter-pounders. Spotted under the Golden Arches, the French "often behave as if they just got caught leaving an X-rated movie," said Jean-Pierre Poulain, a sociologist at the University of Toulouse recently quoted in the newspaper Le Monde.
Having recovered from Mr. Bove's attack, the Millau McDonald's was doing brisk business the other day. "I come here only once in a great while," said one customer, Laurent Jeniez, who was getting into his car alone. "I do it only with my children," he added, though none could be seen.
Yet Millau is awash in pro-Bove graffiti. "End McDomination" and "Free Bove" are scrawled on roadside signs, bus shelters and walls.
Mr. Bove himself favors a rhyming slogan that uses the French nickname for McDonald's: "McDo Dehors, Gardons le Roquefort!" (McDonald's Get Out, Let's Keep the Roquefort!). That is what he painted on the McDonald's construction site on Aug. 12. He considers his actions that day to be rather ordinary. This is, after all, a country where protesting is a national pastime. The development that really shocked Mr. Bove, who heads a farmers' union called the Confederation Paysanne, was being put in jail five days later.
"They never do that," he said. "But there was a young judge and they are independent and they just saw property damage."
Mr. Bove clinched his moment of fame when he initially refused to be freed on bail, even though his supporters had come up with the cash. It was a stand that lasted only three weeks. He smiles when asked about his change of heart. "The conditions in there were really bad," he said. "And the food was inedible. And I said to myself, 'If all these people are trying to help me by raising the money, why should I refuse to come out?' "
Mr. Bove said his actions had been announced in the local paper the day before. "There was nothing menacing about it," he said. "The children were there. There was singing. It had a festival atmosphere."
The owner of the McDonald's, Marc Dehani, sees it a bit differently. He says $120,000 worth of damage was done. But even though Mr. Bove awaits trial on state criminal charges, McDonald's has decided not to take any civil action against him, out of fear of turning him into a martyr. The restaurant chain has lately tried to calm protests by issuing statements pointing out that the franchises in France are owned by the French, employ French workers and almost exclusively sell food grown in France.
In the press, Mr. Bove is often described as the last holdout against creeping American imperialism. But he is eager to say that he likes Americans. His parents were researchers who spent years at the University of California at Berkeley studying diseases that attacked citrus trees. Mr. Bove lived there until he was 7 and still speaks English.
But his contempt for American eating habits is obvious. He offers statistics on the rate of obesity in America -- about three times that of the French -- and disdains Americans for eating all day long. He says America has no right to force its hormone-enhanced food down French throats.
Mr. Bove said he intended to travel to Seattle in November, when the World Trade Organization is expected to meet and consider the tariff issue again. The United States' decision to impose the tax was authorized by the W.T.O.
With four other farmers, Mr. Bove owns about 500 sheep. About half are raised to produce milk for Roquefort cheese. The rest are sold as meat.
Mr. Bove says he has never eaten at McDonald's, not even once. No, he insists, he is not curious. He does, however, like grilled hamburgers with sliced tomatoes and onions.
"And mayonnaise," he added. "But only the homemade kind."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1251 words

HEADLINE: Too Much of a Good Thing? Doctor Challenges Drug Manual

BYLINE: By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
When doctors need information about what dose of medicine to prescribe, they usually consult a fat navy blue book called the Physicians' Desk Reference -- P.D.R. for short -- which is an extensive compilation of data about drugs from their manufacturers.
But now a new report suggests that the doses recommended in the P.D.R. may be too high for many people and may cause adverse reactions, ranging from dizziness and nausea all the way to death. The report, published in a recent issue of the journal Postgraduate Medicine, said many drugs -- including Viagra, Prozac and some medicines used to treat high blood pressure, allergies, insomnia and high cholesterol -- might work just as well in smaller doses, with far less risk of bad reactions. 
 "Side effects drive a lot of people out of treatment that they need," said the author of the article, Dr. Jay S. Cohen, an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of California at San Diego. People with chronic conditions like high blood pressure, headaches and depression often give up trying to treat their illnesses, he said, when they find that the cure is worse than the disease. But if doctors were to individualize dosages for each patient, more people might take their medicine.
The P.D.R., however, is not designed to make personalized prescriptions. Instead, it provides doctors with the dosing information drug manufacturers calculate based on their studies and provide to the Food and Drug Administration. In fact, the P.D.R. entries repeat the packaging information the agency approves for every prescription drug.
Dr. Cohen said he became aware of the problem because he encountered many patients who suffered from side effects even though they had taken what were supposedly the correct doses of medicine. When Dr. Cohen consulted medical journals and textbooks, he discovered studies showing that many patients were helped by smaller than usual amounts of medication. And many of his own patients did better with reduced doses.
He said his findings helped explain a study published last year by other researchers, who reported that drug reactions in hospitals were among the nation's leading causes of death, killing more than 100,000 Americans a year. The deaths that the team studied were not due to medication errors by doctors or patients; they occurred in people taking doses thought to be correct.
But Dr. Cohen thinks many of the patients died because they were taking too much medicine: the "correct" doses were too strong for them. People vary greatly in their sensitivity to drugs, he said, and one person's remedy may be another's overdose. Although weight, age and sex help determine how a dose of medicine will affect someone, it is also possible for two people who are identical in those traits to react quite differently to the same dose of the same drug. Dosing guidelines from drug companies may be right for most people, but too high for "large subsets of patients," Dr. Cohen said.
Dosing guidelines are based on studies conducted by drug companies when they are seeking approval for new products, Dr. Cohen said. For those studies to run efficiently, doses need to be high enough to show as quickly as possible that the drug works. But later, after the drug is approved, far more people take it, sometimes along with other drugs, and individual differences begin to show up. That information does not always make it into the P.D.R., Dr. Cohen said.
Dr. Peter Honig, deputy director of the Office of Postmarketing Risk Assessment at the Food and Drug Administration, said: "We learn a lot about a drug after it's been approved. I think we would agree with that. He makes some good points. Individualized dosing is the way to go. But it's not well taught in medical school."
Dr. David Bates, an associate professor of medicine at the Harvard Medical School, called Dr. Cohen's idea an interesting hypothesis.
"In the elderly, it's clear that you want to start with lower doses," said Dr. Bates, who has written about adverse reactions for medical journals. "In them in particular it's quite clear that you get in trouble if you use a 'one size fits all' dosing, which doctors have tended to do. It may well be for younger people, too, that there's considerable variability in the way drugs are broken down."
Doctors are taught to "start low, go slow," Dr. Bates said, when prescribing medicines for people over 60 or 65, but that the advice may apply to younger patients as well.
Dr. Raymond Woosley, chairman of the department of pharmacology at Georgetown University in Washington, called Dr. Cohen's article "an outstanding paper, and a very important message."
Dr. Woosley named several drugs with recommended doses that he considered too high, including Viagra and the over-the-counter allergy medicine Chlortrimeton. In addition, he said, the AIDS drug AZT was first marketed at doses that turned out to be far too high and that had to be reduced.
Dr. Cohen said doctors might identify some people at risk for reactions by asking patients whether they had ever had an adverse reaction to a drug and whether they considered themselves unusually sensitive to medications or prone to side effects. Having a strong reaction to a little bit of alcohol or caffeine may also be a clue that a patient will be very sensitive to medicines, he said.
Drugs that have caused trouble in the past should be avoided, he said, and people who seem very sensitive to medicines can be started on low doses, which can be gradually increased if necessary. Some pills, but not capsules, can be cut to fine-tune doses.
But Dr. Woosley said that in his experience a bad reaction to one medicine could not be used to predict how a patient would fare with others.
Dr. Cohen cautioned that patients should not begin tinkering with doses of prescription drugs on their own. He said they needed to work with doctors to adjust the doses safely. With some drugs, doses cannot be changed; for example, antibiotics, antivirals and other medications used to treat infections must be taken full strength, according to the directions on the label. And in emergencies, he said, it is always safest to stick with the recommended doses.
A spokesman for Medical Economics Inc., publisher of the P.D.R., said that the information in the book was supplied by drug manufacturers and approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
Dr. Carl Peck, a former director of the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research at the Federal drug agency, said, "One dose fits all is a marketing myth, but it's the holy grail that every drug company tries to achieve."
While at the drug agency, Dr. Peck conducted a study that showed that some drugs did come to market from 1980 to 1993 with dosing advice that had to be lowered. But, he said, that is less likely to occur today because during the last decade drug manufacturers have begun to study ranges of doses in the trials done before drugs are approved.
Some newer drugs, like cholesterol lowering agents and a nose spray for allergies, come with labeling that gives a recommended dose range and advises doctors to try to find the lowest effective dose.
Dr. Peck is now director of the center for drug development science at the Georgetown University Medical Center.
"The whole issue of getting the dose right has become an important focus for the F.D.A.," Dr. Peck said, "and I think the F.D.A. and the drug companies are making a good-faith effort to do better these days."

Chart: "How Big a Dose? Ask the Patient" -- Before writing a prescription, says Dr. Jay S. Cohen, doctors should give every patient a questionnaire to determine whether they need the standard dose. Here are excerpts.
 
1. Are you sensitive to any prescription or nonprescription drugs?
 
2. How are you affected by alcohol?
 
3. Do some drugs make you tired or sleepy: Cold or allergy remedies or antihistamines? Tranquilizers or anticonvulsants? Motion-sickness remedies or antinausea agents?
 
4. Do some drugs give you energy or cause anxiety or insomnia: Coffee, tea, chocolate, other caffeinelike substances? Appetite suppressants (prescription or nonprescription)? Cold or allergy remedies or decongestants? 1
 
5. Have you ever had a reaction to epinephrine (adrenaline chloride, often injected by dentists along with pain-numbing medication)?
 
6. Have you had any side effects from any other prescription or nonprescription drugs (like impaired memory or coordination, blurred vision, headaches indigestion, diarrhea, constipation, dizziness, palpitations, rashes, swelling, ringing in ears, other reactions)?
 
8. Over all, how would you describe yourself with regard to medication: Very sensitive? Not particularly sensitive? Very tolerant; usually require high doses? (pg. F2)

HEADLINE: NYC;
Giving Trump A Swift Kick Upstairs

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
BY the reckoning of no less than the United Nations, the world's population hits the six billion mark today.
With all respect to international experts in such matters, that figure cannot be right. There must be many more people than that on the planet because most days there are at least six billion people traipsing through mid-Manhattan alone. 
 That's what it feels like, anyway, much of the time; six billion people pushing and shoving their way past endless construction sites, looking faintly unhinged as they claw their way to an appointment or a lunch or a matinee. Times Square, ground zero for much of the frenzy, can make a Nine Inch Nails concert seem uncrowded and serene. The streets there, stripped to the roadbed, bring back visions of the Ho Chi Minh Trail after a B-52 strike.
You may think that a patriotic New Yorker should feel thrilled with all the construction because it is a sign of boom times and of a resurgent city, bigger and better than ever.
Bigger, for sure. But even someone who bleeds New York blue, white and orange has to wonder if all sense of proportion has been lost. One 40-story tower is good for a neighborhood? Well, then, several 40-story towers must be several times better. That seems to be the prevailing logic among city planners, who, if they were bakers, would probably decorate a wedding cake with dozens of little brides and grooms. More is better, no?
But there are encouraging signals that City Hall has begun to get a grip. The indications include plans to change the zoning laws so that, at last, height limits are put on new skyscrapers.
Had such restrictions been in place a few years ago, for example, the latest monument to Donald J. Trump's ego could not have legally been built. That's Trump World Tower, a 72-story apartment building rising on First Avenue in the 40's, a corner of the city whose populace is divided into two principal categories: the haves and the have-mores. Mr. Trump hopes to lure a third group, the have-mosts, to his building, where condominiums up in the ozone layer leave million-dollar price tags far behind.
To really restore rational planning to New York civic life, an even more effective tactic than zoning laws might be to elect Mr. Trump President next year. Once he moves into the White House with the First Babe, whoever she may be, he will presumably be too busy setting the world right to tart up Manhattan with any more marble and glass odes to himself.
Go ahead, laugh. But Mr. Trump insists he can win, and a National Enquirer poll backs him up. You need better proof than that?
O.K., he has image problems, including the fact that he looks a little like someone who shares a barber with Slobodan Milosevic. But that shouldn't hurt him much if he runs for the Reform Party nomination against the likes of Patrick J. Buchanan, whom Mr. Trump portrays as out of goose step with mainstream America.
IT may not even be necessary to wait for Mr. Trump's election for New Yorkers to feel the benefits. That could happen once he formally declares his candidacy.
Given the near-impossibility of turning a corner here without seeing the name Trump plastered on one tower or another, the City Council would have reason to deem this an unfair campaign advantage and order the immediate de-Trumping of buildings. Taking down his name could be rationalized as a blow not only for political equity, but also for good taste.
Of course, to avoid possible charges of bias in the race for United States senator next year, Council members might also have to redesignate the several Clinton Streets and Clinton Avenues. But that should present no hardship. Naming streets is one thing the Council does very well.
Then, with Mr. Trump out of the picture, New Yorkers can focus on truly urgent development issues likely to emerge in the 21st century. There are too many to go into, but here's one:
The United Nations -- let's assume it is right with that six billion figure -- projects that by 2050, a quarter of the developed world will be over 65. Think what that will mean for a city like New York, whose economy depends heavily on its thousands of restaurants.
How many early-bird specials do you think those places can offer and still stay in business? Yet, with the clock ticking, not a single politician is talking about this issue. Where is leadership when you need it?

HEADLINE: The Italianization of Europe

BYLINE: By Josef Joffe; Josef Joffe, editorial page editor of Suddeutsche Zeitung in Munich, is a visiting lecturer at Stanford University.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
We are quite the best country in Europe," Lady Thatcher, she of the tart tongue and whiplash diction, recently informed her fellow Tories. In her lifetime, she added, "all the problems have come from mainland Europe and all the solutions have come from the English-speaking nations across the world."
One might quibble with that harsh verdict, but she is certainly right that the "English-speaking nations" are different from the rest of the West. Start with the Magna Carta and the United States Constitution, which enshrined limited government while Europe was aching under popes, emperors and Sun Kings. They think differently: the English-speaking nations have Locke and Jefferson, while the Europeans have Hegel and Marx. When in doubt, the English speakers will go for liberty and the market while the Europeans will opt for equality and paternalism. 
 These are the deepest cultural roots of Reaganism and Thatcherism, those brutal movements of the 1980's that whacked regulation, chopped welfare and defenestrated organized labor. The fine points will be argued forever, but it was that revolution from above that gave America full employment and Britain a jobless rate half that of the European Union.
Sure, European unemployment has declined from 12 percent in the mid-90's to an average of 9 percent today. But that is not good enough, especially since much of the improvement is not the result of market-minded reform but of the end of a European slump almost as old as the American boom.
Is anybody capable of pulling a Thatcher? Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany is talking like his British soul mate Tony Blair, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France sometimes talks like Mr. Schroder. "People must stop expecting the Government and the state to take charge of everything," he said in mid-September.
But Mr. Jospin also said, "We are not going in for 'social liberalism' " -- a code word for the freer-market doctrines pushed by Mr. Blair and Mr. Schroder. While the Jospinistes have privatized some state companies, they have also introduced a 35-hour workweek, which will not do wonders for French competitiveness.
Mr. Schroder is in more serious trouble because after months of wavering, he has started hawking a harsh reformist line of cuts in taxes, regulations and welfare. The reward? He has been bloodied in every regional election since -- Brandenburg, Saarland, Thuringia, Saxony and, last weekend, Berlin. And his Social Democrats have lost many a city hall in their traditional stronghold of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's Rust Belt.
The lesson is that Continental leaders cannot pull a Reagan or Thatcher. First, because of Europe's proportional-representation voting systems, coalition governments will rule from here to eternity. And they generate not power but stalemate.
More fundamentally, Europeans do not like change that might rob them of a little security here and a few entitlements there. Two unwritten articles of their constitutions say: No change, please, and if it is absolutely unavoidable, losers must be compensated. So voters will punish those who, like Mr. Schroder, timidly try to dismantle a towering edifice of entitlements that eats up half of Europe's gross domestic product.
But do not cry for us, Lady Thatcher. Look instead beneath the level of stalemated state power, and you will detect the wondrous winds of change. Business is downsizing. Labor markets, though formally untouched, are displaying work-rule flexibility and even giving back wages. Call it the "Italianization" of the Continent. Italy has had some 60 revolving-door governments since World War II. So Italians have learned not just to flout their rulers, but to do without them, ignoring laws, regulations and tax collectors. The Italian economy long ago decoupled from the state.
Other European societies have begun to follow, though minus the Mafia and endemic corruption. Take Germany. Those vaunted nationwide collective bargaining agreements that make work as expensive in rich Munich as in impoverished Bremen endure on paper only. Companies strike their own deals on the shop floor. To save jobs, shop stewards will simply ignore union headquarters. Likewise, the French tire maker Michelin recently vowed to cut 10 percent from its work force, never mind that Mr. Jospin was "shocked."
Sometimes economic activity goes underground, where it is neither taxed nor regulated. Some 15 percent of Germany's G.D.P. is produced in the "shadow economy," meaning that dour old Deutschland is mutating into a Northern version of la bella Italia. The productive parts of society are learning to take care of themselves, prodded by the stern discipline of the global market.
"Get out of my way," is the economy's message to government. The chairman of General Electric, Jack Welsh, said it first. But if the Iron Lady were listening, she would hear a multivoiced "amen" -- from Calais to Calabria.

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Blues Reconnect With Roots

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

DATELINE: HELENA, ARK.

 BODY:
This former plantation town in eastern Arkansas is not an obvious choice for a festival, with a crumbling downtown, a shrinking population now at 7,000 and all the economic problems and racial tensions one would expect in Phillips County, the poorest county in the state. But back in the 1930's and 40's, when Helena was a relatively thriving agricultural port on the Mississippi, it was the blues center of the Delta, with juke joints lining the streets, now-legendary musicians playing for change on the piers, and, beginning in 1941, a groundbreaking, highly influential afternoon blues broadcast called "King Biscuit Time," featuring the harmonica player Sonny Boy Williamson (the former Rice Miller).
Capitalizing on this heritage, local officials and blues fans borrowed a trailer from a traveling evangelist 13 years ago and used it as a stage for the first King Biscuit Blues Festival, which has now grown to become the largest free blues gathering in the South and an extraordinary opportunity for fans of the music to see a living tradition reconnect with its roots. 
 The 14th annual festival took place last week, from Thursday to Saturday, and thus overcame what may have been the greatest odds ever stacked against it. First came a lawsuit filed by a handful of local disgruntled black merchants and the regional branch of the N.A.A.C.P. charging civil rights violations. Naming the city's Mayor, Dr. Robert D. Miller (the first-ever black Mayor in this town with a minority white population), and the City Council as defendants, the lawsuit alleged that the city favored white merchants and festival organizers.
In the meantime, several sponsors (whose support is crucial to pulling off a free concert that doesn't receive any government money) threatened to withdraw if the festival didn't change its logo. That was a replica of the design on packages of Sonny Boy Cornmeal (an illustration of Sonny Boy Williamson sitting on an ear of corn with a harmonica in his hands), which were sold in the 40's by the makers of King Biscuit Flour to exploit the popularity of the radio show. Although Williamson was said to have been proud of the package, festival sponsors thought the image could be construed as racist. And then there was one more threat to the festival, the weather report: rain, rain and more rain.
But three weeks ago, a Federal judge ruled in favor of the festival. And promoters solved the logo dispute by cropping the cornmeal image so that it showed just a close-up of Williamson's face and harmonica.
But they could not stop the rain. It either poured or drizzled through most of the festival, forcing the cancellation of several acts, including Little Milton. As loyal locals and blues hounds from around the world stood in the downpour while Magic Slim and the Teardrops performed, the electric shocks Magic Slim kept getting from the microphone didn't help the performance any. Because of the terrible weather, the festival, which expected attendance to top last year's 135,000, saw fewer than 100,000 people over the weekend.
Nonetheless, for those who showed up, the King Biscuit Blues Festival was a casual and ideal way to experience the music. Fans sat on railroad tracks or in folding chairs on the grassy levee, watching performances by Robert Lockwood Jr., Son Seals, Pinetop Perkins with Bob Margolin, Sam Carr, W. C. Clark, the duo of Cephas and Wiggins and dozens more. Cherry Street, running behind the stage, seemed to be in a time warp, with musicians who weren't booked in the festival playing for change in the street, their electric guitars plugged into the outlets of obliging stores like the V.I.P. Beauty Salon. At stalls in the road, the James Alexander Masonic Lodge sold hog maws, Live Critters offered hermit crabs and the Lighthouse Assembly of God displayed dolls made out of hymn books.
Onstage on Saturday night was Son Seals, who has become a road warrior in recent years despite having had his leg amputated over the summer because of diabetes complications and the lower half of his face reconstructed after being shot by his wife two years ago. For more than an hour he played fast, melting lead guitar lines that oozed off the stage like syrup. Backstage, sitting with the pianist Pinetop Perkins, he discussed the letter he had written to the local newspaper to help defend the festival from accusations of racism, accusations that festival promoters and most townspeople say are trumped up. "I had to do that," Mr. Seals said. "I wanted to tell the truth."
Mr. Perkins, 86, sat slouched in a chair next to him, nodding in agreement and telling stories about performing in Helena more than 50 years ago. "I've been playing here since way back, as the King Biscuit Boys," he said, clicking his tongue. "Ain't but two of us left."
The other remaining King Biscuit Time mainstay, Robert Lockwood Jr., lived around Helena as a teen-ager, playing guitar with his stepfather, Robert Johnson. Of all the Delta musicians onstage, Mr. Lockwood had deviated most from his roots, playing his own blues-jazz hybrid on 12-string guitar over the swing and jump of a brassy backing band.
As if performances by Mr. Lockwood and Mr. Perkins weren't enough of a connection to Helena's musical past, a further reminder came from the fact that not only was there a street named after the bluesman Frank Frost two blocks away from the main stage, but Mr. Frost was still living on that street. Barely able to play because of ill health, Mr. Frost made a brief appearance during a set by his bandmate of 45 years, the drummer Sam Carr. Spectators onstage said they saw Mr. Carr crying as he played.
Blues in the Delta has always been an around-the-clock occupation. After performing on the main stage for tens of thousands of people, many musicians went straight to nearby hangouts like Ellie Mae's to perform in dilapidated barrooms for just a handful of locals and fans.
The best of these impromptu performances was a small picnic at Mr. Carr's shack, which stands in the middle of a picturesque stretch of farmland across the Mississippi River. Identifying the house and its occupant is a mailbox that, Mr. Carr said, has occasionally been stolen by blues souvenir hunters. For an audience of about 25 people, Mr. Carr beat highly stylized stiff-armed patterns. Accompanying him from the other side of a picnic table was the harpist Arthur Williams, who sat under a tree wailing merrily away with a briefcase full of harmonicas splayed open at his feet.
For those whose tastes ran beyond the blues, the festival had more to offer. Inside the Malco Theater on Cherry Street local gospel groups sang and preached for enthusiastic townspeople. Among them was Mayor Miller, who stood in the lobby buying popcorn. "I know it looks a little odd for the Mayor of a town with the largest blues festival in the South to be at the gospel stage," he said sheepishly. "Especially since I'm a Roman Catholic. But my son is a Pentecostal minister, and he's my spiritual adviser."
Mayor Miller said he was thinking of starting a gospel festival, although he remained a blues fan and played piano with the King Biscuit Boys in 1945 to fill in for an ailing musician. He stuffed a handful of popcorn in his mouth and reached to pick up a leather medical bag on the counter, explaining that he was also the local general practitioner and had just attended to an emergency.
As for the lawsuit, he dismissed it. "As long as I'm Mayor, the festival is not going anywhere," he said, adding after a reflective pause, "and that's probably why I am Mayor here."

HEADLINE: Coca-Cola Plans New Program For Its Flagship Soft Drink

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
With demand for cola on the wane, the Coca-Cola Company is planning what amounts to a reintroduction of its flagship soft drink, Coca-Cola Classic.
The program, known as Ignition 2000, will drop the "Always Coca-Cola" tagline that has been in place since 1993, replacing it with a new set of graphics known inside the company as the Sensation Graphics. 
 The move comes as record numbers of consumers are scorning cola in favor of fruit drinks, teas, bottled water and other beverages that were not available a decade ago. It is not clear whether all of those consumers are new to the market, or whether longtime cola drinkers are switching to something else.
The changes were reported earlier this week in Beverage Digest, an industry newsletter, which cited materials distributed to bottlers. A report in Brandweek last month also discussed some of the changes. A spokesman for Coca-Cola would not provide any details, but did confirm that a major program was being planned for Coca-Cola Classic. "We have a number of initiatives in the works," said the spokesman, Bob Bertini. "They are still in the development stages, and we're not going to comment on anything."
But others who had been briefed on the program said it included a heavy emphasis on eight-ounce glass bottles, which would be sold chilled as part of an effort to promote the taste of Coca-Cola Classic, which is the name regular Coke took after the New Coke debacle.
Coke, which packages the vast majority of its colas in aluminum cans or plastic bottles, has used glass bottles for various commemorative products in recent years, but one analyst said the plans outlined in Ignition 2000 went well beyond that.
"It's going to be more than commemorative," said Andrew J. Conway, a beverage analyst for Morgan Stanley. "It's a push to build the brand again."
Cola remains the biggest-selling soft drink in the United States, but its grip on consumers has softened considerably in the last decade. According to Beverage Digest/Maxwell, in 1990, about 71.7 percent of all soft drinks sold were colas. But by last year, that had fallen to 61.9 percent. Coca-Cola Classic's share of that dwindling market has risen, from 28.1 percent to 33.3 percent in the period, while Pepsi-Cola's share has declined, from 24.6 percent in 1990 to 22.9 percent last year.
Pepsi-Cola tried to reinvigorate its brand in the spring with a new advertising campaign that included the tagline "Joy of Cola" and featured a series of mostly well-received television commercials. Pepsi's market share has also been nibbling at Coke's dominance, according to recent supermarket scanner data. But both Coke and Pepsi have been hurt by declining sales, brought about partly by a jump in retail prices that appears to have shocked consumers who had grown used to deep discounts on soft drinks over the last several years.
Other changes Coke is expected to announce include a tagline, "Enjoy all that's inside." The "Sensation" graphics being distributed to bottlers show a contoured bottle of Coca-Cola tipped to one side, its cap off and its contents spurting out.
Coca-Cola, like many other consumer products companies that bet heavily on global growth, has been suffering through a kind of corporate annus horribilis, with its share price and earnings falling and its sales off in many places around the world. In addition, Coca-Cola's public image was tarnished by a recall of drinks in parts of Europe this spring, which began after dozens of people in Belgium said they felt ill after drinking the company's products.
Yesterday the share price fell $1.8125, to close at $50.5625, which was $24.875 off its 52-week high.
One bottler said he had not seen the new ads, but was well aware of the flagging consumer desire for cola. "They want to try root beer, then fruit drinks; they jump all over the place," said J. Bruce Llewellyn, chairman and chief executive of the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Company.

HEADLINE: The Six Billion Mark

 BODY:
The world's population reached six billion this week, by United Nations estimates. The news is daunting, given that the figure has doubled since 1960. Yet six billion actually represents significant progress made in the past 30 years in reducing birth rates, improving health care and giving women greater access to education and economic opportunities. Without such modernization, population growth would have been higher than it is now.
In a single generation, fertility rates have declined in virtually every nation. Industrialized countries have seen birthrates fall from 2.8 children per woman in the 1950's to roughly 1.6 today. In the developing world, birthrates have dropped from 6.2 children per woman to slightly less than 3. Over the next several decades the world's population will continue to grow, but more slowly, reaching 8.9 billion in 2050, and stabilizing at about 10 billion in 2200. 
 This scenario is a far cry from the dire predictions about the population explosion commonly made in the 1960's. Even so, population growth will occur mostly in the poorest nations that are least prepared to deal with worsening population pressures on the environment, water supply, food production and social infrastructure.
One of the great lessons learned in the past three decades is that controlling population growth is inextricably tied to development strategies that improve gender equity, expand education for women, increase access to reproductive health care and give women more economic power. All these factors help enable women to choose to have smaller, healthier families.
The 1994 International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo set a broad agenda focused on these objectives, which were agreed to by 179 countries. Many nations are now trying to put these population development goals into practice. But financial support from the industrialized nations has been lacking.
The Cairo Conference estimated that $17 billion would be needed annually for population and health activities, with about two-thirds coming from the developing countries themselves and one-third from international donors. But total funding from international donors in 1997 was less than $2 billion, far short of the goal. The United States remains the leading donor in family planning programs, but its support has been declining in recent years. Anti-abortion rhetoric continues to be used in Congress to limit aid for international family planning programs.
The challenges facing developing nations are enormous. Even now, nearly 600,000 women die annually during pregnancy, more than 350 million women do not have access to a range of effective contraceptive methods, and 600 million women cannot read or write. These conditions remain big obstacles in achieving population stabilization. Unless international funding increases, the next billion people may be consigned to lives of privation in countries where resources are already stretched to the limit. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: High Court Is Urged to Uphold 'Citizen Suit' to Curb Pollution

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
When Congress passed the Clean Water Act 27 years ago, it included a "citizen suit" provision authorizing private individuals to sue polluters and collect fines that would go not to the successful plaintiffs but directly to the Federal treasury.
In the face of growing judicial hostility to such suits, a case argued today before the Supreme Court could determine whether that provision, and similar clauses in other Federal environmental laws, would continue to be of much use. 
 The case, an appeal by Friends of the Earth and other environmental groups from a ruling that dismissed their suit against the operator of a hazardous waste incinerator on a river in South Carolina, has galvanized the environmental movement as have few Supreme Court cases in recent years.
The hourlong argument was highly technical, laced with references to Supreme Court precedents on jurisdictional issues like standing and mootness, but the policy debate at the heart of the case peeked through.
"What cases do you know," Justice Antonin Scalia asked the environmental groups' lawyer, Bruce J. Terris, that consider it "a proper function of the courts to impose a public penalty in private litigation?"
Justice Scalia, perhaps the judiciary's strongest critic of citizen suit provisions, said such suits usurped the ordinary function of the executive branch and brought about "a major alteration of power between the various branches of government and between the Federal and state governments."
When Mr. Terris replied that in the view of Congress citizen suits were not really private lawsuits but served to "carry out a public function," Justice Scalia cut him off.
"I understand that Congress has said it," he said. "The question is whether it's constitutional."
No other members of the Court appeared eager to take up Justice Scalia's effort to turn a discussion on the meaning of a Federal statute into a major constitutional debate over the separation of powers. Nonetheless, the exchange was a reminder that although the environmental groups were relieved last spring when the Justices agreed to hear their appeal of what they considered a very damaging lower court ruling, that relief could prove to be premature. The Supreme Court, which itself has restricted citizen suits in several recent rulings, could use this case, Friends of the Earth v. Laidlaw Environmental Services, No. 98-822, to restrict such suits further.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, made new law in this case in two respects. First, it ruled that the suit had to be dismissed as moot because, although the incinerator was still discharging excess levels of mercury into the North Tyger River when the suit was filed, in 1992, the operator acquired new anti-pollution equipment and stopped the discharges soon thereafter.
Second, the appellate court said, since the plaintiffs had not "prevailed" in their litigation, they were not entitled to reimbursement of their lawyers' fees and court costs. The Fourth Circuit thus became the only appellate court to reject what has become known as the catalyst theory, under which environmental and civil rights plaintiffs who can show that their lawsuit brought about a change in the defendant's behavior can recover their fees and costs even if the lawsuit did not result in an official court judgment.
Both aspects of the Fourth Circuit's ruling are before the Supreme Court. The plaintiffs are arguing that if a defendant can avoid all liability by modifying its behavior once a suit is filed, citizen suits will become economically impractical.
A separate question the Court may need to address is whether the closing of the plant in May, two months after the Justices agreed to hear the case, means there is no longer a live issue for them to resolve and, if so, whether the Fourth Circuit decision should remain on the books.
New York, Connecticut and 12 other states entered the case on the side of the environmental groups, arguing in a brief that citizen suits fill gaps in enforcement and "help states focus their regulatory aims." The Clinton Administration also supports the plaintiffs. Jeffrey P. Minear, an assistant solicitor general, told the Court today that the fines imposed in these suits are valuable deterrents against continued violations.
Donald A. Cockrill, arguing today for the company, now known as the Safety-Kleen Corporation and based in Columbia, S.C., said the $405,000 in penalties the Federal District Court imposed on his client "had no deterrent effect." He said that while "deterrence to me implies that someone doesn't want to do what's right and you have to goad them into it," the company was already close to compliance by the time the suit was filed. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Worry Over Rates Causes Dow to Drop 231.12 Points

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices staged a broad, sharp retreat yesterday, pulled down by rising interest rates, political instability in Pakistan and the prospect that third-quarter corporate earnings may not live up to expectations.
Interest rates rose in reaction to a surge in crude oil prices. Late yesterday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond stood at 6.22 percent, its highest level in nearly two years. 
 Concern about rising rates was worsened by an announcement from the Raytheon Company that sales and earnings would not be up to expectations for the balance of this year and in 2000. Word of a possible military coup in Pakistan, a development that could heighten tension with India, became an additional source of instability.
"We are still stuck squarely in a trading range, but it looks like the market may be adjusting to the downside again," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "It will be tough to get positive momentum back until many of the issues that are confronting the market are resolved."
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 231.12 points, or 2.17 percent, to 10,417.06, its biggest decline in more than four months. Of the 30 stocks that make up the blue-chip index only 2, Chevron and International Paper, managed to rise in price. Hewlett-Packard, American Express and I.B.M. all fell by more than 3 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index lost 22.17, or 1.66 percent, to 1,313.04.
Raytheon, the biggest loser among S.& P. 500 stocks, did not trade for much of the day. The stock suffered its worst one-day decline in nearly two decades once it finally did open for trading, and closed at 24 1/4, down 18 3/4.
The Nasdaq composite index, which set a record on Monday, fell 43.52, or 1.5 percent, to 2,872.43. And the Russell 2000 index of small company stocks dropped 5.51, or 1.3 percent, to 424.68.
At 772 million shares, trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was fairly light. But losing stocks outnumbered those that rose in price by a margin of five to two.
On the Nasdaq stock market, 992 million shares changed hands.
Additional questions about the market's near-term direction emerged after the close yesterday, when the technology bellwether Intel released an earnings report that fell a bit short of expectations. During regular trading, Intel was one of a small number of stocks that moved higher on the day, closing at 76 11/16, up 3/16. But the stock was down as much as 5 in after-hours trading.
The rise in crude oil prices helped to bolster oil stocks.
Royal Dutch Petroleum gained 5/8, to 58. Chevron was up 1 1/8, to 88. And BP Amoco rose 7/8, to 54.
The rise in interest rates hammered big Internet stocks. America Online fell 7 1/16, to 114. Yahoo fell for a second day, dropping 7 1/2, to 173 7/8. And eBay lost 5, to 144 3/4.
"The Federal Reserve Board has to be happy to see some air come out of the market," said David L. Mead, chief investment officer at Harris Bank in Chicago.
Mr. Mead said stocks could correct a bit more from here, and that over the near-term bonds seem a better investment.

HEADLINE: Leadership Succession at Unesco: An Open Selection This Time

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 12

 BODY:
In a cautious move toward greater openness, Unesco's executive board will hold job interviews on Wednesday for the post of the organization's director general.
No less unusual, all 11 candidates have been campaigning publicly, creating the impression that for the first time personality and ideas may be as important as back-room political deals. 
 Political maneuvering has of course not stopped, with some countries and regions openly backing candidates and rumors flying of "checkbook" lobbying by at least two governments. But the quality of the contenders may become more relevant than in past years when the 58-nation board votes in secret next week to pick a successor to Federico Mayor Zaragoza of Spain.
The single candidate to be presented to Unesco's 186-nation general conference on Nov. 12 must win a majority.
Diplomats said that if no winner emerges from the first four ballots -- on successive days, starting Monday -- a runoff will be held between the two front-runners on Oct. 22.
What is at stake is a six-year term to run a 2,326-member staff, a $544 million annual budget and a mandate as broad as the Paris-based organization's full name: the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
But the new director general will also take over a Unesco still plagued by bureaucracy, inefficiency and nepotism and widely viewed as urgently needing an overhaul.
Western diplomats say Unesco today is nonetheless a far cry from the left-leaning talk shop that the United States and Britain abandoned in 1985. Britain rejoined in 1997.
At the time, with Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal as director general, Unesco became particularly identified with promotion of a so-called new world information order, which was aimed at breaking a perceived monopoly of Western news organizations and which Western governments viewed as an attempt at global censorship.
Ismail Serageldin, an Egyptian intellectual who is a vice president of the World Bank, likes to describe himself as the candidate of "civic society" and, as such, has been most active in mobilizing outside support, with 43 Nobel Prize winners endorsing his candidacy.
In contrast, Ghazi Algosaibi, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to London, has the Arab League's backing. Coming from a country with a monarchical form of government, he has been eager to portray himself as a poet and liberal.
Japan's Ambassador to Paris, Koichiro Matsuura, starts with the advantage that Japan is the largest contributor to Unesco's budget, to which he adds the promise of an efficient administration of Unesco. Gareth Evans, until recently Australia's Foreign Minister, is a late candidate who is thought to enjoy considerable European support. Neither Mr. Matsuura nor Mr. Evans is fluent in French, which may hurt them.
The next director general is widely expected to be one of those four men, although seven other candidates will also have a chance to make their pitch on Wednesday: Senake Bandaranaike, Sri Lanka's Ambassador to France; Ion Caramitru, Romania's Culture Minister; Lawrence Carrington, a diplomat from Trinidad and Tobago; Daniel Janicot, a French diplomat, currently Unesco's deputy director general; Rosario Manalo, the Philippines' Deputy Foreign Minister; Makaminan Makagiansar, Indonesia's delegate to Unesco, and Pal Pataki, a Hungarian diplomat.
