HEADLINE: On Paper, Budget Balances Without Customary Raid on Social Security

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Something symbolically enormous may have happened today: the Congressional Budget Office announced that the Government may have balanced the budget in fiscal 1999 without spending Social Security money.
If so, it would be the first time that has happened since 1960, when Dwight Eisenhower was President, gentlemen sported felt fedoras and women wore fox stoles. 
 Republicans, who have struggled to find a way to balance the 2000 budget without spending Social Security money, jumped on the budget office's estimate as evidence of their fiscal discipline.
"Even with all the emergency spending we had in '99, we did not spend Social Security dollars," said the House majority leader, Dick Armey, Republican of Texas. "This is, like, the first time, and we really stepped over the line now."
President Clinton and the Republicans in Congress are locked in a political struggle over whether the spending bills that Congress writes and the President signs will once again dip into the Social Security surplus. Both parties have portrayed themselves as protectors of the retirement funds.
Today's announcement may make those arguments more politically potent than ever. But budget experts continue to point out that the arguments are over such relatively small figures that they have almost no impact on the economy.
"We've reached the promised land, at least temporarily," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the budget office from 1989 to 1995.
"Fiscally, it's irrelevant," he said. "But it's psychologically and symbolically very important. If any budget expert told you in 1997 that we would have balanced the budget by 1999, this person would have been committed" to an asylum.
The budget office said the Government's general revenues showed a $1 billion surplus for fiscal 1999, which ended Sept. 30. It cautioned that the figures were preliminary. They may be off by as much as $3 billion, so the promised land may be a mirage.
Surplus Social Security funds have functioned as money under the mattress for Congress for four decades. When general Government revenues to run Federal agencies run out, Congress taps into the retirement funds. Almost all outside experts say that spending Social Security surpluses has had no effect on its benefits.
Republicans have been vowing almost daily never again to spend the money. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert again promised today never to "return to the days when Democrats raided Social Security."
The struggle, which both sides have represented as a fight to "save Social Security," has driven the Republicans to employ tens of billions of dollars in accounting devices, which even some in their own party are calling gimmicks and tricks, to make their spending bills appear to keep that promise.
Though both parties rushed to claim credit for today's supposed surplus, the new numbers calculated by the budget office show that everyone in Washington underestimated the force that may have balanced the budget: unexpectedly high tax revenues generated by a rip-roaring economy.
A year ago, most people believed that Congress had spent at least $21 billion and as much as $37 billion in Social Security funds in the fiscal 1999 spending bills.
But as the tax money rolled into the Federal counting house this spring and summer, that number dwindled. Today, on paper, it disappeared.
The report that the budget may be balanced "is probably worth a good headline, but beyond that it is not clear what it will portend," said Dan Crippen, director of the budget office since 1995.
"Whether we are on one side or another of the line by a billion is not as important as the economic growth that caused us to arrive at the line," Mr. Crippen said.
And Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council, credited the White House for "an enormous fiscal achievement that seemed unimaginable when President Clinton took office."
Mr. Reischauer, a veteran of past budget battles, demurred.
"There is every likelihood that we will fall from grace in the current fiscal year unless saved again by the power of the economy to generate unexpected revenues," he said "And woe be to those who are blamed for a fall from grace."
The new budget office figures show about $125 billion in excess Social Security funds for fiscal 1999, above and beyond the projected $1 billion surplus in general Government revenues.
If Congress really has the will to keep its hands off the Social Security surpluses for the next 10 years, about $2 trillion of those revenues will accrue, says the budget office. Left untouched, they would halve the Federal debt of more than $3.6 trillion.

LENGTH: 1695 words

HEADLINE: What Makes A Big Airport Hum?;
Atlanta's May Do It Best, But Growing Pains Loom

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
When he was a Marine Corps pilot in the 1970's, Michael J. Quiello learned to appreciate the teamwork necessary to take off from or land a plane safely on a rolling, pitching aircraft carrier. In his subsequent 19 years as a pilot for Delta Air Lines, Mr. Quiello, who is now Delta's system manager for international operations, has been equally impressed by the teamwork necessary to make an airport hum. And in his opinion, no large airport functions as smoothly as Hartsfield Atlanta International.
"This is the best airport in the world," said Mr. Quiello, who has flown into and out of such highly regarded airports as Charles de Gaulle in Paris, Schiphol in Amsterdam and Changi in Singapore. 
 With 73.5 million passengers last year, Hartsfield is now, incontestably, the world's busiest airport, pushing the perennial front-runner, Chicago O'Hare, to second place.
But is Mr. Quiello being objective when he says it's the best? After all, his employer, Delta, has its main hub here and, together with its regional subsidiary, Atlantic Southeast Airlines, accounts for almost 80 percent of the passengers.
His praise for this onetime raceway, though, is echoed by other pilots. "There are taxiways all over the place, it's easy for passengers to get around in, and they planned it very well," said Larry Coy, a longtime pilot for Continental Airlines, which has its main hubs at Houston and Newark. "It's just a great airport."
It is far from perfect, however, for with its phenomenal growth have come flight delays, parking shortages and clogged traffic. But while some cities, like New York, have been glacially slow in providing airport rail links, Atlanta has a quick rail route from downtown. Hartsfield, then, may offer a shining example of how an airport can become a giant and help transform a city into a global crossroads. Yet it also provides a cautionary tale about the downside of the boom in air travel. And as more and more people take to the skies, Atlanta and other cities have little choice but to make do with existing airports, for the cost of building new ones is increasingly prohibitive.
"Over all, it's a good airport," said Henrietta Aswad, owner of the Global Journeys travel agency in Atlanta. "But there are never enough parking spaces. They don't have enough spots where you can pick up or drop off passengers. And getting into the airport from the main highway is a nightmare."
Benjamin R. DeCosta, Hartsfield's general manager, said: "We're No. 1 in passengers, and we intend to stay No. 1. But we're also the most-delayed airport in the U.S., with an average of eight-plus minutes a flight. We're committed to changing that."
That will not be easy, even for Mr. DeCosta, a determined Brooklyn-born lawyer who was general manager of Newark International Airport and Teterboro Airport in New Jersey until he was recruited last year by the Mayor of Atlanta, Bill Campbell.
The main reason for the delays is that when Hartsfield's last master plan was drawn up, in the 1970's, it envisioned a maximum of 65 million passengers a year, said John Boat right, a vice president at Delta (which has been a continuous Hartsfield tenant since 1934). The current master plan, not yet formally adopted, forecasts 121 million passengers a year by 2015.
Unless something is done well before then, aviation specialists say, delays could average a half-hour or more, and at peak times departing planes could be backed up as far as the eye can see. The airport's growth, after all, remains rapid. So far this year, Hartsfield has handled almost 3.4 million more passengers than O'Hare. For the first time ever, it also leads all United States airports in takeoffs and landings, its 295,000 so far this year more than 10,000 higher than O'Hare and more than 27,500 ahead of Dallas-Fort Worth.
Traffic will get worse, too, because in spite of predictions that Atlanta would slide backward after its 1996 Olympics high, the city has become more of a destination and less of a stopover. Ten years ago, 70 percent of Hartsfield passengers connected to other flights, Mr. DeCosta said. That is down to about 55 percent, thanks in part to the city's growth as a business center. In addition, though international passengers, especially from Europe and Latin America, account for fewer than 6 percent of the Hartsfield total, they have been growing about 20 percent a year for several years.
Hartsfield has been able to accommodate as many passengers as it does in part because of what Joe Leonard, chief executive of the airline Airtran Holdings Inc. (which also has its hub here), says are its skilled air traffic controllers, control tower operators and "an airport whose superb design has stood the test of time."
That design consists of a terminal building and six concourses flanked by four east-west runways -- the direction of the prevailing winds in the region. Taxiways are wide enough for two jumbo jets to pass on their way to or from any of the 143 domestic or 24 international gates. And the airspace over Atlanta is not as congested as it is over New York and other urban areas.
"Even with only four runways here, compared with seven at O'Hare and Dallas," said James M. Stogner, the assistant general manager, "Hartsfield can get people and planes in and out more efficiently than any airport in the world. We were a hub before that word was ever used for an airport. Delta pioneered bringing a tremendous number of people into a central station and sending them out again."
What is now the airport was an abandoned auto racetrack until the City of Atlanta bought the site in the 1920's and turned it into Hartsfield International. Hartsfield owes its current stature to a blessing in disguise -- the economic downturn in the 1970's, which cut air travel and thus the need to expand quickly to accommodate more passengers.
"That gave us some breathing room," said Mr. Stogner, who has served under eight of the airport's nine general managers. "So we went back and refined our research, this time with substantial input from the airlines."
Much of that input came from Eastern Airlines as well as Delta. Eastern, which shut down in 1991, had the first continuous passenger service from Atlanta to New York, in 1930, and the first international flight out of Atlanta, to Montreal, in 1956.
From atop a hill at the southern edge of the airport, it is possible to see what Mr. Quiello described as the airport's daily "coming together like a symphony orchestra." One day recently, as waves of planes landed and took off on adjoining runways below, Thomas E. Nissalke 2d, the airport's aviation simulation manager, said: "In good weather we can simultaneously depart 94 planes an hour and can land 90 an hour. No other airport can handle as many airplanes in an hour on a four-runway system."
To prepare for those 121 million passengers expected by 2015, some city officials would like to build a second airport -- a project that would face many hurdles. Meantime, Hartsfield is going to build another runway, but the one on the drawing boards is already outmoded for today's jets. That is because it was planned as a runway for commuter planes, and when environmental and legal clearances for the project were approved, in 1994, most commuter aircraft were prop planes, not jets. Though Mr. DeCosta and others hope to extend the runway, some property owners who would be displaced in nearby College Park are opposed.
For passengers, Hartsfield's strengths are its relative convenience and, despite the long distances involved, the relative ease of getting from here to there. But arriving by car can be numbing -- cars clog the approach roads at peak times, and even the 31,000 parking spaces can sometimes all seem to be occupied.
Still, Hartsfield moves masses of people more efficiently than most. It is one of the few American airports with a mass-transit rail station inside the terminal, transporting about 8,000 people to the airport each day and connecting the airport and downtown in about 20 minutes for $1.50. Nine trains make a 3.5-mile loop underground, stopping at 13 stations.
Hartsfield maintains a squad of volunteer hosts in red shirts or blouses who help passengers throughout the airport and a bicycle patrol trained to answer questions. Mr. DeCosta is a stickler for passenger satisfaction and a clean, orderly airport. He personally inspects men's rooms and picks up litter, and he alternates with his deputies in the terminal's atrium each month fielding passengers' questions.
With an annual payroll of $1.9 billion, the airport, which is owned and operated by the City of Atlanta, brings in nearly $15 billion a year to the local and regional economy. About 43,000 people are employed by the airport, its suppliers and concessionaires. "The support the city gives is excellent," Mr. Leonard of Airtran said. "They and the officials at the airport do a nice job of investing in facilities and keeping them up."
Still, the relationship is not always smooth. In April 1998, Mayor Campbell dismissed Angela Gittens, the independent-minded general manager, and replaced her with Mr. DeCosta. Also independent-minded, if more circumspect than his predecessor, Mr. DeCosta says he has more authority here than he had in Newark.
Among the examples he cited was a recent meeting with Senator Max Clelland, to brief him on expansion plans -- projects that are forecast to cost $5.4 billion in the next decade.
Unlike many others in Atlanta's Department of Aviation, Mr. DeCosta contends that a second airport is unnecessary. He favors a master plan proposal that Hartsfield buy the property to expand the projected fifth runway, add and expand terminals and add many more parking spaces.
He also suspects that a change in technology, specifically planes capable of vertical landings and takeoffs, will help make a second airport unnecessary.
And, ultimately, there is the matter of cost. "A new airport is very expensive," he added, "so you would have to identify who would pay off the bonds. That would have to be an airline with deep pockets, and so far I don't know of any volunteers."

HEADLINE: For Seattle, Triumph and Protest

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 12

 BODY:
When Seattle beat 40 other cities in the United States early this year for the right to host a meeting of the world's governing trade organization, local leaders were exultant. Here in what is often called the most trade-dependent region of the nation, they said the meeting would be a chance to show off Seattle as a world-class center of high-tech innovation and a friend to global trade.
All that may still happen when 5,000 delegates and dignitaries from 134 nations -- including President Clinton -- gather to start a new round of global trade negotiations here next month. Those negotiations will encompass some of the most politically sensitive issues facing the world's trading nations, including rules on agriculture and new technologies. But it is increasingly clear that the largest free-trade meeting ever held in this country has also become a giant protest magnet for a broad array of environmental, labor and other groups that say the trade body is a handmaid to corporate interests whose authority should be sharply curtailed. 
 Three hundred groups are vowing to bring 50,000 people or more to downtown Seattle to picket, demonstrate, hold teach-ins and cause general disruption during the meeting on Nov. 30 to Dec. 3 that could turn the city's streets into a carnival of protest and, perhaps, a morass of gridlock.
It is a sign of how crucial trade issues have become to average people that a meeting once might have excited only policy experts has now drawn the attention of a cross-section of America that includes farmers, fishermen and assembly-line workers.
Already the trade organization has been entangled in spats over items that include Caribbean-grown bananas, hormone-fed beef from the United States, gasoline refined in Venezuela and Japanese imported liquor.
Even more contentious issues loom: over loss of price supports for American farmers and over rulings about what kinds of genetically modified foods countries can offer to consumers on supermarket shelves.
Underlying all the individual issues is a fundamental disagreement about the proper role of the trade organization. Proponents say it serves a crucial role in bolstering the world economy by tearing down trade barriers all over the globe. But opponents believe the trade group is using its power as an arbiter in trade disputes to systematically undermine laws adopted by various countries to promote health, food safety, environmental protection and better working conditions.
It is from those diverse concerns that a vigorous protest movement has emerged. Just how extensive or disruptive any protests will be is difficult to gauge, partly because even the groups themselves, more than 300 at latest count, are not exactly of one mind. Some say they have no plans to be unduly raucous and simply want their perspective to be heard by the trade negotiators, while others are boasting that their goal is to bring the city to a standstill with guerrilla-like tactics like scaling skyscrapers to unfurl huge banners, lying in the street to stop traffic or chaining themselves to buildings and trees.
But the city is already budgeting $6 million for a major security operation, and Mayor Paul Schell, noting the potential for disruption, has taken to joking: "I'm hoping for rain, frankly." While Seattle is indeed likely to get some rain at that time of year, it may not dampen the fervency of the protesters.
"I'm in the camp that wants to shut the W.T.O. down," explained John Sellers, director of the Ruckus Society of Berkeley, Calif., which recently helped to lead what was called a "Globalize This!" training session for protesters at a farm near the Cascade Mountains, outside Seattle.
"I think this is the largest gathering of unaccountable corporate power that has ever occurred on this planet, and it should be stopped," said Mr. Sellers, who described his group as "open to work with anyone who is working for progressive social change on the left side of the spectrum."
In some ways, the protesters have already scored important victories and in Seattle, a city with a long history of union activity and a decidedly favorable bent toward environmental causes, they are clearly generating some sympathy. The local King County Council, for instance, recently haggled over and nearly failed to approve wording for a routine resolution of welcome to the trade organization delegates.
"I was thrilled when Seattle was selected," said Michael Dolan, a field organizer for the protesters, who is deputy director of the Global Trade Watch program of Public Citizen, a group founded by Ralph Nader. "It's almost like they're giving us home-field advantage. There are great labor unions here, great labor energy, all these environmentalists."
The protesters have commanded attention of local news organizations and, in what was clearly a bid to defuse some of the potential for conflict, the Clinton Administration has taken the unusual step of pressing the trade organization's leaders to hold a one-day meeting just before the conference gets under way to listen to the protester's concerns. The President also plans to send several members of his Cabinet to Seattle in the weeks before the conference to talk up the benefits of free trade.
The new director-general of the trade body, based in Geneva, Mike Moore, a former prime minister of New Zealand, was in Seattle earlier this month and used a forum at the University of Washington to concede that the trade body had not done an adequate job of explaining its mission to the public.
"I thought the case had been made," Mr. Moore said. "But I guess we have to back up the truck and explain how we got here. We've never reached out."
Advocates for the five-year-old trade organization and the 1948 framework pact that preceded it, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, say it is helping to bolster the world economy and lift workers out of poverty by bringing down barriers to trade all over the globe.
But opponents believe that the trade organization is using its power as an arbiter to systematically undermine laws passed by various countries to promote health, food safety, environmental protection and better working conditions.
In just one such case, several Asian nations won a preliminary ruling from the trade organization last year after they charged that the United States laws intended to protect sea turtles from shrimpers' nets unfairly blocked their exports to American markets. The protesters also say a ruling in favor of Venezuelan gasoline exporters had the effect of weakening anti-pollution laws in the United States.
"The record of the W.T.O. speaks for itself," said Jeremy Madsen, an organizer with the Citizens Trade Campaign, a coalition of dozens of groups opposed to the trade organization. "It's not something that is beneficial for workers, it's not beneficial for the environment. It has an atrocious impact on everyone but the elite, the very wealthy."
Business groups, clearly alarmed at the attention the protesters have already generated here, plan to organize their own campaign to promote the benefits of free trade. However, as a spokesman for one such group said, they do not exactly plan to rappel down the Space Needle to explain their point of view and therefore may not draw as much attention.
"I think the story in terms of media coverage is that we do pretty well in print, but we lose big-time on the pictures," said Scott Miller, a lobbyist with Procter & Gamble who is chairman of the United States Alliance for Trade Expansion, a group backed by business and based in Washington, D.C. "That will continue to be the dynamic."
Some opponents of the trade organization say the organization has adopted secretive operating rules that are practically forcing critics into public protests. Even when Mr. Moore came here on his scouting trip, he was met with protesters who carried signs that said "Stop child labor now" and "No globalization without representation."
"There isn't all that much left, really, because the system is so closed," said Patti Goldman, managing lawyer of the Earthjustice Legal Defense Fund, an environmental group. "It isn't democratic. There's no participation process for the public to play a role. That is a fundamental problem."
Mayor Schell, among others, is clearly walking a bit of a political tightrope, but he says he simply wants to make sure that the city is a good host to both those attending the trade conference and those who come here to protest it.
"I've been on the other side of the picket lines, and so have a lot of people here," the Mayor said in an interview. "They need to be heard. Seattle likes hosting these kinds of things. We see ourselves as an open city, a center for creative debate.
"Now," he added, "one of the things I'm going to try to convey to the protesters is that they are more likely to be effective if they find the right ways to be heard. People listen better when they're not being shouted at."
Mr. Madsen of the Citizens Trade Campaign, said the protests would be respectful.
"The intention of everyone involved is to have a very peaceful event, or series of events, that really speak to the issues," he said. "The goal is not really to disrupt the city per se. Traffic probably is going to get clogged, it's going to be hard to get downtown. But a lot of that won't have anything to do with us, it will have to do with security perimeters set up by the police, the F.B.I. The potential for real catastrophe is being greatly exaggerated."
But with such a widespread call to protest, and with some groups already vowing disruption, the potential is certainly there, said Walt Crowley, a local author and director of a Web site of Seattle history, historylink.org.
"Clearly the labor movement, the environmental movement, and other interest groups have legitimate concerns and even grievances with the W.T.O.," said Mr. Crowley.
"They're trying to reform a process and the structures for guiding international trade, they're not trying to blow them up," he said. "But they kind of have a protest going on with festival seating, which means you really have no control over who's sitting next to you. And I think there's some anxiety that the theatrics of protest are going to eclipse the content."

HEADLINE: President Urges Government To Reach Uninsured Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR and ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton directed Federal officials today to visit America's schools and enroll children in a health insurance program that he said had fallen far short of his original goal of providing coverage to five million youngsters.
"It is simply inexcusable that we're sitting here, and have been, with the money for two years to provide health insurance to five million kids, and 80 percent of them are still uninsured," Mr. Clinton said at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics. 
 Census Bureau data show that the number of children without health insurance has increased by 15.6 percent since Mr. Clinton took office, to 11.1 million last year from 9.6 million in 1993. The number of uninsured children rose by 330,000 in 1998 alone, despite an exceptionally strong economy and billions of dollars of new Federal money made available to pay for children's health insurance.
Congress created the new program, the Children's Health Insurance Program, in 1997. It provided $24 billion over five years and a total of $39 billion over 10 years, but states have used less than 25 percent of the money made available so far.
"If we're going to bring health care coverage to more children, we have to start with where the children are -- in the schools," Mr. Clinton said today.
He instructed officials from the Departments of Education, Agriculture and Health and Human Services to find eligible children in the schools and sign them up in the new program.
Mr. Clinton said schools would disseminate information on health insurance along with the forms used to apply for school lunch subsidies.
"Millions of parents who fill out their school lunch forms now will have a chance to learn about these health programs," he said.
In addition, the President said, "thousands of Americorps and Vista volunteers who deal directly with low-income families every day" will be trained to enroll children in Medicaid and in the new program.
But children are not the only ones without insurance. A new study shows that 20 percent of all uninsured people are offered health insurance by employers, but choose not to take it. Most of those people cite cost as the reason, saying premiums are too high.
The study was issued today by a research organization, the Center for Studying Health System Change.
Peter J. Cunningham, a co-author of the study, said: "If all uninsured people with access to employer-sponsored health plans were to enroll in those plans, that would do more to reduce the number of uninsured than any of the incremental expansions of coverage that have been passed or proposed in recent years."
Seven business, consumer and medical groups said today that they would work together to investigate ways of providing coverage to the uninsured. The groups include Families USA, a consumer group that supported Mr. Clinton's proposal for universal insurance coverage in 1993-94, and the Health Insurance Association of America, which helped kill the Clinton plan with television advertisements featuring "Harry" and "Louise."
Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families USA, and Charles N. Kahn 3d, president of the insurance association, said today that they wanted to force candidates to address the problems of the uninsured in next year's elections.
Those groups will offer proposals to help the uninsured at a conference in January. Detailed proposals will also be offered by the other participants: the American Hospital Association, the American Medical Association, the American Nurses Association, the Service Employees International Union and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
A poll commissioned by Families USA and the Health Insurance Association of America indicates that two-thirds of Americans would be willing to pay $50 a year in additional taxes to insure that all Americans had health coverage. The poll, conducted by Celinda Lake and William D. McInturff, also suggests that at least half of all adults would be more likely to vote for a Presidential candidate if the candidate talked about expanding access to health care.
The poll found that the number of Americans touched directly or indirectly by a lack of health insurance was much larger than commonly assumed. Twelve percent of people ages 18 to 64 said they were uninsured today. Seventeen percent said they had coverage now but had been uninsured at some time in the last three years. And 43 percent said they had been insured for three straight years, but knew someone who had been uninsured in those years.
"There are large numbers of people who drift in and out of coverage," Mr. McInturff said.
The survey, based on telephone interviews with 800 adults from Sept. 29 to Oct. 4, had a margin of sampling error of three to four percentage points.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Park Restroom Building Could Become a Wendy's

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Abandoned more than 20 years ago but still quite elegant -- yes, elegant -- an old comfort station in a small South Bronx park would be turned into a Wendy's restaurant under a deal now being negotiated.
It would be the most unusual conversion of a park structure into a restaurant since 1934, when the Sheepfold in Central Park, where the flock that grazed on Sheep Meadow spent its nights, became Tavern on the Green. 
 "It strikes me as a perfectly sensible thing to do, when you have a park, to give people a place to eat," said Henry J. Stern, the New York City Parks Commissioner. "We want to make a live park out of a dead space. If Wendy's at one corner will do it, it's worth trying."
With columns, pediments, arches and cornices, the brick comfort station at Jerome Avenue and East 170th Street looks like a little neo-classical temple set in a grove of sycamores, although the arcadian mood of Keltch Park is easily broken by the rumble of No. 4 trains along the tracks overhead.
"Show me another comfort station with Corinthian columns," said Neil W. Pariser, senior vice president of Sobro, the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation.
Under the pending deal, the Parks Department would grant a 12-year revocable license to Sobro, which would spend about $70,000 to repair and clean the structure and then sublease it to a Wendy's franchisee.
A glass-walled enclosure would be added to the east side of the 1,250-square-foot building, and its open-air portico would be enclosed in glass, yielding a space with about 80 seats. Architectural details would be preserved. The city would receive $21,000 a year, plus 2 percent of gross sales above $1.4 million.
"They are going to save a building and make money during our tenancy," Mr. Pariser said. Wendy's could be open within nine months, he said, serving the many residents of the Highbridge neighborhood who cross 170th Street on their way to buses and subways.
No one involved in the project denies that there is a hygienic stigma to the building. But they are confident that its past will be forgotten by customers.
"We should be able to overcome that," said Esther Y. Yip, a partner in the Wendy's franchise that would operate the restaurant, "but it will be in our operation, our food and how we can retain the architecture of the structure and make it a pleasant place, pleasing to the community. I feel people would rather see us than an abandoned structure. We have something to offer. Hopefully, that will separate us from the past."
Parks Department records are not too helpful on the origins of the structure. They show that a plan was filed in 1934, but the building's neo-classical touches suggest that it was built at least a decade earlier.
The portico led into an office at the south end. There was a storeroom at the north end. Men's and women's toilets were in the center. It has not been used as a comfort station since the 1970's. Mr. Stern hopes eventually to expand Keltch Park a bit northward by taking a slice out of Macombs Road.
The park was named for Rubin Keltch, an ensign who died aboard the patrol gunboat Plymouth when it was torpedoed 90 miles east of Elizabeth, N.J., in 1943. "You can assume he was a kid from the neighborhood," Mr. Stern said.
Sobro, a nonprofit organization charged with revitalizing business and creating job opportunities, began looking for a new user of the park building after it bought a former Chemical Bank branch across Jerome Avenue in 1986.
At first, Mr. Pariser said, McDonald's was interested. That deal fell through because the 12-year term was too short an amortization period. Mr. Stern suggested Wendy's instead. "Their 99-cent specials like salads and baked potatoes provide a quality food at low prices," he said.
Although it is unusual for Wendy's to adapt an existing structure of any kind, the Bronx comfort station conforms in some respects with the majority of units in the chain, as it is a one-story, freestanding brick building.
"What struck me were the arches," Ms. Yip said, referring to the windows, not her competitors. "I'm no architecture student, but there was tremendous appeal to me."
Reuben Sabbagh, proprietor of El Cheapo, a general merchandise store in the former bank, said he believed that Wendy's would be a "winner."
"It's a stunning building if it's fixed up right," he said.

HEADLINE: Union Leaders See Grim News In Labor Study

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12

 BODY:
After years of blithely ignoring labor's decline, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is force-feeding union leaders a heavy dose of bad news: that job growth is fastest in industries where unions are weakest while job losses are greatest in industries where unions are strongest.
The news came in a study commissioned by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. as a call to union leaders across the nation to organize or see the labor movement continue its decades-long decline. 
 The study, which was made public last week and is being discussed at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention here this week, also shows that the fastest-growing metropolitan areas, like Atlanta, Dallas, Houston, Miami and Phoenix, tended to have the lowest percentage of workers in unions. And the slowest-growing metropolitan areas, including Chicago and New York, which has 13 percent of the nation's union members, tended to have the highest percentage of workers in unions.
"In overall terms, the economy is moving against us," said David Chu, the labor federation's director of strategic research and the official who was in charge of the study.
For decades, following the lead of its 68 member unions, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations took little interest in organizing. But distressed about labor's declining numbers and influence, the federation's president, John J. Sweeney, has made it take a more forceful role, goading and cajoling the member unions to get more serious about organizing.
Mr. Sweeney has said he is worried that as the percentage of workers in unions has plunged to 13.9 percent today, from 35 percent four decades ago, labor's bargaining influence has atrophied, making it easier for employers to hold down wages not just for unionized workers, but for nonunion ones, too.
The study found that from 1984 to 1997, the 30 fastest-growing sectors of the economy, including hotels, child-care, finance, retail trade and airlines, added 26 million new jobs, but only 1 in 20 of workers in those industries joined unions.
The study also showed that in eight industries with the greatest job loss, including steel and automobile manufacturing, four-fifths of the 2.1 million jobs lost belonged to union members. Those jobs were often lost because of competition from imports and because managers moved operations overseas to take advantage of lower-cost labor.
"We're somewhat a victim of our own success," Mr. Chu said. "Heavily organized industries have high wages and benefits."
Despite Mr. Sweeney's calls for more organizing, only a few unions -- most notably the Service Employees International Union and the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union -- have aggressively increased their spending on organizing.
In addition, the communication workers' union has begun an uphill fight to organize workers at Microsoft and I.B.M., while the auto workers' union is stepping up efforts to organize auto parts plants. And with the apparel industry continuing to shed jobs because of imports, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees is making a big push to unionize the industrial laundry industry, having organized 9,000 laundry workers last year.
"It's a major growth industry, and it can't move offshore," said Bruce Raynor, secretary-treasurer of the needletrades union.

HEADLINE: Vote Looms, But Debate On Altering Charter Falls

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the creation of a Charter Revision Commission in June, he did not deny that a primary motivation was to block one of his principal tormentors, Mark Green, the Public Advocate, from succeeding him as Mayor.
But now that Mr. Green's future is no longer part of the 14 proposals that the commission will put before voters on Nov. 2, Mr. Giuliani, with less than three weeks to go before the election, has been largely silent on a subject he once described as vital to the city's future. 
 Although Randy M. Mastro, the commission's chairman and a former Deputy Mayor under Mr. Giuliani, said this week that the Mayor "has done everything that I would have hoped he would do up to this point," aides at City Hall said they could not remember the last time the Mayor had spoken out in support of the commission's work. In September, shortly after the commission decided to drop a proposal that could have hindered Mr. Green's mayoral ambitions, Mr. Giuliani's responses to reporters about the committee's work grew tepid.
When Sunny Mindel, the Mayor's spokeswoman, was asked yesterday about the Mayor's support of the commission's proposals, she said she would have to find out and call back. She never did. Mr. Mastro did say that the Mayor has submitted a statement in support of the commission's work in the New York City Voter Guide, a nonpartisan publication to be mailed out next week.
"Perhaps he's keeping his distance because he sees what a stinker it is," Mr. Green said yesterday of the charter initiative. But Mr. Green, whose staff spent the summer heckling the commission during a series of public hearings, has himself retreated, literally from the front row, now that the proposals no longer directly affect his political future.
Nonetheless, Mr. Green and Mr. Mastro both said they could not attribute the relative quiet on the charter changes to the absence of a brawl between two major political personalities who have been in near-constant conflict with each other for the last five years. Instead, both said it was because voters in a minor election year with only a handful of races at stake are almost entirely uninterested in the issue.
 "It's not that it's too close to call," Mr. Green said. "It's too obscure to call."
Gene Russianoff, the senior lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a civic advocacy organization, said this: "It's charter revision. You know what I mean? It's like 11 people care about it."
In fact, Mr. Russianoff and a number of critics have cared enough to say vociferously that changing the city's basic governing document is a bad idea in a year when the expected voter turnout will be 5 to 10 percent.
Although some of the commission's proposals, such as banning guns within 1,000 feet of schools, are clearly popular, critics also say that Mr. Giuliani has rushed the initiative through in a high-handed, politicized and undemocratic way. Other proposals, like a cap on budget increases, are seen by opponents as efforts to restrict the City Council's powers in favor of the Mayor. Critics are also displeased that voters will have to approve or reject the entire initiative instead of individual proposals.
Both Mr. Green and Mr. Mastro made promises of increased activity from each of their sides closer to the election. Mr. Mastro said there would be "some public education campaign," although he also said he had not decided what form it might take. Mr. Green said that his side would pass out leaflets in the week before the campaign. But neither talked about the kind of television advertising wars that some opponents of the charter revision had predicted in the summer.
Mr. Green's side consists of a coalition of labor groups, who are positioning to oppose Mr. Giuliani in his presumed Senate campaign, as well as Vote No on Charter Inc., an advocacy group led by Richard Schrader, who went on leave as Mr. Green's chief of public affairs to campaign against the changes.
Under the original proposals, the commission would have required a special election within 60 days if the Mayor leaves office early, as is possible if Mr. Giuliani runs for the United States Senate in 2000 and is elected with a year left in his term as Mayor. Under the Charter's current provisions, the Public Advocate automatically finishes the term of any Mayor who leaves office early.
The special election proposal was immediately attacked by critics who said Mr. Giuliani was engaging in a political vendetta against Mr. Green, who by the nature of his job and his personality has gnawed at the Mayor since both men took office in 1994. Mr. Mastro retreated under the assaults on the proposal, and last month announced that the commission would delay the special election provision until 2002, when both Mr. Green and Mr. Giuliani are out of office.
The City Council has also opposed the changes as cynical and an assault on democracy, and plans hearings next week to urge voters to reject the charter revision.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "REVISING THE CHARTER: The Initiative for the November Ballot"
 
Here are the 14 proposed revisions in the City Charter to be voted on next month:
 
* Imposing a cap, tied to the inflation rate, on increases in the city budget.
 
* Requiring that at least half of any budget surplus be set aside for a fiscal emergency or other need that the Mayor and the City Council jointly decide is in the city's best interest.
 
* Requiring at least a two-thirds vote of the City Council to impose a new tax or increase an existing tax, and requiring a four-fifths vote of the Council to override a mayoral veto of a new tax or tax increase.
 
* Making the city's Human Rights Commission a permanent agency, and incorporating the city's Human Rights Law into the Charter.
 
* Requiring that a special election be held within two months to fill any mayoral vacancy.
 
* Making the Administration for Children's Services a permanent agency.
 
* Merging the Department of Health and the Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services.
 
* Creating an Organized Crime Control Commission to handle the regulatory, investigative and licensing functions of agencies that oversee the carting industry, public wholesale food markets and shipboard gambling.
 
* Requiring that domestic violence services be coordinated through the Mayor's Office of Operations.
 
* Making the Mayor's Office of Immigrant Affairs a permanent agency, and incorporating the city's laws protecting the rights of immigrants into the Charter.
 
* Eliminating from the Charter detailed requirements concerning bidding on city contracts, streamlining the city's procurement process.
 
* Authorizing a centralized review of the integrity of vendors who want to do business with the city.
 
* Creating gun-free zones within 1,000 feet of schools.
 
* Requiring safety-locking devices on legally owned guns.

HEADLINE: U.S. Urges Pakistani Army To Restore Democracy Soon

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration urged the Pakistani military today to restore democratic government as quickly as possible, but at the same time officials acknowledged that Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's rule had been increasingly corrupt and autocratic.
The overthrow of Mr. Sharif is the latest in a series of turbulent events on the subcontinent that have left the Administration fearful that Islamic militancy will strengthen in Pakistan, a poor and heavily populated country that tested nuclear weapons last year. 
 Administration officials said they did not believe that the control of Pakistan's nuclear capacity was significantly affected by the military takeover. Under Prime Minister Sharif, the Pakistani Army managed the nuclear sites and devices and maintained final authority over them, they said.
"The military has custodial control over nuclear weapons," a senior Administration official said. "We have been assured by Pakistani civilian authorities in the past they have control over their release. How this is playing out with the military government we will have to see. We see this as a political crisis, not one concerning the control or use of nuclear weapons."
Pakistan's slide toward chaos as it faced a hostile neighbor, India, which also tested nuclear weapons last year, helped make the subcontinent one of the world's most precarious regions, officials said.
"The last thing we need is a chaotic Pakistan where you have democracy put on the back shelf, the economy in a shambles and we get a Talibanization of Pakistan," said a senior United States official. Islamic fundamentalism has become more prevalent in the Pakistani Army since the military was cut off from United States aid in the early 1990's, officials said.
The Administration said that after a televised address tonight by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, proclaiming army rule, it remained unclear what steps he would take next.
"We want to see the earliest possible restoration of democracy in Pakistan," said James P. Rubin, the chief State Department spokesman. "We hope General Musharraf will set forth clear plans for the restoration of a civilian government in Pakistan."
It is possible, officials said, that General Musharraf may follow the pattern of the last two military takeovers in Pakistan and appoint a government of civilian technocrats to run the country.
Rumors of a possible coup in Pakistan had been surfacing since Prime Minister Sharif, under pressure from President Clinton in July, urged General Musharraf to withdraw his forces from the Indian-held side of the cease-fire line in the disputed Himalayan territory of Kashmir.
That withdrawal has been cited by the White House as one of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy successes this year.
But the withdrawal was unpopular on the streets of Pakistan and in the military. Mr. Sharif reacted by cracking down on opposition parties, the courts and the press and downgrading the status of the President.
In September, Shahbaz Sharif, the brother of the Prime Minister, came to Washington to meet with Administration officials to follow up on the July meeting. In the process, he warned of the worsening domestic crisis, a senior Administration official said.
Soon after, opposition leaders began to tell American officials the same things. The State Department then issued a public statement warning Pakistan not to undertake any "extraconstitutional" measures.
At about the same time, in late September, the Pakistani chief of intelligence, Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Ziauddin, visited Washington and warned the director of Central Intelligence, George Tenet, and others that tensions between Mr. Sharif and General Musharraf were coming to a climax, an official said.
The possibility of a coup appeared to abate slightly when Mr. Sharif formally extended General Musharraf's tenure into 2001, but revived again, officials said.
Two weeks ago, the Administration warned Mr. Sharif against continuing his "undermining of democracy."
General Musharraf became the second army chief to be dismissed by the Prime Minister within a year, a situation that the military interpreted as a threat to its traditional role.
The Prime Minister handpicked General Musharraf, a commando-trained, headstrong officer with less education than his predecessor, Gen. Jehangir Karamat, who was fired last October after making unfavorable public comments about the Prime Minister's style of leadership.
The United States cut military aid to the Pakistani Army in the early 1990's after President Bush could no longer certify to Congress that Pakistan was not in possession of nuclear devices.
Traditionally, the Pakistani Army has been a stabilizing influence, but it has become more vulnerable to Islamic influences in recent years. This was especially so as the tradition of better-educated men joining the military faded, experts said.
In the last year, as the economy has weakened, army officers have collected electric bill payments and done other menial tasks to try to keep the country running, said Michael Krepon, the president of the Henry L. Stimson Center, which studies arms control issues.
"The army does not want to run the country but the army wants to be the main repository of power," Mr. Krepon said.
But he added that there were increasing possibilities of the army's fracturing.
"There are eight or nine core commanders in Pakistan," he said. "The army has one of two choices: they could rally behind a guy who is a loose cannon like Musharraf or they could divide."
If the army divided, then the question of command and control over the nuclear devices would come to the fore, he said.

HEADLINE: COUP IN PAKISTAN: THE OVERVIEW;
PAKISTAN ARMY SEIZES POWER HOURS AFTER PRIME MINISTER DISMISSES HIS MILITARY CHIEF

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Prime Minister of Pakistan fired the powerful army chief Tuesday afternoon, and hours later the army struck back with a swift, apparently bloodless coup. Troops surrounded the Prime Minister's home, closed all the major airports and shut down the state-run television and radio stations for several hours.
At 2:50 A.M. today the army chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, addressing the nation on state television in a tone of patriotic earnestness, said the military had ousted Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and his Government to stop any further politicization or destabilization of the military. 
 He was apparently referring to Mr. Sharif's efforts to strengthen his hold over the courts and the military, and to his success at pushing through a constitutional amendment that had ended a President's power to dismiss an elected Prime Minister -- a vestige of military rule.
General Musharraf offered no timetable for elections, nor did he say whether he would rule personally or whether the army would install a caretaker government.
"Despite all my advice," said the general, neatly attired in a camouflage uniform and wire-rimmed glasses, "they tried to interfere with the armed forces, the last remaining viable institution in which all of you take so much pride and look up to at all times for stability, unity and integrity of our beloved country."
 A military spokesman, quoted by Reuters, said Mr. Sharif; his brother Shahbaz, chief minister of Punjab Province, and the intelligence chief, Lieut. Gen. Mohammad Ziauddin, were all taken into "protective custody."
Mr. Sharif's sudden, unexplained decision to fire General Musharraf was risky; in Pakistan, generals have ruled for almost half of its 52 years as an independent nation.
The firing came only a year after Mr. Sharif had replaced another army chief who had sought a greater role for the army and technocrats in running the country.
There was virtually no public protest against the coup, and some demonstrators celebrated Mr. Sharif's demise, including one group near Parliament House in Islamabad, the capital.
Mr. Sharif, whose party won a landslide victory in February 1997, had become increasingly unpopular because of the deteriorating economy and uncontrolled sectarian violence, and because of Mr. Sharif's handling of a crisis over Kashmir.
The military takeover is likely to have serious international repercussions for Pakistan. A State Department spokesman said that if a coup were confirmed, the United States would call for the earliest possible restoration of democracy and would not carry on "business as usual" with Pakistan.
India, too, voiced "grave concern" and placed its military on high alert along the border.
The deepening political crisis in Pakistan raises new questions about the prospects for restarting peace talks with India. These two new nuclear powers, bitter antagonists who have fought three wars, edged close a fourth this summer over the disputed territory of Kashmir.
Relations between Mr. Sharif and the military had soured over his handling of the Kashmir conflict. India fought intensely this summer to drive out infiltrators who had crossed from Pakistan to occupy Indian-held portions of Kashmir, a Himalayan territory both Pakistan and India want for their own.
After meeting with President Clinton in July, Mr. Sharif had called for the withdrawal of the infiltrators, who Western analysts now believe were mainly Pakistani soldiers. Army leaders, including General Musharraf, saw the withdrawal as a capitulation to American pressure, the abandonment of a rare military victory over India and a humiliation of the army.
Still, the timing of the coup was curious. Only two weeks ago, apparently attempting to quash rumors about a clash with military leaders, Mr. Sharif stated that the general would complete his term. It is not clear whether something happened since then that inspired Mr. Sharif's abrupt decision to fire General Musharraf, who was in Sri Lanka when he was dismissed.
The drama began to unfold just a few hours after the state news service reported at about 5 P.M. on Tuesday that General Musharraf was being immediately retired.
Troops began moving through Islamabad. They seized the Cabinet building and climbed over the fence around the television station. All flights were canceled as the troops took over the major airports.
General Musharraf said in his speech that as he tried to return to Pakistan from Sri Lanka, his commercial flight, short of fuel, was ordered to land outside of Pakistan, endangering the lives of all the passengers.
"Thanks be to Allah, this evil design was thwarted through speedy army action," said the general, whose flight landed in Karachi.
Mr. Sharif's home was cordoned off and the road to it blocked. There were also reports that the Information Minister, Mushahid Hussain; the Foreign Minister, Sartaj Aziz, and the Kashmir Affairs Minister, Majid Malik, were under house arrest.
As accounts of the army's takeover of Government buildings began to come in from witnesses, there was confusion about exactly what was going on.
Telephone calls to Government and army spokesmen in Islamabad rang unanswered. The television station went dark soon after announcing that the Prime Minister had fired the general.
The first official confirmation that the army had taken action against the Government came at 10:15 P.M., when the state television came back to life and a news reader announced that Mr. Sharif had been dismissed. After midnight, the state television announced that all banks would be closed today.
Then, finally, at almost 3 A.M., the general laid out the reasons for the coup. He said the country was in a state of "turmoil and uncertainty," and the economy in a state of collapse. He accused Mr. Sharif's Government of systematically destroying the institutions of Pakistan.
The armed forces had taken over as a last resort to restore stability, he said, and he pleaded with the public to continue to be calm.
"I have done so with all sincerity, loyalty and selfless devotion to the country," he said. "And the armed forces are firmly behind me."

HEADLINE: Flak in the Great Hair War;
African-Americans vs. Dominicans, Rollers at the Ready

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Amid black hooded dryers, maroon floor tiles and walls awash in pink, Ana Vasquez is making her magic. Ms. Vasquez, a 39-year-old hairstylist at Classic II Unisex Salon in Hamilton Heights, alternates among three clients, washing, setting and blowdrying their tresses in less than an hour and a half.
In upper Manhattan -- at 143d Street and Broadway, to be exact -- the Dominican-born beautician has a following. Maybe she's not quite as hot with hoi polloi as Frederic Fekkai is with the fabulous and famous, but her name is known nonetheless. Classic II, a narrow storefront with four styling stations, is crowded during the week and clogged on weekends: standing room only. 
 On this northern stretch of Broadway, hair salons that are owned and operated by Dominicans are everywhere, and inside, black Americans are present in great numbers. The same scene is repeated throughout the city, where Dominicans have made significant inroads into the African-American hair market.
Much like Koreans, who have made nail salons their franchise, and Indians, Afghans and Pakistanis, who have made cab-driving theirs, Dominican immigrants have made beauty their business in New York, bringing with them their own hair-straightening techniques and recipes for home-brewed conditioners.
"They own more salons than any other Hispanic group," said Barbara Gonzalez, executive director of the Dominican-American Chamber of Commerce in Washington Heights. "That's one of the ways our community contributes to the economy of the city and country."
Not surprisingly, African-American salon owners and stylists accuse the Dominicans of everything from incompetence to undercutting with shamelessly low prices.
Yet Dominican stylists have increasingly been able to build up a varied clientele among African-American women -- from bookkeepers to babysitters and writers to waiters -- largely through word of mouth.
Ava Griffiths, a Jamaican college student who was getting her hair chemically straightened at Family Hair Dresser in Bushwick, Brooklyn, swears by the Dominican-owned and operated shop. All of her friends, she said, go to Dominican beauty parlors. "They do good hair," said Ms. Griffiths, 23, a student at York College. "The perms are bouncy."
Joan Mason, a 29-year-old African-American from Rosedale, Queens, treks through the borough to have her hair, a waterfall of dark brown curls, trimmed at Z-2000, a Dominican-owned salon in Corona. Ms Mason is staunchly supportive of salons operated by Dominicans. "They make the hair feel natural, good," she declared, "just like you stepped off the cover of some magazine."
The secret to their success seems to be multifaceted. Most Dominicans -- many of whom are black or of mixed race and accustomed to handling black hair -- set a client's wet hair in jumbo-sized rollers. When it's dry, they blow out most of the curl. This process, according to Dominicans, is less damaging to the hair than the typical method of washing and blow drying because less heat is used.
Ms. Vasquez also uses two conditioners: one deep conditioner with which the client sits under the dryer, then another that stays in the hair. "You don't fry an egg without oil in it, do you?" Ms. Vasquez said, explaining the theory behind the second conditioner.
Another difference between black American and Dominican salons: Dominican-owned beauty parlors are by and large less expensive than African-American-owned shops. A wash-and-set at a Dominican salon might cost as little as $10 or $15, while an African-American salon on average charges twice that or more.
Statistics on the number of Dominican-owned shops in New York are not available, according to Dr. Romana Hernandez, assistant professor of the Latino Study Program at the University of Massachussetts in Boston. But Dominicans, who number a half million in New York City, tend to be more entrepreneurial, she said. "Seven percent of Dominicans own their own businesses" in New York, she said, "compared with 5.8 percent of other Hispanics."
The 35-year-old proprietor of Z-2000, Daisy Diaz, estimates that 90 percent of her customers are African-American. Her shop has four stylists, all but one from the Dominican Republic.
Blanca Rodriguez, a Dominican and the owner-operator of Blanca Unisex Salon in upper Manhattan, draws a large black American clientele, too. Asked if her African-American patrons have a preference for Dominican stylists, she said, in Spanish, "I've heard some blacks say that."
Stylists and owners of New York's African-American salons have been stung by the competition, and aren't above lobbing barbs at the Dominicans.
Theresa Sampson, an African-American stylist, said that many of her clients who fled to Dominican salons had returned with hair breakage. "I don't think a lot of their stylists are licensed," said Ms. Sampson, who works at Marion's Beauty Shop on Astoria Boulevard in East Elmhurst, Queens.
An African-American stylist known only as Ms. Linda agreed. "Their treatments are more affordable," said Ms. Linda, who works for R. Juno's of New York, also on Astoria Boulevard. "But my clients return with hair breakage, totally unhealthy hair. You get what you pay for. I think they're putting cheap products in brand-name bottles."
At Ebony 2000, a black-owned shop in midtown Manhattan, Merna McNeil -- a co-owner -- said that Dominican salons catered to a young inner-city crowd but not to her clients -- professional women. "We treat with more courtesy," said Ms. McNeil, who also accused Dominicans of mixing products. "We don't play chemists here," she said. "We don't cut corners."
Denying the accusations, Rosa Olivares, the owner of Family Hair Dresser, said, "I wouldn't have so many African-Americans returning if I caused breakage," adding that she used some of the finest hair-care products around. Before she purchased her own shop two years ago, she worked in a black-owned shop in Jamaica, Queens. Blacks would come in, she said, asking if there was a Dominican hairdresser available to do their hair.
Many of the Dominican proprietors and stylists said they didn't feel a rivalry with African-Americans. "In fact," said Juana Ramirez, owner of Twin Beauty Salon in upper Manhattan, "when they come in looking for someone to do dreadlocks or braids, we send them to 125th Street."
That's the right attitude, said Adriano Espaillat, the city's first Dominican assemblyman, who represents Washington Heights, a densely populated precinct with the city's largest Dominican population.
"There's plenty of hair around for everybody," he observed. "Unless you're like me, going a little bald."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Parcells at a Loss to Prevent Jets From Losing

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 12

 BODY:
There have been moments when Bill Parcells must have been as disappointed as he was today. But not many.
He seemed confounded about whether the Jets were going to find their offensive touch. For the second time in his tenure with the Jets, they failed to score a touchdown in losing by 16-6 to the Jaguars on Monday night. 
 Both of those games without a touchdown also were with Rick Mirer at quarterback -- both within the last month. And chances are running out on a Jets season that is now 1-4.
"We've got 11 games left," Parcells said, "and four more losses and we're out."
Perhaps Parcells was contemplating a quarterback change against the Colts Sunday at the Meadowlands. Although he would neither confirm nor deny a change, Parcells does not have many options. Ray Lucas, Mirer's backup, has never started a National Football League game, and Tom Tupa, the punter and sometime quarterback, last started in 1991. As for a trade -- the deadline is next Tuesday -- Parcells ruled that out for economic reasons.
So unless Parcells believes a shift would create a psychological lift, Mirer will take the snaps again.
But whatever Parcells does will make the coach uncomfortable.
"I just can't describe to you the combination of things -- it seemed like almost everyone on offense had five or six plays that affected our ability to move the ball," Parcells said. He also said that only two offensive linemen had a successful game.
"It's a potpourri of things," Parcells said. "We miss a block, we shorten the routes, we throw the ball too low."
The Jets' offensive potpourri was painful to watch:
*Curtis Martin had his best run of the season, 24 yards -- but averaged only 2 yards a carry on his 17 other attempts.
*Mirer completed half of his 38 passes, averaging barely 4 yards a throw.
*The Jets missed 13 of 16 attempts to convert third downs. One failed series ended with boos from the crowd, a sound these current Jets had rarely heard from the home fans.
*Nine of 13 drives ended after only three or four plays.
And yet, said Parcells, "from a defensive-points standpoint, we did all right."
"The special teams did O.K," he said.
Indeed, despite a sputtering offense, the Jets were in position to tie the score late in the game. Jacksonville, now 4-1 and supposedly one of the league's powers, did not put away the Jets.
The Jets approached midfield with fewer than seven minutes remaining. As he has been doing since Game 2, Parcells was calling the plays. It was fourth-and-1 on the Jets' 45.
"We had the offense we wanted," Parcells said. "We had the defense lined up the way we wanted." The play, he said, should have been good enough to reach the Jaguars' secondary.
Martin went off left tackle. But Blake Spence, the backup tight end, missed his block and Martin was hauled down short of the first down. The Jaguars did not score when they got the ball, but they put the Jets in bad field position on the subsequent punt.
Starting from his own 2, Mirer got nowhere. Another fourth-down play -- this one a pass to Eric Green -- was slightly high but playable. Green couldn't hold it, along with the Jets' last best chance.
Asked whether he thought Parcells would yank him following his noncommittal remarks, Mirer said: "I guess there's always that chance, but I'm not going to react until something happens. I felt like I made as good decisions as I can during the game, but it wasn't productive enough. Some days will be harder than others and that was one of those days."
Mirer's main receiver was Keyshawn Johnson, who spent much of the game grimacing after failed plays -- not merely when Mirer didn't spot him, but on blocks that failed and runs that came up short.
"We're not good enough to have mistakes right now," Johnson said today, somewhat recovered from the anger and frustration of Monday night. He was the game's leading receiver with 8 catches for 94 yards, but 2 receptions and 36 yards came on an aborted, go-for-broke final drive.
"I don't care who the quarterback is as long as we win," Johnson said.
And Martin, who is still looking for his initial 100-yard rushing performance of the season, said: "We can't get it consistently. That's what we're all trying to figure out."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bank of New York Executive Resigns in Laundering Inquiry

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
One of two executives suspended in August at the Bank of New York, resigned today and said that the bank had unfairly abandoned her in the Federal investigation of possible money laundering at the bank.
The executive, Natasha Gurfinkel Kagalovsky, a senior vice president who ran the Eastern European division of the bank, said in a letter to the chairman and chief executive officer, Thomas A. Renyi, that "not once during this investigation, with all the media it has had, has the bank seen fit to publicly or privately defend me and let it be known that there is not one negative thing to say about me." 
 A spokesman for the bank declined to comment except to say that the bank had a copy of the letter and that "we acknowledge the resignation and wish her well."
Law enforcement authorities here and abroad have been examining the suspicious movement of $7.5 billion from Russia through a handful of accounts at the bank since 1996. Although much of that money was apparently related to schemes to avoid taxes and duties, investigators have said they believe that a significant part of the funds may have derived from illicit activities in Russia.
Ms. Kagalovsky, who is living in London with her husband and also has a home in New York, has not been charged with wrongdoing by any law enforcement agency. Last week, a Federal grand jury indictment was unsealed in Manhattan that charged three others, a former Bank of New York executive, Lucy Edwards; her husband, Peter Berlin, and a business associate, Aleksey Volkov, with running an illegal wire-transfer business in New York through three companies, including the Benex International Company and Becs International L.L.C.
Ms. Edwards, who worked for Ms. Kagalovsky at the bank, was suspended by the bank on Aug. 18, after press inquiries about the Federal investigation. The bank dismissed Ms. Edwards shortly after her suspension for what the bank called "gross misconduct."
Investigators have focused on Ms. Kagalovsky not only because she supervised Ms. Edwards, but also because she played a leading role in securing business for the bank in Russia. Many bank customers in Russia were large banks that collapsed in the wake of the financial crisis there last year. The Russian banks have been criticized for freewheeling ways. One, Bank Menatep, was overseen by Ms. Kagalovsky's husband, Konstantin Kagalovsky, the bank's former vice chairman.
But Ms. Kagalovsky's lawyer, Stanley Arkin, said beyond innuendo surrounding the Kagalovskys' relationship, investigators have no grounds to be suspicious of his client.
Mr. Arkin said Ms. Kagalovsky is not a target of the Federal investigation and is not formally cooperating with it, but said she is prepared to answer any questions posed to her. "We have nothing to hide," he said.
Moreover, Mr. Arkin added, the Benex and Becs accounts under scrutiny were not opened in Ms. Kagalovsky's division and were not under her supervision. The accounts, according to the indictment, were controlled by Ms. Edwards and Mr. Berlin. But the bank declined to say who supervised the accounts.
People with knowledge of the investigation said the Bank of New York was not preparing to discharge Ms. Kagalovsky. Mr. Arkin said there were no legal reasons behind her decision to resign. He said the decision was based on the desire to move on professionally and leave a bank that refused to support her.
In her letter, Ms. Kagalovsky said she has been "living in professional limbo" and "subjected to painful baseless rumor arising out of the federal investigation." She said the bank's abandonment of her had left her to "swing in the wind."
The United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan and the Federal Bureau of Investigation declined to comment on Ms. Kagalovsky's resignation. The bank has not been charged with wrongdoing and has been cooperating with the inquiry.

HEADLINE: CON EDISON BUYING A NEIGHBOR UTILITY FOR $3.29 BILLION

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Consolidated Edison Company agreed last night to buy Northeast Utilities for $3.29 billion in cash and stock, according to people close to the talks, in a deal that could eventually bring cheaper power to its customers.
The deal, which will give Con Edison access to lower-cost electricity, is the company's biggest move so far to protect its base of three million customers, who will be able to buy power at lower rates from outside companies as New York deregulates its utility market. Con Edison will raise its customer base to 4.7 million and extend its reach as far north as New Hampshire. 
 The transaction, which could be announced as early as today, is also a move to become more competitive in the fast-paced environment of deregulation, which allows customers to choose their provider of electricity. Northeast, the largest utility in New England in terms of customers, has been aggressively preparing for the new era in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire, which are in various stages of deregulation.
Though Northeast had to spin off its power-generating plants as part of the process, it has bought plants -- including some it previously owned -- and built up a source of cheap power, which Con Edison could sell to its customers, possibly lowering their rates eventually. Northeast has also built an organization to market that power throughout the region.
And in a sign of the perceived low value of nuclear power plants, the deal values Northeast at a higher price if it sells two units of its Millstone nuclear plant in Connecticut.
Dale Bryk, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group, said that the transaction could be positive for consumers and environmentalist because it could result in a fresh evaluation of the Millstone nuclear complex independent of Northeast Utilities.
And Ashok Gupta, an energy expert with the council in New York, said, "These mergers are necessary, and they are going to, over time, provide economic efficiency gains that are helpful to consumers."
Deregulation has moved slowly for residential customers so far because the companies that want to market power have not been able to make much money in the early stages, but more players are expected in the future.
Most residential customers have already begun to benefit through rate cuts. For example, Con Edison agreed to cut its rates 10 percent under New York's order to deregulate in 1997. Even though a part of Con Edison's customer base is open to competition, few companies have been aggressive in marketing because it is difficult to make a profit selling to small customers. But as more Con Edison customers are made available to outside companies, the profitability will improve and alternate suppliers should offer further cuts in the cost of electricity. New York's utility market is expected to be fully deregulated by 2002.
The reductions will not be large, however. The cost of power makes up only a portion of an average residential bill, which is about $50 a month. Most charges actually cover the cost of delivery, and those charges will remain regulated. New Yorkers, however, can expect an aggressive marketing pitch from the subsidiaries of the merged Con Edison and Northeast Utilities, which are competing with other marketers.
Under terms of the deal, which the boards of both companies approved yesterday, Con Edison, based in Manhattan, will pay $25 a share in cash and stock for the outstanding shares of Northeast, based in Berlin, Conn. An additional $1 a share will be paid if units 2 and 3 of Millstone are sold.
Millstone has had one of the nation's most troubled histories for a nuclear plant. Unit 1 of Millstone is to be retired and decommissioned. The other two units cost Northeast dearly, with huge expenses for maintenance and the cost of buying expensive power when they were not operating. In 1997 and 1998, the utility had large losses because of its troubles and suspended its dividend for four years. But Northeast has put a lot of its troubles behind it and has seen its earnings recover. It plans to reinstate its dividend in December.
The two operating nuclear units have been put up for sale but are expected to bring low offers, if any. Some analysts said that should mean that Northeast will sell them at a loss. But the sale of the plants is important to Con Edison, which analysts said did not want to acquire more nuclear plants.
Shares of Northeast Utilities rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $21.25, while Con Edison fell 75 cents, to $36.4375.
The people close to the deal said the two utilities expected savings of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion over the next 10 years. Whether there will be layoffs has yet to be determined, people close to the deal said.
Eugene R. McGrath, the chairman and chief executive of Con Edison, will have those positions in the merged company while Michael G. Morris, the chairman, president and chief executive of Northeast will become president, according to the people close to the deal.
Mr. McGrath did not have an easy time reaching the agreement. Since word leaked out last week that talks with Northeast were under way, Con Edison's stock has been pummeled on concerns that a merger with Northeast would depress Con Edison's strong earnings.
The deal is the second step to expand Con Edison's reach.
In May 1998, Con Edison acquired Orange and Rockland Utilities for $1.5 billion, adding to its customer base and expanding its reach northward. The agreement to buy Northeast, however, puts Mr. McGrath and his company on a national stage to compete with other large utilities. Under Mr. Morris, Northeast has also moved quickly and aggressively to prepare itself for deregulation.
"They have a lot of access to customer throughout the Northeast," said Robert Rubin, a utility analyst with Bear, Stearns.
Of Con Edison's strategy, he said: "This is no surprise. They are not doing anything crazy."
