HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
In the specialized world of technology, two multimillion-dollar quests for more attention.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
TWO specialized high-technology magazines are waging multimillion-dollar campaigns to broaden their reach.
PC Computing, which is published by Ziff-Davis, will revamp its content and design starting with its December issue, in part to halt a decline in advertising pages. It is promoting these changes to the advertisers in a campaign that has a budget of more than $2 million and will run through November. 
 And Red Herring, a six-year-old, privately held magazine that focuses on the venture capital and entrepreneurial side of Silicon Valley, is running a $5 million advertising and promotion campaign to heighten awareness of its brand both in the general business community and among media buyers. Besides the magazine, Red Herring runs a Web site, Redherring.com, and a conference business. Ziff-Davis, whose majority owner is the Softbank Corporation of Japan, has an 11 percent stake in Red Herring.
The 11-year-old PC Computing, whose readers are mostly executives who make technology purchases, is changing the focus of its coverage from computer products to the effect of technology on business.
Its new campaign, by Bigmouth, an agency in San Francisco, tries to place PC Computing in the same category as more general interest business magazines like Business Week, Forbes and Fortune.
Through next month, the advertising is appearing in trade publications like Advertising Age and Adweek and through direct mail to existing and potential advertisers. The campaign also includes what Bigmouth calls "rich E-mail," animated E-mail accompanied by music that presents PC Computing's message to media directors and links them to a special Web site that explains the changes in the magazine.
The advertising is a bold tomato red, the color of PC Computing's logo, and the copy is somewhat cheeky. A three-page ad running in trade publications, for example, says: "Like Business Week and Inc. would be, if they offered real business solutions. Like Forbes and Wired would be, if they served some practical purpose. The new PC Computing helps managers boost productivity, increase profits, win new customers and, ultimately, make the cover of one of those fancy coffee-table business books."
Todd Spina, the executive creative director of Bigmouth, said, "We put up the names of the competition to put PC Computing in the same space as Forbes, Fortune and Fast Company and to move them away from PC World."
The campaign for Red Herring, designed by Swirl, another agency in San Francisco, consists of print and radio advertising that will run through December. Some print ads, geared toward advertisers, are appearing in trade publications. Others, intended to attract new readers and Web site visitors, are running in The Wall Street Journal, USA Today, The Economist, Wired and Forbes.
In addition, four 30-second radio ads are being broadcast in Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and San Francisco.
One print ad, created for prospective subscribers and Web site visitors, says, "Now that business has been turned on its head, maybe it's time you used ours." Another says: "Even leaders are led. In today's dynamic business world, no one succeeds alone. You need information and insight that translate into real action. You need Red Herring."
Eric Roos, a partner at Swirl, said, "Everyone's jumped on the Internet bandwagon, but Red Herring built the bandwagon."
"Red Herring is not trendy," he added. "It's not about hype. It provides high-minded, clear business information as it relates to the world of technology."
Linda Kopp, a senior managing editor of Simba Information, a division of Primedia that tracks computer magazines, suggested that Ziff-Davis was refashioning PC Computing because it had recently lost a significant amount of advertising to general business publications. According to Adscope in Eugene, Ore., which follows advertising for high-technology companies, PC Computing's total ad pages fell to 2,625 last year from 3,056 in 1995. Pages are down almost 20 percent for the first nine months of 1999 compared with those in the corresponding period a year earlier.
"The traditional computer trade press has had a tough time of late attracting advertising pages," Ms. Kopp said. "It's natural for them to look at how to get a piece of the pie that used to be theirs back again."
Michael Hiatt, who is the vice president for media services at Blain Olsen White Gurr Advertising in Salt Lake City and the publishing director of Mediadirector.com, a Web site for media directors with high-technology clients, called PC Computing's ad campaign "a bit overstated."
"But there is a story for them to tell," he added. "The proof will be in the execution, and in their ability to transcend gizmos, PC's, how fast PC's are."
Sam Whitmore, editor of Mediasurvey.com, an on-line newsletter that tracks technology publications, said Ziff-Davis had no choice but to refocus PC Computing. "They don't have a title in the hottest part of the publishing business, which talks about new opportunities in the Internet economy," he said. "They're really late to the game."
He also suggested that Red Herring needed to market itself aggressively. If it does not, he warned, it risks "getting its lunch eaten by everybody from Upside to the new Time publication on technology."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
TURKEY: FORBIDDEN TO LEAVE -- A woman from a religion-oriented party was forbidden to leave the country while a prosecutor draws up charges of subversion against her. The politician, Merve Kavakci, was elected to Parliament this year but forbidden to take the oath of office because she insisted on wearing her Muslim head scarf. Later, after it was discovered that she had failed to disclose she held an American passport, she was stripped of her Turkish citizenship.
 Stephen Kinzer (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: ULSTER TALKS IN LONDON -- The leaders of Northern Ireland's political parties taking part in the peace settlement review under former Senator George J. Mitchell are meeting for two days at an undisclosed location in the London area under an agreement not to speak with reporters in an effort to help focus efforts to break the stalemate.
 Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: 'BLOODY SUNDAY' ANONYMITY -- The inquiry into the Bloody Sunday killing of 14 civil rights protesters by paratroopers in Londonderry 27 years ago granted anonymity to all soldiers present at the shootings. Relatives of the dead said they deplored the decision, but a Ministry of Defense spokesman said, "It provides a crucial measure of protection for all military witnesses who could have been subjected to the threat of terrorist reprisal."
 Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BELGIUM: 6 MORE APPLY TO EUROPE -- In a move to accelerate the expansion of the 15-nation European Union, the executive commission in Brussels proposed that six more nations be allowed to start membership negotiations. Talks are under way with Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Malta. The commission has now agreed to consider eventual membership for Slovakia, Latvia, Lithuania, Bulgaria, Romania and Malta.
 Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
GREECE: DEPORTED CHRISTIANS WELCOMED -- The Government announced it would welcome a group of 25 Christian pilgrims, 18 of them Irish, who were deported from Israel as a doomsday cult and then refused entry to Cyprus. A spokesman for the group denied they planned a mass suicide attempt in Bethlehem.
 (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: ZHIRINOVSKY'S NEW BLOC -- Vladimir Zhirinovsky set up a new bloc to run for Parliament after his Liberal Democratic Party was barred from December elections. Facing an Oct. 24 registration deadline, Mr. Zhirinovsky had a congress of two political parties with which he is closely associated form the Zhirinovsky Bloc, which will submit its papers today.
 (AP)

SYRIA: PESSIMISM ON TALKS -- An official newspaper voiced pessimism over the prospects of an Israeli-Syrian peace, accusing the Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, of having "blocked all the routes" that might lead to the resumption of talks. The Syrian Government welcomed Mr. Barak's election last May, but the mood has turned much darker because Mr. Barak has refused to endorse what Syria says is a previous Israeli commitment to withdraw fully from the Golan Heights.
 Douglas Jehl (NYT)
 
ISRAEL: PRISONER PACT -- Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have agreed on the release of more Palestinians jailed for anti-Israeli acts, negotiators said, overcoming an obstacle that had hindered the revived peace talks. The prisoner release, the second under a September agreement, was to have taken place last Friday. It was postponed when the sides could not agree on a list of prisoners, who are now scheduled for release tomorrow.
 (AP)

AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: FISHERS STRIKE -- More than 5,000 west coast fishers and fishery workers have gone on strike, forcing factories to halt processing of pilchards and anchovies and threatening export supplies. Workers have been locked in a dispute over a wage increase, with management offering 7.5 percent and the Food and Allied Workers Union demanding 10.5 percent.
 Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
ASIA

ARGENTINA: PERONIST PICKS UP -- A Gallup poll of 1,537 people suggests Gov. Eduardo Duhalde of Buenos Aires, the presidential candidate of the governing Justicialist Party, is gaining strength before the Oct. 24 election, but but remains far behind the Buenos Aires Mayor, Fernando de la Rua, left. Mr. de la Rua, of the Alianza coalition, leads by 12 points compared with 19 points a month ago. Mr. de la Rua has 43 percent support, Mr. Duhalde 31 percent and former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo 10 percent. The poll had a margin of error of 3 to 4 percentage points.
 Clifford Krauss (NYT)

Mr. Annan met with ethnic Albanian and Serbian leaders.

 Barbara Crossette (NYT)

HEADLINE: The Uses of a Coup

BYLINE: By Robert C. McFarlane; Robert C. McFarlane was national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan from 1983 to 1985.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Governing Pakistan is a near-impossible task. Consider the daunting realities: 25 percent literacy; 70 percent of the gross domestic product devoted to defense or debt service; one million refugees from the war in Afghanistan still living in Pakistan; a home-grown terrorist cadre being trained in local religious schools sponsored by neighboring Muslim countries; Afghan-based drug trafficking; the constant threat that the 40-year, often violent confrontation with nuclear-armed India could spin out of control, and a stagnant economy with virtually no renewal conceivable for years.
Pakistan has the superficial trappings of a democratic system -- a parliament, courts and an elected government. But in fact it is a feudal cabal, now with nuclear weapons, in which a few families struggle with one another to achieve absolute power and are inevitably, in Lord Acton's phrase, corrupted absolutely. Four times in the past 10 years, elected governments have been brought down by popular outrage over corruption or ineptitude or both. The military has governed Pakistan for almost half its 50-year history -- by most accounts the more stable and prosperous half. 
 The current parlous conditions, combined with political history, call into question whether democracy can function at this stage of Pakistan's development. Yet there is a basis for hope. Historically, the Indus basin has been prosperous. And while Pakistan has suffered 40 years of brain drain, many well-educated expatriates would return and work to build a functioning state if there were a serious prospect for civil stability. Indeed, for a brief period in 1993, the country benefited from the selfless and enlightened leadership of a Pakistani World Bank official, Moeen Qureshi, who was appointed as an interim Prime Minister to break a constitutional crisis. But if Pakistan is to emerge from its current state of collapse, we must face several realities.
In the short term, military control is inevitable and in Pakistan's interest. The army can restore order and should do so by putting in place a temporary edict of martial law with accompanying restrictions on public assembly. But military rule presents both a blessing and a risk. Pakistan's often violent standoff with India in the disputed region of Kashmir could escalate beyond control quickly, especially in light of the Pakistani army's wounded pride after its imprudent foray into Kashmir's Indian-occupied areas and its subsequent humiliating retreat.
Our own military leaders must already have been in touch with the army commander, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to urge restraint in dealing with Nawaz Sharif and other ousted leaders as well as with India. The United States should also call immediately for a meeting with leaders of the European Union, China, Russia and Japan as well as India and Pakistan to develop a long-term multilateral strategy for establishing stability in South Asia.
That strategy should include the naming of a full-time emissary responsible for resolving the most volatile political issue, the Kashmir dispute. Such an outside negotiator could serve the dual purposes of finding a fair solution and providing India and Pakistan with someone to blame for the compromises they would be required to make. The strategy must also involve committing World Bank and commercial financing for roads, railroads, ports and other improvements to stimulate growth in both countries. Without a credible promise that life will get better for the average citizen, it will be difficult to achieve acceptance of a Kashmir settlement.
It will be necessary, too, to arrange arms control talks between India and Pakistan, together with talks to put in place measures for stable deterrence: hot lines, risk reduction centers and credible verification measures. The United States must also be prepared to make commitments to both countries concerning how we would respond to a threat of conflict between them.
The world has a huge stake in restraining the centrifugal forces at play in both India and Pakistan. But if efforts to help are to be taken seriously, they must involve a genuine long-term commitment by the great powers, backed by financial resources, to bring these two enemies to a modus vivendi.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1737 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Can Nissan Turn on a Centime?;
Trying to Revamp a Company and a Corporate Culture

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Carlos Ghosn, the foreign executive charged with jump-starting the Nissan Motor Company, has a favorite joke: A fabulously wealthy man -- "rich, successful beyond measure, big ranch with a big lake and mountains, you know, a little obnoxious" -- shows a group of visitors a vast swimming pool stocked with crocodiles and alligators.
He tells them he will give the one who jumps in anything he asks for. Everyone laughs, but as they walk away, they hear a splash and turn to see a man furiously flailing his way across the pool, hungry reptiles in hot pursuit. 
 Miraculously, the man makes it to the other side and scrambles out. His host congratulates him and asks what he wants. Sputtering, the daredevil replies, "I just want to know who pushed me in."
The moral, as Mr. Ghosn sees it: "You do incredible things when you're forced to." And Mr. Ghosn (pronounced gohn) will have to pull off the equivalent of that swim to get Nissan up and running competitively again.
It is Nissan itself that must pull off "incredible things," he said, referring to the much-awaited reorganization plan he will announce on Monday. He came willingly to Nissan from Renault S.A., he noted -- he wasn't pushed. In fact, he was one of the most vocal advocates of the deal that gave the French car company a 37 percent stake in its far-larger Japanese rival.
Still, the joke also applies to Mr. Ghosn, 45, and his efforts to pull off perhaps the toughest turnaround ever. "I'm very aware," he said, "that if we don't succeed, not only is it bad for Nissan and bad for Renault, it will be bad for me personally."
Not only must he restore profitability to a lumbering, heavily indebted company that has not made money on its core operations in years, he must do so under circumstances radically different from those he has faced in past corporate overhauls.
For starters, although the Brazilian-born Mr. Ghosn is fluent in Portuguese, Spanish, Italian, French and English, he speaks only elementary Japanese -- the sole language of most Nissan employees.
Nor can he fully use many of the tools of corporate change that are popular in the West. Layoffs are still anathema here. Closing plants is considered a symbol of failure. Outsourcing is rare, and the concept of pay for performance, not seniority, has only begun to catch on.
Yet without taking bold steps to reorient Nissan, still staggering under an astounding debt load with domestic sales sliding, Mr. Ghosn will almost assuredly fail. "I'm playing big for the company, I'm playing big for myself," he said. "I cannot make compromises."
His track record has won him a honeymoon so far at the company, where he officially took over as chief operating officer in July. "My biggest asset right now is credibility," he said, echoing the sentiments of several analysts.
Much of their faith rests on his role in steering Renault, long the butt of jokes on the international car scene, to a surprising and solid recovery with a plan to slice $3.5 billion in costs by 2000. That plan included a plant closing in Belgium that eliminated 2,700 jobs and a big reduction in the number of parts suppliers.
Less famously, in the seven years he ran Groupe Michelin's North American operations, he restored it to profitability, regaining the confidence of dealers who had all but given up on it.
During both turnarounds, Mr. Ghosn earned respect for setting easy-to-measure targets and hitting them. "At each meeting with me, Ghosn meticulously reviewed his projections and comments from the previous interview to measure how closely on target he had been," Lloyd Stoyer wrote in the industry trade magazine Modern Tire Dealer in 1996, when Mr. Ghosn left Michelin for Renault. "Almost always, they were amazingly close. If not, he explained why."
His plans for Renault have proved more effective than anticipated, and the betting among analysts is that Mr. Ghosn will use a similar blueprint for Nissan.
Union representatives expect the overhaul to include big changes in Nissan's relationships with suppliers, with fewer winning business in the future and doing so only if they offer globally competitive prices. Nissan, in fact, is already pushing suppliers to merge to create economies of scale.
But analysts say Nissan's best opportunity for paring fat is in personnel costs. That has led to speculation that the plan will also include a plant closing, perhaps at Murayama in northeast Japan or Oppama on the southwestern outskirts of Tokyo, as well as a winnowing of white-collar staff worldwide.
Nissan's distribution chain is also likely to face the scalpel. One has only to look at the Mazda Motor Corporation, a Ford affiliate, to understand the savings that can be wrung out of distribution here: In one region, Mazda eliminated 20 percent of its outlets and 23 percent of its work force in a single year, sharply improving profitability, said Steven Uscher, an analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
"Measures like these would be unacceptable," said Masatoshi Sakanoshita, chief executive of the All Japan Metal and Information Machinery Workers Union, a tiny Communist Party affiliate that represents 150 workers at Nissan. Nissan's large company-sponsored union refused a request for an interview.
Mr. Sakanoshita noted that morale at the plant where he works was low already because Nissan cut summer bonuses by an average of 300,000 yen, or about $2,800. The sale of various affiliates and joint ventures has also worried workers, he said.
Mr. Sakanoshita, however, had little in the way of recommendations about overhauling Nissan, beyond saying it needed to increase sales to pay down debt.
And given Japan's weak domestic car market and the expectation that sales in the United States and Europe are close to peaking, increasing sales enough to significantly improve cash flow any time soon is going to be a big challenge.
Mr. Ghosn refused to discuss the plan before next week's announcement, and indeed, one obvious change at Nissan since his arrival is the paucity of information seeping out. Even Japanese executives at the company politely declined to discuss plans, an abrupt change from past practice.
But Yoshikazu Hanawa, Nissan's president and thus nominal head, is not likely to be present for the announcement, which may say something about its scope and the amount of internal pain it will inflict.
Mr. Hanawa noted in an interview that he had to fly to France to attend a Renault board meeting on Monday. Asked why he could not participate via video, Mr. Hanawa said, "I might not communicate as well by video; I might be a little shy."
That may be, but his absence at this pivotal event has raised eyebrows and sent a clear message about who will be in charge of Nissan's hoped-for renaissance.
By all accounts, Mr. Hanawa and Mr. Ghosn have a cordial relationship and confer frequently, but Mr. Hanawa now serves largely as the company's ambassador and leaves day-to-day management to his new sidekick.
In the aftermath of the Renault deal, Mr. Hanawa has adopted the role of senior statesman to a Japanese business community still somewhat incredulous about the foreign alliance, and as ambassador to Nissan's senior managers, who stand to lose the most.
He said he was pleased with the Renault partnership, although he seemed somewhat surprised to find himself saying so. "It was a good decision," he said, "better than I expected."
When the deal was announced in March, Mr. Hanawa was clearly under pressure. Nissan was closer to being broke than most imagined, with its banks pushing it to find a new source of cash fast and talks with DaimlerChrysler A.G. ending abruptly, in an embarrassingly public way. The company had no mid- to long-term strategy; it was simply trying to stay alive day to day.
In hindsight, however, an alliance with DaimlerChrysler, roiled now by its own drastic management changes and the take-no-prisoners style of its chief executive, no doubt seems far less appealing.
And even though some changes at Nissan are uncomfortable -- Mr. Hanawa himself said it was somewhat unsettling how fast decisions were being made -- he is pleased with the deal he made.
"If we were totally the same, there would not be stimulus and inspiration between us," he added. "Sometimes that stimulus is comfortable, and sometimes it's painful."
The two men speak with each other often -- "Between my broken English and Ghosn-san's Japanese, the gap is getting closer," Mr. Hanawa said -- but Mr. Ghosn is clearly calling the shots now. He has startled workers by showing up to stroll the assembly lines and ask questions, not only of senior engineers and managers but also of workers themselves. And he has encouraged the use of E-mail, rarely used in the past at Nissan, although language has proved to be somewhat of a barrier.
Mr. Sakanoshita, the labor representative, said Nissan's senior executives had previously visited production lines only for formal celebrations of new-car introductions. He could recall only one other time when someone of Mr. Ghosn's stature visited the plant at Musashimurayama, when Takashi Ishihara, Nissan's legendary chairman in the early 1980's, paid a call.
"Mr. Hanawa seems more Japanese in that when he collects information, it is after it has worked its way up from the factory floor through the plant managers to the section chiefs and division chiefs," Mr. Sakanoshita said. "Mr. Ghosn skips the process and goes directly to the factory floor."
While Mr. Sakanoshita is not at all certain he likes Mr. Ghosn's common touch, even he recognizes that Nissan must change. "It would be hard for Nissan to avoid," he said. "I'm not sure Renault should have been the partner we chose, but it is clear that Nissan could not survive on its own."
Despite doubters like Mr. Sakanoshita, Mr. Ghosn is confident he will have an easier time selling the plan to Nissan than to outsiders. "Hundreds of people have had a chance to contribute to this inside the company," he said. "I've met no resistance and had a lot of good cooperation."
Has he had any fun in the last six months? He burst into laughter, then said it was a difficult question. "It's an intense job, and I like intense jobs," Mr. Ghosn said. "I'll put it this way: It takes up all your intelligence, all your skill, your capacity to listen, your humor, your patience. You are fully used in this job."

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Further Clouds Issue Of What's Up With the Yen

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan moved today to expand the range of tools it could use to increase the supply of money in the economy to help weaken the resurgent yen.
Japan's currency initially tumbled more than 1 percent in response to the action, taken by the central bank after an unusually long monthly meeting of its policy board. 
 But there was considerable confusion in the markets about whether the bank's action represented a policy change or something less significant.
In a reflection of skepticism about the effectiveness of the action, the yen recovered from a low of 107.96 to the dollar immediately after the bank's meeting in Tokyo to 106.60 to the dollar by the end of trading in New York -- only slightly weaker than the 106.31 rate of a day earlier.
The Bank of Japan has been under increasing pressure from the Government and its global economic partners, notably the United States, to take steps that would weaken the yen, which has risen to the highest levels in more than three years against the dollar.
The yen's strength is threatening to undermine Japan's slow recovery from its worst recession in a half-century by hurting the sales and profits of Japanese exporters.
In a display of independence, the Bank of Japan has shown little sign of capitulation to the domestic and foreign pressure to weaken the yen. Rather, the central bank has been insisting that its monetary policy of keeping interest rates extremely low and keeping one trillion yen in excess cash sloshing around in the system is sufficient.
But the action today seemed to at least be an enhancement of that policy. The bank said it would expand the maturity range of government securities it purchases from time to time, which theoretically could put even more yen into circulation and dilute the currency's value.
Marshall Gittler, an economist at the Bank of America in Hong Kong, said the bank's decision could even lead to purchases of long-term government bonds, something the bank has staunchly resisted in the past.
But most analysts seemed to be concluding that while the bank's decision might be a more effective way of increasing the supply of yen in the system, it was not an about-face by the bank.
"All they have done is open another channel for their money market operations," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. "It doesn't mean they'll use it, and it doesn't mean a change of policy."
Rather, Mr. Feldman said, he read it as an effort by the bank to demonstrate concern about the impact of the yen's strength.
Jeffrey D. Young, an economist at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney who has written about the possibility of the bank adding treasury note purchases to its tool chest, agreed.
"People inside the bank are not convinced the economy is in a self-sustaining recovery, and they're worried about the rise of the yen and bond yields," he said. "They're looking for a way of boosting the impact their policy has, and this is one way of doing that."
A senior bank official confirmed the economists' analysis. "Nothing has changed," he said. "The essence of the bank's policy has not changed, but it has tried to make the appearance more attractive."
He said that the bank had made no commitment to increasing the amount of yen in the system and that he did not expect it to do so.
"Unless you see the bank put more than one trillion yen of surplus money into the market tomorrow morning, it has not changed its policy," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Sink on Intel Earnings and Plunging Bond Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply for a second consecutive session yesterday as Intel's disappointing earnings report Tuesday hammered technology shares and a plunge in bond prices dragged the broader market lower.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 184.90 points, to 10,232.16, extending its drop of 231.12 points on Tuesday. The Dow is down 3.9 percent so far this week. 
 Broader stock indicators also closed sharply lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 27.49 points, to 1,285.55, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 71.16 points, to 2,801.27.
Intel, often considered a bellwether stock for the technology sector, tumbled 4 9/16, to 72 1/8. The company, the leading manufacturer of semiconductors, reported late Tuesday that it earned 55 cents a share in the quarter, 2 cents below analysts' forecasts.
The results surprised investors who have come to expect Intel to meet or surpass Wall Street forecasts. Other technology leaders also fell, including Microsoft, which slipped 1 1/2, to 91 1/16.
Traders said Intel's report fostered nervousness about other chip makers, which may face production troubles in the coming months as Taiwan, a major producer of semiconductor parts, rebuilds from a recent earthquake. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index fell 2.5 percent.
Intel also deflated some optimism about corporate profits in general. The companies making up the S.& P. 500 are expected to post average profit growth of more than 19 percent in the third quarter, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. But with expectations high, analysts warn that any companies that miss analysts' forecasts are in line for harsh punishment from investors.
In recent quarters, however, even companies that have met estimates have faltered if their profit reports contained any hint of trouble. So yesterday, the retailer Abercrombie & Fitch fell 6 3/16, to 26 5/16, after saying sales rose at a slower pace than at a rival, American Eagle Outfitters. Investors brushed off the news that Abercrombie's earnings would meet expectations.
Stephen Shobin, technical analyst at Lehman Brothers, warned that unless investors can shake lingering nervousness about rising interest rates, earnings may be unable to drive stocks much higher.
"Wall Street is expecting phenomenal earnings, and that might already be priced into the market," he said. "Right now, investors seem willing to ignore the good news and embrace the bad."
The bond market provided a major dose of bad news. Prices dropped sharply, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 6.27 percent. At that level, the bond market can lure investors away from stocks by offering fixed, guaranteed returns.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, pushing yields to their highest level in almost two years on concern that reports due today and tomorrow would add to evidence that may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again.
Sales of $8 billion of new bonds by Freddie Mac, the Dupont Company and the Inter-American Development Bank sapped demand for Treasuries, traders said. Rising commodity prices fueled inflation concerns and the dollar erased most of its gains against the yen.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 20/32, to 98 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.27 percent from 6.22 percent on Tuesday.
Analysts expect a report today to show retail sales increased two-tenths of a percent in September from 1.2 percent in August. Producer prices, which will be reported tomorrow, are expected to show a gain of five-tenths of a percent last month.
Unexpected gains could increase concerns that the Fed will raise interest rates again.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Investors Are Jumpy, and the Fed Is Making Matters Worse

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN the Federal Reserve policy makers want to, they can still stir the pot on Wall Street. Their Oct. 5 decision to leave their interest rate target unchanged at 5.25 percent but to hint at a future increase in rates has left investors uncertain, has tripped up stocks and has pushed long-term interest rates near a two-year high.
Stocks tumbled yesterday after the Intel Corporation announced disappointing third quarter earnings late Tuesday and interest rates moved higher. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.48 percent while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 2.09 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.77 percent. 
 At the same time, the yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.27 percent, its high since Aug. 12 and just below 6.28 percent in October 1997. The yield on the two-year note, which is more sensitive to the threat of Fed interest rate increases, jumped to 5.83 percent, its highest since October 1997.
The Fed policy makers did not say this was their intent when they released their statement explaining what they decided after the policy making session earlier this month. They would not do that. But the members of the Federal Open Market Committee had to know that the uncertainty about the next rate increase would have an impact on the market.
Fed policy makers have been worrying about the rally in the stock market all year because the gains are spurring consumer spending through what is called the wealth effect.
Even after yesterday's declines, the Dow is up 11.44 percent so far this year and the Nasdaq has jumped 27.58 percent this year. Consumer spending has been the driving force of an economy that is growing at a 4 percent pace, much faster than the Fed would like.
A Federal Reserve governor, Laurence H. Meyer, has been talking about the problem of the stock market and how it affects the central bank's interest rate policy for some time. He realizes that the danger of a rate increase to cool the stock market is that investors could overreact, setting off a big selloff that could damage the economy rather than slow it.
Policy makers, he said in a speech last month, "should be alert to the potential that a tightening of policy could have a disproportionate effect on demand, if it induces a reassessment of market fundamentals."
So maybe no rate increase but a lean toward higher rates is a step in between.
"I don't think the Fed is disappointed in seeing the stock market stabilizing or moving lower," said Joseph Abate, senior economist at Lehman Brothers. "A little bit of uncertainty about the outlook for monetary policy is not necessarily a bad thing."
With the selloff this week, the Dow has given back the 4.3 percent rally that started at the end of September. Investors are jittery, although third-quarter earnings over all are supposed to be strong followed by a good fourth quarter. But if the interest rate worries subside some, the earnings outlook -- backed by some important companies beating expectations -- could give stocks a lift again.
Louis Crandall of R. H. Wrightson & Associates said that if the Fed had increased its short-term interest rate target a quarter of a percentage point to 5.50 percent Oct. 5, many investors would have taken that as an all-clear signal for the year. And that could have opened the door for stocks to move higher.
What is adding to the negative environment now is the anticipation of reports of rising inflation in September at both the producer and consumer levels. Although analysts argue that the jumps are caused by the recent increases in tobacco prices and in oil prices, which last month rose to just under $25 a barrel and caused a subsequent jump in gasoline prices, the jumps are still disturbing investors.
The core rate for the September Producer Price Index, which excludes food and energy, is forecast to rise five-tenths of a percent, well above the trend for the year. For the Consumer Price Index, the core rate is forecast to jump three-tenths of a percent, the biggest move since April and well above the trend for the year.
Although economists are telling Wall Street traders that these jumps in September inflation gauges are not signaling a trend, they do not tend to make someone buy bonds a week after Fed policy makers said they were leaning toward a rate increase, Mr. Crandall said. "If buyers see reasons to sit on their hands for a period of time," he added, "the market suffers for it."
In addition, although September retail sales, which will be reported today, are expected to slow to an increase of two-tenths of a percent, that is coming after two months of 1 percent or more growth. And that means the economy may not be slowing fast enough to satisfy the Fed.
Mr. Crandall said that the threat of a weakening dollar was also worrying investors. The dollar is down sharply against the yen this year, but has leveled off recently. But it is not yet clear if steps taken by the Bank of Japan yesterday will really lead to an easier monetary policy there that could end the dollar's decline.
But the dollar, which has rallied for most of the year against the euro, could turn around, especially if growth here slows while it is picking up in Europe. A steady dollar decline against the euro, Mr. Crandall said, would make investment by Europeans in the United States less attractive because the weaker dollar would reduce returns when translated back into euros. That would slow foreign investment in both stocks and bonds here, taking away an important prop for both markets.
But, a rise in rates -- home mortgage rates are near their highs for the year -- and a modest slump in the stock market could help change the mood of investors by slowing economic growth enough to get Fed policy makers less worried about the tight labor market and rises in wages and commodity prices.

HEADLINE: Times Is Said to Consider a New Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company is negotiating with state and city officials to build its third home in the Times Square area in 94 years, a 1.3-million-square-foot tower on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, according to government officials and real estate executives involved in the talks.
The proposed tower would enable the company to consolidate and modernize its operations, which are now scattered across six buildings in Manhattan. The company's headquarters are now at 229 West 43d Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. 
 In what has become a routine bargaining stance for many of the city's largest corporations, The New York Times has asked government officials for tax breaks and other incentives for the proposed tower at the Eighth Avenue site, which sits within the borders of the 42d Street Development Project, a 15-year-old effort to revive the area around Times Square. Otherwise, the company has insisted that it would have to move some employees to locations outside New York, state and city officials said.
Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine did not return telephone calls requesting comment, and a spokeswoman at the Empire State Development Corporation, Maura Gallucci, declined to comment. Executives with The New York Times declined to discuss their plans.
"The company regularly looks at alternatives to provide the kind of office space we need for the future," said Nancy Nielsen, vice president for corporate communications for The Times. "Those alternatives include a continuing renovation of our current building, as well as moving to new quarters."
But one government official who has talked with The Times was enthusiastic about the prospect of a new Times tower. "It would really set the tone for how Eighth Avenue would develop," the official said.
Even if a deal is struck by the end of the year, construction could not begin until the end of 2000.
More than a half-dozen low-slung buildings now occupying the proposed Eighth Avenue site, including an adult entertainment shop, a vacant office building and a kung fu video store, would have to be condemned by the state and demolished to make way for the tower. The tenants would be relocated.
But the environmental reviews and public hearings have already been completed for the site, according to state and city officials.
"If it happens, it would be a wonderful development for Eighth Avenue," said Douglas Durst, the developer who recently completed building the skyscraper 4 Times Square. "With The Times leaving the area, it will give us the opportunity to rename it Durst Square."
In the last four years, the once seedy district has exploded with billboards, neon and new construction. Conde Nast recently moved into Mr. Durst's new skyscraper on Broadway, between 42d and 43d Streets. Across the street, Reuters and Ernst & Young are building new headquarters.
But the resurgence is only just beginning on Eighth Avenue. Under the original plan for the 42d Street Development Project, the site on Eighth Avenue at 41st Street was designated for a huge 20-story merchandise mart. But that project succumbed to squabbling among participants and to the recession in the early 1990's.
This summer, the state was preparing to solicit proposals from developers interested in building on the parcel when The New York Times Company contacted state officials about building a new headquarters tower, people involved in the talks said.
In 1994, city officials gave the newspaper more than $29 million in tax breaks and other incentives to build a new printing plant at College Point, Queens. City and state officials expect that The Times will be asking for a far greater sum this time.
The new headquarters would become the company's third home in Times Square.
In 1905, Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher, moved The Times to a new tower on 42d Street in the center of what was then called Longacre Square, a rough-and-tumble intersection of bawdy houses and prostitutes. He persuaded the Mayor, George B. McClellan, to build a subway stop there and to rename the area Times Square. The tower, now known as 1 Times Square, which is the site of the New Year's Eve ball drop, served as the newspaper's home until 1913, when most operations moved to an annex at 229 West 43d Street.
In 1997, the company shut down the presses on 43d Street and moved some printing operations to a new plant at the College Point location. In recent years, the company is said to have spent tens of millions of dollars renovating its 43d Street headquarters.
But, according to real estate executives, the company has decided that because of technological demands and expanded operations, it would be better off in a new skyscraper.
According to government officials, executives from The Times told them that they would rather not adhere to several requirements for projects in the redevelopment district: neon lights and billboards on the sides of the building and entertainment-related tenants on the ground floor.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Profit at Apple Computer Beats Reduced Estimates
After warning last month of an earnings shortfall, Apple Computer reported results for its fourth quarter that exceeded revised estimates. Apple executives also predicted strong sales for the quarter ended in December. 
 Apple earned $111 million, or 63 cents a diluted share, compared with $106 million, or 68 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Analysts had expected Apple to earn 45 cents. That number would have been reachable but for the limited availability of microprocessors, said Steven P. Jobs, Apple's interim chief executive. Page C2.
 
Frontier to Buy Planes From Airbus
Frontier Airlines has decided to buy 20 new narrow-body jets from Airbus Industrie, two people close to the negotiations said, becoming the latest airline to choose the European consortium over its archrival, Boeing. C7.
 
Stocks Decline for Second Session
Stocks fell sharply for a second consecutive session. The Dow Jones industrial average decreased 184.90 points, to 10,232.16. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 27.49 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,285.55, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 71.16 points, or 2.5 percent, to 2,801.27. C10.
 
Web Is a Grab Bag of Free Goods
With hundreds of Internet start-ups competing for immediate visibility and rapid growth, giveaways have moved beyond information into products and services that sometimes cost hundreds of dollars. A1.
 
Motorola Charge Linked to Iridium
Motorola said that it expected to take a $500 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter, a move that would essentially write off its entire exposure to Iridium, the bankrupt global satellite telephone service. C6.
 
Profit Falls Short at Bear Stearns
Bear Stearns posted first-quarter earnings that fell short of expectations, a trend-breaking disappointment that the securities firm attributed to weaker markets for the stocks and bonds it underwrites and trades. The company made $1 a share, but that fell short of estimates of $1.15 a share. Investors reacted by pushing shares of Bear Stearns down $3.50, or 8.7 percent, to $36.75. C5.
 
Paint Makers Sued in Rhode Island
The Rhode Island Attorney General sued eight paint manufacturers and a lead industry trade group in an effort to make them pay for treating children poisoned by lead paint and removing lead paint from buildings. A18.
 
Palm Computing Forms Partnership
Forming an alliance to create a de facto standard for wireless Internet access, the Palm Computing unit of 3Com announced a partnership with Symbian, a joint venture of five wireless phone manufacturers. C5.
 
W. R. Grace to Recoup $3.7 Million
W. R. Grace said that it would recover $3.7 million from an insurance company for excess payments and benefits that were paid to two former chief executives. C6.
 
Con Ed Announces Deal for Utility
Consolidated Edison announced a $3.29 billion acquisition of Northeast Utilities in a deal that puts the utility on a national stage and holds the promise of cheaper power. C2.
 
Japan Clouds Issue of Surging Yen
The Bank of Japan moved to expand the range of tools it could use to increase the supply of money in the economy to help weaken the resurgent yen. But there was confusion about whether the bank's action marked a policy change or something less significant. C4.

HEADLINE: In Wired World, Much Is Free at Click of a Mouse

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
For years, marketers have known that one word, more than any other, can spur people to action.
The magic word, of course, is "free." And the wheels of commerce have long been greased with free samples, free trial issues, free toasters at the bank, or free tote bags with every bottle of perfume. 
 But those are Cracker Jack prizes compared with what is happening these days on the Internet, where the slogan is quickly becoming: buy nothing, get everything free.
With hundreds of Internet start-ups hellbent on immediate visibility and rapid growth, the giveaways have moved beyond information, like magazine articles and stock quotes, into products and services that could otherwise cost hundreds of dollars. Consumers can download a word-processing program or a recording of a hit single, sign up for a new phone number to receive faxes and voice mail, or even call long distance -- all without paying a penny.
Some sites will set you up in business with your own on-line store free, if you can think of something to sell that people will pay for.
If you want to take advantage of this costless cornucopia but are not yet wired to the Web, don't despair. A bunch of companies want to provide free Internet access. FreePC.com hopes to give away a computer, too. And if you need to communicate with your militantly unwired Uncle Waldo, postage4free.com will send you a stack of stamped envelopes, gratis.
"You name it, and there is a start-up somewhere that wants to give it away free," said James Breyer, the managing partner of Accel Partners, a Silicon Valley venture-capital firm.
All this comes at a price, of course. Those free envelopes are covered with advertising, and so are most of the other free offers. To get freebies, customers often must also disclose a dossier's worth of personal information for use by marketers and put up with minimal customer service.
Not everyone wants to listen to 30 seconds of commercials to make a free two-minute long-distance call, as offered by mytalk.com. But enough of these deals are attracting enough customers that the free offers keep coming, despite questions about whether there will be enough advertising to support many more such businesses.
Mytalk is hardly striking fear in the heart of AT&T, but other giveaways are roiling certain markets. Investors in Internet service providers are scared by the prospect of free competitors. And even software companies are feeling the impact because so many functions can now be performed on the Web free.
"There are markets that could be spoiled," said Gill Cogan, a general partner with the venture-capital arm of Weiss, Peck & Greer. "After you give something away free, it is very difficult to start charging for it, or even for other things."
The trend is being driven by the ever-plummeting prices on computers and communications, which make it so inexpensive to offer many services that it makes as much sense to give them away covered in ads as it does to try to sell them.
"The general rule is that anything that has a potential for a broad audience will eventually be free," said Joe Kraus, a co-founder of the Excite service, which searches the Web free and now also offers free E-mail, voice mail, auctions, classified ads, chat rooms and a small library's worth of information. Ultimately, he said, companies would rather have consumers' time than their money -- assuming that they can make money from those consumers some other way.
"We are shifting from a retail economy to what I call an attention economy," Mr. Kraus said. "You are willing to give away services or even pay people to use services, if you can get a lot of people listening to your message."
Marketers have always looked to place ads in new and prominent locations, but the popularity of the Internet has given rise to hundreds of new companies with rich backers, desperately racing to get lots of new customers right away, even if they do not know exactly how they will make money.
Many newer start-ups look to the example of Hotmail, the first big Web site offering free E-mail with advertising. In 18 months, Hotmail signed up 11 million customers. And even though it never made much selling advertising, Microsoft bought Hotmail for some $400 million.
Timothy Draper, of the venture-capital firm Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Hotmail's early backer, said he was so convinced that free services were the way to build really big businesses that he had invested in a variety of others, including free Web sites, free disk space and free Internet access. "If you believe that the Web is opening up a whole new world economy where there will be a lot of winners, what you want to do is back one of the 30 companies that ends up being worth a trillion dollars," he said.
Not everyone is so sure that the way to make a trillion dollars is to give away the most stuff free.
"There is an unwarranted frenzy around the free model on the Internet," said Mr. Breyer of Accel Partners, who argues that there just is not enough money to be made in advertising to justify most of these companies. "In most cases, if one does the math, the business assumptions simply will not hold up, and the companies are pursuing suicidal strategies."
One site challenging that premise is Free-PC.com, which has to sell about $30 a month in advertising to cover the costs of a computer and its free Internet access.
Donald S. La Vigne, its chief executive, maintains that the prominent placement of the ads, in strips along two sides of the screen, and the data the company collects observing how its customers use the machine, will make the service attractive to advertisers.
"If someone goes to E-Loan and four other housing sites in one week, it's a good bet they're shopping for a mortgage," he said. "Banks will pay a lot of money to find someone in the market for a home loan." Still, the company will wait to see how this idea works on 30,000 computers before it gives away more.
The hurdle for NetZero Inc. and other companies that want to offer free Internet service is almost as high. It costs about $10 a month to cover the telecommunications cost of Internet access. So far the biggest Internet service, America Online, takes in only about $5 monthly from ads per user, on top of its $21.95 monthly fee.
Wall Street appears to have fewer doubts. With 900,000 active accounts, NetZero is now worth about $3 billion, after its public offering late last month. That compares with Earthlink, a big Internet service provider with 1.5 million paying customers, that investors value around $1.3 billion.
Implicit in Wall Street's assumptions is that millions of consumers are willing to make their homes, or at least their computers, look like the logo-covered outfield wall of a Major League Baseball park. So far they are.
"The average consumer gets 3,000 marketing messages a day," Mr. La Vigne said. "That doesn't mean they like it, but they are used to it."
Indeed, these Internet sites are riding a cultural shift, in which more people embrace, rather than fight, commercialism.
"People in this generation are not as concerned with advertising as older people," said Bo Peabody, 28, the founder of Tripod, an on-line gathering place for Generation X now owned by Lycos. "We feel that everybody has an agenda."
Sometimes the sales pitch is very subtle. Onebox is a start-up that is offering free voice mail with no visible advertising. It hopes to profit ultimately by selling a premium service linked to people's home phone numbers. "It costs long-distance companies $100 to $300 to get a new customer," said Bill Nguyen, the company's founder. "Our free service costs less than $2 to provide. If one person in 50 ever pays us, we will make a lot of money."
There are already myriad examples of free services on the Internet eating into lucrative markets. Five years ago, for example, 40 percent of the revenue of Dow Jones & Company's on-line unit came from news headlines and stock quotes it sold for 25 cents a quote. Now, hundreds of sites give those away.
Similarly, it took two years for a company called Jfax to attract 35,000 customers to its $12-a-month service that forwards faxes to an E-mail address. In February, a rival called Efax introduced a service that is similar but free, and to date has a million customers. Jfax was forced to respond with its own free service.
An even-higher-stakes battle is occurring over Internet auctions. Ebay, the auction leader, charges a fee of 2 to 5 percent. But Yahoo is gaining ground with totally free auctions.
Yahoo is getting the same treatment, though in reverse, at its business that charges $100 a month or more for a company to set up a store on the Internet. Now, services like BigStep.com and FreeMerchant.com will do all that without charge.
Another free service meant to bite into Yahoo and other popular Internet sites is Rocketboard, a company that hopes to give free keyboards, with 18 extra buttons that send the user to certain on-line stores.
"The portals now have the ocean-front views, but with Rocketboard we are putting up a building that is closer to the water," said Scott Heiferman, the company's founder.
So where does the free frenzy end? Venture capitalists say that entrepreneurs are now trying to raise money for everything from free cellular phones to free movies to free stock trades. So far, there is little inclination to give away such basic nondigital commodities and services as food, shelter or transportation.
"In the end, someone has to sell something, or it's all a shell game," Mr. Kraus of Excite said. "The car companies are never going to give away free cars."
Or will they? Mr. Draper, the venture capitalist, said the idea might not be as crazy as it sounds. "It's a captive audience," he remarked. "If you control my radio while I'm driving, keep track of where I go with a global positioning system, and maybe do something with my cell phone, there's a possibility you might be willing to pay $50,000 to own me for two hours a day."
And yes, someone has already registered the Internet address free-cars.com.

THE GIMMICK -- Site tries to sell other services to the businesses, like long distance service and office supplies.

www.sun.com/products/staroffice
WHAT'S FREE -- A package of computer programs including word processor, spreadsheet and E-mail.
THE GIMMICK -- Service and support cost extra.
THE COMPETITION -- Microsoft Office costs $300 and up, but includes limited support.
 
NetZero.com
WHAT'S FREE -- A connection to the Internet over telephone lines.
THE GIMMICK -- The service displays advertising while the user is on line and monitors what sites are visited.
THE COMPETITION -- Earthlink, a big Internet service provider, charges $20 a month for unlimited access with no superimposed advertising and no data collection.

HEADLINE: Anger on Agenda for World Trade Meeting

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 13

 BODY:
A dispute over the agenda that appears to pit developing nations against the United States has injected a tense atmosphere into preparations for the World Trade Organization's summit meeting next month.
Nonindustrialized countries in the 134-member group that makes the rules for global commerce had drafted a detailed list of priorities for the Seattle meeting agenda, determined to rectify what they see as bias in current trade rules that have benefited larger economic powers at their expense. 
 But their two-page list was mysteriously deleted from the first formal draft of the agenda that circulated at the organization's Geneva headquarters earlier this week. Representatives of developing nations expressed outrage, particularly because the coming summit meeting has been publicly extolled by the group's new director general, Mike Moore, as a forum meant for them.
"It was totally, totally unfair," said India's trade envoy to Geneva, Srinivasan Narayanan. "It shocks us, frankly."
While no names were publicly mentioned, the United States was blamed and accused of bullying tactics. "It was too convenient. Every single item developing countries wanted was eliminated," said one aggrieved trade envoy.
United States representatives to the trade group declined to comment on these accusations today, saying only that the agenda remained subject to negotiation.
But a subsequent version of the agenda draft restored much of what developing nations had proposed earlier. Whether all or even some of those issues survive the final draft remains unclear.
Among them are a proposal to weaken antidumping measures, an important American trade tool used to protect United States manufacturers from low-priced imports. Developing countries want a one-year waiting period between inquiries into a product that has flooded the market. The United States would likely reject such a change.
Another agenda item sought by developing countries would reintroduce subsidies to protect domestic manufacturers, made illegal in previous trade agreements. Countries like India argue that subsidies are necessary to protect their native businesses from foreign competition.
Modifying rules for the textile trade is also on the developing countries' list. They want to shorten the 10-year schedule for lifting restrictions on imports. The Americans want to keep the schedule unchanged.
Developing nations also want the agenda to include proposed changes that would delay enforcement of intellectual property rights, postpone a tightening of trade-related investment rules and force pharmaceutical companies to sell essential drugs at affordable prices.
In recent congressional testimony, the United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, gave little support for such a wish list, saying that institution of existing agreements is necessary to the credibility of future negotiations.
But comments by a top Commerce Department official this week indicate that the United States may offer some room to compromise, partly because it wants the trade summit conference to include negotiations on raising labor standards among all member nations. This is an important issue to American and European unions.
"I don't think we could get a trade deal though Congress without some kind of concessions," said Deputy Commerce Secretary Robert Mallett. He indicated that United States negotiators may have to put "some incentives on the table. . . perhaps a more protracted timetable for the implementation of some issues."

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
Wrestling (In the Mud) With Faludi

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
MEN of New York, turn off the baseball playoffs. Put aside your magazines glorifying babes and gear. Stop trying to win games and get promotions. Don't pretend you're enjoying this so-called economic boom.
Susan Faludi knows what you're feeling. In her new book, "Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man," she discloses that modern men are in "agony." And those of us in New York are largely to blame for it. 
 Ms. Faludi reveals these truths through the sad stories of a representative sample of laid-off shipyard workers, out-of-work X-rated film actors, wife beaters, sexual predators and gang members. She plumbs the philosophies of a militiaman who blames Hillary Rodham Clinton for the deaths at Waco, and a 385-pound football fan who goes to games in a dog costume and barks after every play.
Why are these guys unhappy? They don't have a clue. "The very paradigm of modern masculinity," Ms. Faludi explains, "prevents men from thinking their way out of their dilemma." It takes a woman to trace the problems back to New York's corporate headquarters.
Ruthless executives here have been downsizing companies and shutting factories in the heartland. Now that men can't work in shipyards all their lives, they feel worthless, so they have fallen for the false images of masculinity promoted by Madison Avenue and the rest of the media industry: athletes, action heroes, masters of the universe who win the competition for money and toys and women.
"The male paradigm of confrontation," Ms. Faludi announces, "has, in fact, proved worthless to men." Hailing the cooperative spirit of the W.P.A. -- ah, the good old days of the Great Depression! -- Ms. Faludi urges men to stop their brutish competition and learn the nurturing traits of a good mother. We should link arms with feminists to create a "community where people are knit together by meaningful and mutual concerns." Only then can we move beyond being "masculine" to being "human" -- i.e., someone like Susan Faludi.
There is probably no way for men to repay Ms. Faludi for "Stiffed." But some of us are trying to reach across the gender divide. We are gathering material for "Miffed," a male analysis of women's angst, as shown in case histories like these:
*Paula, a high-powered corporate lawyer with three children, is overcome with mysterious feelings of fatigue and frustration. In her confused anger, she lashes out at her unemployed husband for refusing to do any cooking or housework.
But with his help, she sees the true cause of her dissatisfaction: the corporate marketers that have filled their home with unnecessary appliances. Inspired by her grandmother's stories of the 1930's, she begins washing clothes and rugs by hand, and soon has the energy to churn her own butter. On weekends, she happily declares the entire house her "personal space," banishing her husband to the golf course.
*Foxi, a dancer brutally downsized by Mayor Giuliani's crackdown on strip clubs, is tricked by a newspaper ad into spending $137,000 on shoes at Bergdorf Goodman. Unable to pay the credit card bill, she languishes helplessly -- until her teen-age brother introduces her to a video game called Quake II.
By blasting the heads off vicious zombies, Foxi acquires the discipline to remain at the computer 12 hours a day. She creates her own Web page with pictures from her dancing days, attracting enough visitors and advertisers to make her rich. She celebrates by buying her brother a top-of-the line DVD player.
*Anita, a member of the Moral Majority, blames her feminist neighbor, Susan, for brainwashing women into abandoning their God-given roles at home. Susan blames Anita for oppressing women. Their screaming matches -- "Family destroyer!" "Sexist stereotyper!" -- escalate until a man across the street introduces a traditional male mediation technique.
"Why don't you two gals settle this with some mud wrestling," he suggests.
The two women don bikinis and grapple furiously in the mud, all the while muttering about the forces afflicting modern women: biased media coverage, vulgar advertisements, crude television shows, exploitative movies. Suddenly they stop thrashing. They've found a common enemy: the media! That's why men and women are misbehaving! They've been corrupted by the media!
Anita and Susan embrace, swear eternal sisterhood and schedule another mud-wrestling session. In gratitude to the mediator, they invite him to bring his camcorder next time.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
For Bidders, Jets' Value Is in Eye of the Beholder

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The New York Jets, who play in the nation's largest market, lost money in 1997 and have produced modest returns by National Football League standards over the last two years, a prospectus written for the team's sale shows.
The thick, black-jacketed document, a copy of which was shown to The New York Times, provides a picture of a team that lacks the robust stadium revenues that some of the league's most valuable franchises enjoy. 
 Sports-finance experts have suggested that the team could be sold for $500 million or more. But the detailed figures in the prospectus raise significant questions about the real market value of the team -- unless a new owner lands a lucrative deal for a new stadium.
The Jets lost $8 million in the year ending in February 1998, which covered the 1997 season, the prospectus says. The team rebounded with net income of $24.3 million last season, but the figure was inflated by a one-time payment of $16.8 million, the team's share of the league's sale of the Cleveland Browns expansion franchise.
For this season, the Jets project a net profit of $5.4 million.
The estate of the late owner, Leon Hess, has offered the Jets for sale, and so far more than two dozen potential buyers have examined the team's finances. Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banker for the Hess estate, last week reduced the roster of potential buyers to about six or eight.
Two of the suitors have said privately that the bottom-line reality contained in the prospectus does not support a $500 million bid.
"If someone told me right now the Jets are worth $500 million, I'd say, 'How can that be?' " said Michael Ozanian, a valuation expert at Forbes.
In an era when many N.F.L. teams bank nearly all the revenues from ticket sales, luxury suites and club seats at new sports palaces, the Jets' lease at Giants Stadium is one of the least lucrative in football. Moreover, the team pays one of the league's highest rents -- $3.9 million last season.
By one significant measure -- operating cash flow, or revenues minus expenses -- the Jets are far below average. This season's estimated cash flow, $11.6 million, greatly lags behind the league average of $19.7 million, according to Forbes magazine. The Dallas Cowboys top Forbes's list, with a cash flow of $56.7 million.
But these are fascinating fiscal days in the N.F.L., which boasts the sports world's most expensive teams. Last week, the new Houston expansion franchise sold for $700 million. In May, Dan Snyder bought the Washington Redskins for $805 million. Last year, the expansion Cleveland Browns sold for $530 million.
What are the Jets worth? Forbes says $363 million.
The Jets are not in financial distress -- not when the team can open the season with a guaranteed $58 million in network television revenues. But the league judged the team needy enough to have funneled $6 million in cash to it since 1997 from a supplemental revenue sharing fund.
By one method for calculating sale price, the Jets are a stretch to reach $500 million. The Redskins sold for $805 million, or 16.5 times team and stadium cash flow of $48.8 million. The Browns sold at a multiple of 16.6.
If the Jets' value were determined by a similar yardstick, the team would be worth $191 million, or 16.6 times this season's estimated cash flow of $11.5 million. To fetch a $500 million sale price, the Jets would require a 43.4 multiple.
But multiples may be irrelevant if bidders care far more about the New York market and the possibility of a higher-revenue future -- not the underwhelming past and present.
The prospectus touts the team as a "storied sports franchise" and revels in its 1969 Super Bowl victory, "numerous individual records," educated fans and a high season-ticket renewal rate. It features photographs of Vinny Testaverde, Keyshawn Johnson, Joe Namath and Fireman Ed Anzalone, the spirited fan who leads J-E-T-S cheers at home games.
But within the slick, colorful document is an oft-repeated mantra: if you buy this team, you could renegotiate your lease or get a new stadium. That's the upside and, really, the only story.
"You'd only buy the team if you got a new stadium," said Randy Vataha, president of Game Plan LLC, a sports investment bank.
The Jets are bound to Giants Stadium until 2008, which means a new owner could endure losses unless a new stadium could be built, either privately, or with help from a state or city government.
"You have to think about how much the team would be worth in a new stadium, and all the other ways you can increase your cash flow," Vataha said, in areas like luxury suites, club seats, higher ticket prices, sponsorships, advertising and Internet deals.
The Hess estate is relying on the hope that a new owner will somehow get a new stadium in New Jersey or New York by 2009. It also hopes a buyer will pay a large premium to own a team in the New York market.
The prospectus notes that recent deals for naming rights range from $3.1 million a year at Raymond James Stadium, where the Tampa Bay Buccaneers play, to $9.3 million annually for Philips Arena in Atlanta, home of the hockey Thrashers.
"The potential for a football team is so enormous in New York that if you bid less than $700 million for the Jets, you'll be passed by, even if you have to wait eight or nine years for a new stadium," said Mark Rosentraub, associate dean at the School of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana University.
In its estimate of the impact of a new stadium on the Jets' economics -- if it were in place now -- Goldman, Sachs estimated $55 million in ticket revenues and $5 million in stadium naming rights. Both numbers are conservative and are based on a 72,000-seat stadium with 150 luxury suites and 9,000 club seats.
Washington Redskins Stadium, for example, has 80,116 seats, 280 luxury suites and 15,044 club seats -- the most in the league, in the nation's eighth largest market.
Under Hess's ownership, the Jets were not marketed aggressively. But getting new sponsors or raising prices at Giants Stadium is not enough to compete with wealthier teams like the Cowboys, Browns, Redskins, Buccaneers and Carolina Panthers. The team's net ticket revenues -- gate receipts, a one-third split of luxury suite rentals and club seats -- jumped from $18 million to $24.9 million last season and are pegged at $27.4 million this season. The increase is tied to the construction of additional suites and higher ticket prices.
In 1997, the Jets' $30.50 average ticket price was the N.F.L.'s cheapest. Since then, the average has risen 33 percent to $41.50, according to the publication Team Marketing Report.
And now, the buyer selection grinds on quietly, without comment from the suitors, Jets or Goldman, Sachs. Cablevision's Charles F. Dolan is considered a leader. There is no timetable to choose a new owner, although it is likely to follow what is shaping up to be a disappointing season on the field. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Pataki to Order Emissions Cuts For Power Sites

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki will order power plants in New York State to make sharp cuts in the smokestack emissions that cause acid rain and smog, his aides said yesterday.
The move will raise the state's electricity rates by 1 to 2 percent, they said, but it will put New York substantially ahead of the rest of the country in the cleanup schedule set by the Federal Clean Air Act. 
 Mr. Pataki, who is expected to outline the plan at a news conference today, will order cuts in two kinds of pollution: sulfur dioxide, the main cause of acid rain, and nitrogen oxides, which cause smog and also contribute to acid rain, administration officials said.
While an impending Federal rule would require cuts in nitrogen oxides only in the summer, when smog is at its worst, the new New York State regulations would require the same reductions all year, the officials said.
Word of Mr. Pataki's plans pleased both environmental groups seeking cleaner air and power companies with proposals to build new natural-gas power plants in the state. These plants are costly to build but produce much less pollution than the old coal-burning plants that dominate in western New York.
Under the new rules, the gas-fired plants will be able to compete against coal plants, energy experts say, because the coal plants will have to invest in expensive systems to filter pollution.
"This is a very exciting and bold move by the Governor," said Ned Sullivan, the executive director of Scenic Hudson, a private environmental group. "No other state has mandated this level of reduction for acid rain control."
The slight increase in electric rates would be more than offset by the environmental benefits, said John P. Cahill, the New York Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.
"No one could dispute now that New York has done more than any other state in the country to control emissions from its sources," Mr. Cahill said yesterday, after describing the plan.
In addition, he said, the New York plan could add momentum to efforts in Congress to pass Federal legislation that would require similar reductions.
Owners of some of the state's coal-fired plants, which sit mainly in western New York and the upper Hudson Valley, said they could not comment on specifics until after the Pataki administration released details today.
But some said they planned to comply with whatever new standards emerged once the new regulations were written.
"Our goal is always to meet or exceed environmental standards," said Frank Rapley, a spokesman for NRG Energy Inc., a Minneapolis company that recently bought two of the biggest power plants in the state, Dunkirk and C. R. Huntley, near Buffalo.
Starting next year, a provision of the Clean Air Act will require a 35 percent reduction in nitrogen oxide emissions from power plants, but only from May through September. The state would require the same reduction throughout the year.
As a result, annual emissions would drop from levels like those seen in 1998 -- 102,000 tons -- to 62,000 tons a year, according to state environmental officials. That level is 20,000 tons less than the Federal rule would allow, they said.
The planned reductions in sulfur dioxide emissions would be even sharper, dropping from more than 300,000 tons a year -- the level in 1998 -- to less than 130,000 tons a year, with the reduction being phased in from 2003 to 2007, Mr. Cahill said. Under the Clean Air Act, New York would only be required to cut its sulfur dioxide pollution to 262,000 tons a year, according to state officials.
A spate of recent studies has shown that pollution cuts called for under the Clean Air Act will not be sufficient to repair damage to forests, streams and lakes around the Northeast from acidic rain and snow.
Over all, New York environmental officials calculate, only 17 to 20 percent of the acid rain problem in the Adirondacks and other areas upstate comes from pollution produced by New York's own power plants. The rest comes from coal-fired power plants in the Middle West and South, Mr. Cahill said.
New York has been locked in a dispute for a decade with those states. By moving to cut its pollution, Mr. Cahill said, the state can increase the pressure on them to follow suit.
Officials at the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said that some of Mr. Pataki's planned cuts in power-plant pollution would have been required anyway. Some states downwind of New York have petitioned the E.P.A. to force some of New York's old coal-fired plants to cut pollution that drifts east and contributes to problems.
But they conceded that some of New York's moves, particularly the cut in nitrogen oxides throughout the year, went beyond anything done by any other states.
Many private environmental groups were delighted by the Pataki plan. "It sets a new tone and increases New York's commitment to putting more pressure on Washington to make it all happen," said Ashok Gupta, an economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. But, he said that if Congress did not quickly follow suit with stronger Federal laws, it might still be possible in several years for New York to retreat.
In a separate development, Eliot L. Spitzer, the State Attorney General, who is investigating eight of New York's older power plants for possible violations of Federal and state pollution rules, sent letters on Tuesday to their owners requesting hundreds of pages of documents.
Mr. Spitzer announced last month that he planned to sue the owners of power plants in upwind states, on the ground that their pollution harmed New Yorkers.
According to Larry Shapiro, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a lobbying and environmental organization, the moves by Mr. Pataki and Mr. Spitzer show that New York is finally getting serious about stanching the flow of air pollution, whether its source is smokestacks in upwind states or in New York itself.
"We're going to have to lead by example," Mr. Shapiro said, "and that's what the Governor's doing."
Many air pollution experts said that the maneuvers implied a significant amount of political competition for credit as New York moved toward cutting pollution, with the Republican Governor and Democratic Attorney General eager to be perceived as a leader on the issue.
But Darren Dopp, a spokesman for Mr. Spitzer, said the final result was a good one. "The bottom line is that a little competition between us and them is good for the air," he said yesterday.
