HEADLINE: Senate Approves $8.7 Billion for Emergency Aid to Farmers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Driven by low crop prices, bad weather in many parts of the country and arcane farm-state politics, the Senate gave final legislative approval today to an $8.7 billion package of emergency aid to farmers.
This is the second straight year Congress has spent billions to bail farmers out of financial trouble, raising doubt about the political practicality of applying free-market principles to American farmers. 
 The emergency assistance is part of a $69 billion spending bill to finance agriculture and food programs in the current fiscal year.
The Senate approved the final version by a vote of 74 to 26. The opponents were almost all Easterners from both parties who opposed the way it dealt with milk prices.
The House gave its final approval to the measure on Oct. 1. President Clinton is expected to sign the measure quickly. The Agriculture Department said checks should begin going out to farmers within two weeks.
The new fiscal year began on Oct. 1, but the agriculture bill is only the sixth of 13 spending bills for the Federal departments and agencies to clear Congress. The President vetoed one of those, the bill for the District of Columbia, so only four have become law.
The Government has been running on stop-gap legislation that will expire on Oct. 21 and will almost certainly have to be extended to keep Federal offices open while the politicians work out their differences.
More than half the money in the bill approved today will go for food stamps and other nutrition programs. Much of the rest is earmarked for uncontested agriculture and rural development programs.
To get the final version through Congress, several potentially controversial items were left out by the conferees who reconciled the bills passed by the House and Senate. One would have allowed food and medicine to be shipped to Cuba. Another would have prohibited the Food and Drug Administration from approving abortion drugs like RU-486.
But senators from the East balked when the conferees excluded provisions that would have blocked a new milk-pricing system favored by the Clinton Administration and would have allowed the continuation of a special arrangement that keeps a floor on milk prices in New England. Several other Eastern states hoped to join the New England compact.
On Tuesday the Senate voted, 79 to 20, to cut off a filibuster by the Easterners and bring the bill to a vote.
The dairy question led to strange political bedfellows. Liberal Democrats like Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey voted alongside conservatives like Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Robert C. Smith, the Republican-turned-independent from New Hampshire.
The emergency assistance itself had no opposition, though many senators argued that $8.7 billion was inadequate in the face of Midwestern grain prices that are the lowest in decades and the large crop losses from the drought this summer in the East, floods in the South and crop disease in the upper Midwest.
Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat who voted for the bill, compared it to "throwing a leaking life raft to a drowning person."
"It helps a little bit," he added, "but it's not a long-term solution to the problem."
The consensus in Congress is that additional emergency assistance will be needed when the farm losses in North Carolina from Hurricane Floyd are tallied.
Farm politics is guided much more by regional interests than partisan ones. But Democrats used the bill today to renew their attack on the Freedom to Farm Act of 1996.
The law was one of the central elements of Republican dogma that party leaders got enacted after they won control of Congress in the 1994 elections. It abolished most of the Government price-support programs, in place since the 1930's, on the theory that farmers would fare better in an unfettered marketplace.
Farmers were happy in 1996 and 1997, when commodity prices were high and they were still entitled to what were called transition payments from Washington. But when grain prices began to plunge last year, farmers turned to the Government for help. And the politicians who represent them, regardless of party, obliged.
"The transition turned out to be more difficult than we anticipated," said Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, a leading Republican supporter of the Freedom to Farm Act.
The problem, Mr. Grassley said, was not the principle of the law but the fact that its authors did not anticipate such events as the devaluation of Brazilian currency and the crash in Asian economies, which had a devastating effect on American farm exports.

HEADLINE: State House Journal;
In Massachusetts, Budget Race Is Not to the Swift

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Massachusetts effectively claimed the budgetary booby prize for 1999 today when legislative leaders announced a long-awaited agreement that would finally let the state pass its annual financial plan -- 104 days after the fiscal year began on July 1 and dead last among all 50 states.
The Senate President, Thomas F. Birmingham, and the House Speaker, Thomas M. Finneran -- both Democrats, both powerful figures, and lumped together by some as "the Toms" -- announced their breakthrough today with unconcealed relief after weeks of one-on-one wrangling, often on a secluded State House balcony high on Beacon Hill. 
 When white smoke wafts up from the Vatican, Mr. Birmingham told reporters, people say, "Habemus papam' -- "We have a Pope." So perhaps today it would be appropriate to say, "Habemus rationem pecuniae" -- "We have a financial plan." "Amen!" responded Mr. Finneran with enthusiasm.
Both said the wait had been worthwhile because it had allowed them to hash out compromises on moves of long-term importance to the state, from reforming the finances of the subway system to salting away 70 percent of the hundreds of millions of dollars the state will receive from the tobacco settlement. The two also managed after long debates to agree on increasing prescription drug coverage for low-income elderly, proposing that old people with incomes up to 188 percent of the Federal poverty level be covered by the state for up to $1,250 a year.
But critics remained unmoved by their post-game back-patting and bonhomie, saying the weeks of tardiness, during which monthly interim budgets were passed and no new programs could be financed, had hurt the state, including many poor people and underpaid state employees who were waiting for promised state money.
Critics also derided the two leaders as chamber chieftains whose tete-a-tete talks bespoke an autocratic style typical of a traditional, troubling Massachusetts style of back-room politics.
"The legislature has accomplished next to nothing this year, and I think it's embarrassing," said Brian Cresta, chairman of the state's Republican Party. "Along the way a lot of issues languished and almost died on the vine."
"You expect to see this during bad economic times," Mr. Cresta said, but in good times like these, "It just doesn't make sense to me."
Actually, some experts on state budgets say, it does make sense that financial plans become much harder to pass when times are good -- just as family budgets are harder to agree upon when parents' incomes are up and a "no" to a child's request for a new bike or sound system is harder to justify.
"It appears to be more difficult in times of plenty for states to pass a budget compared to relatively lean years, because in those years, at least legislators understand that there is a limit to how much they can ask for special projects in districts or for special programs they favor," said Arturo Perez, a senior policy specialist who follows state budgets at the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Coming at the end of a record spell of peacetime prosperity, this year's budgets have been especially slow, Mr. Perez said. In Wisconsin, the next-to-last state, the Legislature passed its budget only last week, and perennially tardy New York, whose fiscal year starts in April, was four months late as well.
In Massachusetts, disagreement in the overwhelmingly Democratic legislature was not so much over tax cuts, though the two leaders did wrestle to an agreement over phasing the income tax down from 5.95 percent to 5.75 percent. Rather, it was an intra-Democrat tussle focused more on how much windfall money to squirrel away versus how much to spend now on social programs. Mr. Birmingham appeared to be more for spending, Mr. Finneran more for squirreling.
Prosperity also contributes to slow state budgets in the complacency it engenders among voters, some lawmakers noted.
"Ten years ago, if we didn't have a budget this late in the year, legislators didn't dare go out in public for fear of bodily harm," said State Representative Jim Marzilli, a Democrat from Arlington. "Now, when I meet my constituents on the street, there is a mix of befuddlement and contempt for government -- they ask, 'What's wrong with us?' -- but nobody calls me going, 'Make the budget move!' Even while literally hundreds of thousands of people are harmed by the failure of the legislature to act."
For weeks, The Boston Globe has been carrying a "Budget Watch" noting how many days the budget was late and naming a different set of victims each day, from parents awaiting day care subsidies to school districts crippled in their hiring to elderly patients skimping on their medications.
In contrast, officials in the Republican administration of Gov. Paul Cellucci and some columnists in the more conservative Boston Herald emphasized the positive side of the stalemate: that it saved millions of dollars by holding back planned new spending. (And the wait is not over yet: Mr. Finneran estimates it will be two weeks or so before final details can be worked out and the budget passed.)
But critics like Mr. Marzilli called the delay outrageous.
"As our economy creates two huge classes -- one of winners and one of losers -- the folks who were most hurt by the budget stalemate were the ones left behind," he said. "They are not the people who elect us. And most legislators know that."

HEADLINE: Real Estate Franchising

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"As Market Booms, Real Estate Brokers Slip Their Chains" (Sept. 30) unfortunately drew broad and inaccurate conclusions about our industry. Even the strongest franchise cannot dramatically increase referrals to a location that has little or no population growth, such as Roscoe, N.Y. What it does provide is name recognition and trust, education and training for agents, broad exposure on the Internet and the clout of a strong national marketing campaign. 
 A major point missed by the article is the changing nature of the real estate industry. Residential real estate is undergoing a period of consolidation. The current trend in our industry is toward fewer small offices and more large, well-capitalized, full-service offices. Though this trend varies from market to market, it is driven not only by industry economics, but also by consumer demands for more services. The article correctly noted that Cendant brand franchises participate in about 25 percent of the nation's home sales, but it failed to add that Cendant has been a leader in promoting this consolidation. The result: fewer firms and offices selling more houses. If you analyze the industry by number of firms, there is a drop in franchise affiliations in terms of office count. But if you assess the industry by percentage of transactions handled by brokers and agents of franchised firms, the picture is very different.
 
RICHARD A. SMITH
Chairman and Chief Executive
Cendant real estate division
Parsippany, N.J.
 
Cendant Corporation owns the Century 21, Coldwell Banker and ERA residential franchise systems.

HEADLINE: AT&T on the Electronic Highway

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Oct. 10 editorial "Control of the Electronic Highway" naively perpetuates the myth that AT&T will somehow control television programming in the United States. 
 The combination of AT&T and Mediaone will have fewer than 24 million cable customers -- less than a third of the more than 80 million households subscribing to cable or satellite television service.
AT&T will also have a nearly 25 percent economic interest in the Time Warner Entertainment partnership after our merger with Mediaone.
Reasonable people can disagree about how to attribute Time Warner Entertainment's cable customers to AT&T. But there is no way it could more than double AT&T's cable ownership to the "60 percent of American households" you claim will be "within reach of AT&T's cable programs."
Further, the Federal Communications Commission's new rules appropriately provide that, if a company's economic interest in a cable system is insulated from programming decisions, it should not count toward ownership limits. This is not some "loophole," as you suggest. Rather, this rule preserves programming diversity while allowing companies like AT&T access to a sufficient number of cable lines over which we can offer American families a choice in local phone service. After all, one of the local telephone monopolies will control well over 30 percent of American telephone lines.
You correctly assert that AT&T's cable purchases represent "the first important challenge to the Baby Bells." For that very reason, we look forward to regulatory approval of our acquisition of Mediaone.
 
JAMES CICCONI
Exec. V.P. & Gen. Counsel, AT&T
Washington, Oct. 12, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1173 words

HEADLINE: DEFEAT OF A TREATY: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The G.O.P. Torpedo

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Senate's decisive rejection tonight of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty was the most explicit American repudiation of a major international agreement in 80 years, and it further weakened the already shaky standing of the United States as a global moral leader.
Not since the Versailles Treaty was voted down in November 1919, an action that was repeated in March 1920, has so far-reaching an accord been turned down. In the entire history of the Republic, only 20 treaties negotiated by American Presidents or other officials have been defeated, while 1,523 have been ratified. Tonight, that number rose to 21. 
 By torpedoing a face-saving compromise that was in the works between the White House and the Republican leadership, conservative Republicans made a vote inevitable. And by denying the treaty not only the requisite two-thirds majority but even a simple majority, the conservatives and their allies made good on Senator Jesse Helms's promise to give the agreement a Capitol Hill "funeral."
The control of nuclear weapons has been a central goal of American foreign policy since Dwight D. Eisenhower proposed a ban on all nuclear testing in 1958. All Presidents in the four decades since, Republicans and Democrats, have sought to limit testing and weapons development.
In rejecting the test ban treaty, which President Clinton signed on Sept. 24, 1996, at a ceremony at the United Nations, the Senate halted the momentum built up over the years. No modern arms-control treaty had ever been rejected, although President Carter, who had a hard time winning passage of the Panama Canal treaties, withdrew the SALT II agreement with the Soviet Union from consideration after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.
The SALT agreement was finally ratified in 1996, when memories of Afghanistan had faded, but the Russian Parliament has never acted on it.
The treaty rejected tonight was to have been the capstone of arms control efforts, banning even nuclear tests conducted underground.
Only last week, an international conference in Vienna urged the United States, Russia and China, all of which had signed the global agreement without ratifying it, to accelerate approval as a means of bringing renewed pressure on North Korea, India and Pakistan. They are the only 3 of the world's 44 nuclear-capable nations that have not signed the pact.
On Tuesday of this week, a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry urged American ratification, arguing that it would "serve as an example and promote the ratification of the treaty by other countries."
North Korea has not stated its intentions clearly. India and Pakistan are still trying to decide whether to sign, although the coup in Pakistan this week has raised doubts.
The 15 nations that have signed but not ratified the accord now have far less incentive to ratify. In addition to Russia and China, Egypt and Israel are on that list. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said in a speech in Maine today that the United States would continue to observe the terms of the treaty, conducting no nuclear testing, and urge other nations to do the same.
But the whole point of the treaty was to make such undertakings legally binding, not voluntary, and that now seems unachievable. Ratification by all 44 countries is required for the agreement to take effect.
So the United States finds itself in the position of the spoiler, at a time when it is already stigmatized as a nation that refuses to pay its dues to the United Nations and, in some quarters, as a nation that takes part in international peacekeeping and other such efforts only reluctantly, only in some parts of the world and only when its own ox is being gored.
For Mr. Clinton, whose influence abroad is waning, perhaps more than that of the typical President approaching his final year in office, the rejection of the treaty was the latest in a series of difficulties.
It took place against a backdrop of intense partisan and ideological polarization between the White House and Congress, which the President was unable to neutralize with the finesse he often displays on domestic issues. Such polarization also played a key role in the defeat of the Versailles Treaty, which came at the end of the most popular war the United States had ever fought up to then.
President Wilson invited neither Republican leaders nor important figures in the Senate to Paris for the peace talks, telling associates that the Republicans, who had taken control of both houses of Congress in the 1918 elections, would never dare to refuse ratification. Compounding his error, he refused to compromise with Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and leader of the opposition to the treaty and the League of Nations, which was set up by a covenant within the treaty.
Many of the Republicans, including Lodge, disliked Wilson intensely, and that contributed to the defeat, as did the enmity toward President Clinton of Senator Helms of North Carolina, who is now the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and other conservatives in today's vote. But in 1919 and 1920, unlike today, there was a detailed debate about the treaty on both sides of the Atlantic, with leading thinkers joining in attacks on the treaty.
For example, the great British economist John Maynard Keynes condemned Wilson as "a blind and deaf Don Quixote" who had been "bamboozled" by the more sophisticated Europeans. This time, the debate has been brief and muted, with opponents relying on generalized assertions that the accord would harm United States national security by unwisely limiting sovereignty.
Because it never joined the League of Nations, the United States was able to play no role in its attempts to head off the approach of World War II in places like Ethiopia, then called Abyssinia, and that inevitably weakened the League's peace efforts.
After the defeat of the Versailles Treaty and before today, only five other treaties had been rejected by the Senate. United States adherence to the World Court, an arm of the League of Nations, was one of the most important of the issues involved; it was turned aside in January 1935, at the height of the New Deal, with 20 Democrats forsaking President Roosevelt.
Described as a historic setback at the time, it proved to be much less than that, as the influence of the World Court crumbled in the rush towards war. American adherence would have made little difference.
The St. Lawrence Seaway project was blocked a year earlier, but it was built after World War II. A commercial rights treaty with Turkey was voted down in 1927. More recently, a protocol of the Law of the Sea treaty regarding the compulsory settlement of disputes was rejected (though not the treaty itself), as was an obscure Montreal aviation protocol.
But none of those actions had anything approaching the gravity of tonight's rejection, which went to the very heart of the efforts by the victorious allies to build a safer world in the wake of World War II.

HEADLINE: Canadian-Born Columbia University Economist Wins Nobel Award

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Robert A. Mundell of Columbia University, an eccentric Canadian-born economist whose influence was felt from the supply-side economics of the Reagan years to the creation of the euro, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday.
Professor Mundell, who is 66, was recognized by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences not for his influence on what came to be called Reaganomics, but for his contributions to international economics as the first theorist to demonstrate how the international flow of capital could affect an individual country's ability to manage its own economy through interest rate changes and tax and budget policies. 
 His discovery may seem commonplace today, when tidal waves of money surge around the globe at the click of a computer mouse as professional currency speculators like George Soros cruise from dollars to lire to yen and back again.
But in the early 1960's, when Professor Mundell was developing his prize-winning theories, most nations except for Canada and the United States heavily regulated the flow of capital across their borders and government officials typically tinkered with their own economies without much attention to global currency movements.
"He was way ahead of his time in recognizing that capital mobility had profound effects on the functioning of a country's economy," said Peter Kenen, an economist at Princeton University.
Professor Mundell was in London for a conference yesterday when he learned he had won the prize and the $1 million cash award that accompanies it. He did not return calls left at his hotel, but many economists said yesterday that he had long been considered a leading contender for the profession's top honor.
Although a longtime resident of the United States, Professor Mundell grew up in a small town in Ontario and earned his undergraduate degree in economics at the University of British Columbia. Those Canadian roots were critical to the development of his ideas, several colleagues said.
"In Canada, he had his laboratory," said Rudi Dornbusch, a professor of international economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who once studied under Professor Mundell.
His experiments focused on the two tools that governments use to affect their economic health: monetary policy, which involves changes in interest rates and the money supply, and fiscal policy, the sum of a government's budget and tax decisions.
As a young doctoral student, Professor Mundell observed that Canada's use of monetary policy sometimes worked and sometimes did not, depending on what kind of currency exchange rate policies were in place at the time.
His conclusion, according to the citation released yesterday by the academy in Stockholm, was that "under a floating exchange rate, monetary policy becomes powerful and fiscal policy powerless, whereas the opposite is true when the exchange rate is fixed."
Professor Mundell's work "was very precocious at the time," said Jadish Bhagwhati, a colleague at Columbia. "In those days, you could actually teach about closed economic models -- today it would be ludicrous to do so."
A rumpled, broad-faced man who once wore his unruly white hair down to his shoulders, Professor Mundell was an early advocate of substantial tax cuts as a stimulus to economic growth. When his views attracted the attention of political conservatives in the late 1970's, he found himself on the front lines of Washington policy battles between those who feared the economic impact of huge deficits and those who believed that tax cuts were just the tonic the economy needed.
"His work really began to give intellectual firepower to the supply-side tax cuts movement," said former New York Representative Jack F. Kemp yesterday. "By 1980, then-candidate Ronald Reagan had become persuaded about what Robert Mundell was saying -- and the rest is history."
Jude Wanniski, a former editorial writer for The Wall Street Journal who helped promote Professor Mundell's views, was elated at the news from Stockholm. On his Web site yesterday, he predicted that the honor would give Professor Mundell "the standing to consolidate the supply-side revolution he began."
Professor Mundell has also contributed substantially to the emergence of a common currency for Europe, said Kenneth Rogoff, a professor of economics at Harvard University. "He started people on the road to realizing that it is very, very hard to go to a fixed exchange rate without a common currency," Professor Rogoff said.
More recently, Professor Mundell has generated controversy by encouraging a return to a system of fixed exchange rates, similar to the arrangement established after World War II that called for the value of world currencies to be tied to the United States dollar, which in turn could be redeemed for gold. That system died in 1971, after huge trade deficits had put piles of dollars into the hands of the nation's trading partners, who threatened to redeem them for gold.
One recent paper, published by the Center for Economic Policy Studies at St. Vincent College in Latrobe, Pa., is entitled, "The International Monetary System in the 21st Century: Could Gold Make a Comeback?"
But if exchange rates and monetary policy conjure up an image of a tedious ideologue, nothing could be further from reality, the professor's colleagues and friends said.
"He is decidedly not a nerd," Professor Dornbusch said.
Professor Mundell earned his doctorate in economics in 1956 from M.I.T., after spending a year at the London School of Economics. His various faculty posts included at stint at the University of Chicago, where from 1966 through 1970 he was an editor of the prestigious Journal of Political Economy. The university's famous economics department "was sort of like a mining town in those days, with lots of hard drinking and long poker games," one friend recalled.
He joined Columbia's faculty in 1974, establishing himself in a rambling book-filled apartment in Morningside Heights. An avid painter, he produced roughly 400 richly colored canvases in a single 18-month period, said Mr. Wanniski, who compared the professor's bold abstract artistic style to "Van Gogh gone wild."
Colleagues and proteges have come to covet invitations to his second home, Santa Colomba, an ancient Tuscan villa in Monteriggioni, near Siena, which he purchased from the Catholic Church about 30 years ago and has been slowly restoring to its Renaissance glory.
And a visit to the professor's home page at Columbia's Web site reveals his latest fascination: his baby son, Nicholas, his photogenic offspring from a second marriage. He has three grown children from an earlier marriage, which ended in divorce in 1972.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Sues Makers of Lead Paint

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
The Rhode Island Attorney General sued eight paint manufacturers and a lead industry trade group in state court on Tuesday in an effort to make them pay for treating children poisoned by lead paint and removing lead paint from buildings.
At least a dozen other states, counties and cities are considering filing similar suits, as governments did earlier against the tobacco and gun industries, lawyers involved in the cases said. 
 And as in the suits against cigarette makers, which led to settlements with the states totaling $246 billion, lawyers for Rhode Island are accusing paint manufacturers of knowing lead paint was dangerous, especially to children, and of covering up the risk.
The Federal Government banned lead paint in 1978 because of health concerns, but studies this decade have found that two-thirds of the nation's housing still contains lead paint and that 890,000 children ages 1 to 5 have elevated lead levels in their blood. Ingesting paint chips or dust containing lead can cause severe mental, developmental and behavioral problems, including lowered intelligence, in children.
High lead levels are more common in the Northeast, where many homes and buildings were built more than a generation ago, when lead was a standard ingredient in paint. Rhode Island officials say 20 percent of the state's kindergarten pupils have elevated blood-lead levels.
The Rhode Island suit accuses the eight companies, or companies that they now own, of promoting the use of lead paint while covering up the dangers it posed to children. The suit, filed by Attorney General Sheldon Whitehouse, also names as a defendant the Lead Industries Association, an industry trade group.
The suit did not seek a specific amount in damages but asks the court to force the manufacturers to pay the cost of treating lead poisoned children and the cost of removing lead paint from buildings in the state. Mr. Whitehouse said these costs totaled in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
Several lawsuits against lead paint manufacturers by individual plaintiffs have failed. But the Rhode Island lawsuit seeks a different remedy, following the path of state lawsuits against the tobacco industry.
As in those cases, which sought to recoup the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses, Rhode Island is seeking reimbursement of money spent on the health costs of lead paint, not money to compensate individual victims.
The lawyers pressing the new cases also plan to harness the same financial resources used to pay for the tobacco litigation, as at least three lawyers who played major roles and won huge fee awards in suits against tobacco will be involved in lead-paint cases. The Rhode Island Attorney General said the plaintiffs' lawyers would receive about 17 percent of any verdict or settlement.
Lead industry officials called the lawsuit a "groundless and wasteful action" and said that past lawsuits accusing the industry of conspiracies had failed.
"This is litigation that is trying to make a scapegoat of responsible companies," said Timothy S. Hardy, a lawyer representing N.L. Industries, a defendant in the Rhode Island suit. "The story the plaintiff lawyers are trying to tell is wrong."
Jeff Miller, of the Lead Industries Association, said he had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment on its specifics. But Mr. Miller said lead levels in blood had been falling for years, in part because the industry quit selling lead paint in the early 1960's.
"Most kids are way below any medical level of concern," he said.
Ron Motley, a lawyer in the state tobacco lawsuits, whose firm filed the Rhode Island lead-paint suit, said he believed that documents he has show that the industry covered up the dangers of lead paint, much as tobacco executives had misled the public by disputing government findings on the dangers of smoking.
"They were as omnipresent and evil as the tobacco industry ever hoped to be," Mr. Motley said. "This is not a teen-age problem. This is a toddler problem. The tobacco industry targeted teen-agers, but at least teen-agers could read. You're talking about poisoning children with an odorless, colorless but tasty thing. It's insidious."
A spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York said that the city was looking at the possibility of suing lead paint manufacturers but that no decision had been made.
Other defendants include E.I. duPont De Nemours & Company; the O'Brien Corporation; the Glidden Company, a division of Imperial Chemical Industries, P.L.C.; S.C.M. Chemicals, the Sherwin-Williams Company; American Cyanamid, and the Atlantic Richfield Company. Representatives of some of those companies said that the lawsuit was meritless and that they had always manufactured paint in a safe and appropriate manner. Some companies also said they had not manufactured paint in years. Cytec Industries Inc., which acquired certain assets of American Cyanamid six years ago, said it did not believe the company made lead paint.
The Rhode Island lawyers will seek to contrast advertisements and statements by manufacturers that lead is not harmful with internal and other documents that they contend demonstrate the industry knew of serious health risks but lied about them and sought to delay increased labeling and disclosure.
Subpoenas to the defendants will begin going out this week, lawyers said. But they already have obtained some documents that they say support their accusations, with industry officials dismissing concerns about poisoning as a problem faced largely by "slum children," while also showing that they knew more than 50 years ago that lead was toxic and lead paint dangerous.
One document, from the Lead Industries Association's 1959 annual report, comments that lead poisoning, or the threat of it, "means thousands of items of unfavorable publicity every year."
"This is particularly true," it continued, "since most cases of lead poisoning today are in children, and anything sad that happens to a child is meat for newspaper editors and is gobbled up by the public. It makes no difference that it is essentially a problem of slums, a public welfare problem. Just the same the publicity hits us where it hurts."
And, according to the lawsuit, the association's director of health and safety informed members in 1955 that "childhood lead poisoning is common enough to constitute perhaps my major 'headache,' this being in part due to the very poor prognosis in many such cases, and also to the fact that the only real remedy lies in educating a relatively ineducable category of parents. It is mainly a slum problem with us."
Mr. Hardy, the lawyer for N.L. Industries, said that these documents had been introduced into courts before, and that no judge or jury had yet ruled against the manufacturers.
Don Ryan, executive director of the Alliance to End Childhood Lead Poisoning, a public interest group in Washington, said lead poisoning had long been a more severe problem in lower-income areas. But he said it also afflicted affluent areas, especially when renovations cause the release of lead-paint dust.
Some problems happen because of "the inadvertent creation of hazards at the other end of the economic spectrum, yuppies fixing up the grand old Victorian," said Mr. Ryan, who estimated it would cost $500 billion to remove all the lead paint in the nation's dwellings.
The lead-paint lawsuits will be a reunion of sorts for some of the most important lawyers involved in the state tobacco settlements.
Aside from Mr. Motley, whosefirm in Charleston, S.C., Ness, Motley, Loadholdt Richardson & Poole, represented 28 states in the tobacco litigation, Peter Angelos, the Baltimore Orioles owner who is also a prominent anti-tobacco plaintiff lawyer, filed two cases against lead-paint manufacturers last month in Maryland.
And Richard Scruggs, a Pascagoula, Miss., lawyer who also was instrumental in the tobacco litigation, is expected to play a part in at least a few lead paint lawsuits in the Southeast.

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
A City Reclaims Its Cultural Past

BYLINE: By PAULA DEITZ; Paula Deitz is the editor of The Hudson Review.

 BODY:
During the late 1940's, right after World War II, there was a rich cultural life in Trenton, including opera, ballet and symphony, that centered on the theater in the War Memorial building, completed in 1932 to commemorate local citizens who died in World War I. Unlike the sprawling performing arts centers that succeeded this compact genre, War Memorial buildings were designed to house numerous civic events. Half town meeting house, half theater, the civic auditorium as a civilizing force in the community had an architectural presence akin to museums, banks, courthouses and city halls.
Trenton's War Memorial building exuded a sophisticated opulence and grandeur that made the audience dress up to attend performances, but like many civic structures during the great catastrophe of urban renewal that obliterated downtowns, the War Memorial, despite its proximity to the State Capitol, slipped into dowdiness as the downtown area shifted away. Governor Thomas H. Kean took notice in 1988 (it has been the site of all gubernatorial inaugurations since its opening) and announced that the building would be renovated. Earlier this year, after going dark for five years, the War Memorial reopened and is more splendid than ever. But best of all, it once again has a full program of performances. 
 The reborn Trenton War Memorial Theater is only one of several cultural and historic places in Trenton to visit for special reasons this fall, all in what is known as the Capitol Complex, the buildings clustered around the State House along the Delaware River. In addition to attending a matinee or evening performance in the theater, one can visit the New Jersey State Museum; the restored 19th-century rotunda under the Capitol dome; the Old Barracks Museum, reconfigured to its 18th-century military period, and the 1719 Queen Anne-style mansion of William Trent, after whom the city is named.
Trenton's limestone and granite War Memorial is a blend of neo-Italian Renaissance and Art Deco styles with a high parapet and an Ionic colonnade leading to the Memorial Court, the main entrance, with its blue, green and gold terra-cotta ceiling and dedication plaques.
In 1946 and 1947 the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo performed dances there choreographed by George Balanchine before he helped found the New York City Ballet. Among the works were "Concerto Barocco," the first "Mozartiana" and "The Night Shadow" (now "La Sonnambula"), the latter with Alexandra Danilova and Maria Tallchief, who had danced at its premiere in New York in 1946.
And in 1948, before starring in "South Pacific" on Broadway, Ezio Pinza sang Mephistopheles in Gounod's "Faust," and his daughter, Claudia, sang Marguerite in the Trenton Opera Association's production. In addition to being performed by invited stars, the opera repertory was presented by local singers in the minor roles and the Trenton Opera Chorus.
Trenton at that period had a cultural life unto itself, not necessarily dependent on Philadelphia or New York. What's more, the theater would hold a graduating class of more than 1,000 from Trenton Central High School. Dance teachers held their student recitals in the ballroom. And when John F. Kennedy ran for President, he stood between the Ionic columns during an autumn twilight and spoke to thousands standing in the plaza below.
While the War Memorial's interior remained intact during the renovation, every marble and painted surface and all the bronze light fixtures and railings had to be revitalized to restore their gleam and glitter. The Vitetta Group, architects and engineers based in Cherry Hill, N.J., and Philadelphia who undertook the renovation, had the advantage of the original drawings by the building's architect, Louis S. Kaplan. Kaplan had been the chief draftsman for William A. Klemann, the architect for the preliminary plan, who died during the process. An analysis by Matthew J. Mosca, a historical paint consultant, revealed the bright colors that gave the theater its fantasy environment.
Hyman Myers, the director of historic preservation for Vitetta, sees the 1,800-seat theater, in its new raiment, fulfilling its role as "a spaceship to an imaginary dream world," with updating to enhance the acoustics and improve the stage machinery.
 
Architecture Grand as Opera
What delights the eye are the decorative surfaces of rose and saffron further embellished with gilded plaster; the newly polished marble walls and terrazzo floors of the corridors, and bronze classical motifs like the image of Terpsichore, the muse of the dance in her diaphanous garb. An immense ceiling medallion festooned with garlands and smaller medallions in the same warm palette glows in soft illumination. Even the rust-colored stage curtain was reproduced down to the last gold tassel from a photograph in the archives of the Greater Trenton Symphony Orchestra.
A performance last spring of "Rigoletto" by the War Memorial's resident company, Boheme Opera N.J., took full advantage of the broad stage with one architectural set that seemed to turn inside out depending on the scene. The hall was filled, and those with years in the know found the balcony seats the best for a complete overview of the theater, the stage and the recent addition of supertitles.
The company's artistic director and conductor, Trenton-born Joseph Pucciatti, founded Boheme Opera 11 years ago with his wife, Sandra Milstein-Pucciatti, a concert pianist who is managing director and assistant conductor. One hour before the "Rigoletto" performance, the couple gave their customary cogent and amusing precurtain talk in the War Memorial's blue, mauve and silver Art Deco ballroom. These talks are usually packed, and as in earlier times, it was heartening to see many children in attendance. While Mr. Pucciatti gave the background of the characters, describing the real Duke of Mantua, and of Victor Hugo's 1832 play "Le Roi S'Amuse," on which the opera is based, his wife played the relevant themes on the piano.
 
A Link to Russia
Since 1986 Trenton has been a sister city to the Central District of Moscow. Out of this relationship and under the sponsorship of the American-Russian Cultural Cooperation Foundation, Trenton was selected as the only East Coast site for a major international touring exhibition: "Unseen Treasures: Imperial Russia and the New World," which includes 300 art objects and artifacts from the Russian State Historical Museum and the State Archive of the Russian Federation in Moscow. Its opening, which had been scheduled for this weekend, has been postponed because of delays in shipping the works from Russia; it is now expected to open in late November.
Commemorating the founding in 1799 of the Russian-American Company, the exhibition will document the little-known story of the Russian colonization of what is now Northern California and Alaska, an effort motivated by the fur trade.
Marilyn Pfeifer Swezey, the guest curator of "Unseen Treasures," describes the exhibition as "a trip from imperial Russia across Siberia to the New World, and back for the coronation of Alexander II in 1855." This unusual and sumptuous display combines objects from the imperial courts, including paintings, costumes, jewelry and furniture, with those of the world of Siberian merchants and voyages to the New World. An important segment of cultural history incorporating the role of the Orthodox Church is being shown in the United States for the first time, Ms. Swezey said.
 
A Restored Rotunda
While the museum is in a 1960's building, the State House is the second oldest state capitol in continuous use. Completed in 1792, four years behind the one in Annapolis, Md., there were several additions and demolitions due to fire over the years. The present north wing and rotunda, reflecting the French style of the Italian Renaissance, was built in 1889 and is the work of a Jersey City architect, Lewis Broome. Recently regilded with Florentine gold leaf, the dome, which symbolizes representative government in the United States, has once again become a gleaming beacon over the city.
Under the dome, the 105-foot-high, three-tiered rotunda has also been restored. Completed this summer, it equals the War Memorial's in its richness of decor, as Mr. Mosca was on board again to discover the original paint pigments. Venetian-red walls and a salmon ceiling from the 1895 period once again offset the marble wainscoting trimmed in bronze and the gleaming balcony railings supported by cast-iron brackets in the form of fire-breathing dragons. On walls between stained-glass windows hang the portraits of New Jersey's Governors, beginning with its first, William Livingston. It is a dignified and exhilarating space.
 
Historic Barracks
Around the corner, going back even earlier to the Colonial period, is the Old Barracks. It has also seen many transitions since it first quartered British soldiers in 1758, when the local residents no longer wished to house them. When it was built, it was the largest building in Trenton. It probably housed Tory sympathizers and Hessian military scouts before Gen. George Washington routed them out in the Battle of Trenton, the day after Christmas in 1776.
For many years in this century the Old Barracks was a museum of Colonial curios. Since 1985, archeologists, architects and historians have put the fieldstone building back into its original configuration, trimmed with cantilevered wooden balconies and staircases. The Georgian-style officers' house at one end shows clearly that the upper ranks lived in more genteel conditions than the soldiers, who slept four to a two-tiered bunk in the barracks. The parade ground in front reinforces the military air.
But the man who truly set a stylish tone for the early township was William Trent. His brick house built in 1719, the oldest surviving dwelling in Trenton, is surrounded by a little park and once again has a view of the river now that the surrounding streets have been cleared away during urban renewal. A merchant and ship owner from Scotland who was a partner with William Penn in Philadelphia, Trent settled at his country estate on 800 acres along the Delaware in New Jersey and became the state's Chief Justice.
The house, mostly intact from the period and furnished with paneling and William and Mary furniture described in a 1726 inventory taken two years after his death, resembles on a smaller scale a fine Baroque mansion in England. It not only demonstrates that early Colonial leaders were in touch with current English taste, but also represents the high standard that Trent set for Trenton.
In addition to being the state capital, Trenton gained prominence as an industrial town in the 19th century from the production of Roebling wire cable for suspension bridges and from the manufacture of ceramics and fine china. And with this prominence came a motto emblazoned across one of the bridges over the Delaware River that can be seen from trains running between Philadelphia and New York. Now, as the city makes a comeback with its reputation for cultural life, the motto still applies: "Trenton Makes, the World Takes."
 
Travels in Trenton
 
Trenton is about 53 miles south of New York City. The Trenton Convention and Visitors Bureau is on Lafayette Street at Barrack Street, (609) 777-1770. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
 
Attractions

Boheme Opera NJ: "Sang Sista' Sang," a musical tribute to the singers Bessie Smith, Billie Holliday, Dinah Washington, Dorothy Dandridge, Josephine Baker and Mahalia Jackson, featuring an ensemble of six singers, Oct. 26-28; tickets, $18.50 to $25. "L'Elisir d'Amore" by Donizetti with Lorraine Ernest, soprano; Barton Green, tenor; David Arnold, baritone; William Walker, bass-baritone. Performances on Nov. 5 at 8 P.M (precurtain talk at 7 P.M.) and Nov. 7 at 3 P.M. (precurtain talk at 1:45 P.M.) Opera box office: (609) 581-7200. Tickets: $20 to $50. Tomorrow, 8 P.M. Tickets: $15 to $58. All-Haydn program. Conductor and violinist: Pinchas Zukerman; Dec. 10, 8 P.M. Tickets: $14 to $46. Symphony box office: (800) 255-3476. Tickets: $10 to $58.

The trip takes from 60 to 80 minutes. Amtrak round trip fare, $62 to $96 (half-price for children 2 to 15). New Jersey Transit, $18.90 (half-price for children under 11).

HEADLINE: Boeing Profit Beats Forecasts for Third Consecutive Quarter

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Continuing its financial rebound, the Boeing Company beat Wall Street earnings estimates for the third consecutive quarter yesterday and promised more good news to come.
Boeing, the world's largest aerospace company and the nation's single largest exporter, said its third-quarter profit grew 37 percent as its formerly ailing passenger jet business improved its efficiency. Net income for the quarter was $477 million, or 52 cents a diluted share, compared with profit of $347 million, or 36 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $13.28 billion from $12.72 billion. 
 Analysts had expected the company to earn 49 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Shares of Boeing soared $3.125 yesterday, to $43.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"There was some decent productivity in the quarter," said Howard Rubel, an aerospace and military industry analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.
Boeing's stock was battered last year in the wake of production problems at its flagship commercial airplane division in late 1997, which forced the company to halt production of its 747 and 737 jetliners for a month. Boeing has continued to suffer because it sold many of its jets to airlines at steep discounts while its costs soared.
The company has since tried to streamline factory production, a process that appears to be bearing fruit. At the passenger jet division, quarterly profit was $501 million on sales of $8.5 billion, in contrast to a loss of $142 million on revenue of $7.8 billion in the quarter a year earlier. Operating profit rose to 5.9 percent from a negative 1.8 percent in the period a year earlier.
At the height of the crisis last year, Boeing warned that production of the 747 jumbo jet, which is the company's most profitable airplane, might fall to one a month because of the economic crisis in Asia. But the company announced yesterday what analysts and investors had assumed for months: 747 production will remain at two a month next year.
"The strengthening Asian economy looks like it will give us a smooth landing," Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday during a conference call with analysts. He also predicted that demand for Boeing's passenger jets would remain flat in 2001 rather than decline from next year's projected level, as the company had previously estimated.
Boeing raised its forecast for its full-year operating profit margins to a range of 5.5 percent to 6 percent this year from its prediction of 4.5 percent in January. Next year's profit margins are expected to be 5.5 percent to 6.5 percent, Boeing said, up from a forecast of 3.5 percent to 5 percent earlier this year.
But Deborah Hopkins, Boeing's chief financial officer, said the company hoped to do better than that next year, even though Boeing's revenue is expected to decline by $11 billion as deliveries of passenger jets decline to 480 from 620. "Our challenge is to attempt to have 2000 earnings be equal or exceed 1999," she said. "That would require us to get to operating margins of about 7 percent for the total company."
Some analysts worried that Boeing might be cutting too much. Research and development spending was down for the third consecutive quarter. It has fallen 28 percent in the first nine months of this year, to $1 billion from $1.4 billion in 1998. But Ms. Hopkins said that the decline was temporary and that Boeing had earmarked enough research money to finance new planes, including a larger version of the 747.
Indeed, Boeing generated $1.1 billion in cash during the latest quarter after spending $1 billion buying 2.25 million shares of its own stock. It now has $2.8 billion in cash on its balance sheet.
Mr. Condit said that he was not worried by recent gains by Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, which has received orders for 329 jets this year, compared with 138 for Boeing, according to Merrill Lynch. Confirming a report that Frontier Airlines was the latest airline to choose Airbus's narrow-body planes over Boeing's 737, Mr. Condit said that Boeing could not match the low price offered by Airbus and still make a profit.

HEADLINE: The Senate's Harmful Vote

 BODY:
President Clinton's forceful and focused performance at yesterday's news conference must mark the beginning of a sustained White House effort to limit the damage inflicted by the Senate's reckless vote Wednesday against the nuclear test ban treaty. It will be up to Mr. Clinton to convince other nations, including those that have already signed the treaty, like Russia and China, and those that have not, like India, Pakistan and North Korea, that the United States remains committed to observing its provisions and eventually ratifying it in a new Senate vote. In these and other ways, his Administration must demonstrate America's continued determination to reduce nuclear dangers throughout the world. The Senate should want to send exactly the same message. Unfortunately, it did not.
With its abrupt scheduling, rushed debate and needless negative vote on the test ban treaty, the Republican Senate majority all but abdicated its constitutional responsibility to play a thoughtful and deliberative role in the shaping of American foreign policy. It also undermined Washington's ability to provide diplomatic leadership on one of the most important questions facing the world today -- controlling the development and spread of nuclear weapons. 
 With the United States now the world's foremost military and economic power, senators as well as presidents must rise to the challenge of international leadership, helping to project the moral vision of the American people onto the global arena. Too many senators failed this crucial test.
Senators have a complex and serious role to play on foreign policy matters. Their duty is not to assent passively to every presidential initiative, but to engage their own minds and consciences, particularly on grave questions of war, peace and treaties. Too many Republican senators shortchanged that duty by allowing the majority leader, Trent Lott, and a handful of committed treaty opponents to turn the test ban issue into a partisan arm-wrestling contest with the White House and Senate Democratic leadership.
At no time in the ludicrously compressed Senate debate was the country offered a serious alternative Republican view of how to contain the alarming development of nuclear weapons in South Asia and their potential spread to such troubled areas as the Middle East and the Korean Peninsula. Instead, many opponents spoke as if the United States could afford to turn its back on international arms control treaties and address the spread of nuclear weapons solely through superior military strength. As Mr. Clinton noted yesterday, that kind of armed isolationism makes little sense and offers no real security at the dawn of the 21st century.
America's most honored foreign policy tradition is bipartisanship. The Senate so rarely votes to reject major treaties that the last comparable precedent was Woodrow Wilson's defeat over the Treaty of Versailles nearly 80 years ago. That disastrous decision weakened Washington's voice in international affairs. This one threatens to do the same unless Mr. Clinton manages to keep alive some momentum for nuclear arms control and the Senate returns to its traditions of serious and constructive foreign policy debate. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Decline Further; 30-Year Yield Is Now 6.32%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Driven by some investors' concern that strong economic growth will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates, bond yields climbed for a third consecutive day yesterday.
Prices of Treasury securities, which move in the opposite direction from yields, fell again on fresh evidence that consumers are buying more and paying more for imported goods. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond declined 20/32, to 97 13/32. Its yield rose to 6.32 percent from 6.27 percent on Wednesday, the highest level since Oct. 22, 1997, when it reached 6.41 percent. 
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales were up last month, but not as much as expected, while the Labor Department stirred market fears with a report saying that prices of imported goods kept rising last month.
Analysts argued that yesterday's figures had proved counterproductive for the bond market because they did not really suggest that the trend of strong consumer spending had changed.
Referring to the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee, Donald Fine of Chase Asset Management said, "The bond market has been in a heightened state of alert for signs of inflation now that the F.O.M.C. is officially biased toward tightening, particularly in light of upcoming data that are not expected to be market-friendly."
He continued: "While the Fed specifically stated that it is not committed to any near-term action, a firming of its policy stance at the next F.O.M.C. meeting on Nov. 16 is a distinct possibility, and in fact is now expected by market participants, judging from the spread between the two-year Treasury note and the Federal funds rate. At this juncture, it would appear that only a sudden, significant deterioration in the economy's performance or imminent sharp contraction in the stock market could quickly alleviate inflation concerns and keep the Fed at bay."
Consumer spending, the key to the economic outlook, still seems healthy. September retail sales rose one-tenth of a percent, compared with the two-tenths of a point that had been expected. But, some argued, this did not seem to indicate a slowdown in the economy since it came on the heels of outsized increases of 1.5 percent and 1 percent in August and July, respectively.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said the retail sales report masked powerful third-quarter growth. "U.S. consumers paused for breath in September," she said, "but the underlying trend remains undeniably strong. Even with the September lull, sales are still up a towering 10.5 percent from year-ago levels and they expanded at a healthy 9.5 percent annual pace in the third quarter."
Analysts are awaiting today's producer price figures. They forecast that the core and overall price figures will be up four-tenths or five-tenths of a percent, stronger than in recent months. "Each new piece of strong data is adding to fears that the Fed is falling behind," said Stanley Shepard of Standard & Poor's MMS in San Francisco.
Many investors are opting to buy corporate debt to give them a bigger yield cushion if inflation accelerates.
Robert Pugliese, fixed-income director at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., said he saw a lack of conviction in the market at this point, with not many people willing to make buying bets. "If the P.P.I. number takes an inflationary turn, I see the long-bond yield gravitating toward 6.5 percent," he said. "If it proves benign, do not expect a major rally, either."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rise Again; Jobless ClaimsFall 29,000

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Retail sales rose in September as furniture and department stores reported their best months since early this year, Government figures showed today.
Retail sales rose one-tenth of a percent in September on top of a 1.5 percent gain in August, the largest in six months, the Commerce Department said. Compared with results in the month a year earlier, sales were up 10.5 percent, the second-highest year-over-year gain since March 1994. 
 When automobiles are excluded, the September increase was a larger-than-expected six-tenths of a percent after a gain of nine-tenths of a percent in August.
Spending could continue to gain as workers have little trouble finding jobs, a separate report from the Labor Department suggested today. First-time claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell below 300,000 last week after two weekly increases because of Hurricane Floyd.
"The U.S. consumer is not showing any sign of shopping fatigue," said Tim O'Neill, chief economist with Bank of Montreal and Harris Bank in Toronto. "Once you get past the impact of Hurricane Floyd, you have a tight labor market and robust consumer spending."
Federal Reserve policy makers have indicated they may raise interest rates again if strong economic growth leads to higher inflation. That has not shown up yet, even as a Labor Department report today showed that prices businesses paid for imports rose seven-tenths of a percent last month after rising 1 percent in August, both mostly because of higher oil costs. Excluding oil, September import prices rose one-tenth of a percent, the same as in August. Including oil, import prices have increased in six of the last seven months. Without it, they have changed little month to month.
Same-store sales at United States retailers rose 5.5 percent in September, according to industry figures released last week. Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, reported a 7.2 percent increase in sales last month as shoppers stocked up on school supplies and bought provisions before Hurricane Floyd.
The home furnishing industry continues to benefit from record housing sales. The furniture makers Ethan Allen Interiors and Stanley Furniture reported record sales and earnings this week for the three months ended in late September.
Another inflation concern for Fed officials is whether the supply of available workers is dwindling so much that businesses will have to increase wages -- and eventually prices -- to attract and retain employees. Today's report on jobless claims did nothing to ease that concern.
First-time jobless claims fell 29,000, to a seasonally adjusted 285,000 for the week ended Oct. 9, Labor Department figures showed. The unexpected decline came after a gain of 12,000, to 314,000 claims, the previous week that was mostly a result of to work disruptions caused by the hurricane in mid-September.
The four-week average for claims, which smoothes out the volatile weekly data, fell to 293,750 last week from 294,500. That was the 12th week the average has been below 300,000, the longest such stretch since 1974. Jobless claims have averaged 300,756 a week so far this year, lower than the 1998 average of 316,000.

HEADLINE: South Carolina High Court Derails Video Poker Games

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The country's largest video gambling industry faced extinction today when the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that the state's 34,000 video poker machines must be unplugged by midnight June 30.
In a swift stroke, the court put an end to the most rancorous issue now confronting South Carolina, with all five justices voting to silence the poker machines that have taken root in virtually every convenience store and gas station in the state. 
 The poker machines were at the core of the state's election for governor last year, and public anger against them had produced a feverish campaign in recent weeks for a Nov. 2 referendum on whether the machines should remain legal.
That referendum was declared unconstitutional today by the Supreme Court, triggering a legal provision requiring the machines to be banned after June 30.
The surprise decision, the result of a legal miscalculation by one video poker operator, is the second major defeat this week for organized gambling in the South. On Tuesday, with the encouragement of religious leaders, voters in Alabama rejected a plan to create a state lottery for the benefit of education.
Church groups had also been active in South Carolina in campaigning against the video machines, which were called the crack cocaine of gambling in a recent national study because of their addictive nature. Joined by most of the state's business community and many of its politicians, the anti-poker effort had appeared likely to suffocate the state's $2.8-billion-a-year gambling industry at the ballot box. Polls showed 61 percent of expected voters planned to vote against the machines.
The court's ruling, however, said the referendum was unconstitutional because it improperly gave voters the ability to legislate, a right reserved for the State Legislature. The South Carolina Constitution, unlike those of some other states, does not contain a provision allowing referendums on legislative matters.
The court then went a step further and said that under the law authorizing the referendum, video poker could continue only if the voters approved. Because the referendum was illegal, the court said, the machines would have to be prohibited.
Opponents of video poker had helped write the law with this possibility in mind, because it was never clear that the public had a legitimate right to vote on the matter.
The video industry wanted the law to say that poker would stay alive unless it was killed by the voters, but legislators decided that poker would die unless it was kept alive by the voters. And the law explicitly said that if the referendum should be declared illegal the provision outlawing video poker would stay in effect. The high court upheld that section of the law.
Gambling opponents were overjoyed by the decision.
"We were watching on TV when it was announced, and there was a lot of shouting, high-fives, tears of disbelief, and joy," said the Rev. Steve Hogg, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Rock Hill and a leader of Change South Carolina, a prominent anti-poker group. "It looks the gambling industry knew they were going to lose at the ballot box, and one of them went to court to stop the vote. Boy, did that backfire on them."
In fact, most of the industry, fearing just such a ruling, had declined to challenge the referendum in court. But one small operator, Joytime Distributors and Amusements in Greenville, filed suit against the referendum law, hoping the entire law would be thrown out and the machines could stay.
Other operators filed briefs to get the lawsuit thrown out. But to the industry's chagrin, the court ruled that only the referendum was illegal, while the rest of the law banning poker was upheld.
Theoretically, the industry could persuade the Legislature to change the law, but legislative leaders said they were unlikely to revive the issue. Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat who accepted $3 million from poker interests last year, half his campaign treasury, but later announced he would vote against gambling, said today that the industry did not have the votes to revive itself.
"Clearly, as of June 30, the net result of this will be that video gaming will no longer exist in South Carolina," Governor Hodges said. "We will move on and talk about other important issues on the agenda in South Carolina."
One issue will be a state lottery, which will be on the South Carolina ballot in November 2000. Although Mr. Hodges built much of his campaign last year on support for a lottery, opponents of gambling hope the momentum from the effort against video poker will carry over into a defeat for a state numbers game, much like the vote in Alabama.
But video poker has far more opponents than the lottery. Business leaders have said poker is destroying South Carolina's image, and many people have been galvanized by the sight of impoverished poker players feeding money into the machines.
The poker industry, which had held out hopes that a statewide advertising blitz might persuade voters to keep their business alive, was clearly stunned by today' court ruling. Mike Fletcher, a spokesman for the South Carolina Coin Operators Association, said the state's 650 operators were so focused on the referendum that they barely knew how to respond to the ruling.
"It's the highest court in the state, so I don't know how you change that," Mr. Fletcher said. "We're all kind of shocked and saddened, but I guess we'll take some time to study the order and figure out where we go next. Fortunately, we're not out of business tomorrow."
He said there might be some way to convert the machines to nongambling amusements, like pinball, but he admitted that would make them far less popular.
Gambling supporters had warned that 28,000 workers faced layoffs if poker was outlawed, from repairers to store clerks to the attendants that were required by law to supervise every five machines. Even if that 28,000 figure was an exaggeration, it was clear that many people whose livelihoods came from the machines faced an uncertain future.
"The unemployment line is going to be out the door, and I'm going to be in it," said Chris Moskovic, assistant manager of the Slots of Fun video parlor in West Columbia, which has 10 machines. "This is like the state is telling me I have no rights, taking food from my family's table. It's pretty close to being communist."
Francis Rice, a cashier at Cherokee Games in Fort Mill, one of the casino-like parlors that cluster on the border with North Carolina, said she would miss the friends she had made among the parlor's regulars.
"This was one of the nice places," Ms. Rice said. "It was nicely decorated, and they even paid benefits. But I guess I could always go back to waitressing."

HEADLINE: 1999 PLAYOFFS: LEAGUE CHAMPIONSHIPS;
Polar People Surfacing With Yanks and Mets In

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
I am in conflict, too.
Why shouldn't choosing between the Yankees and the Mets be as easy as choosing between the Beatles and the Stones, Apple and I.B.M., Lancaster and York, Good and Evil? It's just brand equity. Two ball teams. 
 But no. Ever since Dr. Margaret Mead and the sports pundits who also considered themselves anthropologists proclaimed the Yankees and the Mets rival tribes, their fans have been made to define themselves by the choice. When it merely leads to bar fights over who would win a Subway Series, there is no harm done. But when cultural, class and economic divisions are perpetuated, we have trouble here on River Avenue.
The anthro pop quizzes drive me nuts. Do you like opera? You're a Yankee fan. Do you shop at Kmart? You're a Mets fan. And this is supposed to be whether your seat is behind the dugout or behind the right fielder. Do you call them drapes or curtains, a couch or a sofa? From that answer, someone will be able to tell you that the rich man you admire is either Fred Wilpon or George Steinbrenner. Do you perceive cancer or mental illness as the frontier of health care discussion? From that answer we know you identify with either Joe Torre (recovering from prostate treatment) or Bobby Valentine (reveling in mood swings). This is sick.
And the lunch-pail versus humidor construct, polyester versus linen, Figaro versus Count Almaviva, is basically lame. The Mets of the 80's personified the stinking cigars of Wall Street, while Yankee Stadium has for years been overrun with low-rent slobs.
And not only is this lame, it also leads to the easy, dangerous thinking that there are only two kinds of people in the world, and the twain will never meet or merge or morph. Yea and behold, we call these polar people, Yankees or Mets.
So where does that leave me? I love them both. Differently.
I was born in the Bronx, as were my father and mother, and so my diapers were pinstripes (chalk stripes, actually, but that just leads us back to drapes and couches). My father wasn't impressed by Joe DiMaggio because he had grown up with the Babe.
During my childhood in Queens, there were three major league teams and no regional pressure. I always felt that Giant fans were arrogant front-runners and Dodger fans were sweatily righteous, but I did not make my choice based on rooting for the equivalent of U.S. Steel. I always thought the Yankees were the true outsider-immigrant-striver team. They were the best because of merit, not because swells trooped up to the Polo Grounds or poets found Elysium in Ebbets Field.
And then I met the Mets on my first important out-of-town assignment. I brought my glove to their opening spring training in 1962, which was also the first time I tried to hit major league pitching -- actually, it was a sore-armed coach throwing batting practice. For me, it might as well have been Whitey Ford. I have never lost respect. That day, I just went to the bar and let Mets Manager Casey Stengel talk and drink me under the table. He had also been manager of the Yankees.
In fact, three of the most interesting New York ballplayers of my times have been both Mets and the Yankees. David Cone as a young wise guy was one of those rich, victorious, out-of-control 80's Mets. He was accused of flashing in the bullpen. He was an outlaw hero of the tell-all tomes. Perfect David Cone is now an elder statesman of the Yankee locker room.
Darryl Strawberry, brought up before his time by the greedy Mets, never quite fulfilled his promise (Mets' management billed him as "the next DiMaggio") but he enjoyed and destroyed himself in the garden of earthly delights. Who resurrected him? The Boss.
And Marvelous Marv Throneberry, promoted as the quintessential Met when the team was lionized as the worst in baseball (it was the rebirth of irony), had come up as a Yankee bonus baby. He roamed the outfield with the Mick, pinch-hit in the 1958 World Series. Years later, he said: "I kind of think of myself as a former Yankee, not a Met. A man is always sentimental about his first team."
So, you see my problem and I see yours.
Let's leave it at this: There are only two kinds of people in the world; those who duck foul balls and those who stand up to catch them.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Co. BuysMassachusetts Paper for $295 Million and Posts Rise in Profit

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company bought The Worcester Telegram & Gazette yesterday for $295 million, expanding its reach in Massachusetts, where it already owns The Boston Globe, and making a major investment in the newspaper industry, which is currently buoyed by record advertising.
The industry's boom was reflected yesterday in the Times Company's earnings report, which showed net income for the third quarter rising 9.2 percent, to $60 million, on revenue of $729.7 million. The revenue total was 6.9 percent above the 1998 third-quarter total of $682.7 million. 
 Operating profit, excluding such special items as the cost of work force reductions at The Boston Globe, rose 11.2 percent, to $112.8 million from $101.4 million, an increase spurred by a 9.9 percent increase in newspaper advertising revenue, which rose to $460.9 million.
Excluding the special items, the company earned 36 cents a diluted share, one cent above the consensus estimate reported by First Call/ Thomson Financial.
The company's purchase of the Worcester newspaper, with a daily circulation of 107,000 and a Sunday circulation of 134,000 in central Massachusetts, ended a lively competition among at least seven newspaper companies bidding for the remaining newspaper properties of the Chronicle Publishing Company, which sold its flagship, The San Francisco Chronicle, this summer to the Hearst Corporation.
One rival bidder, according to those who participated in the negotiations, was the Community Newspaper Company, which is based in Needham, Mass., and publishes dailies in Framingham and Milford, Mass., as well as more than 100 nondaily newspapers around the state. Another was the Denver-based Media News Group Inc., which owns five dailies in northern and central Massachusetts.
The competition among bidders reflects the desire of newspaper companies to consolidate, or cluster, their holdings in one geographic area, to gain efficiencies in everything from printing and distribution to advertising sales.
Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for the Times Company, said that the company forecast economies in joint advertising sales between The Globe and The Telegram & Gazette as well as centralizing of newsprint buying, accounting and record-keeping.
According to one person who has inspected the paper's financial statements, the $295 million price was about 13.5 times the 1998 cash flow of The Telegram & Gazette -- a multiple well below that paid by Pulitzer Inc. to Chronicle Publishing for The Pantagraph, a newspaper in Bloomington, Ill., that has a circulation of 49,600.
Eight days ago, Pulitzer announced its acquisition of The Pantagraph for a purchase price of $180 million, representing a multiple of roughly 19 times 1998 cash flow, according to one newspaper company adviser who had seen the financial information circulated by Chronicle Publishing.
But the Worcester acquisition was still a strong reminder of the prices newspapers can command these days.
"The Worcester price is just reflective of the very strong state of the newspaper marketplace," said Owen Van Essen, the president of the newspaper brokerage firm of Dirks, Van Essen. He also said that newspapers the size of The Telegram & Gazette that dominate their markets -- the newspaper reaches 43 percent of the homes in Worcester County -- do not come on the market often.
Mr. Van Essen added, "There is bullishness in newspaper companies" -- a comment bolstered by recent increases in the share price of some newspaper companies. The Times Company, Knight Ridder, Dow Jones & Company and Times Mirror Company all hit 52-week highs within the last week.
The Worcester purchase, however, had little effect on analysts' views of the activities of the Times Company, particularly since the cash outlay for the deal is dwarfed by the $376 million the company has spent to repurchase its stock this year.
Two analysts, Lauren Rich Fine of Merrill Lynch & Company and Kevin R. Gruneich of Bear, Stearns, used the same word -- "nonevent" -- to describe the Worcester newspaper purchase.
Both analysts focused instead on the resurgence of advertising revenue at The Boston Globe, which took in $114.4 million in ad revenue in the third quarter, a 9.8 percent increase over the corresponding period in 1998. The New York Times newspaper took in $260.5 million in the period, an increase of 10.9 percent.
"The most pleasant surprise was the upward pivot in Boston Globe advertising," Mr. Gruneich said. He added that he also saw "some awfully good momentum at Times Company Digital" -- the division of the company that includes Web sites like nytimes.com and boston.com.
The number of registered users of The New York Times on the Web rose to 8.7 million, an increase of 900,000 over the June 30 figure.
Times Company shares closed yesterday at $40.4375, down 56.25 cents and off more than $2 from the record high of $43 reached on Monday.
