HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: When Being Wrong Won't Hurt;
Economists' Ideas Are Valued More Than Their Forecasts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
If the forecasts of Wall Street economists are often so wrong, how do they keep their jobs? How do they make any money?
Those are fair questions after a string of years -- including 1999 -- when many seers of Wall Street missed their calls on interest rates, were wrong on the direction of Federal Reserve policy, and substantially underestimated economic growth and even overestimated inflation. 
 From 1996 through 1998, for example, the consensus economic forecast at the start of the year turned out to be, on average, 1.4 percentage points below the actual annual growth rate, according to the Blue Chip Economic Indicators. And the consensus estimate for 1999 -- 2.4 percent as recently as January -- is already well below the 3.4 percent growth rate in the nation's gross domestic product for the first six months of the year. It is likely to be further off the mark for the full year.
The answer is that Wall Street economists forecast because they have to. But their money-making product is a stream of, they hope, good ideas about how the economy works that stimulates the thinking of the money managers that make up much of their clientele.
"People wanting to read what you write and learn how you're thinking about substantive matters is more important than whether you are precisely right in your macro forecasts of G.D.P. or interest rates," said Charley Ellis, managing partner at Greenwich Associates, which assesses Wall Street performance by interviewing institutional investors.
This research -- whether a long-term analysis of the surprising rise in productivity or an instant interpretation of the newest employment report -- plays an integral role in most Wall Street firms and smaller boutiques. Research is the everyday grist for a firm's sales representatives, who deal with clients on a regular basis. It is used to attract clients who then trade through the firm or compensate it in other ways, adding to profits.
"Research helps write trading tickets," said Donald H. Layton, Chase Manhattan Bank's vice chairman in charge of overseeing its global market business.
John Lipsky, the chief economist and the director of research at Chase, and Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, are two such economists from the 50-odd firms constantly scrambling to get the attention of money managers. Both, who themselves spend a third of their time seeing clients, have to regularly contend with the economists at the Wall Street leaders in this business, including Bruce Steinberg at Merrill Lynch and Stephen S. Roach at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
It is a business whose top players have not changed very much in the last several years, according to Greenwich Associates. But that only intensifies the challenge to come up with the Next Big Idea.
One of the most attention-grabbing ideas this year came from Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities. He says that Year 2000 computer disruptions will cause a recession in the beginning of next year. Even if it proves wrong, the idea forced many money managers to address the issue.
But good ideas, right or wrong, are not easy to come by. "If we have three great ideas in a year that is a home run year," said Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Mr. Lipsky, 52, heads Chase's 120-person research team, which is striving to become one of the major players on the Street. He was chief economist at Salomon Brothers before coming to Chase in 1997. Before that he worked for Salomon in London and New York, after a decade at the International Monetary Fund.
"No one is able to consistently foresee specific market developments far into the future," said Mr. Lipsky, who speaks to hundreds of clients all over the world. "That is why forecasts are inevitably revised as new facts emerge." An economist's real job, he explained, is to "help our clients organize their own thinking, even if they come to different conclusions about market implications; we are doing the digging, analysis and thinking that they would do if they had the time."
Chase's 1998 forecast, done by Mr. Lipsky and his research staff, shows how a forecast can be off base on growth but still contain crucial insights. While predicting about 1.5 percent growth -- which was off by 2.4 percentage points -- Chase said that long-term interest rates would fall toward 5 percent, which was correct, and that inflation would decline to about 1.5 percent, also correct. A forecast that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates, based in part on the expected decline in inflation and helped by the deepening of the world financial crisis, was also on the mark.
For 1999, Chase has gone astray again, missing on interest rates, Federal Reserve policy and economic growth. On the other hand, overall inflation, although slightly higher, is still contained -- one of Mr. Lipsky's main themes. And the forecast of a stronger-than-expected dollar early in the year was a contrarian gem.
But Lee Thomas, senior international portfolio manager at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif., the world's largest active bond manager, brushes off the muffs. "His forecast record changed from last year to this year," he said of Mr. Lipsky, "but the quality of his ideas has not changed.
"It is your job," Mr. Thomas said of money managers like himself, "to sit down and decide which idea makes sense and construct your own world view." It is the economist's job, he said, "to explain a theme that catalyzes my thinking."
Mr. Barbera, 47, left the heart of Wall Street after seven years at Lehman Brothers to become a sole practitioner at Hoenig & Company, a small brokerage firm based in Rye Brook, N.Y.
He scored this year with his contention that Japan's economy would rebound and, even more strikingly, last year with his contrarian theme that the pain in Asia would be a gain for the United States. Mr. Barbera reasoned, correctly, that the recession in Asia would lead to lower inflation, lower interest rates and more growth in the United States.
"I get paid for looking out for what might change the conventional view," Mr. Barbera said. "There is a small list of portfolio managers who think I have something to deliver, and we talk."
Paul DeRosa, a partner at Mount Lucas Management, an asset management company in Princeton, N.J., and one of Mr. Barbera's 60 clients, said: "The money is made and lost in interpreting situations as they develop."
And this is what he counts on from Mr. Barbera. In summer 1998, as the Asian economic crisis spread to Russia and Latin America, Mr. DeRosa said that Mr. Barbera was quick to say that the situation would force the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates, which it did three times.
While getting this right, Mr. De Rosa said that Mr. Barbera did not foresee the big rally in the bond market that occurred the previous year.
The de-emphasis on economic forecasting, obviously, is partly a result of being wrong so often. But it also reflects how the once-revered job of forecasting has become little more than a basic commodity in a world where just about everybody has access to his own black box.
"I can decide what way interest rates are going," said Rob Kapito, vice chairman of Black Rock Management, an asset manangement company, and a client of Mr. Lipsky.
The decline of forecasting is reflected in the name change of the National Association of Business Economists to the National Association for Business Economics. The association's membership has fallen substantially as many corporations turned from reliance on teams of macro-economists who were supposed to predict the overall economy to smaller groups of micro-economists focused on specific markets.
In addition, forecasts, even when they are right, are no longer enough for most clients. With just a forecast, Mr. Barbera said, "you are simply asking clients to bet on your black box, and good portfolio managers won't do that."
What portfolio managers do want instead is easy access to good idea merchants.
Mr. Thomas of Pacific Investment, who sees Mr. Lipsky three to five times a year, said that he narrowed the choice of whom he traded through based on the quality of the ideas from the economists he talked to. And despite Mr. Lipsky's forecasting misses, Chase is being called as often as last year.
And on the other end of the trade, Peter Frey, the head of credit market sales at J. P. Morgan Securities, said: "It is not clear that there is a good correlation between how precise our forecasting calls are and our pay back. The correlation between the access and dialogue we give our clients and our payback is clearer."
Firms also rely, at least in part, on their economists' views when they bet their own money on movements in the market.
Mr. Lipsky's views are considered, for example, when Chase stress tests its own bets in the financial markets to assess the amount of risk it is taking. His sense that the world's economic crisis was deepening in the summer of 1998 played a role in Chase's decision to count on interest rates to decline as investors ran to the safety of the bond market.
"We act with even more conviction when the views of the economist are aligned with those of the traders," said Ina Drew, head of the domestic treasury at Chase. That successful bet was one reason Chase reported record earnings in the fourth quarter last year even as some of its rivals reported profit declines for the same period.
Mr. Layton also said that Mr. Lipsky's connections to international financial leaders around the world can help in getting underwriting business for the bank when countries, especially in emerging markets, issue new debt or privatize a state-owned company.
Economists are also useful to money managers who disagree with their views. Mr. Kapito of Black Rock Management, for instance, said that although he disputed Mr. Lipsky's argument that inflation would remain contained, the reasoning helped Black Rock form its own view that inflation was at a bottom and likely to move higher, even if only modestly. And on this basis, Black Rock decided to buy more of the Treasury's bonds that are indexed to inflation and rise in value when inflation expectations rise.
Mr. Barbera likes to provide his clients with what he calls signposts. For example, as early as February this year he was writing that the Japanese economy would recover this year. Along with his reasons for the recovery, he listed developments money managers could watch on their own to see if the recovery was developing along the lines he predicted. For example, Mr. Barbera said that the confidence level among the exectivies of smaller Japanese companies would rise and that the bankruptcy rate would fall.
"I happened to agree with that, and so we made a small play in Nikkei futures that have done very well," said Mr. De Rosa of Mount Lucas Management.
"You cast a wide net," Mr. Barbera said, "and try to catch on to one or two things that have changed in a specific fashion that could have an impact on things. But you never catch it all."

HEADLINE: Being Exclusive Draws Big Crowds;
Private Schools Enjoy a Boom, But Demand Exceeds Growth

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
The crowds around the tables were three people thick.
In an East Side gym as steamy as a summer subway platform, 1,300 parents and children gathered up pamphlets, conversed with admissions officers in their most polite tones and ticked names of exclusive schools off their lists. 
 For most attending this open house on Sept. 27, the hunt was on for a spot in a private school kindergarten that costs up to $18,750, almost as much as a starting teacher in a public school made just a few years ago. While in past years a pint-size chair in a private school could usually be found for every well-heeled preschooler who applied, this year the admissions crowding is the most intense and frenzied in a long time.
"People are thinking about it: Is this going to be the year when we can't serve everyone?" said Cynthia Bing, head of the school advisory service for the Parents League of New York, which assists parents in their search for private schools and sponsored the open house at the Loyola School at East 83d Street and Park Avenue.
As the open house made clear, these are flush times for New York City's private schools.
With personal fortunes ballooning in the strong stock market, applications are rising, at some schools by 50 percent over three years. At the Trinity School on the Upper West Side, for example, there is a waiting list just to get a tour and interview for kindergarten.
Endowments are also growing -- Grace Church School in Greenwich Village quintupled its investments in five years -- and fund-raising has grown easier. A city that appears safer and saner is more attractive to live in, stemming the exodus to the suburbs by school-age children of privilege. And more parents seem to be convinced that private school is a shortcut to an Ivy League degree, even at a cost of up to $20,000 a year.
"The real driving factor is people have more discretionary income today than they did five or six years ago," said George Davison, head of the Grace Church School, who watches admissions trends as chairman of the committee of trustees for the Independent Schools Admissions Association of Greater New York. "I'm not sure whether that is driven by the birthrate, or by people doing well enough that they feel they can afford independent schools and not move to Mamaroneck or many of the suburbs where they would go before."
In such a bullish climate, more than a dozen top schools are constructing or buying up new buildings, sometimes just to catch up with the growth of the past few years. The Brearley School on the Upper East Side has added a field house. The Horace Mann School in the Bronx is adding 90,000 square feet for classrooms and an arts center to its Riverdale campus. Also in the Bronx, the Riverdale Country Day school recently bought several buildings and seven acres from Manhattan College for an arts center and sports.
Outside the city, schools like Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., are experiencing similar growth. Exeter, which has seen a 12 percent rise in applications over the last five years along with a 17 percent rise in the size of its freshman class, broke ground recently on a $38 million science building.
To the dismay of many applying families, the building boom has not translated into a matching surge in the numbers of students admitted, at least in the most competitive and expensive schools. The schools say they want to remain small and intimate, while indulging their students with science labs, sports complexes and arts centers that most colleges would envy.
"We have decided that we are at the cap -- to expand beyond this would change the nature of the school," said Mr. Davison, adding that Grace Church has a record enrollment this fall. "With 394 kids I can know them all, and all the teachers and most of their parents and dogs and baby sitters and all of that," he said. "If we added another section of each grade, another 180 kids, the dynamic becomes very different."
That is bad news for parents like Nadine Morrison, a recent survivor of a nerve-racking application and interview season, who barely found a spot for her kindergartner, Oliver. "It's a horrible process," she said, after picking up her son from school. He was turned down at three exclusive schools, including one that had only six openings for kindergartners.
"It's very competitive, very stressful, and they reject your child based on I don't know what," she said. "They're only 4 1/2 when they take these tests, and it's kind of elitist in a way. It's just that it's ludicrous for children that age, to have to go through the stress."
Oliver now commutes -- 70 blocks, 45 minutes -- to the Trevor Day School on the Upper East Side, where, she said, he is very happy.
Even older students, like Steph anie Paseornek, 11, are feeling the admissions squeeze. She is now in the sixth grade at the Caedmon School on the Upper East Side, which does not have a middle school or high school, so she has to apply for limited spots in seventh-grade classrooms next fall.
"I want to move out of the city," Stephanie said in frustration.
She is interested in a handful of the top-tier private high schools, but she said the application process is so daunting that she wants her family to move anywhere -- she suggested New Jersey or Los Angeles -- to avoid going up against the competition.
Victoria Goldman, co-author of "The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools" (Soho Press, 1999), which provides capsule descriptions of almost 70 schools in the New York region, said children are often able to find placements even if they are not accepted in the first round of admissions.
"The smaller, more gentle, less competitive schools are getting a little bigger, because that's where the overflow's going," she said.
Nationally, the private school student population has grown 16.8 percent in the last 10 years, with 4.1 percentage points of that growth coming in the last two years, according to the National Association of Independent Schools. In New York there has been an increase of about 3.9 percent in private school admissions since the 1997-98 school year. The public school population during the last decade grew 15.3 percent.
Nowhere is the boom as palpable as in the new private school buildings popping up like new BMW's around the Upper East Side, Upper West Side and Riverdale in the Bronx. In the last three years many of the most prestigious schools have used the vigorous stock market to expand their campuses, adding new buildings or taking over adjoining brownstones.
At Brearley, a $25 million fund-raising campaign built a field house and two new floors, and response was so enthusiastic that the school increased its goal to $30 million, said Lewise Lucaire, development director. The girls' school's endowment rose from $25.6 million in 1994 to $49.8 million this year, she said, adding that some of the endowment would cover scholarships for students whose families cannot afford the $17,000 annual tuition for 12th graders.
After a $25 million capital campaign, Horace Mann added two buildings designed by Gruzen Samton, the architectural firm that designed Police Headquarters. The Chapin School added a gym, two-floor library, theater and foreign language lab in 1998, when it also added a kindergarten. The Dalton School, which like Chapin is on the Upper East Side, built a gym and a science center that increased space for the science program by 25 percent.
On the West Side, Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School, which expects a 7 percent increase in enrollment, has plans to build a 26,000-square-foot building for fifth and sixth graders, with construction slated to begin in June.
Manhattan schools like Collegiate, Spence, Friends Seminary, Trinity and Buckley have also either gone through renovations or built or bought new buildings recently, as have Marymount, Ramaz, St. Aloysius, Rodeph Sholom and Churchill in Manhattan and Poly Prep Country Day School and St. Ann's in Brooklyn.
The booming stock market has helped the bank accounts of the private schools significantly. The endowment at Grace Church School, for example, grew to more than $5 million this year from $1 million in 1994, in part through donations, in part through an 18 percent growth in investments. The school has been able to increase its size by 8,000 square feet in the last six years and accommodates a third more students than a decade ago.
Some school officials note that with the increased competition, families are applying to more schools than they might have in previous years. "Part of it is they're less certain about where they want to go," said Lisa Moreira, director of admissions at Horace Mann, "and as it gets more competitive, it's smart for them to hedge their bets and have lots of options available to them as well."
Brian Walsh, headmaster of the Buckley School, said that in the last three or four years there were more applications to Buckley, a boys' school on the Upper East Side, but not necessarily more children applying to private schools overall. Approximately the same number of students have taken the Educational Records Bureau test in nursery school, but their parents are applying to three to five schools, instead of two. Two mothers at the open house said they planned to try for 10.
Helena Yien, whose son, Garrett, 5, now attends kindergarten at St. David's School on East 89th Street by the Guggenheim Museum, helped him apply to six schools. He got into three.
"It's difficult, very difficult, and awful," she said. "There are just a lot of interviews with different schools, and it's not one appointment per school, but usually three."
Many school administrators have been careful to increase their endowments to support new buildings so they can avoid being overextended if the growth they have been enjoying should falter.
If that time comes, it would be harder to preserve the current popularity of private schools.
Catherine Hausman, co-author of the guide to private schools, noted: "Admissions are robust and the schools are healthy, but all it takes is a downtick in the economy and you'll see admissions dropping like the Dow."

HEADLINE: Treasury and Fed Reach A Compromise

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
After decades of bickering over control of the nation's banking system, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve announced today that they had reached an agreement, resolving one of the last outstanding issues in the fight to overhaul the nation's financial system.
The compromise, brokered in the early morning by Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, was disclosed shortly before lawmakers met to reconcile the few remaining differences between competing measures that had already passed in the Senate and the House. 
 The legislation still has privacy and lending provisions that the White House says fail to adequately protect consumers and the disadvantaged, but the compromise significantly increased the odds of passage of a sweeping financial services bill that President Clinton may ultimately agree to sign. The legislation would repeal laws like the Glass-Steagall Act, fashioned by the banking crisis of the 1930's, that had sharply limited the ability of banks, securities firms and insurance companies from expanding into each other's businesses.
"The Treasury-Fed agreement puts us closer than ever before to writing financial- services-modernization legislation," said Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican who is chairman of the conference committee. "Let's finish the job."
Lobbyists said the deal was certain to put pressure on the lawmakers to change the legislation in a way that the President would be able to sign it. Still, by this evening, the measure under discussion still had provisions, objectionable to the White House, that watered down the Community Reinvestment Act. That act requires banks to make loans to minorities, residents of inner cities, farmers and others who have historically had trouble getting credit.
White House officials said tonight that the President still intended to veto the legislation unless major changes were made on the provisions in the Community Reinvestment Act.
Despite those provisions, there was broad optimism today that Congress was nearing completion on legislation that would significantly reshape the nation's financial services industry.
For years, a central stumbling block to overhauling the system has been an arcane regulatory turf fight between the Treasury Department's Comptroller of the Currency, which supervises nationally chartered banks, and the Fed, which oversees bank holding companies. By allowing insurers, bankers and investment bankers to enter each other's business, any new legislation would have to prescribe a corporate structure for the new financial conglomerates, and as such, would ultimately dictate which agency had primacy.
The debate traces its roots to the establishment of the Federal Reserve in 1913, and the tension that followed between the Fed and the executive branch over both of the banks and the carrying out of economic policy.
The issue now has no practical significance for either consumers or most banks. But it has been an enduring struggle between two of Washington's power centers. The squabbling between a long line of Treasury secretaries and Fed chairmen had inevitably stalled any efforts at trying to eliminate the legislation adopted during the Great Depression and later that has limited the cross-ownership of banks, insurers and investment banks.
The Fed wanted financial service conglomerates to keep their banking, insurance and securities functions separate and under the umbrella of a holding company. The Treasury proposed giving banking companies the option of organizing financial service companies as operating subsidiaries of the parent company.
The Treasury maintained that it needed to play a big role in bank oversight so that the executive branch could carry out economic policy. But over the years officials at the Fed had two replies.
One was that the central bank would be unable to carry out monetary policy without some control over a large portion of the banks. Mr. Greenspan also maintained that financial conglomerates should organize under a holding company so as to prevent the banks from using certain Government subsidies to their advantage as they expand into new areas like investment banking and insurance. Those subsidies include deposit insurance backed by the Federal Government, access to credit through the discount window and a Federal clearinghouse.
The agreement brokered a few hours after midnight this morning by Mr. Summers and Mr. Greenspan is as complex as you would expect to get from the two economic engineers and Ph.D.'s.
Administration officials said that under the compromise, both agencies would continue to play significant roles in overseeing the nation's banks and emerging financial conglomerates. The deal provides for operating subsidiaries of banks to underwrite securities. After five years, a subsidiary could also engage in merchant banking activities if jointly approved by the Federal Reserve and the Treasury. Banks interested in insurance underwriting and real estate development would have to set up separate affiliates.
The agreement also imposes certain other financial safeguards intended to protect the banking components of a financial conglomerate because those units have insured deposits ultimately backed by the Federal Government.
The agreement requires, for instance, that the aggregate asset value of the financial subsidiaries of a bank not be greater than 80 percent of the bank's assets. And the equity capital in the subsidiaries cannot be greater than 20 percent of the bank's equity capital. Finally, the assets of all the financial subsidiaries of a bank would not be able to exceed $50 billion.

HEADLINE: Clintons Obtain New Loan for House, Without Friend's Help

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have secured new financing on the house they are buying in Chappaqua, N.Y., the White House said today, enabling them to drop an earlier loan arrangement that had come under sharp criticism.
The new loan, for $1.36 million, is in the form of a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage with an annual interest rate of 7.5 percent for the first three years, said Jim Kennedy, a White House spokesman. After the first three years, the rate will be set at the one-year Treasury bill rate plus 2.75 percentage points, he said. The current Treasury bill rate is just under 5.5 percent. 
 Asked whether the Clintons obtained new financing so they could cancel a much-criticized arrangement they had with a prominent Democratic Party fund-raiser, Mr. Kennedy said: "I'm aware of that speculation. Once they had the initial contract, a number of different mortgage companies came forward with different options. This one made the most sense."
Mr. Kennedy said the loan is from PNC Mortgage, a subsidiary of the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh. The Clintons are to make a down payment of $340,000, or 20 percent of the purchase price of $1.7 million, and are to close on the deal on Nov. 1, Mr. Kennedy said.
He said the party fund-raiser, Terry McAuliffe, has no role in the loan from PNC Mortgage. When the Clintons decided to buy the white-shingled, five-bedroom Chappaqua house in September, Mr. McAuliffe agreed to guarantee a mortgage with $1.35 million of his money as collateral. That mortgage was to have been with Bankers Trust Private Banking, a unit of Deutsche Bank, and its initial interest was calculated at just over 6.5 percent.
Mr. McAuliffe is a good friend of the Clintons and is raising millions of dollars for their legal defense fund and for a Presidential library to be built in Little Rock, Ark. The First Couple's eagerness to accept his help brought criticism from Republicans and public-interest groups who said the arrangement smacked of special treatment and might constitute an illegal gift.
The Clintons' move to Westchester County will clear the way for Mrs. Clinton to run for the Senate from New York State, which she seems likely to do. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been widely mentioned as her likely Republican opponent, had questioned the propriety of the arrangement with Mr. McAuliffe, signaling that the issue would be a hot one in a campaign against Mrs. Clinton.
Mr. Kennedy said that when the Clintons decided they wanted the house in Chappaqua, their situation was like that of other couples who fall in love with a house and know they must make a solid offer quickly or risk losing out. "They had a very short time to put together the financing," Mr. Kennedy said.
But in other ways, the Clintons' situation is hard to compare with those of other people their age. While they list slightly more than $1 million in assets, they have about $5 million in legal bills, a debt that might make it hard for other couples in their 50's to qualify for a mortgage.
On the other hand, former Presidents of the United States have been able to command lucrative speaking fees and big book advances. And both Clintons are lawyers.
Before Mr. McAuliffe offered his help, the Clintons sought financial aid from former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and two former White House chiefs of staff, Erskine B. Bowles and Thomas F. McLarty 3d, who declined to help, according to several people familiar with the couple's house-hunting.
Principal and interest payments on a 30-year mortgage at 7.5 percent are just over $9,500 a month, exclusive of taxes and insurance. The taxes on the Chappaqua house are estimated at $26,000 a year.
Mr. Kennedy said several lending institutions had offered their services to the Clintons after the flurry of publicity about the house in Westchester. The PNC Bank Corporation advertises itself as one of the biggest financial-services organizations in the country. It says that PNC Mortgage provided more than $6 billion to more than 43,000 borrowers in 1997.
"Buying a home is one of the biggest financial decisions you'll ever make," PNC Mortgage tells prospective borrowers on its web site.

HEADLINE: Court Backs Law Docking Legislators

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 14

 BODY:
New York's highest court upheld a bitterly contested law today that calls for withholding the pay of state legislators when a state budget is late, bolstering efforts to speed up the state's notoriously slow budget-making process.
In a 6-to-1 ruling, the Court of Appeals overturned a lower court decision that declared the new law unconstitutional on the ground that it had the potential to coerce the State Legislature into passing a budget and thus curbed its legal authority and independence. 
 In December, as part of a deal with Gov. George E. Pataki to raise the salaries of lawmakers for the first time in a decade, the Legislature agreed to pass a law that would penalize legislators if a budget was not in place by the April 1 deadline: They would not be paid until one had been passed.
The law, the only one of its kind in the nation, was considered an important victory for Mr. Pataki, a Republican whose tenure has been marked by passage of the latest budgets in state history. That happened despite his promise to deliver budgets on time, which he made in 1994, when he first ran for governor.
But the law was immediately challenged in court by 14 Democratic state legislators, who maintained that it gave the Governor coercive powers over the Legislature that were unconstitutional. The 14 plaintiffs either voted against the new law or were elected in November and had not taken office when it passed.
In a strongly worded decision on May 21, Justice Richard D. Huttner of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn found that the law gave the Governor a coercive power over the Legislature, violating the State Constitution.
"When even one legislator, by dint of economic circumstance, is coerced into passing a budget that may require him or her to sacrifice conscientiously held beliefs, then the entire process is tainted," he wrote.
The Court of Appeals rejected the plaintiffs' claim of coercion. Writing for the majority, Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa said that all lawmakers "are entitled to the presumption that they act only in accordance with and fulfillment of their oaths of office."
The court also rejected the plaintiffs' assertion that the new law violated the constitutional separation of powers by transferring power from the Legislature to the Governor, noting that the law had been passed by both houses of the Legislature.
"The Legislature has decided to restrict itself and discipline its own work and power in this fashion," Judge Bellacosa wrote. He added that the law was a "credit to the legislative branch's internal management practices," not a surrendering of power.
The decision elicited predictable responses from both sides. The law's opponents said that it could subvert the legislative process, while its supporters said that it gave lawmakers a powerful incentive to do their work in a timely manner.
Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader in the State Senate, who was one the law's chief sponsors, issued a statement this afternoon chiding Democrats for bringing the lawsuit instead of focusing on completing the budget on time.
"Now that this issue has been resolved by the court," he said, "I once again urge all parties to renew the effort to enact budget reform so that we can help restore the public's confidence in our ability to do our jobs well and to do them within the parameters set by law."
But Alexander B. Grannis, a Democratic Assemblyman from Manhattan who was one of the plaintiffs, said the ruling was not just a setback for lawmakers. "We're disappointed," Mr. Grannis said. "But the real losers are the citizens of New York, who will never know whether we have passed a budget because we believed it was the right budget or because we wanted to get our pay to feed our families."
For all the legal wrangling it spurred, the law did not produce, in its first year, anyway, the result its supporters desired: the adoption of a budget on time. Instead, lawmakers adopted a budget on Aug. 4, 126 days into the current fiscal year, tying the record for lateness.
To get by, many legislators borrowed money or dipped into their savings accounts. If anything, some lawmakers said, the law served only to deepen the hostilities between the Legislature and the Governor, whose pay was not withheld.
For more than two decades, it has been almost impossible for a timely budget to be adopted in Albany. The budget has been late 21 times since 1975, largely because the Legislature has been divided during that period, with the Assembly controlled by Democrats and the Senate in the hands of Republicans.

HEADLINE: LIPA Delivers Ultimatum On Shoreham

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Oct. 14

 BODY:
Delivering an ultimatum in his long battle with Suffolk County, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard M. Kessel, said today that county officials must agree by Monday to a $625 million settlement for past overassessment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant or share in paying the full $1.3 billion he said the authority was owed.
An immediate cash payment of $1.3 billion -- rather than a negotiated payment through electric rates over many years -- would present a financial crisis requiring property tax increases, large-scale borrowing or a combination of both for the county, the Town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham-Wading River School district, officials of the governments and the district have said. 
 Mr. Kessel said that if the County Legislature failed to act by Monday, the power authority would move immediately to collect the $1.3 billion that court rulings have said the authority may collect from the county, the town and the school district. Each would pay about a third, he said.
"Let's enter into this settlement and put this issue behind us," Mr. Kessel said at a news conference here today. He said that County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, the town, and the school district had agreed to the settlement, but that it still needed the approval of the County Legislature. "We have asked the Suffolk legislature time and time again to settle this matter for the good of the ratepayers of Long Island, including their own constituents," Mr. Kessel said. "It's time for them to stop playing politics."
But legislators said they had no plans to meet before the deadline. "We're not going to be threatened by LIPA," said Michael M. D'Andre, the deputy legislative presiding officer. He said the county would await the outcome of an appeal challenging the authority of LIPA to collect the money.
George O. Guldi, chairman of the legislature's LIPA negotiations committee, said, "This is not a rational way to formulate policy or decide the fate of ratepayers and taxpayers on Long Island."
The county is seeking permission to appeal a unanimous ruling in July by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court that upheld the authority's right to recover the excess Shoreham plant taxes.
Mr. Kessel warned that if the county's appeal fails, the authority will no longer be able to negotiate a settlement for a lower amount.
The settlement provides that Suffolk electric customers repay the $625 million through electric rates. Even though Suffolk has not agreed to the settlement, the authority has already begun collecting it through rates that are about 2 percent higher than in Nassau County.
The school district Superintendent, Edward Tronolone, said the district would be unable to pay. "I can't even imagine what it would mean if we had to pay that much money," he said. The plant, which was mothballed in 1989, is in the school district, which is in the Town of Brookhaven.
Mr. Kessel said today that the authority would resume payments in lieu of taxes to the school district that were provided for in the 1993 state takeover of the Shoreham plant. The takeover removed the plant from tax rolls.
The school district warned this week that it was owed $4.8 million in LIPA payments and would close by the end of the month unless it got the money.
Mr. Kessel said the authority would resume payments because the district had agreed to support the $625 million tax settlement, but did not specify an amount. Mr. Tronolone said the district would be relieved by payment of any amount. "A starving person doesn't turn down food," he said.

HEADLINE: Con Ed Posts Drop in 3d-Quarter Earnings

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Consolidated Edison Inc. posted a slight dip in third-quarter profit yesterday as costs from Hurricane Floyd and a summer heat wave pulled earnings below analysts' expectations.
Con Edison, which announced this week that it would acquire Northeast Utilities for $3.29 billion in cash and stock, posted a profit of $336 million, or $1.50 a diluted share, compared with $347 million, or $1.49 a share in the period a year earlier. 
 Analysts had expected the company to earn $1.51 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Con Edison, which provides electricity to New York City and its northern suburbs, said that quarterly earnings were helped by higher electric revenue resulting from the warmer-than-normal weather, continued strength in the New York City economy and a common stock buyback program, which reduces the number of shares outstanding.
"These factors were offset by the costs incurred in recovering from Hurricane Floyd and its aftermath and by increased electrical distribution expenses associated with the very hot summer weather," the company said in a statement.
Con Edison's electric sales volume in New York in the first nine months increased 4.3 percent compared with figures in the period a year earlier.
Gas sales and transportation volume increased 6.2 percent, and steam sales volume also increased 6.2 percent, primarily because of colder winter weather in 1999 compared with that of 1998.
Through the end of the third quarter, Con Edison bought back 17 million shares, amounting to almost $790 million of its previously announced $1 billion stock buyback program. The company said it expected to continue the repurchase plan.
Before the results were announced, shares of Con Edison closed up 87.5 cents, to $37.25.

HEADLINE: States' Big Suits Against Industry Bring Battle on Contingency Fees

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
A growing wave of lawsuits by cities and states against makers of cigarettes, guns, and now lead paint, has reignited a fierce debate over the role of lawyers and the enormous fees they can earn in legal actions brought by public officials.
The issue erupted after prominent plaintiffs' lawyers, hired by state attorneys general to sue cigarette makers, earned billions of dollars in contingency fees as a result of the $246 billion in settlements with the companies. Now some of those same lawyers, who only get paid if they win a case or settle it, have been hired by states and cities to sue gun makers and lead paint producers. 
 As part of a business counteroffensive against the trend, the United States Chamber of Commerce will soon begin an intensive lobbying campaign to get legislatures to drastically restrict states' use of contingency lawyers. Recently, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas signed a law, backed by companies, that sharply limited the ability of the state's Attorney General to hire contingency-fee lawyers.
The question has split legal experts. Economically strapped elected officials need the skills and resources of outside lawyers to handle difficult cases, they say. "It levels the playing field because the other side is relying on very skilled lawyers," said Robert L. Rabin, a professor of law at Stanford University.
But the interests of those lawyers can conflict with those of the public.
"The fees can be out of line with the amount of work and effort that is actually put in," Mr. Rabin said.
Some cities suing the gun industry have decided to use their own lawyers, rather than outside counsel.
Under the legislation proposed by the Chamber of Commerce, any outside lawyer who contributed more than $250 to the campaign of a public official would be barred from being hired to pursue a lawsuit. Jim Wootton, executive director of Institute for Legal Reform at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said that provision would restrict influence peddling. Plaintiffs' lawyers, though, have contributed largely to Democratic candidates, while the business interests they sue have traditionally supported Republicans.
The law would prohibit a state from changing any laws that could affect litigation while the state sued an industry or even contemplated such a lawsuit, Mr. Wootton said.
Mr. Wootton said limiting the use of contingency lawyers was a vital issue for industry. "We think this is one of the biggest threats facing American industry today," he said.
The latest challenge came on Tuesday when Rhode Island's Attorney General, Sheldon Whitehouse, sued eight paint companies and a lead industry group to seek payment for the treatment of children poisoned by lead paint and for its removal.
The case will be handled by the firm of Ness, Motley, Loadholt, Richardson & Poole of Charleston, S.C., which represented some two dozen states in tobacco cases, earning hundreds of millions in fees in the process. Rhode Island will pay 17 percent of any award or settlement to the firm, which is financing the lawsuit and is in talks with other states about similar actions.
Other tobacco veterans are also posed to jump in. Richard Scruggs, a Pascagoula, Miss., lawyer who represented that state and some 20 others against cigarette makers, has had talks with public officials interested in suing. And Steve Berman, a Seattle lawyer who represented several states, including Washington, in their tobacco case, said he had discussed lead paint lawsuits with two attorneys general.
Many legal experts believe that such high-powered law firms can play a valuable role in public litigation because they have financial resources to spend years, if necessary, tracking documents, interviewing witnesses and aggressively fighting pretrial motions.
John Coffee, a professor of law at Columbia University said he believed that it would be a "disaster" for the public if the type of legislation being promoted by the Chamber of Commerce was adopted.
But Mr. Coffee also voiced concerns about potential conflicts between lawyers who donate heavily to the campaigns of officials who can hire them. And other legal experts said that outside lawyers could have a financial stake in settling a case that might be at odds with the broad public's goals.
"The public might have been interested in getting more concessions from cigarette companies in return for taking less money," said Susan Koniak, a professor of law at Boston University.
Mr. Berman, the plaintiff's lawyer in Seattle, said he believed that outside lawyers representing states cut the best deals possible in striking settlements with tobacco companies. But he acknowledged that some of the huge legal fees awarded in those cases had fueled the larger controversy.
Last year, lawyers representing the first three states that settled -- Florida, Mississippi and Texas -- were awarded $8.2 billion. The staggering fees prompted public uproar, particularly in Texas, where one lawyer, Marc D. Murr of Houston, who appeared to play little role in the litigation, sought $260 million in fees.
Faced by a state investigation, Mr. Murr, whose request was supported by the former Texas Attorney General who hired him, backed down. But this year, Republican lawmakers with the backing of business groups passed legislation requiring the State Attorney General to have contingency-fee contracts approved by a board appointed by top state officials. Legal fees could not exceed $4,000 an hour.
Utah legislators also passed a bill this year requiring that state's Attorney General to get approval from the Governor before filing a civil lawsuit. But after the State Attorney General, Jan Graham, threatened to challenge its constitutionality, she struck a deal with lawmakers under which her office will keep the Governor informed about any litigation.
Cities that are heading the legal assault against gun makers have taken different stances on outside lawyers. While some, like New Orleans, Atlanta and Newark have hired lawyers involved in tobacco cases under contingency deals, others like Chicago are using their own lawyers.
Mr. Berman, the Seattle plaintiff's lawyer, said those various approaches had apparently created some conflicts. Recently, for example, when lawyers representing several cities suing gun makers and a few states considering such actions met with manufacturers, cities that had hired outside lawyers were excluded from the talks.
Along with suing gun makers and paint producers, some of the tobacco lawyers like Mr. Scruggs have also filed actions against health maintenance organizations, saying they had failed to provide policyholders with promised benefits. And Mr. Coffee, the law professor, said he would not be surprised if public entities like cities soon took similar actions.
"If you look over the horizon, the filings on behalf of state plaintiffs tend to come after the lawsuits filed on behalf of individuals," he said.

HEADLINE: DEFEAT OF A TREATY: THE ARMS EXPERTS;
A Nuclear Safety Valve Is Shut Off, but U.S. Maintains Other Safeguards

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The test ban treaty defeated in the Senate yesterday was a critical foreign policy objective of the Clinton Administration, but it was far from the only component of the Government's strategy to control the proliferation of nuclear arms -- which embraces a menu of measures ranging from broad treaties to tailor-made solutions like sanctions aimed at rogue countries.
Thus, according to arms control experts, the Senate action was unlikely to have immediate effects on American efforts, for example, to curb nuclear development in such nations as North Korea, Iraq and Iran. "There is no single solution to the problem of proliferation, only multiple, complementary solutions, and the Senate has just taken away one of the solutions," said Michael Krepon, president of the Henry L. Stimson Center, a research institute that examines arms control issues. 
 For years, Washington has marshaled a variety of carrots and sticks in its efforts to combat proliferation and curb nuclear arsenals. These include arms control accords with the old Soviet Union; economic and political incentives to persuade non-nuclear nations not to build the bomb, and the threat of political and economic isolation against those who do.
In a speech in July, the Administration's senior arms control official, John D. Holum, acting Under Secretary of State for arms control, listed seven major elements in the Administration's policy, starting with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty of the 1960's and the recent test ban treaty. He mentioned inducements to North Korea that include $40 million a year in fuel from the United States and the building of two power plants financed by South Korea and Japan in exchange for a freeze by Pyongyang on its plutonium production.
He also mentioned sanctions, which in the 90's have been imposed as punishment for bad nuclear behavior or lifted as a reward for improved conduct. Of sanctions, Mr. Holum acknowledged that "nobody likes them much." And he cited intrusive inspections of nuclear plants that are being carried out by the International Atomic Energy Agency.
At the same time, the Administration is pushing forward on a series of traditional arms control deals with Moscow. The Start 2 treaty, which calls for the reduction of the two countries' nuclear stockpiles, has languished in the lower house of the Russian Parliament since 1993 and looks unlikely to be approved before legislative elections there in February. Linked to the passage of the Start 2 treaty are talks on Start 3, which would reduce arsenals from their cold war peak by 80 percent.
Mr. Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia agreed in June to begin talks on Start 3, although Administration officials acknowledge that the cuts required by Start 3 would face opposition in Congress.
Largely because of the failure of nonproliferation measures against nations like Iraq and Iran, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott has started pushing another possible deal with Moscow. That is a modification of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, a move that would allow Washington to build a limited missile defense system as a shield against the weapons of emerging nuclear states. "We're looking at protection from a handful of missiles from the nations that the Central Intelligence Agency sees as having nuclear capacity a dozen years down the road," an Administration official said.
Last year, a panel led by former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld warned that North Korea and Iran could strike American territory with "little or no warning." A follow-up report gave ominous scenarios of what potential enemies could do against the United States in the next 15 years.
Administration officials said the Russians view the modification of the 1972 treaty as an effort to strip them of the last vestiges of superpower status, making the success of the new discussions fairly dim.
The most unpredictable and perhaps toughest problems for Washington, however, lie with what Mr. Holum called in his policy address the hazards. He listed India and Pakistan, Iraq, Iran and North Korea. Most of these have been addressed with a mixture of what Mr. Krepon of the Stimson Center called individually tailored "incentives and disincentives" to stop them from developing nuclear capacities.
Thus, after India and Pakistan each tested nuclear weapons last year, the Clinton Administration imposed a series of economic sanctions against the two countries and led the effort to curb lending by international financial institutions.
Then, as an incentive to get both to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, the sanctions were eased. India pledged to agree to the treaty after the elections that were just held. Pakistan offered to follow suit once India signed. Both these promises are now at risk.
For Iraq, the medicine was largely economic sanctions and United Nations inspections of suspected nuclear sites. But Saddam Hussein has refused to allow the inspectors back since last November's air strikes, and the sanctions appear to be crumbling.
A United Nations resolution under discussion offers Iraq the possibility of easing sanctions in return for a new inspection regimen. Whether it will be adopted by the Security Council remains unclear.
The Clinton Administration has tried to deal with Iran by placing sanctions on 10 Russian institutes suspected of helping transfer missile and nuclear technology to Teheran. The sanctions prevent the United States or private businesses from trading with the institutes. But such sanctions, officials said, do not deal with another, virtually untouchable problem: the flight of poorly paid and neglected Russian nuclear scientists to Iran.
Skeptics on the Clinton Administration's approach to North Korea complain of a "cycle of extortion" by the Communist authorities. Fear of North Korea's intentions intensified last year when it fired a missile that could potentially land weapons on the United States and when it threatened to repeat the exercise again this fall.
Last month, Mr. Clinton ordered the relaxing of a total trade embargo, imposed in 1950, in exchange for a temporary halt to tests of North Korea's long-range missiles.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Himalayan Error

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Ever since their independence, the U.S. has made decisions about India and Pakistan fully aware that it was dealing with countries that would have increasing political and military significance, for international good or evil.
 Now that both have nuclear arms capability and Pakistan has been taken over again by the hard-wing military, the American Government and people stare at them as if they were creatures that had suddenly popped out of nowhere -- and as if their crises had no connection at all to those 50 years of American involvement in the India-Pakistan subcontinent. 
 The destiny of the two countries -- war or peace, democracy or despotism -- lies with their billion-plus people, their needs and passions.
But American decision-making about them has been of Himalayan importance -- because from the beginning it was almost entirely based on a great error. America chose Pakistan as more important to its interests than India.
Both countries have a powerful sliver of their population who are plain villains -- politicians who deliberately splinter their society instead of knitting it, men of immense wealth who zealously evade taxes and the public good, religious bottom-feeders who spread violence between Hindu and Muslim in India and Muslim and Muslim in Pakistan.
But living for about four years as a New York Times correspondent based in India and traveling often in Pakistan, I knew that the American error was widening and catastrophic.
Although there were important mavericks, American officialdom clearly tilted toward Pakistan, knighted it a military ally and looked with contempt or condescension on India. Pakistan -- a country whose leadership provided a virtually unbroken record of economic, social and military failure and increasing influence of Islamicists.
Many U.S. officials preferred to deal with the Pakistanis over the Indians not despite Pakistan's tendency to militarism but because of it. Man, the military fellows can get things done for you.
Washington saw the country as some kind of barrier-post against China, which it never was, and against Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. The Pakistanis did their part there. But when the Taliban fanatics seized Afghanistan, Pakistan's military helped them pass arms for terrorists to the Mideast.
Pakistan's weakness as an American ally, though Washington never seemed to mind, was its leaders' refusal to create continuity of democratic governments long enough to convince Pakistanis that the military would not take over again tomorrow.
Across the border, India, for all its slowness of economic growth and its caste system, showed what the U.S. is supposed to want -- consistent faithfulness to elected democracy. Where Pakistan failed to maintain political democracy in a one-religion nation, India has kept it in a Hindu-majority country that has four other large religions and a garden of small ones.
Danger sign: The newly re-elected Hindu-led coalition will have to clamp down harder against any religious persecution of Muslims and Christians. India's real friends will never lessen pressure against that. And the new government is not likely to stay in office long if it does not fulfill its anti-persecution promises to several parties in the coalition.
No, the U.S. did not itself create a militaristic Pakistan. But by showing for years that it did not care much, it encouraged Pakistani officers prowling for power, lessened the public's confidence in democratic government when Pakistan happened to have one, and slighted the Indians' constancy to democratic elections.
In 1961, in the U.S. Embassy in Seoul, I heard the ranking U.S. diplomat urge Washington not to recognize the military gang that had just taken over South Korea after ousting the country's first elected government in its history.
But the Kennedy Administration did recognize the military government. That throttled South Koreans with military regimes for almost another two decades.
The Clinton Administration is doing what America should: demand the departure of the generals. Maybe America still has enough influence to be of use to democracy someplace or other in Asia. It's the least it can do for its colossal error on the subcontinent -- do for Indians, but mostly for Pakistanis. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: DEFEAT OF A TREATY: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Says 'New Isolationism' Imperils U.S. Security

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that the Republicans who defeated a treaty to ban underground nuclear testing were retreating into a "new isolationism" that threatened national security.
He pledged to abide by the treaty's provisions and warned countries with nuclear ambitions, like China, India and Pakistan, not to interpret the defeat as a signal that they were free to resume testing. 
 In an hourlong news conference, Mr. Clinton tried to make the best of what his aides conceded was a humiliating setback, one that some White House officials fear could lead foreign leaders to wait until the end of Mr. Clinton's term before seeking to strike deals with the United States.
With a series of attacks on Congress for what he called "reckless partisanship," Mr. Clinton made it clear that he hoped that Democrats would turn the defeat of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty into a campaign issue. He argued that the Senate's rejection effectively sent a four-word message to America's allies: "Go take a hike."
And he added, "By this vote, the Senate majority has turned its back on 50 years of American leadership against the spread of weapons of mass destruction."
Presidential candidates of both parties seized on the issue to defend the superiority of their approaches to foreign policy. Page A13.
Without a hint of the usual Washington bipartisan niceties toward the Republican leaders who organized the defeat of what was supposed to be the crowning achievement of his foreign policy, Mr. Clinton used the Senate vote to begin a sweeping denunciation of the Republicans on the full range of domestic issues -- the budget surplus, Social Security, education, the environment, Head Start, taxes, Medicare, medical research and air-traffic safety. Text of news conference, pages A14, A15 and A16.
"I say to the Congressional majority, 'Enough is enough,' " Mr. Clinton said. "We've got a job to do for the American people. It is not that difficult. Let's just do it."
By announcing his resolve to abide by the provisions of the first major treaty rejected by the Senate since 1920, Mr. Clinton was essentially challenging the Republican aspirants for President to say whether they would resume underground explosions in the Nevada desert, a policy change that would invite other nuclear powers to do the same.
"Now, if we ever get a President that's against the test ban treaty, which we may get," the President said, the world should know that "all bets are off."
"We'll have Russia testing," he said. "We'll have China testing. We'll have India testing. We'll have Pakistan testing. We'll have countries abandoning the nonproliferation treaty."
Republican Presidential hopefuls were careful to focus their criticism on specific flaws in the treaty and not to dismiss the notion of banning nuclear-weapons testing altogether. Republicans in Congress were quick to reject the isolationist label. They shot back that the Senate had simply voted against the treaty because it could never be confident that China, Russia, North Korea or others had truly abandoned testing.
"Since the substance, the facts, were not with the President or with the supporters of this treaty, they are saying, 'Oh, well, it was politics,' " the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said. "That was absolutely not the case."
Although the rejection and the reaction to it dominated the news conference this afternoon, Mr. Clinton also used the occasion to press his case against the budget that Republicans are assembling and to lay out America's agenda for what is likely to be a noisy, protest-filled meeting of the world's top trade officials next month in Seattle.
Mr. Clinton said he would veto any spending bill that eliminated his plans to increase education spending, specifically for additional classroom teachers and computers. The current Republican plan for across-the-board spending cuts would eliminate many of those programs.
He also said he was willing to negotiate over an increased tobacco tax, a tax that most Republicans oppose.
Only once did Mr. Clinton begin to sound defensive, when a reporter questioned whether the White House, by inattention or ineptitude, was partly responsible for the defeat of the treaty.
Though he insisted that he had spoken "30 times" about the need to approve the treaty, his aides have acknowledged that he made little effort to build support until Republicans caught the Administration off guard by putting it on the agenda for a speedy vote. Only then, as one adviser to Mr. Clinton said today, "did everyone discover that there was a wildly wrong estimate of where we were on this thing."
Now Mr. Clinton faces a delicate dance. He has to convince his domestic audience that the Senate has made a terrible mistake, and he has to persuade other nations not to take his defeat as carte blanche to abandon the treaty themselves or to challenge Mr. Clinton's authority.
A delay in the vote would have made that two-step much simpler. On Tuesday, when it appeared possible that Democrats and Republicans would strike an agreement that would delay a vote until after the next President took office, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said, "There is an enormous difference between a postponement and a defeat."
An outright defeat, Mr. Berger said, could vitiate American credibility and "give other countries a pretext" to resume testing.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that prospect today, and he specifically warned India and Pakistan, neither of which has signed the treaty, against interpreting the Senate vote as a green light to proceed with their nuclear-weapons programs.
"Let me say to India and Pakistan, 'Do not take yesterday's vote as a sign that America doesn't care whether you resume nuclear testing and build up your nuclear arsenals,' " Mr. Clinton said. Such a move, he added, " 'will hurt your economy and endanger your future.' "
At the same moment, he acknowledged that the message that the vote sent would be a confused one. He said he told three ambassadors whom he saw on Wednesday night, hours after the vote, that they should tell their governments that he remained "in a battle with the new isolationists in the Republican Party."
But he expressed confidence about not reversing the United States' "commitment on nonproliferation," and he insisted that the treaty remained on the Senate calendar, even though there is no interest, in either party, in reviving it.
It is far from clear whether the vote will become a potent election issue over the next year. Without a clear threat from the likes of the former Soviet Union or China, nuclear politics do not have the resonance that they did when Lyndon B. Johnson ran a campaign advertisement in 1964 of a giant mushroom cloud.
But Mr. Clinton made a run at reviving that strategy. "Imagine the world we will live in if they prevail," he said of the Republicans, whom he accused -- three times -- of isolationism.
He suggested that the Republicans' ultimate goal was to wipe out all arms-control accords and leave the United States free to expand a huge advantage. "They think we ought to go it alone," he said.
In a lengthy aside, the President said that if the conventions on nuclear arms and chemical weapons were swept aside, military budgets would soar, not only in the United States but elsewhere. He painted a picture of countries' diverting money from education and health care to the military and raised the fear that Japan, which has pledged never to possess nuclear arms, might be forced to reconsider that position.
Republicans and some nuclear experts questioned whether Mr. Clinton was stretching to make his point. Japan has never seriously been tempted to build weapons, despite years of tests by Russia and China, and India and Pakistan have been living under mutual nuclear threats for years.
On economics, Mr. Clinton said he welcomed the thousands of protesters who say they will sweep into Seattle for the meeting next month of the World Trade Organization, where Mr. Clinton hopes to begin a new round of trade talks.
"I welcome them," he said, adding that they would help his drive to "put a more human face on the global economy." But, he said, "if their fundamental view is, 'If we had less trade instead of more,' " workers would prosper and countries would hold on to more wealth, "that is simply not true. So I want an expansive trade round that helps America and helps them, too."
