HEADLINE: Excerpts From Greenspan Talk on Financial Risk

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a Washington conference on risk management sponsored by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency:
The decline in recent years in the equity premium -- the margin by which the implied rate of discount on common stock exceeds the riskless rate of interest -- should prompt careful consideration of the robustness of our portfolio risk-management models in the event this judgment proves wrong. 
 The key question is whether the recent decline in equity premiums is permanent or temporary. If the decline is permanent, portfolio risk managers need not spend much time revisiting a history that is unlikely to repeat itself. But if it proves temporary, portfolio risk managers could find that they are underestimating the credit risk of individual loans based on the market value of assets and overestimating the benefits of portfolio diversification.
There can be little doubt that the dramatic improvements in information technology in recent years have altered our approach to risk. Some analysts perceive that information technology has permanently lowered equity premiums and, hence, permanently raised the prices of the collateral that underlies all financial assets.
The reason, of course, is that information is critical to the evaluation of risk. The less that is known about the current state of a market or a venture, the less the ability to project future outcomes and, hence, the more those potential outcomes will be discounted.
The rise in the availability of real-time information has reduced the uncertainties and thereby lowered the variances that we employ to guide portfolio decisions. At least part of the observed fall in equity premiums in our economy and others over the past five years does not appear to be the result of ephemeral changes in perceptions. It is presumably the result of a permanent technology-driven increase in information availability, which by definition reduces uncertainty and therefore risk premiums. This decline is most evident in equity risk premiums. It is less clear in the corporate bond market, where relative supplies of corporate and Treasury bonds and other factors we cannot easily identify have outweighed the effects of more readily available information about borrowers. . . .
That equity premiums have generally declined during the past decade is not in dispute. What is at issue is how much of the decline reflects new, irreversible technologies, and what part is a consequence of a prolonged business expansion without a significant period of adjustment. The business expansion is, of course, reversible, whereas the technological advancements presumably are not.
Some analysts have offered an entirely different interpretation of the drop in equity premiums. They assert that a long history of a rate of return on equity persistently exceeding the riskless rate of interest is bound to induce a learning-curve response that will eventually close the gap. According to this argument, much, possibly all, of the decline in equity premiums over the past five years reflects this learning response. It would be a mistake to dismiss such notions out of hand. We have learned to no longer cower at an eclipse of the sun or to run for cover at the sight of a newfangled automobile. . . .
As I have indicated on previous occasions, history tells us that sharp reversals in confidence occur abruptly, most often with little advance notice. These reversals can be self-reinforcing processes that can compress sizable adjustments into a very short period. Panic reactions in the market are characterized by dramatic shifts in behavior that are intended to minimize short-term losses. Claims on far-distant future values are discounted to insignificance. What is so intriguing, as I noted earlier, is that this type of behavior has characterized human interaction with little appreciable change over the generations. Whether Dutch tulip bulbs or Russian equities, the market price patterns remain much the same. . . .
The uncertainties inherent in valuations of assets and the potential for abrupt changes in perceptions of those uncertainties clearly must be adjudged by risk managers at banks and other financial intermediaries. At a minimum, risk managers need to stress test the assumptions underlying their models and set aside somewhat higher contingency resources -- reserves or capital -- to cover the losses that will inevitably emerge from time to time when investors suffer a loss of confidence. . . .
More important, boards of directors, senior managers and supervisory authorities need to balance emphasis on risk models that essentially have only dimly perceived sampling characteristics with emphasis on the skills, experience and judgment of the people who have to apply those models. Being able to judge which structural model best describes the forces driving asset pricing in any particular period is itself priceless. To paraphrase my former colleague Jerry Corrigan, the advent of sophisticated risk models has not made people with gray hair, or none, wholly obsolete.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar's Earnings Decline Sharply

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 15

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment manufacturer, reported today that a continued slump in heavy machinery sales lowered its third-quarter earnings by 35 percent.
The company said it had earned $219 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $336 million, or 92 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. 
 The results were a penny over the expectations of Wall Street analysts, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Caterpillar's stock was up 43.75 cents, to $56.0625 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
Third-quarter revenues were $4.72 billion, down 8.9 percent from $5.17 billion a year earlier.
Caterpillar reported a drop in heavy machinery sales in North America and Asia during the quarter. As a result, the company lowered its overall estimated sales and revenue for 1999. Caterpillar's chairman and chief executive, Glen Barton, said in a statement that the company now expects a decline of about 5 percent.
But Mr. Barton said he expected higher sales in 2000. Analysts have predicted that global economic recovery will result in higher earnings for Caterpillar next year.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Show Gain of 1.1 Percent,Biggest in Nine Years

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level shot up 1.1 percent in September, the biggest monthly increase in nine years, the Government reported today.
The report stoked fears among investors that inflation might be accelerating and helped to set off a wave of selling on Wall Street, which was already jittery over comments on Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, about the difficulty of determining whether stock prices are too high. 
 Analysts said the increase in the Producer Price Index, while nearly three times what had been anticipated, overstated any inflation threat. The rise in the index, they said, was largely driven by increases in a few categories, including oil, tobacco and automobiles.
But the jump in the price index was substantial enough that it increased the odds of the Federal Reserve's raising interest rates at its next meeting on Nov. 16. Fed officials are leaning toward increasing rates for the third time this year, said Mark Vitner, an economist at First Union Securities, and today's figures "give them the cover they need to do so at their mid-November meeting."
The so-called core price index, which excludes food and energy, rose eight-tenths of a percent in September, after being roughly flat for most of the year.
Excluding food, energy, tobacco and cars, the index rose just one-tenth of a percent in September, suggesting that there is no broad-based increase in prices paid by producers for finished goods. And there did not appear to be much inflation pressure in the pipeline, with the core index on intermediate goods -- a stage of production between raw materials and finished goods -- rising three-tenths of a percent in September after jumping eight-tenths of a percent in August and six-tenths of a percent in July.
Oil prices have been rising for months as global demand has grown. Tobacco companies have been raising prices to pass along the costs of their settlement with the states over the health effects of smoking. Car prices often jump in September, reflecting the start of a new model year.
The jump in all three categories is likely to flatten out this month, analysts said, but will show up in the Consumer Price Index for September, scheduled to be released on Tuesday.
The Fed said in a separate report today that industrial production fell three-tenths of a percent in September, largely because of the disruption caused on the East Coast by Hurricane Floyd. Excluding the effects of the storm, the Fed said, production would have increased slightly.
Although the chances of another rate increase from the Fed are growing, the decision is by no means a foregone conclusion, analysts said. Among the factors that might persuade the central bank to hold off is the decline in stock prices and the rise over much of the year in the long-term interest rates set in the bond market.
"The bottom line is that to a large degree, the markets are doing the Fed's job," said Stephen D. Slifer, an economist at Lehman Brothers. "Eventually the cooling off in financial markets should result in a cooling off in economic activity. The Fed must be asking, why tighten when jawboning works so well?"
With Wall Street waiting anxiously for any further sign from him, Mr. Greenspan spoke publicly again today, but confined his remarks mostly to preparations for the Year 2000 computer problem. Investors, however, continued to chew over the remarks he made Thursday night, in which he discussed the complexities of measuring financial risk.
Mr. Greenspan has been trying for the last several years to assess how swings in the prices of stocks and other assets affect consumer confidence, the long-term health of the financial system and economic growth -- and how and when the Fed should respond to them.
He has generally concluded that the central bank should not try to second-guess investors about whether stocks are overvalued, especially at a time when technology is reshaping the economy. Rather, Mr. Greenspan has said, the Fed should be prepared to act quickly if financial markets run into trouble.
At the same time, Mr. Greenspan and other Fed officials have been increasingly vocal in telling banks and other financial institutions not to assume that the good times will continue forever.
It was against that backdrop that Mr. Greenspan spoke to a conference on Thursday night sponsored by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency in Washington.
Mr. Greenspan noted a decline in recent years in the "equity premium," or the additional return demanded by investors to buy stocks rather than relatively less risky securities like Government bonds. The decline in the equity premium, Mr. Greenspan told the bank regulators, "should prompt careful consideration" of assumptions about how well financial institutions could cope if asset prices should plunge.
"The key question is whether the recent decline in equity premiums is permanent or temporary," Mr. Greenspan said, touching on a debate over whether the economy has been fundamentally strengthened by technology or is simply in the midst of an unsustainable bubble.
"What is at issue is how much of the decline reflects new, irreversible technologies, and what part is a consequence of a prolonged business expansion without a significant period of adjustment," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Greenspan has considerable experience with financial crises, having taken office just before the October 1987 stock market crash and having weathered the problems of last fall, when global markets all but seized up as financial problems in Asia spread to Russia and Latin America.
"As I have indicated on previous occasions, history tells us that sharp reversals in confidence occur abruptly, most often with little advance notice," Mr. Greenspan said. The bursting of a bubble, he said, is "incontrovertibly evident only in retrospect."
The lesson, he said, is that regulators should insist that financial institutions set aside enough money to weather "the losses that will inevitably emerge from time to time when investors suffer a loss of confidence."
"These reserves will appear almost all the time to be a suboptimal use of capital," Mr. Greenspan said. "So do fire insurance premiums."

HEADLINE: Asarco Accepts Grupo Mexico's $1.18 Billion Takeover Bid

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Asarco Inc. said yesterday that its board had voted to accept a sweetened $1.18 billion all-cash takeover bid from Grupo Mexico A.G. and that it planned to break its $1.17 billion cash-and-stock merger agreement with the Phelps Dodge Corporation.
Unless Phelps Dodge decides to increase its bid -- a move analysts said was unlikely -- its seven-week effort to acquire Asarco, the nation's third-largest copper producer, will come to an end. 
 "At this point, the story is virtually complete," said Clarence Morrison, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "I don't see Phelps Dodge increasing its offer, for the simple reason that they have come to the realization that it is no longer economic to purchase the company at this point for more than they are currently offering."
Asarco shareholders could, however, opt for the Phelps Dodge offer, particularly if the suitor's stock price rises in coming days.
Under the deal struck on Oct. 5, Phelps Dodge agreed to pay $14.75 in cash and 0.2513 Phelps Dodge share for each of Asarco's 39.8 million shares.
Grupo Mexico, a rail and mining conglomerate and Asarco's largest shareholder, made a $26-a-share, $1.03 billion cash bid for Asarco in September, topping an earlier hostile offer from Phelps Dodge. Grupo Mexico sweetened the offer on Oct. 7 to $29.50 a share, or $1.18 billion.
Phelps Dodge said on Oct. 8 that it would not raise its bid.
Susan Suber, a spokeswoman for Phelps Dodge, said yesterday that the company had no comment on the Asarco decision.
In a statement, Asarco said it intended to end its agreement with Phelps Dodge "at or after" 9 A.M. on Oct. 23.
Asarco will pay Phelps Dodge a $30 million breakup fee when it ends the deal, Jerry Cooper, an Asarco spokesman, said.
"The Phelps Dodge exchange offer is still open, but it looks likely Asarco shareholders will go with the cash bid," said Tom Burnett, founder of Merger Insight, which is based in New York. "However, if Phelps Dodge sees its stock price go up to $62 or higher, all things could change."
Phelps Dodge and Asarco shares withstood yesterday's stock market dive. Phelps Dodge closed at $57.875, up 62.5 cents a share, while Asarco rose 6.25 cents, to $29.375.
The purchase of Asarco would make Grupo Mexico one of the world's largest copper companies, with annual production of about 800,000 metric tons.
For now, Asarco's decision to accept the Grupo Mexico bid has apparently stifled Phelps Dodge's sweeping effort to become the world's largest copper company. As copper prices slumped earlier this year, Phelps Dodge began an offensive in August to acquire both Asarco and the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company, in an effort to cut costs through consolidation.
Until yesterday, it looked as if its efforts had succeeded: earlier this month, in addition to striking a deal with Asarco, it agreed to acquire Cyprus for $1.8 billion.
John Tumazos, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said that even if Phelps Dodge abandoned its effort to acquire Asarco now, it might choose to revive its interest later on, particularly if copper prices slide from their current levels of around 78 cents a pound.
"Phelps Dodge may have the idea to try and buy part of Asarco at a lower valuation than $29.75 a share if the outlook for copper turns out to be unfavorable 6, 12 or 18 months from now," he said. "Grupo's all-cash offer reinforces my thought that their expectation about copper prices is very aggressive."

HEADLINE: Quebec Gains as a Language Lab

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
When Thomas Stasko, a University of Maryland graduate student, signed up for a French language immersion program in a foreign university, he decided to go to there by car.
"It was convenient getting up to Quebec," Mr. Stasko said of his semester at the Universite du Quebec at Chicoutimi. "They all spoke French and were very friendly people." 
 With the Canadian dollar trading a near historic low, American teachers of French are promoting language studies in Quebec universities and summer camps. By looking north to Canada, French language teachers are borrowing a tactic from Spanish language teachers who have long looked south to Mexico.
This discovery of Quebec is one of several new tactics intended to make French more appealing to an increasingly diverse American study body. Hoping especially to interest African-Americans, colleges offer courses in the literature of the French-speaking countries of West Africa and the Caribbean, as well as study trips to these regions. French teachers in Louisiana and the Mississippi River Valley teach language students about local French history. Study of Quebec and the Acadian diaspora appeals to many of the 17 million Americans who are descended from French Canadians.
At stake in this battle for relevancy is the future of language training in American universities. Over the last 30 years, the portion of American college students studying a foreign language has dropped by half, to 7.9 percent in 1998, according to a survey released on Thursday by the Modern Language Association in New York.
But the survey indicates a slowing in the sharp erosion of French, which ranks second to Spanish among foreign languages taught in the United States. During the first half of the 1990's, French language enrollments in American colleges dropped by one quarter. But since then, enrollments have dropped only 3.1 percent, to 199,064 college students last year.
Over all, foreign language enrollments were up 4.8 percent. But this was largely due to Americans' growing interest in Spanish. An additional 60,000 students took Spanish in 1998, for a total of 656,690. About 30 years ago, Spanish began to surpass French in popularity among students, and today it attracts more than three times as many students as French does. The survey showed minor gains for Italian, Chinese and Portuguese. Losses were recorded for German, Japanese and Russian.
The biggest news appeared to be the stabilization in French enrollments, which had dropped by almost half since 1970.
"There are lots of American schools we work with that 10 years ago had four French teachers and two Spanish teachers, and now it is the reverse," said Woodruff Halsey, executive director of School Year Abroad, a program that sends about 60 high school juniors a year to France and Spain.
In the last decade, the number of American college students studying overseas nearly doubled, reaching 113,954 last year. But France as a study destination has slipped to fourth place from second, attracting fewer than 10,000 Americans today. Now, fewer American college students study French in France than study Spanish in Mexico and Costa Rica combined.
Quebec was long overlooked as an American study option because of the province's distinctive accent and because of the heavy English influence. The twangy accent has not softened, and some students said they did not want it to replace the Parisian accents they had learned in college. Regarding the other factor, however, the nationalist government in Quebec has worked to purge English from signs and public places.
"The Quebec connection has become quite marked now," said Elaine Marks, a French professor at the University of Wisconsin. "There are students who are interested in going to Quebec over the summer, who are unable to go to do the summer in Europe because of the expense."
The Canadian dollar trades at 68 American cents, an exchange rate that makes Quebec a bargain, helping to attract almost 15 million American tourists to Canada last year. The linguistic bastion of French in North America, Canada has seven million native French speakers.
With the strengthening of French in Canada, the American Association of Teachers of French has started to alternate its annual meetings between France and Quebec.
"Quebec is affordable," said Jayne Abrate, the association's executive director, who teaches French at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale.
Ms. Abrate said elementary school teachers "who are intimidated about taking a group to France will start out by taking them to Quebec."
Every year, more than 100 American college students study French at the university at Chicoutimi, a French-speaking city about 225 miles northeast of Montreal. For programs under 12 weeks, Americans do not need student visas.
"The kids come back happy and speaking French," said Tom Carr, a lecturer at the University of Maryland. "It's so much more economic, and they can get there by car, which gives them a certain amount of mobility."
Summer language camps in Quebec are also attracting more Americans. And on the American side of the border, a high school French language camp now takes students on regular trips to Montreal and Quebec City from the Potsdam campus at the State University of New York.
Despite the old tourism slogan of Canada as "friendly, familiar, foreign and near," Americans can go through a bit of culture shock in Quebec.
"The cuisine is definitely different," said Alanna Prisby, a 22-year-old French major from Central Michigan University. She is spending the fall semester in Chicoutimi with a family that has some distinctive favorite dishes.
"For one meal we had cabbage rolls with potatoes, but with vanilla ice cream on top," Ms. Prisby said. "We've also had fried bologna with creamed corn on top."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Speech on Retirement

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the speech by Bill Bradley in August 1995 when he announced his decision to retire from the Senate:
I have always preferred moving to standing still. As a small forward with the Knicks and then as a U.S. senator from New Jersey, I've had two of the best jobs in the world. Each kept me on the move, each offered unique perspective on America, and in each there came a time to go. 
 So today I announce that I am leaving the U.S. Senate at the end of my term and I will not run for re-election. . . .
During my time in the Senate, I have tried to balance the private interests and the public interests; the rights of property owners and the needs of society; the big players and the forgotten players. I haven't always pleased everyone, but I've tried to be consistent on the big issues such as the economy, race and America's role in the world.
I've also tried to take the long view, often passing up a headline to make sure that when I spoke I knew what I was talking about. Questions of structure, whether on taxes, trade or the environment, always interested me more than issues of marginal gain or questions of blame or strategies for partisan politician advantage.
We live in a time when, on a basic level, politics is broken. In growing numbers, people have lost faith in the political process and don't see how it can help their threatened economic circumstances. The political debate has settled into two familiar ruts. The Republicans are infatuated with the "magic" of the private sector and reflexively criticize government as the enemy of freedom, and the Democrats distrust the market, preach government as the answer to our problems and prefer the bureaucrat they know to the consumer they can't control. Neither party speaks to people where they live their lives. Both have moved away from my own concept of service and my own vision of what America can be.
I am saddened on occasion when the media, and politicians, themselves, convey that politics is mean, cheap and dirty; that what we hold in common as Americans is somehow less than what we harbor in our hearts and minds for ourselves as individuals. I have never believed that.
As I listen to our current political debate, I feel that among the things missing are the big ambitions that have always guided Americans who settled this continent, ended slavery, won two world wars and saw our liberal democratic ideals triumph around the globe.
I am leaving the U.S. Senate, but I am not leaving public life. The quest for a decent life and good wages for all Americans is shaped by many influences that work on many levels. The imperative to engage the world flows through many channels. The fight for justice occurs in many places.
I will expand my dialogue with the American people. I will continue to speak out and call it like I see it on race, on America's role in the world, on the economic plight of the middle class and the poor, and on the need for thorough-going reform that will remove special interests from elections and reduce their influence on government.
In the coming months, I will not lessen my efforts. To the contrary, I will increase them. As I leave the familiar surroundings of the U.S. Senate, I don't know where the future will lead. But, I recall the words of Robert Frost: "The woods are lovely, dark and deep, but I have promises to keep, and miles to go before I sleep; and miles to go before I sleep."

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Is That an Epidemic -- or a Terrorist Attack?;
Bioterrorism Is the Least of Our Worries

BYLINE: By Jonathan B. Tucker; Jonathan B. Tucker, a former biological weapons inspector in Iraq, edited the forthcoming book, "Toxic Terror: Assessing Terrorist Use of Chemical and Biological Weapons."

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
The news media are fascinated with bioterrorism. After a New Yorker article this week quoted unnamed Central Intelligence Agency analysts who speculated, apparently wrongly, that the outbreak of West Nile-like fever in New York could have been the work of Iraqi terrorists, a number of television news programs reported the story. And earlier this month, ABC's "Nightline" aired a weeklong docudrama in which a hypothetical anthrax attack on the subway system of a major city inflicts more than 50,000 deaths.
This sort of worst-case scenario is extremely unlikely. In truth, most terrorists aren't interested in staging catastrophic biological attacks, and those who are would have significant technical hurdles to overcome. 
 Over the past century, not a single American has died from bioterrorism. Hundreds of hoaxes involving anthrax have been staged during the past two years, but only one successful biological attack has been reported in the United States. In 1984, members of the Rajneeshee cult contaminated an Oregon town's salad bars with salmonella bacteria, making 751 people temporarily sick. The objective was to manipulate the outcome of a local election by keeping voters home.
There are reasons why there has been only one successful bioterrorist attack. Most politically motivated terrorist groups have no incentive to engage in biological warfare. Conventional weapons are easier to use than microbes, and bioterrorist attacks could alienate supporters and provoke severe government repression.
The sort of group likely to engage in bioterrorism has no political constituency and is motivated by apocalyptic prophecy, religious fanaticism, racist ideology or revenge. Yet groups of this kind are usually small and lack the money and the technological know-how to produce and deliver biological weapons.
True, a rogue state like Iraq might provide technical help, but only at grave risk: the sponsor could lose control over the terrorists and invite severe retaliation if its involvement became known. Or a wealthy terrorist group might try to recruit scientists formerly employed by the Soviet Union, for example, which had advanced bioweapons programs. But no evidence currently available points to such assistance.
Without technical help, small terrorist cells would have a hard time mounting a large-scale biological attack. Germs suitable for warfare are difficult to mass-produce and even harder to disseminate effectively. Microbes might be spread, for example, as an aerosol cloud, but it is technically complex and dangerous to produce a concentrated aerosol that could infect thousands of people. Contaminating urban water supplies is also beyond the ability of most terrorists, mainly because a huge volume of harmful agent would be needed to overcome the effects of dilution, chlorination and filtration.
In the late 1980's in Japan, the Aum Shinrikyo cult, which had vast financial resources, recruited scientists from leading Japanese universities to develop bioweapons. But even though the cult acquired anthrax bacteria and botulinum toxin and carried out several attacks in Japan, no injuries or deaths were reported. The cult then resorted to sarin, a chemical nerve agent. In March 1995, the group released the poison on the Tokyo subway, killing 12 people and injuring more than a thousand.
Given the constraints, a bioterrorist attack in the United States in which thousands of people are killed remains extremely unlikely. While planning for such an event is warranted, government authorities should pay attention to a far more probable scenario: small-scale incidents involving food or drug contamination, which could cause widespread fear and economic disruption.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Agreement Has Led to Boom In U.S.-Canada Air Traffic

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The last time President Clinton came to Ottawa, Canada's capital, was in 1995. He visited the neo-Gothic Parliament building to witness the signing of an abstract piece of economic diplomacy: an open-skies agreement with Canada.
When Mr. Clinton returned there last week, the benefits were as concrete as the direct flights between Ottawa and Reagan National Airport in Washington that began two months ago, just in time for the President's advance team. 
 The new flight is part of a two-thirds increase in the number of flights between Canada and the United States over the last five years. Across the United States, 24 cities have begun direct flights to Canada. Freed to choose routes and equipped with smaller commuter jets, Air Canada, the nation's largest airline, has tripled its American destinations to 45.
By bringing the regional jet revolution to north-south air travel, Canada now paces Britain as the favored destination for Americans. Last year, about 8.4 million Americans boarded planes for each country.
In 1999, according to analysis by BACK Associates Inc., a research firm, there are 193,427 commercial flights from the United States to Canada -- more than the total for Asia and Europe combined.
Deregulation led Air Canada to inaugurate direct flights from its Toronto hub to a series of unlikely American destinations: Allentown and Harrisburg, Pa.; Charlotte, N.C.; Columbus, Ohio; New Orleans; Phoenix; Providence, R.I., and San Jose, Calif. As a result, Ontario now receives more American air travelers than France or Germany.
"Air Canada built up a nice model for adding direct city pairs," said Don Ogden, an industry analyst in Vancouver, British Columbia. "Over the first couple of years they were able to add route after route after route."
On the Canadian side, American and Canadian airlines have channeled most of the growth into the nation's two busiest airport hubs, Toronto and Vancouver. But new pairings have also evolved: Winnipeg-Denver, Edmonton-Chicago, Whitehorse-Anchorage, Ottawa-Philadelphia and Montreal-Portland, Me.
Moving aggressively into western Canada, Alaska Airlines has begun service from Seattle to Calgary and Edmonton in Alberta and Kelowna, British Columbia. Connecting the prairies, Northwest Airlines has started flights linking Minneapolis to Regina and Saskatoon in Saskatchewan and Kenora, Ontario.
On Canada's Atlantic side, Air Canada has service between Prince Edward Island and Boston and has just begun a daily flight from Halifax, Nova Scotia, to Dulles International Airport near Washington.
Since the open-skies agreement was signed in February 1995, Northwest and Continental Airlines have each started 10 flights to Canada. American Airlines has begun 8; United Airlines, 6; U S Airways, 4 and Delta, 3.
"Every day I find out there are new routes being established between our two countries," said Raymond Chretien, Canada's Ambassador to the United States, who came to Ottawa for the Clinton visit. "Open skies is great because it has changed the way we do business. It has brought far more Americans to Canada."
It has not always been this way. Before the accord was signed, passenger traffic was stagnating. Since the accord, it has jumped about one-third.
"There was enormous frustration on the part of business travelers, tourists and family members how to get to Canada," recalled Federico Pena, who was United States Transportation Secretary when the 1995 agreement was signed. Speaking from Denver, where he advises an investment firm, he added: "There were very, very few flights, very few locations. If you wanted to fly to Canada, you had to go through a number of airports."
Deregulation negotiations had dragged on for years, stalled largely because Air Canada and its smaller rival, Canadian Airlines, feared they would lose market share to American competitors. In the end, a fresh team was brought in and the Canadians were given a two-year head start to open new routes.
"I was at the signing on Parliament Hill in 1995," recalled Paul Frazer, spokesman for the Canadian Embassy in Washington. "There were all these other people, some with gray hair. I was trying to figure out who they all were. It turned out the room was full of negotiating teams going back 25 years."
Air Canada is currently fighting a hostile takeover proposal to merge with Canadian Airlines. Shareholders are to vote on the issue Nov. 8.
It is unclear how a merger might affect the new American air links, and there is some fear that fledgling American routes might be cut to increase the combined airlines' profitability.
Partly to head off criticism that he wants to create a monopoly, Gerald Schwartz, a Canadian financier who is leading the takeover bid, announced last week that if his merger plan was approved, he would largely freeze domestic fares and route networks for five years.

Dow Jones Industrials Drop On New Fears of Inflation
The Dow Jones industrial average and other stock market gauges plunged after an inflation report showed the biggest monthly increase in nine years in prices at the producer level and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, alarmed investors by warning that the stock market might be more risky than many people now believe. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 266.90 points, to 10,019.71. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fared even worse than the Dow, dropping 2.81 percent, to 1,247.41, The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.67 percent, or 75 points, to 2,731.83. Long-term interest rates have been rising lately, although the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined to 6.26 percent yesterday as investors sought alternatives to stocks. Page A1.
 
Paying a Call on the West Bank
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, leading a delegation of American executives in the first United States Department of Commerce business mission to the Middle East to include the West Bank, sees encouraging signs. C2.
 
More Planes Are Heading to Canada
An open skies agreement signed in February 1995 has proved to be a boon to travel between the United States and Canada. Canada now matches Britain as the favored destination for Americans. Last year, about 8.4 million Americans boarded planes for each country. C2.
 
Vaccine Maker Withdraws Product
American Home Products, which makes the only licensed vaccine to prevent the most common cause of severe diarrhea in infants and children, is withdrawing the vaccine from the market because of concerns over possible side effects. A10.
 
Apple Backs Off Price Increase
Apple Computer backed off from a decision to raise prices retroactively on some computers that customers already had ordered and paid for. It did so after receiving many customer complaints. The turnaround came after the matter threatened to blemish an otherwise positive public image for Apple, which has delivered a string of popular new computers and strong financial results in the last year. C4.

But he denied speculation that B Sky B, which is 40 percent owned by Mr. Murdoch's company, the News Corporation, might buy or merge with Canal Plus, the big French pay-per-view company. C2.
 
Profits Decline 35% at Caterpillar
Caterpillar said a continued slump in heavy machinery sales lowered its third-quarter earnings by 35 percent. The company earned $219 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $336 million, or 92 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. The results were a penny over the expectations of Wall Street analysts. C14.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: For Many Pakistanis, Coup Opens to Applause

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER with STEVE LeVINE 

DATELINE: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 15

 BODY:
If there is such a thing as a good coup, this one is winning raves in the bazaars of Rawalpindi.
A decade of crooked and incompetent civilian rule before the takeover this week, a decade of competently brutal dictatorship before that, and life keeps getting harder for Pakistan's 138 million souls. A Pakistani poet, Faiz Ahmed Faiz, once was asked what would become of his nation. "My great fear," he said, "is that nothing will happen. Things will go on the way they are." 
 There is not much passion for politicians or for going to the polls again. There is a thirst for leadership, or even something stronger.
"I don't think there should be any elections," said Kalsoon Syed, an elementary school principal. "There should be a strong dictator."
The American Ambassador, William B. Milam, met today for 90 minutes with the coup leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, at the army's headquarters here, just hours after the general declared himself the country's chief executive, suspended the Constitution and dismissed Parliament. The general's Government also froze the assets of more than 500 politicians, including Nawaz Sharif, the ousted Prime Minister, and his predecessor, Benazir Bhutto. A United States Embassy spokesman said the Ambassador had given the general a message from President Clinton calling for a return to civilian rule as soon as possible.
Mr. Clinton may be calling for a return to democratic principles, but politicians here have rarely practiced them. For 11 years, since the end of the last military dictatorship, most of them have behaved like medieval barons, plundering what remained of the nation's wealth.
What was left was not enough to run a civil society. The principal export of Pakistan today is Pakistanis. The most talented, the best educated, the potential leaders are gone. So nostalgia for a strongman fills the marketplace.
That feeling may support the military Government of General Musharraf, who seized power this week, becoming the latest in a series of rulers who have led and misled the nation for 25 of its 52 years.
Pakistan was created in 1947 out of the violent partition of India. While it often has been ruled by military dictatorships, it has also had the trappings of democracy: a Parliament, a lively press, political debate.
But to many Pakistanis, democracy is a facade. Waheed Zaman, 30, the well-spoken owner of a trophy shop, said his middle-class family was "like other people; we are fed up with politicians; we have love for our armed forces despite their checkered history."
Mr. Zaman and others in the teeming bazaar here, 25 miles southwest of the national capital, Islamabad, spoke in heroic terms of a man who was once was a national demon: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who ruled Pakistan for 11 years. His rule and his life ended in 1988 in a plane crash, a still unexplained mid-air explosion that also took the life of Arnold Raphel, the American Ambassador to Pakistan.
"General Zia was an angel," said a grizzled rickshaw driver named Amir Khan, 59. "Then there was no inflation. Crime was under control. When I heard he was killed, I thought Pakistan was an orphan."
That sentiment is sometimes tinged with blood; many Pakistanis want their political miscreants punished. "These smugglers, these bribe-taking people, should be behind bars or hanged," said Mrs. Syed, the school principal.
"Pervez Musharraf, my prayers and my best wishes are with him," she said. "This man is a general. He knows law and order and how to get things done. We expect him to do things for the common people."
Much needs to be done. Pakistan is a basket case, and the coup may make things worse.
Today two-thirds of the country's wealth goes to the military and to paying its debts. Three-quarters of the aid Pakistan receives from the International Monetary Fund goes to pay off i.o.u.'s to the I.M.F. That aid was immediately suspended after the coup, as was a trade agreement with the European Union. Pakistan has only $1.4 billion in foreign reserves -- just enough to buy three weeks of imports.
In the troubled two-and-a half-year tenure of Mr. Sharif, Pakistan's currency, the rupee, lost half its value against the dollar. Everything in the bazaar seems to cost far more than it did in 1997. And the $600 million in annual military and economic aid Pakistan received from the United States in General Zia's day ended after he died and when the cold war was over, blocked by law after the United States acknowledged that Pakistan was building a nuclear bomb.
Washington is now uneasily contemplating the prospect of dealing with a Pakistani dictator once more. Western diplomats said the general had given Ambassador Milam a preview of the speech he is to give on Saturday, in which he is expected to set forth his plans for dealing with Pakistan's crushing problems.
Those plans may include a slow return to what the West would like to call democracy. It may come, but for now the bazaar has spoken, and in much the same voice as that of Talat Massoud, a retired lieutenant general who served as Defense Secretary from 1988 to 1990.
"The coup was a good thing," he said, in a voice devoid of happiness or anticipation. "There was no choice left for the military. Our politicians put us on the brink of disaster. They were making a mockery of democracy. The Prime Minister had corrupted every institution. The judiciary was bought off; there was no justice. The police were run as a fiefdom. What kind of democracy was that?"

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
BIG SELLOFF CAPS DOW'S WORST WEEK SINCE OCTOBER '89

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
A jittery stock market dropped sharply yesterday after an inflation report showed prices rising at an unexpectedly rapid rate and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, alarmed investors by warning that the stock market might be riskier than many people believe. The market suffered its worst week in a decade.
The Dow Jones industrial average traded below 10,000 for the first time since April. It rallied a bit, to close at 10,019.71, but still was down 266.90 points, or 2.59 percent, for the day. The weekly decline of 5.9 percent was the worst since a fall of 7.8 percent in the week ended Oct. 13, 1989. That problems are happening again in October -- a month that has recorded steep drops before -- added to the market's nervousness. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fared even worse than the Dow, dropping 2.8 percent yesterday, to close at 1,247.41, and falling 6.6 percent for the week. That index is up just 1.48 percent since the end of 1998, while the Dow, which has a larger representation of energy issues that have benefited from rising oil prices, is still up 9.13 percent for the year.
The market has been unusually volatile in recent weeks, reflecting concerns that the Fed might raise short-term interest rates again when it meets next month. At the same time, the market has been pushing up long-term interest rates, although they fell a bit yesterday. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which set a two-year high of 6.32 percent on Thursday, slipped to 6.26 percent yesterday as investors sought alternatives to stocks.
All this has come against the backdrop of a booming economy, which has produced strong corporate profits. "Earnings have been good, but interest rates have surprised people by rising," said Byron Wien, an equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Inflation is not dead, and that has been the undoing of the market."
The Government reported yesterday that the Producer Price Index rose 1.1 percent in September, the largest monthly climb in nine years. Page B1. While most of that could be explained by rising prices of tobacco, cars, food and energy, the figure was much larger than expected, and that contributed to the weakness in the stock market.
Mr. Greenspan, addressing a banking conference Thursday night in Washington, was careful to express no opinion on whether stock prices were justified by the current economic outlook. But he cautioned that stock prices had increased in recent years in significant part because investors think equities are far less risky than they have historically been thought to be, making prices vulnerable if such confidence were to fade.
"History tells us that sharp reversals in confidence occur abruptly, most often with little advance notice," Mr. Greenspan said. "Panic reactions in the market are characterized by dramatic shifts in behavior that are intended to minimize short-term losses." He warned that banks should carry high levels of reserves to protect themselves against such an occurrence.
Hugh Johnson, an economist at the First Albany Corporation, said: "He's telling bankers to be prudent. That is extremely benign. Does it signal a change in policy? I don't think so."
The Fed is widely expected to raise short-term interest rates by a quarter-percentage point when it meets on Nov. 16. If it does, that will be the third increase since June, completely erasing the three cuts it made last year, when the Fed feared world recession in the wake of the Asian and Russian financial crises. Asian economies have since recovered much of their losses, and many European countries are also doing better.
"When global growth recovers from a significant period of weakness, inflation and interest rates tend to go up," said Doug Cliggott, an equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities.
Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, said he believed the producer price figure had "ended the debate" about whether the Fed would raise rates again. "They recognize the economy is growing too fast, and they are going to raise rates until they slow it down," he said.
Though Mr. Greenspan said little in his speech about what he was going to do, markets around the world weakened as soon as reports of it were distributed Thursday night. Major stock markets in both Europe and Asia fell by at least 1 percent yesterday, although none performed as poorly as the United States market.
Until recently, the Nasdaq composite index has been a beacon of strength in the market, reflecting its heavy concentration of technology issues that have been market leaders. In fact, that index hit a record high on Monday. But it fell 2.67 percent, or 75 points, yesterday, to 2,731.83, and is now down 6.7 percent since the Monday high, as leading technology stocks have slipped. Yesterday, Microsoft, Cisco and Intel all lost at least $2 a share. Still, the Nasdaq composite is up 24.6 percent in 1999.
By some measures, the stock market in 1999 has been more volatile than at any time since 1987, and that volatility seems to have intensified in recent weeks. Fane Lozman, chairman of Scanshift, a Chicago research firm, noted that the Dow has lost more than 200 points on seven days this year -- four of them since Sept. 21. "This shows there is a change in mentality here," he said.
The nervousness stems in part from the memories of past Octobers. The 12th anniversary of the 1987 crash arrives on Tuesday, 10 days before the 70th anniversary of the worst day of the 1929 crash. The last week this bad, exactly 10 years ago, came as the market was shocked by the collapse of a proposed buyout of United Airlines.
Since World War II, only 16 weeks have been worse than this one, in terms of percentage decline for the Dow, according to Birinyi Associates, a research firm. For the S.& P. 500, this week ranked 11th since the war.
Though it is misleading to pay attention to Dow points because the index has gone up so much in recent years, this week's decline was the largest ever in points. The 630.85-point decrease surpassed the drop of 524.30 points, set in the week ended Sept. 24.
The market's jitters have so far not stopped the booming new-issues market. An Internet stock called Women.com went public yesterday at $10 a share and closed at $18.50, although that was down from a high of $23.375 reached in midafternoon. Companies scheduled to go public next week include Martha Stewart Omnimedia and World Wrestling Federation Entertainment.

HEADLINE: Endorsement Brings Big Labor Test for Gore

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The nation has lost 500,000 manufacturing jobs over the last 18 months, despite the economic boom, and organized labor's eagerness to see that trend reversed is shaping up as an economic test for President Clinton and a huge political test for Vice President Al Gore.
Union leaders say that even though Mr. Gore won the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. at its convention here, the Administration will need to take strong steps toward stopping the loss of manufacturing jobs if the Vice President hopes to excite rank-and-file workers to vote for him. 
 The job losses have become perhaps the most important issue to labor unions in six large industrial states that are crucial swing states in Presidential elections: Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
Many officials from the powerful industrial unions in those states -- the auto workers, the steelworkers and the machinists -- say that if Mr. Gore hopes to motivate union activists to campaign for him and union members to vote for him, he must address labor's concerns on manufacturing and the related subject of trade.
"It's one thing for the Vice President to get the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s endorsement, and it's quite another to mobilize our members," said George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America. Mr. Becker met with Mr. Gore this week to press him on trade and manufacturing. "I have one overall goal in life," Mr. Becker said, "and that is to reverse the trend of de-industrializing America and to stop these insane trade laws that force our manufacturers to compete against impossible odds."
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which is a force in the Middle West as well as in two important early primary states, New York and California, is also warning the Vice President that the Administration needs to do more to stop industrial decline. The teamsters and auto workers were the only unions to oppose the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement of Mr. Gore, and both unions are demanding firmer commitments from the Administration and the Vice President on trade if they are to back him.
Mindful of these pressures, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have called for some labor-friendly provisions in trade treaties and have created a task force to study the plight of manufacturing. While labor leaders are encouraged by these steps, they say the important test will be what specific actions the Administration takes -- and whether Mr. Gore will disagree with the Administration if he feels it does not go far enough.
Complicating matters for the Vice President, many middle-of-the-road Democrats and business executives are cautioning the Administration and Mr. Gore not to become tools of labor and not to comply with demands that they deem protectionist.
Labor unions, which are considered vital to turning out the Democratic base in general elections, have a long wish list for the Administration, and they hope the Vice President will press labor's viewpoint.
Unions want Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore to make sure that any future trade agreements include penalties against trading partners that allow violations of minimal international labor standards, like child labor rules. Unions oppose admitting China to the World Trade Organization, saying a country that uses prison labor and bars independent trade unions should not be given more access to the American market.
While avoiding their blatantly protectionist language of a few years ago, labor leaders have attacked the record trade deficit, which may top $300 billion this year. They also dislike the strong dollar, which has cost American manufacturing jobs by making American goods more expensive overseas and by making foreign goods cheaper.
Christopher Lehane, a spokesman for the Vice President's campaign, said, "Al Gore agrees with the many representatives of labor, including those from the industrial unions, that there is nothing more important that we can do to make sure we can expand our prosperity to all portions of the country, and that includes, most prominently, our industrial sector -- our steelworkers, our auto workers, our truck drivers, our shipbuilders."
Union leaders say that whatever reservations they have about the Administration and Mr. Gore on trade, the views of former Senator Bill Bradley, the Vice President's only rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, are no better.
The 1.4 million-member teamsters union has its own specific demand, that the Administration stop a provision in the North American Free Trade Agreement from taking effect on Jan. 1. That provision would lift restrictions that bar Mexican truckers from driving in the United States.
Pushing for continued restrictions on cross-border trucking, teamster officials argue that most Mexican trucks are unsafe. They fear that a huge influx of low-wage Mexican drivers would wipe out the jobs of thousands of American truckers.
In a warning to Mr. Gore, Michael Mathis, the teamsters' political director, said, "I think we'd be very much less excited about Gore if the border is open Jan. 1. We'll be very, very disappointed."
Many union leaders have told the Vice President to heed a lesson from 1994, when the Democrats lost control of the House. That year, union members were so angry with President Clinton and the Democrats over passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement that an unusual number of union members decided not to vote, giving the Republicans an edge in many districts.
An early test of whether the Administration and Mr. Gore will pass labor's scrutiny on trade will come in Seattle on Nov. 30, when the World Trade Organization's ministerial meeting begins. The meeting is expected to set ground rules for a new multiyear round of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade.
The unions want future trade pacts to include basic labor protections and to give countries the right to impose penalties against countries that violate minimum labor standards, like a ban on child labor. But many companies and third-world countries say labor-related provisions have no place in trade agreements, and they are pressuring Mr. Clinton and his Vice President to ignore labor's pleas.
"They got to be very careful about how they handle Seattle, notwithstanding labor's endorsement of Gore," said Jay Mazur, chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s international affairs committee and president of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. "Remember, our people are upset about losing 500,000 manufacturing jobs."

HEADLINE: Issue by Issue, First Lady Details Differences With Giuliani

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton moved to draw a series of sharp differences with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, attacking the legacy of Ronald Reagan's economic policies two weeks after Mr. Giuliani celebrated them, and assailing Republicans for blocking a minimum wage increase and promoting the use of school vouchers.
Mrs. Clinton, in the course of a 20-minute speech and a news conference, did not once mention the name of her likely opponent in next year's race for the United States Senate. But her audience -- members of District Council 37, the city workers' union, which supported Mr. Giuliani's mayoral bid in 1997 -- clearly understood her meaning. They cheered boisterously as she methodically attacked positions Mr. Giuliani has embraced while laying the groundwork for his expected campaign. 
 It was by any measure the closest that Mrs. Clinton has come to engaging Mr. Giuliani. The litany of issues that she mentioned, and her repeated allusions to Mr. Reagan, strongly suggested that Mrs. Clinton, like most Democratic candidates running for statewide office in this Democratic state over the last 20 years, would try to frame the contest as a stark choice between Democratic and Republican views.
"I'm talking about what I believe and drawing a contrast with others who don't believe as I do," the First Lady said at a news conference yesterday morning. "I don't think that Reaganomics and supply-side economics was the right direction for this country. I don't think studying the minimum wage to death instead of raising it is fair to working people. I don't think that turning back the comprehensive test ban treaty was in our national security.
"So on this and many other issues, there is a clear contrast -- and there will be a very clear choice," Mrs. Clinton said.
Asked why she never mentioned the Mayor by name, the First Lady, who is in the midst of eight days of unbroken campaigning in New York, responded: "I am not a candidate yet. I am not engaged in the campaign. But I am laying out the positions that I believe in, that I think that most New Yorkers agree with. So as we move forward into the year 2000 -- which is actually the election year, as opposed to this year -- I think that those contrasts and choices will become clearer."
Mrs. Clinton's remarks came at an event that demonstrated the extent of her support among New York's labor unions. District Council 37 supported Mr. Giuliani when he ran for mayor in 1997, in what was a particularly unwelcome moment for Ruth W. Messinger, the Democratic candidate. The union, though, is under new leadership, and from the moment Mrs. Clinton walked in the door -- to shouts of "Run, Hillary, run" -- it was clear that Mr. Giuliani could not rely on its support this time.
"I will say this: When you announce, District Council 37 endorses," the union's administrator, Lee Saunders, said as he introduced Mrs. Clinton. "Aren't I right? Stand up! Aren't I right?" The audience rose in cheers.
Mr. Saunders said afterward that there was a "clear difference in the positions that they take," referring to Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton. Asked about the change since the union endorsed Mr. Giuliani in 1997, the responded: "The mayor's race was the mayor's race. This is the Senate race."
The Mayor, through a spokeswoman, declined to respond to the specifics of Mrs. Clinton's remarks yesterday. "She is right that she is not a candidate," the spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel, said. "She is not a resident. So it is difficult to believe how she might be able to speak for most New Yorkers, or for that matter any New Yorkers."
The First Lady's speech wove together issues that she and her aides have raised piecemeal in recent weeks, in an attempt to prod Mr. Giuliani to take the Republican side on legislation being debated in Congress. The effort aspires to blunt what Mrs. Clinton's advisers see as one of Mr. Giuliani's strengths -- that he is a moderate Republican who can easily draw Democratic and independent votes.
In recent weeks, Mr. Giuliani has aligned himself with Republicans by opposing ratification of a nuclear test ban treaty and declining to endorse legislation passed by the House to regulate health maintenance organizations.
Mr. Giuliani has also declined to endorse an increase in the minimum wage to $6.50 from $5.50, pending studies that he said were necessary to make certain that a higher rate would not lead to the elimination of many low-paying jobs.
Mrs. Clinton devoted much of her attention yesterday to attacking the economic policies of Mr. Reagan, previewing a campaign strategy that evoked Mario M. Cuomo's first successful campaign for governor in 1982. Her remarks came less than three weeks after Mr. Giuliani gave a speech at the Reagan Library in California, presenting himself as a Reagan Republican.
"We need to make sure," Mrs. Clinton said in her speech yesterday, "that we have someone representing New York who will stand up against any effort to go back, to make a U-turn to the days of trickle-down, supply-side economics. Anybody who praises Reaganomics and supply-side economics must not have a good memory about what was happening in New York in the 1980's."
"Let's not let anyone take us back," she said.
She also drew an unstated contrast with Mr. Giuliani in noting his support for school vouchers, something that Mrs. Clinton and labor leaders say would harm the public school system. "There are some who would undermine and dismantle the public school system in our country," she said.
Along the same lines, Mrs. Clinton was critical of Republicans for passing legislation to use part of the nation's projected surplus for cutting taxes, a position that Mr. Giuliani also said he supported. Mrs. Clinton, like her husband and most Democrats, said she supported smaller tax cuts and using the money to shore up the Social Security and Medicare systems. "The Republicans in Congress would instead spend $800 billion in exploding tax cuts," she said. "That is wrong. It will not solve our problems."

HEADLINE: U.S. ASKS RUSSIA TO ALTER TREATY FOR HELP ON RADAR

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 16

 BODY:
In a dramatic reversal of previous policy, the United States is now offering to help Russia complete a large missile tracking radar if Moscow agrees in exchange to renegotiate what both countries long saw as a landmark arms control agreement.
The confidential proposal to help the Russians finish their radar near Irkutsk, Siberia, is part of an intensive American campaign laying the groundwork for a defense against potential missile attacks from North Korea and other nations, Russian and American officials say. 
 Such a nationwide defense is prohibited by the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, a pact viewed for more than 25 years as the bedrock of arms control. Moscow has so far refused to alter it, and announced on Friday -- two days after the Senate voted down a nuclear test ban treaty -- that it would work with China to seek support at the United Nations against American efforts to alter the accord.
The increasingly heated dispute over antimissile defenses comes as the structure of arms control appears to be under siege. The Senate vote drew widespread criticism around the world. The Russian Parliament, meanwhile, has blocked progress on further arms reductions by failing to ratify the Start II treaty.
In addition, the war Russia is fighting in Chechnya means that Moscow has hundreds more armored vehicles in the Northern Caucusus than it is permitted to under a key 1990 accord limiting ground troops and conventional weapons in Europe.
"It used to be argued that rogue states were the main threat to strategic stability," said Sergei Rogov, the director of the U.S.-Canada Institute. "Now it is the United States and Russia who refuse to ratify and implement agreements and who violate their terms."
Senior American officials insist that the Clinton Administration is not aiming to nullify the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. Rather, they maintain, the goal is to update the accord so that the United States can defend itself against new missile threats while at the same time avoiding a new arms race with Russia and China. A formal decision on whether to proceed with antimissile defenses is to be made by next summer, based on technical, economic and arms control considerations.
But Russian officials insist that Washington has vastly exaggerated the missile threat arising from undeclared or potential nuclear powers and say that weakening the ABM treaty would be a reckless move.
"What happened to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty was a disaster," said Grigory V. Berdennikof, a senior arms control specialist at Russia's Foreign Ministry.
"If it happens to the ABM treaty," he said, "it will be a quadruple disaster. The pattern is clear."
When the ABM treaty was concluded, the argument against development of national antimissile defense systems in Russia and the United States was that they would encourage both sides to accumulate more arms to penetrate such shields.
When the Soviet Union built a radar in the 1980's at Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, to fill a gap in its radar coverage, the United States argued successfully that it was a violation of the treaty and pressed the Russians to dismantle it.
In January, however, the Clinton Administration took a different tack. President Clinton sent President Boris N. Yeltsin a letter asking Russia to renegotiate the treaty to permit a limited system of defenses.
The Administration insisted that the accord had to be updated because nations like North Korea and Iran were developing the means to manufacture ocean-spanning ballistic missiles. American intelligence analysts revised their estimates after they failed to anticipate North Korea's unsuccessful effort to launch a tiny satellite into space in 1998 using a three-stage missile.
"During the next 15 years, the United States will mostly face ICBM threats from Russia, China, and North Korea, probably from Iran, and possibly from Iraq," American intelligence experts said in a report last month.
Critics of the Clinton Administration, however, say politics was the driving force behind the proposal. They charge that Mr. Clinton is trying to insure that Vice President Al Gore could not be accused of being soft on defense in the coming presidential race by rushing ahead with plans for an antimissile system that may not be effective. "The proposed defense is fundamentally very fragile," said Theodore A. Postol, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "It seems to be a case of subordinating national security to domestic politics."
With strong support for an antimissile defense in the Republican-dominated Congress, financing is not a problem. The hard part is persuading Russia and China that they should cooperate with the American antimissile plan and not respond by expanding their nuclear arsenals.
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott has held a series of high-level meetings with the Russians, including a session this week in Helsinki with Grigory Mamedov, a senior official at the Russian Foreign Ministry.
By outlining their plans, the Americans are seeking to reassure the Russians that the proposed missile defense is not aimed at them.
According to Russian and American officials familiar with the talks, the first phase of the American antimissile system is to be completed by 2005. It involves building a powerful new battle-management radar in Alaska and deploying up to 100 antimissile interceptors there. American early warning radars in Greenland and Britain and on the east and west coasts of the United States would also be upgraded.
American officials assert that the system would be able to stop a limited attack involving relatively unsophisticated missiles.
The second phase is to be completed by 2010, and could involve construction of a similar radar at Grand Forks, N.D., and deployment of 100 interceptors there.
This level of defense, American officials maintain, would enable the United States to protect itself against a limited missile attack that involved several tens of missiles with more sophisticated warheads and decoys.
But the defense could easily be swamped by Russia's vast arsenal, thus preserving strategic equilibrium between Washington and Moscow, American officials say.
In addition to outlining the proposed missile defense, Washington has sought to reassure the Russians by offering cooperation in several areas.
An offer to help the cash-strapped Russians complete a large radar at Mishelevka, 60 miles northwest of Irkutsk, is included, which could cost millions of dollars. Oriented to the southeast, the radar covers North Korea, among other Asian nations.
Washington has also suggested that it might upgrade a Russian-controlled radar at Lyaki in Azerbaijan. Oriented toward the south, the radar covers Iran and other Middle Eastern nations. Under the American plan, the Lyaki station might be jointly manned with the Russians. But the proposal has yet to be negotiated with the Government of Azerbaijan, and key details about American access to Russian radar data have not been worked out.
Other proposals include Russian visits to American early warning radar stations and, perhaps, access to their data, including that from the new radar to be built in Alaska. American officials have also proposed joint computer simulations of antimissile systems and collaboration in deploying satellite systems.
So far, the Russians have said that weakening the ABM treaty is too high a price to pay. "We are open to cooperation," said Mr. Berdennikof, the Russian arms control specialist. "But if our cooperation means changing the ABM treaty our answer is 'thanks but no thanks.' "
Russian officials insist that the United States has exaggerated North Korea's capacity to develop long-range missiles while minimizing the forms of political and military leverage Washington has over the North.
But Russia's major concern is the effect of the American plan on its nuclear arsenal. Russian officials fear that the costly new radars and command control system the United States might erect in the next century will become the building blocks for a more comprehensive antimissile defense.
Since Russia is too poor to engage in that kind of arms race, the only way it could maintain a strategic balance with the United States would be to cast aside the agreements it negotiated with Washington in the past and build up its arsenal.
One relatively cheap countermeasure would be deployment of land-based missiles with multiple warheads -- either old SS-18 missiles or new Topol-M missiles -- a move that would undo one of the main achievements of arms control.
Russian officials also say they have already begun to consult with China about possible political and military cooperation in the event that the United States withdraws from the ABM treaty.
American intelligence experts say that China will have "tens of missiles" that can reach the United States by 2015, a threat especially vulnerable to American advances in antimissile defenses.
A senior American official dismissed many of the Russian objections to renegotiating the ABM treaty as public posturing intended to weaken Western support for missile defenses and said that it differed from what he called the businesslike tone of private meetings. Still, there seems little doubt that the dispute over an antimissile system will escalate sharply in coming months.
The Clinton Administration says it will not make a formal decision on whether to proceed with its anti-missile program before next summer, although it is widely presumed that Washington will go ahead.
The timing is determined by intelligence estimates and budgetary procedures in the United States. But it means that the decision is likely to fall on the eve of the Russian presidential election, insuring that the issue gets added to the growing litany of bitter American-Russian disputes.
