HEADLINE: Hurricane Reveals Flaws in Farm Law as Animal Waste Threatens N. Carolina Water

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: KENANSVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
In the aftermath of Hurricane Floyd, loose regulations that helped eastern North Carolina become the nation's biggest producer of turkeys and the second biggest of hogs have come back to haunt the state's public health and its environment.
Officials say that the September storm that hit the region harder than anywhere else, killing 48 people and leaving behind more than $1 billion in largely inescapable damage, also left a vast amount of damage that might have been averted: incalculable and continuing hazards in ground water, wells and rivers from animal waste, mostly from giant hog farms. 
 For years, farmers had been free to build hog and poultry operations as big as they wanted and wherever they liked. They were allowed to dig huge pits for animal waste, without regard to the water table or the health and sensibilities of neighbors.
In the hurricane, feces and urine soaked the terrain and flowed into rivers from the overburdened waste pits the industry calls lagoons. The storm killed more than two million turkeys, chickens and livestock in the region, and waste from the farms is expected to keep leaching into the water supply until next spring.
"We do have a practical problem here," Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. said. Normally by mid-October, Mr. Hunt said, farmers would have reduced the levels of waste in the lagoons, where it evolves naturally into nutrients that are sprayed on crops.
But the lagoons are brimming with flood-bloated waste, and there is less use for it now. The growth of crops slows in the fall, and many fields have been saturated or rendered fallow by the storm.
 On Thursday the State Department of Environment and Natural Resources announced an "emergency waste management strategy" for hog and poultry farms in an effort to keep waste out of the water supply. The agency is allowing farmers to spread waste to more fields, but it prohibited reconstruction of severely hurricane-damaged waste lagoons in the flood plain.
 In the current soaked condition of the land, some waste sprayed on the fields will spread. "We recognize this policy could contribute to water quality problems through the winter," said Bill Holman, the state's assistant secretary for environmental protection. "There are so many swine operations we have a long way to go."
In Duplin County, of which Kenansville is the seat, and across the rest of North Carolina east of Interstate 95, Hurricane Floyd has exposed the hazards of one of farming's great innovations of the 1980's and 1990's and the political liaisons that helped it develop. That is the practice of industrial farming, or raising livestock and poultry in close and confined quarters.
It allows farmers to raise thousands of hogs on land where they could once raise only scores and gives them tight and automated control over their livestocks' diets, health and growth. The farmers raise pigs under contract to major hog processors, known in the business as "integrators," like Murphy Family Farms of Duplin County. The processor supervises the construction of barns, supplies the pigs and their feed and medicine and hauls them off to slaughter after the four or five months it takes for them to grow to 250 pounds.
In eastern North Carolina, this assembly-line production of hogs and turkeys has come as a savior for tobacco farmers whose incomes plunged with the decline in smoking. But Hurricane Floyd has stirred controversy over a means of capturing the wastes of a hog, which produces four times that of a human.
Human waste in North Carolina and most of the nation must be captured in public sewers and private septic systems to prevent the spread of disease. But the state lets the waste of hogs, which carry many human diseases, be captured by nothing more than a cesspool. The poultry waste is far less a problem.
The state had few rules for industrial farming until 1993, when it enacted a law to prohibit livestock farms from intentionally contaminating the public water supply. Then, two years ago, it put a moratorium on hog farms.
In Duplin County, 50 miles south of Raleigh and the home to 42,000 people and 2.2 million hogs, Dr. Hervy Kornegay, a family physician and chairman of the County Board of Health, said no disease attributable to the flooding had developed. But as waste seeps into the private wells that half the homes use for drinking water, Dr. Kornegay said, "the greatest potential for harm would be severe gastroenteritis, with diarrhea and vomiting."
Even before the hurricane there had been flooding and ruptures of the waste pits that contaminated rivers and killed millions of fish. And with public fury rising over the acrid, ammonia-laden odors from the waste lagoons, which carry for more than a mile, Governor Hunt had begun to call for restraints on an industry he had long allowed free rein.
Mr. Hunt, a Democrat, backs the Legislature's 1997 moratorium on construction of new and expanded lagoons, which remains in effect until July 2001. In April, the Governor proposed a plan to phase out the lagoon system over 10 years while engineers devise safer methods for disposing of the hog waste. He also brought a former Sierra Club lobbyist, Mr. Holman, the environmental protection official, into his administration.
"My views and most views have evolved to where we have to take stronger action to clear up our water and rivers," Governor Hunt said. "We need a strong economy for our people, but we cannot sacrifice the environment for jobs."
The industry, whose North Carolina Pork Council vies with tobacco as the state's mightiest lobby, contends that the lagoon system held up well in the storm, that the bacteria in wells might have come not from hogs but from people, factories, flooded water treatment plants or migrating geese. The council said that only 3 of some 4,000 waste lagoons ruptured.
To protect the system, the council sent the state's Congressional delegation in Washington a document, dated Sept. 29 and entitled, "Draft Legislation for Flood Relief for Farmers in Eastern North Carolina." It seeks $1 billion in grants for farmers in 41 counties to repair or replace storm-damaged facilities, including waste lagoons, as they were originally built.
Governor Hunt said of the document, "It's 'stunning and it's wrong."
Beth Anne Mumford, the council's spokeswoman, said the document, disclosed on Oct. 8 by The News and Observer of Raleigh, had been misunderstood. "Its intent was to be sure assistance wasn't prohibited," Ms. Mumford said. "We're not illegal operations, so we shouldn't be punished."
Nowhere is the industry more entrenched, or its political power stronger, or the hurricane's farm damage greater, than in Duplin County. With 48 hogs for every resident, the county has the densest concentration of hogs in the country.
The rectangular lagoons of reddish-brown waste, many of them covering more than an acre, dot the flat countryside. Enclosed within dikes, the lagoons sit behind rows of single-story, gray-metal structures as large as football fields that house the hogs. The hog waste flows through slotted boards in the barns to a cellar, and then is carried by plastic pipes to a waste lagoon. The lagoons now and then burp with the bubbles that mark the natural transformation of feces and urine to the nutrients that farmers spray over pastures and fields of corn, tobacco, soybeans and rye.
In the hurricane, said Rick Shiver, regional supervisor for the State Division of Water Quality, many of the lagoons flooded, and the three that ruptured were in Duplin County.
Two of the ruptured lagoons were on farms under contract to Murphy Family Farms of Rose Hill, on the southern edge of the county.
Wendell Murphy, the company's founder and chief executive and a major contributor to Governor Hunt's campaigns, perfected the current system of raising hogs for producers. It is the major reason the state's hog population has grown to more than nine million from less than three million a decade ago.
Mr. Murphy was a State Senator for 10 years, until 1992, and as a legislator supported measures curbing counties' power to zone out hog farms. Mr. Murphy would not comment for this article, said his spokeswoman, Lois Britt.
Ms. Britt said the company thought that counties should look within for solutions to the environmental issues. "It's easy to look from outside and say what's wrong," she said. She said hog farming provided jobs and tax revenue.
"The hog lagoons," she added, "held up fine."
Clearly, many farmers have mastered the intricate balance of waste production, lagoon levels and spraying. The Division of Water Quality said that it had never recorded a complaint against the hog farm of Tony Jones, 30, of Mount Olive.
Like nearly all hog farmers, Mr. Jones works under contract to a producer. He raises 4,100 pigs in six barns and has two waste lagoons.
He said he constantly tested the lagoon waste. "If it needs lime to keep the odor down," he said, "I add lime. If it needs pumping, I pump on days that are optimum for pumping."
But other farms stir frequent complaints. Becky and Danny Lancaster, who operate a rural welding supply business, live within a mile of three farms they call offensive. Mrs. Lancaster, the mother of two teen-agers, said: "You don't plan birthday parties outside. You no longer plan things. You plan around the odors and flies."
She keeps a log of odors that waft her way. In September, she made entries on six days. "Nasty, musty, stifling odor in the air," she wrote on Sept. 9, a humid and rainy day. "Difficult to breathe. Feel like suffocating. Like an old outhouse." On Sept. 23, she wrote, "Smell of urine strong in air."
For years, said H. C. Powers, a 77-year-old retired school principal and current chairman of the six-member Duplin County Board of Commissioners, residents have been complaining of odors and flies. But three board members always support the industry, so efforts by Mr. Powers and two others to regulate the farms die in 3-to-3 votes.
Still, many people here say more pollution control would only imperil more farmers, who are already struggling. Pork prices have been plunging for more than a year, so much so that Mr. Murphy has agreed to sell out, for $450 million, to Smithfield Farms Inc. of Virginia, the nation's leading slaughterhouse.
The County Manager, James W. Barnhardt Jr., said farms in the county that had $620 million in revenue two years ago were expected to receive $170 million less this year. "We are trying to diversify," Mr. Barnhardt said. "On the other hand, Duplin County is a rural agricultural county. That's what we do."

HEADLINE: Protest on Canvas

BYLINE: By John Beardsley; John Beardsley, the author of "Gardens of Revelation: Environments by Visionary Artists," teaches at the Harvard Graduate School of Design.

 BODY:

ROBERT GWATHMEY
 The Life and Art of a Passionate Observer.
 By Michael Kammen.
 Illustrated. 240 pp. Chapel Hill:
 University of North Carolina Press.
 Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $24.95. 
 What are we to make of Robert Gwathmey, the artist and the man? The man who emerges from Michael Kammen's gracious biography is deeply engaging and admirable. He had his faults, from which Kammen doesn't shrink. But he is remembered as the first white artist to paint Southern blacks in a dignified and empathetic way even as he waged a life-long crusade against racial bigotry, social pretension and economic exploitation of the working poor. Against a life of such conviction, how are we to take the measure of his art?
A Virginian by birth who moved to New York to paint, Gwathmey found his artistic footing in the late 1930's with representations of rural life in the South -- even then receding into memory as blacks migrated to the North. His satires of Southern demagogues and idle aristocrats and his compassionate portrayals of black sharecroppers and laborers won him a devoted following in Northern progressive circles; they also won him the enmity of many of his Southern white compatriots and eventually the Government. Gwathmey was kept under surveillance by the F.B.I. for 27 years beginning in 1942, initially for such subversive activities as giving speeches at the Artists' Club in New York on "the rights of the Negroes," later for membership in various left-wing humanitarian, labor and civil liberties organizations. Although no longer deemed a security risk after 1969, he remained politically active. In the early 70's, he was the defendant in a First Amendment case that resulted in a Supreme Court decision overturning a New York State law banning defacement of the American flag.
Although Gwathmey enjoyed the support and friendship of artists like Paul Robeson and Jacob Lawrence, he came under fire from black civil rights leaders in the 70's. Kammen tells the story of a mural Gwathmey painted in 1939-41 for the Post Office in Eutaw, Ala. Depicting blacks and whites hoeing corn, picking cotton and stacking lumber, it was installed over the objections of local white officials who would have preferred something commemorating the Confederacy. Years later, it was denounced by a black judge and a leader in the local chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference as "dehumanizing" and "offensive" to African-Americans, although its focus was class as much as race: it shows blacks and whites laboring equally at the bottom of the socioeconomic ladder. A subsequent report on the mural, commissioned by the Postal Service from the Birmingham Museum of Art, recommended that the mural not be removed; ironically, the report identified the artist as "a black" from Richmond.
Kammen, a social historian, is most effective at positioning Gwathmey in his cultural frame: among Southern writers like James Agee, Erskine Caldwell and Lillian Smith, who were equally critical of their home turf; fellow Social Realists like Philip Evergood and Jack Levine; and the documentary photographers Walker Evans and Margaret Bourke-White. He establishes artistic connections between Gwathmey and the French realists Jean-Francois Millet and Honore Daumier. But Gwathmey's crucial inspirations were closer at hand. One of the pleasant surprises of the book is its brief glimpse into the work of his wife, Rosalie, who made a series of documentary photographs in the 40's of African-American communities in North Carolina, where the Gwathmeys spent their summers, that resemble his work in subject matter and composition. She too felt the chill of McCarthyism: active in the Photo League, a New York organization dedicated to photography that would reveal social conditions and promote political change, she abandoned her art in 1951 when the league disbanded under pressure from the F.B.I.
Kammen is less persuasive in evaluating Gwathmey's art, preferring, for example, to speak of the paintings of the 40's and early 50's as his "best-known" rather than simply his best art, which they assuredly are. In Gwathmey's most successful paintings -- among them "Tobacco" (1947) and "Saturday Afternoon" (1949) -- composition and narrative content are mutually reinforcing. Architectural settings dramatically compress the space, while patterns in clothing and advertising signs vigorously animate the surface. Despite Kammen's evenhanded treatment of the later work, it gets less interesting in structure and content as it becomes more formulaic and anecdotal. In fairness to Gwathmey, surveillance has a repressive effect; Kammen also shows he was disheartened by the waning audience for his socially engaged realism as critics, museums and the public embraced Abstract Expressionism as the reigning national style.
Gwathmey's relationship to Lawrence is instructive. They were friends from the late 40's, and Gwathmey persuaded Lawrence in 1962 to be represented by his dealer, Terry Dintenfass. Kammen says Gwathmey enjoyed being called the "white Jacob Lawrence," and there are similarities in their work: flat areas of color and shallow picture space that recall idioms of folk painting. But there are illuminating differences, too. Lawrence had an epic ambition that led to extended suites of paintings such the 60-panel series "The Migration of the Negro." The same level of ambition isn't in evidence in Gwathmey. If he wasn't quite "sui generis among the artists of his time," as Kammen claims, "a man with a singular vision combining content and style whose compositions compel immediate recognition because of their originality and freshness," neither was his talent inconsiderable. His work warrants critical reappraisal.
In the catalogue of a 1946 exhibition of Gwathmey's work in New York, Paul Robeson wrote, "In the coming years, when as we all hope, true equality and the brotherhood of man will be a reality, Gwathmey's paintings will have earned him the right to feel that he has shared in the shaping of a better world." The impact of art on social transformations is difficult to measure: the very notion might be one of the soothing fictions of a less cynical era. It isn't even clear that Gwathmey felt he was persuading anyone: Kammen notes that he frequently insisted he was an "observer," not a "moralist." Yet he saw what his times demanded and painted his convictions, creating an exemplary life and art worth remembering. For that alone we can say Gwathmey shared in the shaping of a better world.

HEADLINE: Bowling With Others

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe is director of the Center for Religion and American Public Life at Boston College.

 BODY:

THE LADD REPORT
 By Everett Carll Ladd.
 210 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $25. 
 WHEN the political scientist Robert Putnam discovered that Americans no longer joined civic associations the way they once did, he no doubt thought he had produced an interesting finding. Instead, the reaction to his 1995 essay, "Bowling Alone," generally considered the most widely discussed social science journal article of our time, was quasi-religious in nature, as if a nation of egoists, unlike a nation of joiners, was unworthy of God's special dispensation.
Everett Carll Ladd, director of the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, was an early and persistent skeptic. In "The Ladd Report," he assembles all the data he can find to demonstrate exactly how wrong Putnam was.
Some civic and fraternal organizations, like the Lions Clubs or Shriners, have lost members over the past few decades, Ladd writes, but this is only natural; we hardly think it a crisis if the Anti-Saloon League, which once engaged the attention of millions, is no longer able to display long membership lists. But others have expanded rapidly, especially environmental organizations, church groups and, to compensate for any declining interest in bowling, soccer leagues. Nor is it correct to say that the groups that are growing, in contrast to those in decline, are mailing-list organizations that demand little of their members. Actually, Ladd points out, unions, the virtual disappearance of which pushes the panic buttons of those concerned with America's civic health, actively discouraged popular participation, while groups like the Audubon Society have local chapters and encourage local involvement.
Illustrative of Ladd's approach is the question of "schooling alone." The National Congress of Parents and Teachers has reported a sharp drop in P.T.A. memberships, causing great consternation among the civic-minded. But many parents became persuaded that P.T.A.'s represented the interests of teachers, not themselves. All across the country, parents have been dropping out and forming independent parent-teacher organizations, convinced that their dues ought to support local activities, not a top-heavy national organization. Ladd estimates that only one-quarter of American schools are P.T.A.-affiliated these days. Ask teachers and they would probably tell you that parents are, if anything, too involved.
Finally, according to Ladd, the "third sector" -- an insider's term for volunteering and charity -- is not in any state of crisis. Surveys reveal that the number of Americans who say they give their time to voluntary activities has gone up, not down. Charitable donations have also increased. Younger people volunteer less and give less than their elders do, but that has always been true and merely represents a stage in the life cycle, not any kind of permanent shift in values.
Robert Putnam believes that America's "social capital" -- those intangibles of trust and participation that make society work -- is in serious danger of depletion. His thesis, Ladd writes, served the interests of both liberals and conservatives. Liberals could argue that in the absence of strong social ties, government intervention was necessary; while to conservatives, declining social capital underscored the need to emphasize communal and voluntary alternatives to the state. If, as Ladd claims, the empirical evidence cannot sustain the notion that something is wrong in civic America, then we can stop engaging in "insipid nostalgia" and adopt concepts of citizenship obligations in line with historic patterns of American individualism.
Ladd's book is a welcome corrective to any hysteria about the state of civic America left over from the publication of "Bowling Alone." Surely by now we ought to recognize that social capital is not like rain, something we can measure one day to see how it compares to another. The most interesting changes in civic life are qualitative, not quantitative. We want to know how Americans practice the arts of association, not whether they do so in the same way their grandparents did.
Yet while Ladd offers an effective rebuttal to the nostalgia buffs, his insistence that everything is fine is little different from the argument that everything is worse. For if the prophets of social decline can rightly be faulted for spinning the data one way, Ladd all too often spins it the other way. Take trust in government. One of the strongest bits of data confirming Putnam's alarmism is the sharp decline in public trust in government since the 1970's. Can a democracy be considered healthy if ever-increasing numbers of its citizens do not vote and tell pollsters that they have little if any confidence in their leaders? When Ladd considers this question, he seems more concerned with demolishing Putnam's claims than with establishing what is true. Yes, in the 1970's Americans lost confidence in their leaders, he argues, but who wouldn't in the midst of rapid inflation, petroleum shortages and hostage takings? If they dislike government, moreover, Americans have great faith in their society -- and in one another. True, voting turnout for President declined from 62.8 percent in 1960 to 49 percent in 1996, but many absentee voters are never counted and there are a lot more felons who are ineligible to vote. We are simply a people that has always been skeptical of government, Ladd concludes, seeming to forget that Americans also gave their support to the New Deal and to the military establishment.
Had he written a more balanced book, Ladd would have written a more persuasive book. Perhaps his insensitivity to very real declines in public trust of politics led him to underemphasize the importance of trust in social science findings. For if the reader comes to suspect his interpretations where they seem forced, doubt is inevitably cast on his data even when they seem strong. Most, but not all of it, supports Ladd's point of view, which means that he need not have feared that in giving in to any of Putnam's claims he would be giving in to all of them.
Like any good work of social science, Robert Putnam's data and interpretations will be challenged by others. "The Ladd Report" makes it clear that Putnam's thesis requires substantial modification at the very least. But "Bowling Alone" could never have generated the passionate responses it did had it not spoken to something in the atmosphere. Social science can answer many questions, but it cannot peer into the nation's soul. Whether America's social capital has declined, increased or merely changed its form is a debate that ought to continue, and, despite the publication of "The Ladd Report," one senses that it will.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction;
Perils of the Poppy

BYLINE: By Carolyn T. Hughes 

 BODY:
"Farewell to smiles and laughter, farewell to peace of mind! Farewell to hope and to tranquil dreams, and the blessed consolations of sleep!" So Thomas De Quincey wrote in "Confessions of an English Opium-Eater" in 1822. He was among the first of many writers, artists and musicians who found themselves addicted to opium. In OPIUM: A Portrait of the Heavenly Demon (Chronicle, $22.95), Barbara Hodgson chronicles the effects the narcotic had, both positive and negative, on many of the artistic lights of the 19th century. She also analyzes the drug's effect on the general population of China, India, Britain, France and the United States. In fact, the economies of both Britain and France were so dependent on the opium trade that when China tried to stop it, the European powers made war in 1839 and again in 1856. Hodgson, the author and designer of two illustrated novels, "The Sensualist" and "The Tattooed Map," intersperses photographs and woodcuts of addicts in opium dens throughout the book. She also includes movie stills and reproductions of the covers from magazines and books to highlight the strange fascination opium has exerted on our culture. Of special note is the cover of a 1958 edition of Claude Farr<heart>re's 1904 novel "Black Opium"; it features a naked, voluptuous blonde rising out of the smoke of an opium pipe. The image is both absurd and sad, for opium use decreases the sex drive. But then again, as Hodgson notes in her insightful book, the pull of the drug is anything but logical. Carolyn T. Hughes

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Time Off to Dive Into Reality Rather Than Retreat From It

BYLINE: By ANN WILSON LLOYD; Ann Wilson Lloyd's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the painter Layla Ali.

 BODY:
IN a late 20th-century version of J. M. W. Turner's search for the untrammeled landscape, a small band of contemporary artists is spending this month trekking in the Himalayas, seeking fresh vision as well as fresh scenery.
In Salvador, Brazil, artists are working with street children to bring them back into society. In Kansas City, Mo., artists have set up shop in a converted downtown garage, while in San Antonio, a former automobile showroom functions as a high-tech studio. 
 All are new versions of the artist residency program in which, traditionally, artists retreat for sabbaticals in bucolic, cloistered settings like Yaddo or the MacDowell Colony. Now artists may convene in gritty urban environments, participate in group living experiments or join far-flung adventures resembling Outward Bound.
The Himalayan trek, for example, initiated by the Kiasma Museum of Contemporary Art in Helsinki, Finland, is theoretically about perception and how new experience retools its formation, according to Maaretta Jaukkuri, the museum's chief curator. Artists may work while walking, or during a monthlong residency at the museum next spring. An exhibition will be held in the summer of 2000.
Liisa Roberts, a trekker and New York-based artist who is half Finnish, said before leaving that combining nature, art and expeditions is not so strange in Finland. Jussi Heikkila, a Finnish artist who has previously used mountain hiking in his work, came up with the idea. Ms. Roberts was excited but a little nervous. "I am not much of an outdoor person," she said.
Xu Bing, a Chinese artist living in New York and another trekker, may be more prepared, at least ideologically. The trip echoes his student days in China during the cultural revolution, when he was sent to live with farmers. Long conditioning marches were also prescribed. "This project is an avant-garde idea in Western contemporary art," he said, "but it's something they were doing 20 years ago in China. The project addresses a lot of problems in contemporary art, where things are missing between the artist and the audience. A more social-minded approach is needed."
Perhaps a response to withdrawal of funds by the National Endowment for the Arts, these new-style artists' residencies are cropping up everywhere, said Tricia Snell, executive director of the Alliance of Artist Communities. The alliance, which started in 1990, has a membership of 60 nonprofit programs, but there are close to 80 in the field at large. "Twelve have recently opened, 11 more are in planning stages, 40 or 50 people have contacted us about startups," Ms. Snell said. "Here is a grassroots movement much as there was in the 1960's.
ArtPace, the new program in San Antonio, is where Ms. Roberts was contacted to discuss the Himalayan trek. ArtPace was founded in 1993 by Linda Pace, a San Antonio artist, benefactor and collector, whose father developed Pace Picante Sauce. ArtPace residencies, awarded by nomination, are considered the cream. A local-global mix of residents is chosen by a panel of international art professionals or a curator. This year, Okwui Enwezor, director of the next Documenta, tapped Ms. Roberts, Chris Sauter from Texas and Oladl Ajiboy Bamgboy from London. Artists live and work for two months in a sleek new facility carved from a vintage car showroom, are given private apartment and studio space, technical support and facilities, a $500 weekly stipend and an $8,000 budget for supplies. Exhibitions cap the residency.
ArtPace prides itself on underwriting costly new works. "The demise of N.E.A. grants to individual artists and the aftermath of the early 90's economy diminished opportunities for artists to make significant, expensive works," says Ms. Pace. It was here that in 1997 Cornelia Parker, a British artist, made "Mass (Colder Darker Matter)," an installation of charred remains from a burned Texas church that was later exhibited in the Turner Prize show at the Tate Gallery in London. Consequently, San Antonio has become a preview site for the art world, staff members claim.
In a collaborative first, Isaac Julien, a British filmmaker, is splitting his residency this fall between ArtPace and a somewhat similar program, Grand Arts, in Kansas City. It, too, is financed by a private foundation established by Margaret Hall Silva, a member of the Hall family of Hallmark Cards. Ms. Silva is also an artist, though like Ms. Pace, she has found her program eclipsing personal artmaking. Grand Arts is in a former garage in downtown Kansas City that has also undergone an upscale architectural makeover, setting it apart from nearby pawn shops and parking lots.
Grand Arts is slightly smaller in scope and more fluid than ArtPace. "We have no program the artist has to plug into, Ms. Silva said. "Each residency is individual." The stipend and budget are customized. Recently Jim Leedy, a local atist, used Grand Arts state-of-the-art sculpture studio to prepare a large installation. Meanwhile, the staff was also mapping logistics for Mr. Julien's film project and a project with the New York artist Dennis Oppenheimer.
Grand Arts residents come from solicited applications, with final selection made by a revolving panel of national arts professionals. The center offers, in addition to the sculpture studio, an elegant on-site apartment and two galleries. As at ArtPace, Grand Arts' staff says art-world traffic has enlivened the scene in Kansas City.
Evolving from sources exactly opposite from Grand Arts and ArtPace, the new Tryon Center for Visual Art, in Charlotte, N.C., may be the first residency program to be generated by civic leaders rather than art professionals. Opening its doors last month with six artists ranging from local to international, the Tryon Center has a $7 million endowment given by the Bank of America, which has its headquarters in Charlotte. Tryon Center was initiated by Hugh McColl, the C.E.O. of Bank of America who has been behind much of the rebirth of downtown Charlotte. But the new arts center is not necessarily an urban renewal project, says Barbara Spradling, chairman of the Tryon board and a Bank of America senior vice president. "Culture and visual arts are what make cities great," she said. "We would like more artists to live here, to help build audience and collectors, and to fill a gap in Charlotte."
Tryon Center also filled a gap in the urban landscape -- a burned-out shell of a neo-Gothic church just blocks from the bank's downtown corporate tower. The spectacular renovation created 15 spacious studios (almost too handsome for messy art making), lavishly equipped workshops and high-tech labs for everything from digital media to printmaking. Such grand scale corporate largesse stems partly from the fact that Mr. McColl's mother was a painter. "I like art and want to support artists," he explained. "I thought of painters living on the south side of the rebuilt church and painting in north-facing studios, so it's not exactly as I envisioned it. But my philosophy is to do something and then be happy with it. And part of the deal is that artists will give back in some way."
Tryon's residents are chosen half by nomination and half by the staff. Residencies are for three months and artists receive housing, studios, up to $2,500 for materials plus a monthly stipend of $1,500 to $4,000. In return, community involvement is strongly encouraged.
By contrast, everyday life is the leitmotif of the Quiet in the Land, a series of ad hoc residency projects created by France Morin, an independent curator. The first, in 1996 at the Sabbathday Lake, Me., Shaker colony, included 10 artists she personally selected. Now Ms. Morin is in Salvador, Brazil, overseeing the last of 16 staggered residencies in her second project.
In Salvador, completely removed from the typical pampered residency and from the art world, artistswork with Projeto Axe, a philanthropic organization that uses the arts to seduce street children back into society. "By sharing powerful histories, first the Shakers and now children of Axe help artists re-examine relationships of life and work to the world beyond the narrow confines of the art world," Ms. Morin says. "I cannot say all the artists have had the same level of experience, but most of them are leaving troubled and rethinking these relationships."
NARI WARD, who has participated in both Ms. Morin's projects, found Brazil incredibly challenging. "I think artists came on board thinking they were tired of the old model residency, to flex themselves a little more," he said. "The Shaker project was a personal introspection. Brazil is much more a social project, but both had the same premise -- to take everyday situations and regard them the way you would art in a museum or gallery. It has intensified my desire to work more with communities."
Not everyone was completely comfortable with the Salvadoran experience. Kara Walker, who worked with teen-age girls, cited frustrations with language barriers as well as living close together in one house with other participants. She recalls vigorous discussions about why they were there; whether they were artists or missionaries. "I wasn't really sure what we were working toward," she said, "but there were moments when something a little bit magical would happen."
The art generated from her collaboration with the young women had a little bit of a high school feel to it, Ms. Walker said (which may be one reason Ms. Morin and the artists decided not to show the project's exhibition outside of Salvador as originally planned). Ms. Walker, who spent four weeks in Salvador, added, "It affected my real life more than my working life; it made me question all that I do."
These projects stem from Ms. Morin's general dissatisfaction with the gallery and museum circuit (she was formerly the head curator at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York) and her desire to work in more intuitive and personal ways. Two more phases, one at the Parrish Museum on Long Island and another long-term project in Southeast Asia, for which the artist Chen Zhen is teaching himself to become a Chinese doctor, are planned.
Regardless of their quixotic nature, Ms. Morin is passionate about their necessity. "I know these projects are like throwing pebbles in the water," she said. "But they have an amazing capacity to ripple outward."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 2; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 978 words

HEADLINE: The View From/White Plains;
Head of Arts Council Mixes Art and Money on Her Palette

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IN the nine years since she has been executive director of the Westchester Arts Council, Janet T. Langsam has become known as someone not averse to mixing art and business. Now she is bringing that blend of money savvy and interest in esthetics to the forefront in the annual gala entitled, appropriately, "Monopoly."
The party is being held Nov. 13 at 360 Hamilton Avenue in a building recently renovated by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Tarrytown. The 380,000-square-foot, 12-story structure, Ms. Langsam says, is emblematic of the monopoly-like renaissance of buying and selling in downtown White Plains. Empty since 1988, it is being readied by Reckson for December occupancy by a variety of tenants in financial, technological and other fields. Its granite, marble and glass exterior and opulent cherrywood lobby will be a perfect setting, she said, for a benefit that focuses on the interplay of the corporate and arts worlds. 
 "It is not only a local, but a national, trend to use the arts to leverage the revitalization of downtown areas of cities," Ms. Langsam said.
Salvatore Campofranco, managing director of Reckson, added: "The arts attract people, and that's an economic as well as a cultural issue. Historically, cities tend to go from being manufacturing centers to business centers to residential areas. People who live or work in a city want theater, music, museums. Then new smaller businesses -- restaurants, antique shops -- sprout up."
As for 360 Hamilton Avenue, he explained that Reckson bought it in 1996 "just before the White Plains market had started to recover." When it opens, he said, it will "be occupied by Class A tenants." He added that the corporate downsizing trend of the early and mid-90's has been reversed and that most corporations are in a "growth mode." White Plains, with its central location, relative proximity to Manhattan and upscale shops in The Westchester, has a growing profile, he said. Major developers have bought buildings in the downtown area; when that happens, small businesses -- the mom and pop delis, candy stores, jewelry shops that have floundered in recent years -- should be able to stage a comeback.
The party itself will reflect the Monopoly theme. Ms. Langsam expects 700 "of the council's closest friends." (Tickets are $350 a person. The number to call for reservations is 428-4220.) The guests will sit at tables covered with cloths imprinted with Monopoly boards, and they will dine on hors d'oeuvres donated by Abigail Kirsch, appetizers contributed by Crowne Plaza and filet mignon given by Doral Arrowwood. Desserts, which will also be donated, will probably be pastries or servings of ice cream shaped like skyscrapers. On a recent afternoon, Ms. Langsam made a telephone call to Ann Tucker, whose event management company of the same name is planning the gala. "Ann," she said into the phone, "what do you have as dessert -- let's see, can we do buildings, what do you think?"
This wheeling and dealing style even in matters as simple as dessert is typical of Ms. Langsam. She has a New York City background -- she was the city's Deputy Commissioner of Cultural Affairs from 1976 through 1980 -- and she considers herself a pragmatist. As much as she loves the arts, she knows that artists themselves are not always so adroit at making and managing the money they need in order to thrive, work and show or produce the results of their work. She is more than happy to go to bat for them, in an official or unofficial capacity.
"There's a lot of schmoozing, a lot of networking, that goes on at our annual benefit," she said. "It has always been that way."
In fact, the biggest deal of the council's existence was consummated at last year's big party, a 700-person affair at the County Center. It was then that several people formalized the negotiations that enabled the council to move in June to its new headquarters at 31 Mamaroneck Avenue here.
"The negotiations for the building were completed over a glass of wine at 11 P.M.," recalled Joseph P. Carlucci, who overheard the conversation. Mr. Carlucci is managing partner in Cuddy & Feder & Worby, a White Plains-based law firm, which is one of the sponsors of this year's gala.
"We got together over some cigars and a good cabernet," Ms. Langsam added. "At the end of the conversation, I looked around and said, 'I think we just made ourselves a deal.' "
The building, which was owned by Chase Manhattan Bank, was built in 1928 in quasi-Colonial style with brass doors and stone scrolls. It is eight stories high and contains 55,000 square feet. It was sold to the council for $1.35 million by the bank. Under the terms of the agreement, the council will not pay interest or principal on the mortgage for five years, while the group seeks financing.
The building needs work, but Ms. Langsam said she hopes eventually to be able to rent studios, workshops and offices to artists and arts-related businesses, as well as set up rehearsal space, exhibition rooms and areas for poetry readings and performances by individual artists and members of the 100 organizations affiliated with the council. Renovation and construction is proceeding with a state grant of $550,000 as well as a $150,000 loan from Chase Manhattan and money raised by the council's capital campaign.
The $500,000 the organization wants to net at the Monopoly gala will go toward other council programs, including education, grants for artists and organizations and publications. Ms. Langsam said that not only will money be raised through ticket sales and an elaborate silent auction but also that good will and connections generated by the event will help the council in the future. "We like to involve as many people as possible in our work," she said. "The full title of our benefit is 'Monopoly . . . Be a Player.' "

HEADLINE: LIPA Accused of Hiding Surcharge for Debt

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
TAKING a new tack in their running feud with the Long Island Power Authority, officials in Suffolk County have accused the agency of secretly collecting a 5.1 percent surcharge from all customers to amass $1.3 billion over 10 years for early retirement of debt on the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant, and of trying to mask the surcharge with new, higher-interest borrowing.
The authority chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said there was no surcharge and challenged officials to prove its existence. He said the authority would retire 30-year bonds reflecting Shoreham debt in approximately 16 years, saving customers over $2 billion in interest payments. 
 County officials said early retirement of the bonds made no economic sense because it substituted higher-interest new debt for lower-interest existing debt and appeared to be designed to benefit bondholders, not electric customers.
The dispute between the county and LIPA has its roots in a New York state court judgment, won in 1996 by the Long Island Lighting Company, that local governments in Suffolk County had substantially overassessed the Shoreham plant. That judgment, which is now worth over $1 billion, was acquired in 1998 by LIPA when it purchased Lilco's transmission and distribution systems. In July, a state appeals court upheld LIPA's right to enforce the judgment.
LIPA has offered to settle the case for $625 million, through higher electric rates already being paid by Suffolk residents, but has set a Monday deadline for the county to accept its offer. That $625 million was also part of Governor Pataki's plan for a partial state takeover of Lilco. The Suffolk Legislature never agreed to the plan and is seeking to appeal the court ruling.
The counsel to the Suffolk legislature, Paul Sabatino, said he believed that the authority's insistence on collecting the $625 million reflected its need to conceal the 5.1 percent surcharge.
"They have to get that dollar amount because that's the money they need to hide the surcharge," Mr. Sabatino said. He said this explained why the authority had been unwilling to settle the tax case for less.
Mr. Kessel said the authority has tried repeatedly to settle with the county, without success.
County officials said the surcharge would be hidden by the new debt LIPA was taking on, in the amount of $320 million. That debt, county officials said, would be repaid by electric customers in Suffolk County, who pay rates 2.3 percent higher than those in Nassau County.
"It's just a debt shift with no apparent economic benefit for ratepayers," said George O. Guldi, a Democrat from Westhampton Beach and chairman of the legislature's energy and environment committee. "And it creates a mechanism for transferring enormous amounts of money from ratepayers to bond holders."
Suffolk officials said bond holders who would benefit from early retirement of the Shoreham debt made possible by the hidden surcharge were those who purchased 30-year tax-exempt bonds that would now be retired in approximately 16 years.
They said the bond holders would be paid premiums for early retirement and would also have earned higher interest rates for 16 years than they would have earned on bonds with 16-year maturity dates.
Mr. Guldi said he has asked the authority for the names of bond holders to determine whether "selected investors are going to get windfall rates of return."
Frederick B. Pollert, director of the county legislature's budget review office, dismissed LIPA public statements that early retirement of Shoreham-related debt was possible because of lower than projected interest rates on the $6.7 billion in bonds the authority has sold to date.
"That is not the case," he said, because interest savings totaled only $78.8 million, or only a fraction of the $1.3 billion the authority was creating with the 5.1 percent surcharge.
"The bottom line is that even before the interest rates were established by the first bond issue, LIPA knew they were going to charge rates in excess of what they would need to meet expenses and would use the excess revenues to repay Shoreham debt in the 16th year."
Mr. Pollert said the plan to retire the bonds early using cash was contrary to the more common method of retiring higher-interest bonds by refinancing with lower-interest bonds and covering refinancing costs with the interest savings.
He said the authority's plan in effect replaced lower-interest, long-term bonds with higher-interest bonds.
The officials said LIPA could have realized huge savings by initially issuing 15-year rather than 30-year bonds.
Mr. Kessel said the officials' analysis was inaccurate. He said the authority agreed upon early retirement of the Shoreham debt only after initial bonds were sold at favorable interest rates.
"We expected interest rates of 7 percent and we got rates as low as 4.9 percent," Mr. Kessel said. He said the lower-than-expected cost of financing allowed the authority to increase average rate cuts from 17 percent to 20 percent and to set aside remaining amounts to retire Shoreham debt early.
"We probably could have lowered rates an extra 5 percent last year, but we instead used a lot of the extra money that we got from the lower interest rates to accelerate the payment of the Shoreham debt," Mr. Kessel said.
"People are getting the benefits of rate reductions right now," he said, "and this means their children and grandchildren will benefit in the future because they won't have to pay for this ridiculous Shoreham debt."
Mr. Kessel said early retirement of plant debt should have pleased critics of the takeover plan who had complained about the large amount of longterm debt it entailed.
"You can't have it both ways," he said.
Mr. Kessel said the authority would postpone plans to issue new debt backed by Suffolk rates until the Shoreham tax assessment issues were resolved.
In an important part of the Pataki plan, LIPA refinanced $4.2 billion in Shoreham plant-related debt at lower interest, accounting for a large share of the average 20 percent rate reductions for Long Island electric customers.
The authority bonds were heavily oversubscribed, meaning there were more interested buyers than available bonds. Mr. Guldi said the strong interest raised questions about whether investors were aware of potential windfalls.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Restoring the Panache to a Bronx Movie Palace

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE Loew's Paradise theater in the Bronx has been closed for five years, but its seedy appearance will not blemish its stature in the sentimental recollections of Bronx natives of all ages. Many of them attended their high school graduation exercises there, or smooched as teen-agers while watching movies under its starry artificial sky.
The sky and its wafting clouds are coming back, but not the movies. 
 Richard P. DeCesare, a longtime real-estate investor and more recently a boxing promoter as well, took one look at the Paradise and its vacant interior a year ago and decided it would be the perfect spot for musical events geared to a Latin American audience, and for midweek boxing and wrestling events.
He has backed this vision with a construction project that will restore much of the theater's baroque interior. It is one of the rare cases in which a concept for a new use for an obsolete movie palace has emerged that is both compatible with the configuration and decor of the original interior space and at the same time is sufficiently promising economically to encourage a high-cost restoration.
"I had been looking for a venue for boxing promotions," said Mr. DeCesare, 51, who has formed a company called Paradise Promotions and was interviewed at his office on McLean Avenue in Yonkers. "In New York City you have Madison Square Garden for large promotions, but there's no longer any medium-sized venue." A boxer himself in his youth, he became a promoter two years ago and now has three fighters in his stable, including the heavyweight Alex Garcia of the Bronx (40 wins, 5 losses, 1 draw).
Mr. DeCesare signed a 10-year lease last April, entranced by the possibilities of a hall that seats 4,000 people in a central location -- on the Grand Concourse just south of 188th Street, near Fordham Road -- and is surrounded by one of the city's great concentrations of Hispanic-Americans.
The reconstruction will restore the grand staircase, ornate fountain, chandeliers and statuary that early patrons may fondly, if vaguely, recall. Fabrics, rugs and paint will all be consistent with the original. Above all, the two smaller movie theaters into which the auditorium had been divided have been demolished and the Paradise will once again offer a single performance space.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the exterior of the building as a landmark two years ago, but the interior was never landmarked, although the hope has long been that a lessee or owner would be found who would consider restoration an asset in its reuse.
"We were thrilled when Mr. DeCesare came on the scene," said Jennifer Raab, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "He's changing the theater into an entertainment palace for the new century."
Mr. DeCesare hired the Yonkers architectural firm of Lawless & Mangione, which specializes in restorations, and Higgins & Quasebarth, a Manhattan preservation consultant, and they have worked closely with the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The exterior will be restored to its original design, with electronic signs on the marquee and the roof of the building. The style of the signage and the facade renovations have been approved by the Landmarks Commission.
Paradise Promotions will offer boxing on Thursday nights, with Joe DeGuardia as the co-promoter, and wrestling on Monday nights, Mr. DeCesare said.
The main focus will be concerts of popular music, on Friday and Saturday nights and Sunday afternoons. The reopening is scheduled for March.
"We'll have the top names in the music business," Mr. DeCesare said. "There are 30 or 40 Latin groups that have the capacity to sell out the house." The average ticket price will be $50.
The restoration is an $8 million undertaking, about half completed, said Mr. DeCesare, who also has an option to buy the building. The Scarsdale firm of Houlihan-Parnes Realtors is arranging financing.
THE Loew's Paradise has run a circuitous route to get to this point. Its guide has been a seven-year-old asset manager and property owner, Emmes & Company, of Manhattan. In the early 90's, when established real-estate companies were buying large pools of nonperforming or poorly performing real-estate assets from the Resolution Trust Corporation, new partnerships were being formed by individuals with real-estate backgrounds to handle smaller pools of assets.
Emmes was one of them. Its current partners are Andrew Davidoff, Gary Tischler, S. Lawrence Davis and Mark Chertok, joined last year by Northstar Capital Investment Corporation of Manhattan. In 1992 an investment group led by Emmes bought from the R.T.C. a package of 78 nonperforming mortgages that had been in the portfolio of the Ensign Savings Bank. One of the mortgages was on the Loew's Paradise, which was owned by a partnership managed by the Kushner Companies, of Florham Park, N.J. Kushner's main tenant was the Sony Corporation affiliate that bought many of the old Loew's theaters in the 80's.
Mr. Davidoff, the managing partner of Emmes, said that his expectation had been that a restructured mortgage would be negotiated with Kushner. But it turned out that Sony was buying out of its lease from Kushner before it expired, prompting Kushner to assign the ownership interest to Emmes.
So Emmes hired a Yonkers-based firm, H. S. C. Management Corporation, headed by Howard S. Cohen, to manage the property, and proceeded to open conversations with the city's governmental and nongovermental organizations involved with preserving notable structures, trying to figure out how to adapt the building to an economic use.
"We could have walked away, and just written off the building as obsolete," Mr. Davidoff said. "But we got a tremendous sense that this building was a part of Bronx history, almost like Yankee Stadium." Studies were made by the architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle, and Emmes thought its best chance was to find a retail user for the interior space, which would have meant sheetrocking over the plaster detailing pending a possible future, and more appropriate, use. The Landmarks Commission seemed reluctantly willing to support this solution if no other was available. Then Mr. DeCesare came along.
The Paradise is not the only Bronx property that Emmes has found itself nursing back to financial and operational stability. It also acquired title to an apartment development off Eastchester Avenue in the Williamsbridge section of the northeast Bronx called Hillside Homes. It has 1,400 apartments in buildings of four to six stories covering five city blocks. They had become part of a syndicator's portfolio in the 80's; the syndicator's loans in turn were part of a larger portfolio of bad debt that Emmes bought.
Vacancies were high and deterioration severe when Emmes took over, Mr. Davidoff said. Four hundred apartments were uninhabitable. But conditions have improved after an expenditure of $4.5 million, and the apartments are now 97 percent rented, he said. The name of the development has been changed to Eastchester Heights.
Bruno Pietrosanti, the partner at Lawless & Mangione who is in charge of the Paradise project, said that the theater's terra-cotta exterior would be restored and bronze doors replicating the originals would be installed. The building has five retail spaces along the Grand Concourse, fewer than the building had when it opened, and these will be rebuilt in a style in keeping with the original, Mr. Pietrosanti said.
Inside, the ornate ceilings and walls are being restored, the new carpet will replicate the design of the original, and concession stands will be built in the traditional design. The boxing and wrestling ring, when needed, will rise from the orchestra pit, and stage seating will accommodate additional ringside customers.
Lloyd Ultan, the Bronx borough historian, said he was ecstatic that the theater was being restored to its old elegance. "It didn't matter to me what use the theater would have as long as it was used as a theater," he said. "Stores would have been a disaster."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: In the Land of Good and Plenty, a Disturbing Trend;
From Greenwich to Norwich, Demand Is Up at Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens

BYLINE: By MAURA CASEY 

 BODY:
TIMES are booming in Connecticut, but not for everyone. Ask Burt Stratton.
Mr. Stratton, who lives in Norwich, worked in construction until several heart attacks permanently disabled him. His disability income is $685 a month, $400 of which goes to rent a one-bedroom apartment. Utilities are extra. Although the state pays for nearly all of the several medications he takes for his heart condition, Mr. Stratton finds it difficult to come up with the $72 a month needed to pay for his prescriptions. To make ends meet, he eats nearly every day at the St. Vincent de Paul Place soup kitchen on Norwich's Main Street. 
 "It helps a lot," he said recently, while eating a lunch of roast beef, potatoes and green beans.
In direct contradiction to the state's low unemployment numbers and growth in personal income, business is on the upswing at places that feed the poor around Connecticut. In New Haven, Bridgeport, New London, even Greenwich, a growing number of residents like Mr. Stratton are using soup kitchens and food pantries.
"There is so much affluence here, it is hard for people to believe hunger exists," said Mary Biggs, director of the food bank of lower Fairfield County. According to an survey by the Connecticut Association for Human Services, 40 percent of emergency food sites in the state saw demand rise this year, not drop. In New Haven, demand rose an average of 22 percent from the year before, and in Bridgeport it climbed 37.5 percent. Just 15 percent of the sites saw a decrease and 45 percent reported no change at all.
The Connecticut Association for Human Services conducted the survey from November to January by mailing questionnaires to the 250 emergency food sites in Connecticut that are affiliated with the state's three major food centers, which gather and distribute food to shelters and pantries around the state. The results are based upon the 128 surveys returned.
The results, experts say, beg a question: If times are so good, why would only 15 percent of emergency food sites see a drop in demand?
"People see a booming economy and they forget that some are being left behind," said Paul Gionfriddo, executive director of the association, who said the survey was the most comprehensive the organization has ever conducted. "Welfare reform was touted as an answer to the needs of the poor. It clearly hasn't done that. The poor don't have enough money to meet their needs. People are using these sites every day."
Others said the increase in demand was evident, but were cautious about assessing the reasons for the increase. Ms. Biggs said that in the most affluent areas of the state, rents are so high that it becomes more difficult for some people to pay for food. "Last year we had even greater demand for food than the year before," she said.
Dr. Amy E. Sampson, who designed the survey and tabulated the results, said that she conducted a second survey of 400 users of food sites to obtain a snapshot of what groups used the services. She said of those who go to the sites, 25 percent are working either full-time or part-time, 20 percent are elderly, 35 percent are children and 40 percent are parents or other adults. More than 60 percent are white. Her survey contradicts what she feels is the prevalent image of who eats in soup kitchens: chronically poor, unemployed single men.
"Pantry use is being utilized by working families," she said. "People think hunger is only found in Hartford, Bridgeport and New Haven. Yet the survey found increased use across the state. It could be the person living next door who isn't making ends meet. Those who use pantries are like all of us," she said.
While soup kitchens typically set no restrictions on who can eat there, pantries sometimes screen applicants and set income limits.
Greenwich, a well-to-do community few would associate with the problem of hunger, saw an increase in demand at its food bank. In fiscal year 1997-98, Greenwich Social Services gave bags of groceries to 82 people or families from the food bank it operates in town hall. Then demand went up For the '98-99 fiscal year just ended, 130 people or families were given food, said Elisabeth Steinberg, director of adult and family services at Greenwich Social Services. She sees the drop in welfare payments as contributing to the problem.
"As the state cut back on welfare payments and made it harder to qualify for welfare, people have scrambled to make do," Ms. Steinberg said. "People went out and got jobs, sometimes two and three, but often they still weren't earning much more than they made under welfare. Since they have to make economies elsewhere, they do turn to food banks."
Lloyd and Lori Schlough of Norwich say that food banks help struggling families make ends meet, even for working families who have never been on welfare. The couple, both high school graduates who own their own home, ran into financial trouble after a painful nerve disease made it impossible for Mrs. Schlough to continue in her job as a head cook for Poquetanuck Elementary School in Preston.
After she took a leave of absence, the couple found it difficult to support themselves and their four daughters on Mr. Schlough's wages of about $12 an hour. He works as a feeder operator for a printing press at Caraustar Inc.'s plant in Sprague. They turned to the food pantry at Norwich Social Services for help.
"Six people can go through quite a bit of food," Mrs. Schlough said. The couple's daughters range in age from 8 to 13. At first, Mrs. Schlough said, it was difficult to ask for help.
"A lot of people are embarrassed to go to a food bank," she said. "It hit me harder because I am the one not working. I thought, "I am such a loser. I can't even feed my kids.' " About once a month the couple gets three bags of groceries from the pantry, which, she said, has been a great help.
Her medical problems make her wish she had been a better financial planner, Mrs. Schlough said, with three months' salary in the bank that her mother always said she should have set aside. "But when you are 28 years old, you don't think of being disabled," she said.
The high cost of living in Connecticut makes it especially difficult for the working poor, said Beverly Goulet, city welfare director in Norwich. She said that a new advocacy group, End Hunger Connecticut, was formed this year with the goal of eradicating hunger as a problem in Connecticut. But that's difficult, especially in a state with a high cost of living, she said.
"Families on minimum wage can't eat, pay high cost of rent and pay for health care all at once," she said. "So often, it's food that is sacrificed." Ms. Goulet said that the difficulties are magnified for those who dropped out of high school, and even those with a high school degree.
"People once could get a job in a factory without a college degree or even a high school degree and raise their families on the salaries," she said. "Those jobs are gone."
Yet it isn't merely that the manufacturing jobs in Connecticut are fewer, but that the jobs themselves have changed, said Fred Carstensen, a professor of economics at the University of Connecticut and director of the Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis.
"Manufacturing itself has become a highly skilled occupation in this state," he said. "If you want to do manufacturing in this state, there is almost nothing you can get right out of high school. It used to be that a non-high school graduate could go into a manufacturing job, but you can't just walk into those jobs without good literacy skills and math skills, even some computer literacy."
Other emergency food sites saw an increase in the number of elderly people using their services. Norwich's St. Vincent de Paul Place soup kitchen, which keeps statistics on the number of people served and what groups they represent, said about 20 percent more elderly people were eating at the soup kitchen this year than last year.
That so many people eating free meals are elderly may indicate that they qualify for food stamps, but have not or will not apply, said Claudette Beaulieu, spokeswoman for the state Department of Social Services. She said that elderly people are traditionally more reluctant to apply for food stamps, even if they qualify.
"They don't want to be associated with anything such as a welfare program," she said. But there is also a more subtle difference, according to Ms. Beaulieu. Elderly people, she said, "Have a hard time thinking of themselves as poor. They think they just have a hard time making ends meet. A lot of them have lived through the Great Depression. By that token, in their view, they aren't poor."
After all the research she has done on the problem of hunger in Connecticut, Dr. Sampson's reaction is emphatic.
"It's sad," she said. "You should not have hungry people anywhere in the U.S. Especially not here."
