HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY;
New Jersey Brownfields Are Drawing Developers

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: BAYONNE, N.J.

 BODY:
HUGE trucks rumble over uneven ground overlooking Upper New York Bay, carrying loads of construction debris and other fill that are reshaping a site that was the town dump for most of the century. The old dump is to be capped with 4.5 million cubic yards of sediment dredged from nearby shipping channels, and is then to be covered with several feet of clean dirt to create Hudson County's first 18-hole golf course.
The Bayonne site is a "brownfield," contaminated land that has sat unused because of the cost and risks of redevelopment. This area, in the Constable Hook part of the city, was a part of the bay until the early 1900's, when municipal garbage and industrial waste began to be dumped. 
 The site was closed to dumping in 1983 and has been vacant ever since, despite being open land in a densely populated region. What kept developers away was the stew of toxic substances beneath the ground; in addition to garbage residue, the site contained dyes, hydrocarbons and drums filled with unidentified materials.
The long delay in cleaning up such neglected sites is coming to an end in many locations, particularly in New Jersey. Over the last few years an increase in land values, changes in legislation regulating cleanups, the development of insurance policies that limit liability and the success of some pioneering projects have encouraged developers to pay more attention to brownfields.
"Brownfield development in the State of New Jersey is off the scale," said Richard Gimello, the assistant commissioner for remediation in the state's Department of Environmental Protection. He estimated that 1,000 to 1,200 of the state's more than 8,000 known contaminated sites are being worked on or are under active study.
"I'm having trouble finding case managers to handle the workload," he said. "It's a boom."
New Jersey's brownfield redevelopment is the most active in the metropolitan area because the regulatory climate in the other states is less certain. In Connecticut, efforts are under way to clean up former industrial sites in the Housatonic and Naugatuck River valleys.
New York still retains the strict cleanup laws adopted in the 1980's after the discovery of extensive contamination in the Love Canal area of Niagara falls, but state officials are reported by industry executives to be closely studying developments in New Jersey, and pressure is building to change the rules to permit economic development in the low-income areas that are typically near tainted land.
Brownfield developers say the strict standards imposed by these older laws are less of a problem than the uncertainty over how government will act. The developers also argue that it makes economic sense to impose lower cleanup standards on sites that will be put to industrial or commercial use than those that will be used for housing.
"With some of this old legislation, you never knew what the requirements were and how you could get out of a project," said Ronald R. Bruder, president of the Brookhill Group, which says it is the oldest and largest redeveloper of brownfield sites in the country. He said the company was doing business in more than 30 states where legislation more friendly to brownfield development has been adopted or the state environmental agency has taken a helpful stance.
Mr. Bruder said Brookhill was currently looking at four sites in New Jersey and expected to close on at least one before the end of the year. But he said he planned no projects in New York until laws and regulations were changed.
Mr. Bruder said brownfield redevelopment involves two main issues: the cost of cleanup and the property's potential for reuse. "We'll drill a lot of wells and do a lot of investigating and develop a number for the cost of clean-up. Then you have to figure the value in an adaptive reuse to decide whether to do the project."
He said that because many sites can be capped and reused without extensive cleaning, the environmental part of the equation is often less important than the site's real-estate potential. This means that an easily cleaned brownfield in a remote location may be less valuable than a dirty one that's convenient to potential customers.
Location meant a lot to the company that converted an old city dump in Elizabeth to the site of the Jersey Gardens shopping mall, which is due to open before the end of the month on the east side of the New Jersey Turnpike within view of Newark International Airport. Under a complicated arrangement with state officials and private companies, the 255-store outlet mall is to have its own exit from the Turnpike, where 180,000 cars carrying potential shoppers pass by every day. The company, now known as OENJ-Cherokee, bought the 185-acre site land for $10 million in 1992, spent $12.5 million remediating it and sold most of it to Glimcher Realty Trust in 1997 for $38 million to build Jersey Gardens.
OENJ-Cherokee retained about 40 acres of land facing Newark Bay, where it is planning a marina with ferry service to Manhattan and retail, entertainment and hotel development. The same company is also proceeding with the project in Bayonne and is seeking to turn an abandoned railroad and dock site in Woodbridge to an intermodal shipping center.
The structure of the company is an indication of how the brownfield cleanup business has developed in recent years. It was originally started, to do the Elizabeth project, in the early 1990's by two Danish businessmen, Peter Aargaard and Peter Pfeiffer. It has since largely been taken over by Cherokee Investment Security, a Denver-based company that manages funds raised from investors who see bargains in environmentally impaired real estate.
Most recently, Cherokee formed Cherokee Investment Partners II, to raise $250 million in equity from investors such as pension funds. The fund's first investment was to acquire OENJ's three waterfront sites for about $53 million.
Local companies have seen opportunities in converting contaminated sites as well. G. Heller Enterprises, of Edgewater, N.J., capped a site on Route 440 in Jersey City that contained toxic chromium compounds in order to make it suitable as the location for a Home Depot store. More recently, the company, in combination with Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn., purchased a 63-acre site in Edison from the Revlon Corporation for remediation and redevelopment.
A MAJOR spur to the activity in New Jersey was the enacting in early 1998 of the Brownfield and Contaminated Site Remediation Act. The law protects purchasers of contaminated sites -- called innocent purchasers -- from private lawsuits related to past pollution by other parties, as long as the land is cleaned up to state standards.
The law establishes different standards of cleanliness, with the highest for land to be used for residences and a lesser standard for industrial and commercial uses. It also permits the use of impermeable caps to prevent hazardous material from leaking out, rather than a complete removal of industrial residues, a much more costly undertaking.
Another important section is the provision of closure for brownfield projects by authorizing the Department of Environmental Protection to issue a covenant not to sue once a site has been cleaned to the relevant standard. And "innocent party" developers can receive tax breaks up to 75 percent of the cost of a project.
"In the past you were never sure what the requirements were to get out of a project," Mr. Bruder said. "Now there is a lot more certainty." And he said the recognition that all sites do not need to be made utterly pristine was similarly helpful.
"You don't have to get everything out of the ground to guard against health hazards," he said. "You can cap a site and put a covenant in the title that the property is never to be used as a nursery."
But capping and covering leaves pollutants in place, and that may pose a long-term threat to drinking water supplies, said Bill Wolfe, policy director for the Sierra Club of New Jersey. "The problem is with technical standards," he said. "The law now allows a nonpermanent remedy where we prefer a permanent one."
Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York, said economics have to be considered along with environmental concerns. "There are some pollutants -- such as lead and asbestos -- and some uses where capping and covering makes sense. But if you are dealing with volatile hydrocarbons, it has to be cleaned. We have to be sophisticated and allow for a variety of approaches."
As helpful as the New Jersey law and similar legislation in other states has been, some developers say the development of insurance policies for brownfield projects has been more important in limiting a developer's liability and ensuring nervous lenders that they will not be stuck with a dirty tract of land if something goes awry and they have to foreclose on the property.
"What the government giveth, the government can taketh away," said Christopher J. Daggett, a former New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection commissioner, who noted that companies who disposed of wastes in what were considered acceptable ways were branded as evil polluters once the Superfund Act was adopted by Congress. Mr. Daggett is now president of Chadwick Partners of Somerset, N.J., a brownfield developer.
He said he viewed the availability of insurance as a far more secure protection for developers than government regulations, because an insurance policy is a legally enforceable contract that is not as subject to changing political winds as environmental rules. He said that with this protection now available and with the price of land rising in many areas, developers are now more interested in contaminated sites they previously avoided.
Irving Cohen, president of OENJ-Cherokee, said insurance is part of what the company brings to a transaction. "We provide indemnity for the seller of property," he said. "We transfer the risk to the balance sheet of an insurance company."
The company brought a double-barreled environmental approach to both the Elizabeth and Bayonne projects. Both are former municipal and industrial dumps that had to have the worst contaminants removed and the rest stabilized and capped. Subsidence of the surface can be a problem for old garbage dumps as organic material decays, but the Elizabeth and Bayonne sites had been closed for so long that little organic material was left.
The capping material used in Elizabeth and planned at Bayonne is the muck dredged out of New York Harbor to keep shipping lanes deep enough for modern freighters. For decades the spoil was dumped at sea. But the harbor is the recipient of the pollution that flows down the region's rivers and falls from the air. It contains small, but detectable, amounts of heavy metal compounds, PCB's and toxic hydrocarbons.
Environmentalists have argued that when the dredged mud is dumped at sea, these toxics disperse in the water, where they are taken up by marine organisms and tend to accumulate in the flesh of larger hunter species that become seafood for humans. In recent years Federal regulators have greatly restricted ocean dumping of dredge material.
Dredging is a fact of life in the port, where the Newark Bay section is naturally only about 18 to 19 feet deep. The channels leading to the containerports off the Kill Van Kull in Newark and Elizabeth are currently dredged to a depth of 45 feet and there are proposals pending to dig down to 50 feet, to accommodate a new generation of larger ships. In addition to digging deeper channels, dredging must be performed to maintain existing depths in the face on an estimated 1 million metric tons of silt that flows downstream from the region's rivers each year. The New Jersey side of the harbor produces, on average, 1.82 million cubic yards of dredge material each year, according to Frank M. McDonough, executive director of New Jersey's Maritime Resources Agency.
All that muck has to go someplace, and with ocean dumping largely curtailed public officials and private developers have been seeking land applications. This is an approach that has the approval of environmentalists, if the material is treated to prevent the spread of toxics.
"We feel there are a lot less pathways to humans with upland disposal than with aquatic disposal," said Andrew J. Willner, director of the New York-New Jersey Baykeeper program.
OENJ's approach, developed after a year of testing, is to mix the dredge material with binders such as Portland cement and lime kiln dust in a large cylindrical tank called a pug mill which is located at the site. Once mixed, the material is dumped in piles on the site and allowed to dry before being spread out over the land. The resulting material is said to be resistant to penetration by water and with enough physical strength to hold up a shopping center, as it has at the Elizabeth site.
According to Mr. Cohen, the Bayonne site will be capped and contoured according to the needs of the as-yet-unselected golf course developer. It is to be covered with at least two feet of clean fill so grass and plants can be grown and to protect golfers from any contact with the dredged material. The course is expected to open in the latter part of 2001.
This dual approach, which is being employed by others, enables a company to do well by doing good. In addition to improving the value of the land, OENJ gets paid by the Port Authority for accepting the dredge material and treating it.
Tom Wakeman, the Port Authority's dredging program manager, said that demand for dredge material had increased as the Elizabeth project has shown that is a good alternative to buying dirt to seal sites like old dumps. That means the agency has been paying less to get rid of it.
He said OENJ was paid $56 a cubic yard to accept and treat the material used in Elizabeth, $40 to treat it and $16 as a tipping fee to take off the agency's hands. Tipping fees are common in the waste disposal business. And $56 a cubic yard was a huge savings from the $118 a cubic yard the Port Authority had to pay to ship dredge material from the Howland Hook marine terminal on Staten Island to Utah when ocean dumping first became unavailable.
But as dredge material has come to be regarded less as a waste and more as a useful raw material, the tipping fee has declined to $8 a cubic yard in more recent transactions and is expected to go lower still in negotiations now under way, Mr. Wakeman said. However, the agency still is paying developers to bring the material up to environmental standards and is currently paying about $35 a cubic yard, although other harbors have gotten that down to $10 to $20 a cubic yard, according to Mr. Wakeman.
THIS payment for treating dredge material appears to be behind the proposed second phase of the Bayonne project, which would involve filling 300 acres of open water between the upland part of the site and the Military Ocean Terminal to the north. The filling operation would consume as much as 10 million cubic yards of dredge material over five years.
Mr. Cohen said studies had shown that shallow water in the area was not a habitat for marine organisms and said the site would be developed into a park with ballfields, a marina and a wetlands/wildlife refuge area that would be donated to Bayonne.
But securing permits for the second phase may be far more difficult than the first, given the reluctance of environmental groups and government agencies to eliminate any wetlands areas.
The Mayor of Bayonne, Joseph Doria, who as a leader in the State Assembly helped pass the brownfields legislation, said the public golf course would be a welcome addition to the community. "The land had limited use as a brownfield," he said, "but blending it with the dredge creates 130 acres of needed open space."
He said it would neatly complement anticipated commercial development on the 437-acre Military Ocean Terminal, which is reverting to the city's control.
The second phase, he said, "is a much more difficult problem and there is a question of whether it will come to pass." He noted that no permits have been issued for the second phase and said that filling in wetlands "is a significant issue."
The issue of whether particular wetlands should be filled aside, finding a beneficial use for the dredge material is a "triple win" for the port and the environment, according to Mr. McDonough of N.J. Maritime Resources. "We remove the material, use it to cap a brownfield and we get a remediated site," he said.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
With Land Scarce, Developed Sites Are Reused

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: HANOVER TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
THE low-rise office building and warehouse on Park Avenue have been fixtures in this Morris County community for more than 40 years. But by June the two occupied structures, together totaling 74,000 square feet, will be vacated and then demolished to make way for a 150,000-square-foot Class A office building.
The site is at the intersection of Columbia Turnpike and Route 24. The latter artery, roughly an 12-mile stretch completed about seven years ago, connected the area to Newark International Airport via Interstate 78 in 15 minutes instead of 30 and spurred development at the crossroads. 
 The $30-million project has all its approvals and will be developed by the Wm. Blanchard Company of Springfield, which has owned the 14-acre site since 1955. The new building, at 10 Park Avenue, will take a year to complete. Rents in the buildings it will replace average $13 a square foot a year for the office space and $6.50 for the warehouse space.
With annual rents for prime office space in the area of the intersection ranging from $22 to $34 a square foot, Blanchard stands to make a profit in constructing the larger and more modern building on its site.
"We have Class C buildings on what now has become a Class A office location," said William I. Blanchard, secretary-treasurer of the family-run company. That fact, along with the strong economy, "makes this the right time to redevelop the site," he said.
In recent years office buildings and a new Summerfield Suites hotel have been built in the neighborhood around the Blanchard site.
Blanchard is not alone in recycling sites in good locations as the supply of buildable land dwindles. While some developers, like Blanchard, are using the knock-down, build-up strategy that has become popular in residential real estate, variations on that theme are occurring throughout the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market.
In Parsippany, also in Morris County, Wellsford Commercial Properties Trust of Chatham is recycling the 160,000-square-foot vacant former Estee Candy warehouse on Lackawanna Avenue. The company stripped the old warehouse to its steel skeleton and is now rebuilding it and expanding it to 250,000 square feet. The new building, to be called the Morris Technology Center, will be completed early next year.
On River Road in Nutley in Essex County, not far from Route 3, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Melville, N.Y., is transforming an obsolete 128,000-square-foot warehouse into office space. The 17-acre site could accommodate 110,000 more square feet of space.
AND in Edison in Middlesex County, the 63-acre former Revlon plant on Route 27, a collection of manufacturing, research and office buildings, is set to become a mixed-use complex. So far the developer -- G. Heller Enterprises of Edgewater together with Starwood Opportunity Fund IV, an affiliate of Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn. -- has leased back a 100,000-square-foot research building to Revlon along with 75,000 square feet in the 250,000-square-foot office building, which is being renovated.
All but 140,000 square feet of the 750,000 square feet of industrial space on the property have been demolished. Plans call for land on which the demolished structures once stood, as well as 18 undeveloped acres on the site, to be redeveloped for retail, warehouse and, possibly, office space.
"The health of the market is driving developers to seek out underutilized sites near highways so they can maximize the value of the land," said Jonathan Meisel, an associate director at Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage. He said that the activity would continue "as long as development parcels remain scarce, vacancy rates remain low and rents rise."
The Blanchard Company leased the buildings on its site to single users from 1955 to 1995. Since then they have been rented to multiple tenants whose leases expire in June.
"We could have leased the buildings for another five years, but we would have had to put in a lot of money to upgrade them," said Mr. Blanchard. Instead, the decision was "to take the hit in the beginning by stopping a rental income and investing more money to build a new building, for a much better property and revenue stream in the end."
Industry experts said the area's change began with the development of a project called Park Avenue at Morris County in nearby Florham Park. The project, with 1.1 million square feet of space in six buildings, was started by Gale & Wentworth of Florham Park, with J.P. Morgan, in anticipation of the completion of Route 24. Since 1996, the last four buildings, totaling 500,000 square feet, were developed speculatively, said Mark Yeager, president of the Commercial Group at Gale & Wentworth. He said that all six buildings are now fully leased.
Mr. Yeager said the success of that project had encouraged his company to proceed, with Goldman Sachs, on a 203,000-square-foot speculative building in nerby Madison. That building, 7 Giralda Farms, is rising on 20 acres within the Madison Borough portion of the 310-acre Giralda Farms office park. The park spills into Chatham Township and was once the estate of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge.
According to Sitmar Company/ONCOR International, a brokerage in Iselin, some 400,000 square feet of office space is under way on or near Route 24 and an additional 1.4 million square feet is rising throughout the county. Most of it is in the Parsippany submarket, where the conversion of the old Estee Candy warehouse is taking place.
At the same time, sublet space has filtered back onto the market, and that, along with the turbulence of the capital markets last summer and early fall, caused leasing activity in Morris County to level off during the first half of this year. As of Sept. 30, the office vacancy rate in the county was 12.4 percent, up 2.1 percentage points from the same time last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. But that did not have a negative impact on asking rents, which rose by 79 cents a square foot to $28.67, the brokerage reported.
Most real estate experts said that the county had rebounded from its initial sluggishness and that the pace of activity would pick up. Barring an unforeseen economic disaster, said Mr. Meisel of Cushman & Wakefield, "the last wave of building will get absorbed in the next six months and the market will be where it was 12 to 18 months ago with tenants scurrying for space," especially large blocks of prime space.
That is what Mr. Yeager of Gale & Wentworth is betting on to lease the building his company is developing in the Route 24 market. "There will be corporations that will give back some space, but at the end of the day we are confident that the space will be absorbed on a regular basis," he said.
In addition to Blanchard, other developers have the approvals needed to start new office buildings. Among them is the Rockefeller Group, which secured approvals last summer to construct two buildings, each with 220,000 square feet, at its 140-acre Rockefeller Group Corporate Park on Park Avenue in Florham Park. Also, Reckson Associates has approvals to build 436,000 square feet on the property it owns within the Madison Borough portion of Giralda Farms. Neither project will be built on speculation.
Recently, Wellsford Commercial Property Trust purchased Airport Park, a two-building, 100,000-square-foot office complex on 16 acres adjacent to the Morristown Airport and not far from Route 24 in Hanover Township. The company plans to renovate the existing buildings and to seek approvals next year to build an additional 150,000-square-foot structure on the site, said Richard Previdi, its president.
Mr. Blanchard said his company's 150,000-square-foot building was being marketed to tenants looking for large blocks of space and the visibility from and access to Route 24 that the site provides. The hope, he said, is to have a tenant or tenants in place before the old buildings are demolished in June and start construction the following month.
If not, he said, "we probably will not begin the project until at least half the space is preleased."

LENGTH: 3835 words

HEADLINE: After the Flood;
With a Billion of Dollars in Damage, New Jersey Will Be Wringing Out a Long Time

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
IT is now a month later, yet the cocoa-colored dust clings to the roads and sidewalks, the plate glass and vinyl siding, the tennis courts, teddy bears, junked cars and defunct furnaces.
The dried sediment of the record-breaking floodwaters let loose by Tropical Storm Floyd still coats huge swaths of northern and central New Jersey -- from the curb along Route 18 in New Brunswick, where even the flood-prone Raritan River had never intruded before, to the Elizabethtown Water Company pump house in Bridgewater, which was surrounded by berms built to hold back the kind of flood that is only supposed to happen every 500 years. 
 As torrential rains pounded the northern and central parts of the state, floodwaters eventually rose to all-time highs on 14 different rivers, sending thousands of workers home early, closing roads and paralyzing mass transit. More than 20,000 people were evacuated from their homes. Many had to be rescued from the raging, dirty brown water; some could not be. Winds toppled trees as well as power and telephone lines. Loved ones were separated. Heroes were made. The National Guard was called out. The world tuned in.
"It came from places that we've never seen it come from before," said Richard Futter, of Futter's Stride Rite shoe store in Millburn, which straddles the flood-prone Rahway River. "The previous floods came from the brook overflowing. But this time it came from up the street, from down the street, from down the mountain, from over the railroad tracks."
Early estimates put the total damage throughout the state at a billion dollars, including $800 million in the eight counties declared Federal disaster areas. About $250 million of that is uninsured, according to the State Office of Emergency Management.
A month later, the damage from the storm that pounded the area for four days beginning on Sept. 15 is stark indeed. In all, the emergency office said, 4.5 million people, or more than half the state's population, were affected in some way.
The waters of the Hackensack, Rahway and Elizabeth Rivers, the Ho-ho-kus Brook, Pike Run and countless other creeks, streams and nameless tributaries violently awakened by three months of rainfall in a single day have gone back to their muddy beds. But New Jersey is still wringing its hands.
"I've never seen anything like this and I hope to God we don't see it again," said Marie Scannell, 57, director of the Food Bank of Somerset County, who was flooded out of her home in South Bound Brook.
Help may come from the state's Congressional delegation in Washington, which is upset because it fears New Jersey will be short-changed by Federal relief authorities, and plans to introduce a measure providing grants up to $50,000 to each damaged business. But even if the financing is approved, which is by no means certain, it will take months for the Government to review the applications -- more than enough time for a small- or medium-size business to go bankrupt.
In addition, the State Senate on Oct. 25 is scheduled to vote on a bill intended to provide $50 million in grants and loans to flood victims, and another $10 million for local and state agencies to pay for overtime, supplies and other flood-related costs. But last week a spokeswoman for Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate president, said details had not been worked out on when people could expect to receive the money, or even how much would be in the form of grants.
The New Jersey Department of Labor is also offering special disaster unemployment insurance of up to $407 a week for a maximum of 26 weeks to employees and business owners put out of work by the storm. James Borders, a department spokesman, said checks began going out the beginning of this month.
"I'm sure it's going to be a year or better before people get recovered from this flood," said Leroy Gunzelman 3d, Somserset's emergency management coordinator.
Many may never recover.
Indeed, a preliminary assessment this month by the Office of Emergency Management found 251 structures were completely destroyed, including 71 houses, 105 apartment buildings and 75 business. Altogether, the agency said, 6,791 structures sustained major damage, with minor damage to another 26,036. A total of 76,606 structures in 253 communities were effected to some degree, from being reduced to rubble to having their basements flooded.
Two weeks after the storm, 126 inspectors from the Federal Emergency Management Agency had conducted a total 5,211 damage inspections, and $8.2 million in Federal assistance grants had been approved. Final damage assessments by the eight disaster counties will not be in until early November, 30 days after county and Federal officials began holding so-called "kickoff meetings" to begin the formal assessment process early this month.
Some 300 workers from the state and Federal emergency agencies are still working in a field office in a Piscataway office park, where operations were moved following the storm from the state emergency management command center in Trenton, the state's disaster war room.
As late as last week, more than 100 evacuees remained in the last shelter, an old Veteran's Administration office building in Hillsborough, and Red Cross officials said they did not know how long they would be there.
"You know what, if you put on a lot of blankets you can hardly feel its a cot," said Amanda Gonzalez, 17, who takes a bus from the shelter to Bound Brook High School every day. "I'm not, you know, like, devastated. I know God's going to come back and give me a house."
The exceedingly powerful hurricane, known as Floyd, did lose some of its punch as it raked eastern North Carolina with 138-mile-per-hour winds and torrential rains. While making its way up the East Coast, the storm weakened considerably and was downgraded to a tropical storm. Nonetheless, it swept over New Jersey with winds gusting over 70 miles an hour and dumping an average of a half-inch of rain an hour.
A monitoring station in North Plainfield operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration measured 12.03 inches of rain during Floyd's official four-day siege, with most coming on Oct. 16, a Thursday that many will not soon forget; 11.5 inches were recorded in Little Falls; Pequannock got 11 inches; 10.73 inches fell on Franklin Lakes; Greenwood got 10.58 inches; and Wertsville got 10 inches.
In many places, three months average rain fell in 24 hours, said Robert M. Hordon, a hydrologyst in the Geography Department at Rutgers University. "That's simply an enormous, enormous amount of precipitation," Professor Hordon said.
The fact that the storm was downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm meant little for the four people who drowned in flash flooding brought on by the rain. In addition, the police in Cranford blamed the storm for the death of a lieutenant who took his own life after working 48 hours almost non-stop coordinating the rescue of 350 people.
When the storm hit, its swirling, counterclockwise motion actually brought winds from the northeast, like the wintertime nor'easters New Jersey is more familiar with, said Mike Michael Changery, chief of the Climate Monitoring Branch of the National Climate Data Center in Ashville, N.C.
The rain and wind formed a devastating tag team against the utilities. "Trees down, wires down, poles down, and then all kinds of flooding thrown into the mix," said Susan Hohenadel, a spokeswoman for GPU Energy. "A lot of the roads that we needed to use to get to trouble areas were impassible and hindered restoration efforts."
Ms. Hohenadel said 291,500 customers lost power for four days in Burlington, Ocean, Monmouth, Mercer, Middlesex, Hunterdon, Somerset, Union, Warren, Sussex and Passaic counties. There were 8,400 trouble spots, and 578 repair crews assigned to fix them, some lent by utilities in Michigan, Connecticut, Illinois, Delaware and Maryland.
About 310,000 Public Service Electric and Gas customers in Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex and Union counties lost power for up to three days, said Lisa Ciffelli, a spokeswoman for the utility.
George Martins was one of them.
The 48-year-old Mr. Martins, 48, who runs a photo printing business in his basement in Newark, said he lost $50,000 in personal and business property because of the outage. No flooding would have occured, he said, if his sump pump had power. "We never thought we were going to get hit, because we're not considered a flood zone," said Mr. Martins, who was shopping at Home Depot in Garwood on a recent Saturday for cleaning, disinfectant and pest control supplies.
Public Service customers said 17,800 gas customers lost service for up to two weeks, and a handful remained without gas last week waiting for building inspectors to declare their buildings safe.
Floyd also slammed the phone down on much of the state. For four days, 37,000 homes, businesses and other locations served by Bell Atlantic in Rochelle Park, Lodi, Maywood, Paramus and Saddle Brook could not call their local police, ambulance squad, fire department or school, much less friends or family far away. And a million Bell Atlantic customers in 23 towns lost long distance service.
"If you think of long distance service as a freeway, Bell Atlantic is an on-ramp," said a spokesman for AT&T Wireless Services, Dave Johnson. "So it would be as if that on-ramp was blocked by a tractor trailor -- or by floodwaters."
Bergen, Essex, Hunterdon, Middlesex, Morris, Passaic and Union Counties were declared Federal Disaster areas, making them eligible for Federal disaster relief.
In human and dollar terms, the hardest hit was Bergen, where the county office of emergency management's preliminary damage assessment totalled $377 million, and where 7,410 people had to be evacuated. Of the 534 businesses effected, 72 were completely destroyed, and estimated damage totalled $46,588,000. About $40 million in public property was reported damaged in the county alone.
In Bergen County, the flood was felt most dramatically in Lodi. The Saddle River overflowed its banks, washing over the downtown -- including the municipal building , senior citizen's complex and dozens of houses. The Friday after the storm was a beautiful, sunny day, and there was a strangly carnival-like atmosphere in town despite, and perhaps in part because of, the damage, which closed schools and businesses, and gave people the chance to wander the streets that were somehow dry, marvelling at the high water and talking to frinds and strangers alike.
New Jersey Army National Guard troops from Trenton occupied the A & P parking lot, and aided in evacuations and rescues. At Felician College, up to eight feet of water occupied the student center, the cafeteria, a library and an adjacent cemetery where some 200 Felician nuns are buried.
"Our sisters are buried there," said Sister Theresa Mary Martin, the college president. "You can't see any of the tombstones."
Essex County estimated its damage at $134 million, with 21,854 homes effected in one way or another.
Somerset County, which includes Bound Brook, put its total at $130 million, with 4,411 evacuees. Passaic County's estimatewas $59 million, with 3,320 evacuees.
Eerily, the street lights stayed on at ground zero of the flooding, on Main Street in Bound Brook, illuminating the rushing water as it carried 40-gallon drums, car tires, branches and beach balls past second story windows.
Joe Lemire, 29, a freelance videographer, captured the scene from a third-story perch opposite the Bound Brook train station, before he was evacuated by New York City police. He also videotaped hardware store, an Italian bakery and a Chinese restaurant ablaze after the water caused a short-circuit that touched off an electrical fire. It through the night and sent up thick black smoke against a Friday morning dawn that gave the world its first shocking glimpses of the flood's devastation.
"We had every news agency from the BBC to the Moscow News," said Mr. Lemire, who was torn between getting the story and getting out safely. "Watching that water rise and seeing the lights flickering and a few buildings in flames down the street, I was getting a little worried about an electrical fire."
Two weeks later, in noisy testament to merchant resilience, saws and hammers pounded and shrieked from behind the padlocked door and newspaper-covered windows of one shop, where a sign read, "Coming Soon, muy pronto, Joyce's Bakery & Tacqueria."
Ray Woldin, 39, a realtor and former borough councilman who was out surveying the damage, said mere resiliency may not be what Bound Brook and other flood-prone areas need. "Something has to change down here, obviously," Mr. Woldin said. "It's time to step back, take a look and come up with a plan: Where's this town going to go in the next century? It's time to transform this town into something that can survive the water."
To Prof. James K. Mitchell, director of graduate studies in the geography department at Rutgers University, the best way to survive may simply be to move.
"It would probably be cheaper for society in the long run, the medium run, to buy up those properties that were in the flood plain and then relocate them, because those properties are going to be flooded again and again and again," said Professor Mitchell, who wrote book titled, "Crucibles of Hazard: Megacities and Disasters in Transition" (The United United Press, 1999).
Flood control policy makers have already come around to the idea in New Jersey. For instance, Governor Whitman last year set aside $15 million toward the purchase of 800 flood-prone properties along the Passaic River. In the meantime, a proposal by the Army Corps of Engineers for a $1.9 billion flood tunnel to try to control flooding in the region has languished for years for lack of support.
However, the Army Corps is moving head with the long-awaited Green Brook Flood Control Project, a $331 million, 10-year effort to control flooding in Somerset, Middlesex and Union counties, first proposed after a 1973 flood that killed six people.
"We were moving out," said Yvonne E. Spraggins, the project manager. "We were already planning on beginning the first constructino element in the spring."
After last month's flood, some people lamented that the project might have prevented much of the devastation. Ms. Spraggins noted that the timing of two meetings about the project -- on Sept. 21 and 30 -- in Middlesex and Bound Brook may have given the impression that they were spurred by the flood, but she said they had been scheduled well before then.
Working-class communities like Bound Brook, Manville and Lodi seemed to bear the brunt of the storm's assault, and perhaps not coincidentally. After all, Housing is cheaper in a flood plain than in the hills. There is even the possibility, said Professor Hordon, that less affluent areas bear a disproportionate share of the flooding brought about by upscale development at higher elevations.
But in the words of Sgt. Stephen Hoptay of the New Jersey State Police, a spokesman for the state office of emergency management, "The flood recognized no socio-economic bounderies."
In Millburn, a tony township in Essex County, a row of on Millburn Avenue in the heart of downtown were still in shambles last week. At one of them, Muebles Royal, which features reproductions of Louis XIV furniture, a banner read: "Flood Sale. Everything must go!" The armchairs and sofas, in hand-carved Russian oak, with gold leaf and Egyptian cotton and silk upholstery still looked fit for a sun king, but the wood had cracked from the flooding.
"People don't want to buy this," said the owner, Galal Saad, 40, who said he was only days from opening when the xxxxxxxxxx.
Not even the far reaches of Sussex County could escape. In Ogdensberg, the Heaters Pond Dam is being repaired after an overflow etched channels down its back side despite the fact that Police Chief George Lott had ordered the level of the 40-acre pond lowered by 5 feet in anticipation of the rain.
Eskil Danielson, emergency management coordinator in Sussex County, said that at the Concetta Tower nursing home in Franklin Township, high winds kept carbon monoxide generated by the heating system from exiting the building though a escape vent. Two residents and one emergency medical technician had to be hospitalized after inhaling the fumes.
In Middlesex Borough, at a Petroleum 19 service station, the owner, Alex Bruselovsky, spoke for countless frustrated property owners when he pleaed in a heavy Russian accent, "Why does Government give to other countries billions, billions dollars like present?" said Mr. Bruselovsky, 62, of Brooklyn. "Why can't they give to us?"
In the narrow ally between the station and the steep bank of the Middle Brook stood the four gasoline pumps that had to be replaced after the flood. Inside the garage there was vast heap of soggy, crushed cases of motor oil that had been toppled by the raging flood waters. Mr. Bruselovsky, who sold his service station in Brooklyn to escape the frequent robberies there, said the flood cost him $100,000 out of pocket.
"I got liability, everything. I no got flood insurance," he said.
A compact, white-haired man with blue eyes, Mr. Bruselovsky described a grinding routine in which he rises every day, seven days a week, at 2:30 A.M. to commute to the station. He has has sacrificed much of his own life in that fashion for two decades, he said, so that he could leave something behind for his grandchildren in Morganville. Now, he said, "Everything is gone."
Bound Brook quickly became the flood's poster child, with newspapers as far away as Sao Paolo, Brazil, publishing photographs of the borough burning and drowning. To be sure, other areas also suffered significant damage.
"Nobody thought about us during the storm," said Harry Shepherd, the emergency management coordinator for Hunterdon County, which sustained an estimated $8.5 million in damage. "We're still finding places every day that were effected."
Flash flooding completely destroyed five houses and caused $1 million in road damage alone, said Frank Fuzo, a Hunterdon County freeholder, adding that the Hamden River Road Bridge was still out.
On Main Street in Manville, in Somerset County where it used to rain ashes from the old Johns-Manville asbestos plant that is no longer standing, some residents who were drenched in a 1996 flood of the Raritan and Millstone Rivers decided to throw in the towel.
"We will not be back in Manville," said James Stainner, 37, sorting through the stained blueprints and crashed computers of his air systems consulting firm, USC Environmental, few days after the storm. "Three strikes and you're out. And we got hit twice already."
In the Lost Valley neighborhood nearby, washing machines, air conditioners, television sets, cabinets, dressers, mattresses and other possessions were piled up on curbs. Trucks carting debris from the flood lined up for a half-mile waiting to dump their cargo at the county trash transfer station.
Jerry Rzestowski was born and raised in Lost Valley but now lives in Bowling Green, La., where he works for IBM. Mr. Rzestowski, 56, was back in his hometown to bring his 80-year-old mother, Helen, down to live with him. It was the fourth major flood that Mr. Rzestowski said had inundated the little house on Knopf Street where he grew up. Its white vinyl siding was stained a light brown to a point five feet above the ground. As in so many other places, the stench of mildew hung heavily in the air, and the wooden floorboards were buckled. A pair of fiddles made by Mr. Rzestowski's brother, Tom, were spread on the floor with many of the family's other lost possessions. But Tom Rzestowski, 55, who works in a warehouse, has learned to be philosophical about the damage.
"You can't cry over this stuff, you know," Mr. Rzestowski said. "You have to laugh. It's not the first time."
 
Lessons to Be Learned From the Flooding
FOR all its destruction, last month's flooding will yield something positive: information for a research project at Rutgers University.
Under what the department is calling "The Great Raritan Flood Project," professors will research various aspects of Tropical Storm Floyd. The information will be incorporated into classroom material, giving students the benefit of learning by an example experienced firsthand. A report is most likely to be published in the spring, said Prof. Robert M. Hordon, a physical geographer and hydrologist at Rutgers.
This is no ivory tower endeavor.
Professor Hordon is focusing on the effect of 7 to 11 inches of rain in a 24-hour span on the Raritan River Basin -- a 785-square-mile drainage system, or watershed, for the Raritan and its tributaries that embraces much of Hunterdon, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris and Union counties as well as Somerset -- the fastest-growing county in the state.
During the storm, 18 monitoring stations run by the United States Geological Survey recorded new peak water levels, of which 10 were within the Raritan basin.
Professor Hordon will try to explain how development in the area has affected flash flooding. "Instead of allowing the precipitation to come into the ground, by paving it over, forcing the precipitation onto streets and storm sewers and gutters and so forth that quickly convey it to the river, urbanization and suburbanization make a stream flashier," he said.
Professor Hordon is also examining whether the summer drought aggravated the flooding. "If the ground becomes like cement, the infiltration is reduced," he said.
Professor Hordon said the quantity of new peaks suggested that maps delineating flood plains plotted by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in 1979 may no longer accurately indicate an area's likelihood of flooding.
"The more data we collect on this flooding, the more it looks like these instruments are going to have to be revised," he said. The Federal agency agrees.
The maps were developed beginning in 1968 to assist state and local emergency management offices prepare for floods and to help determine premiums for the National Flood Insurance Program, said Mike Buckley, the agency's director for technical services. They are also used by banks to set interest rates for mortgages on property in or near flood-prone areas, and by planning boards and developers in determining the suitability of proposals.
The obvious concern, officials said, is that plans based on obsolete maps are inherently flawed. Indeed, Mr. Buckley said 58 percent of New Jersey's flood maps are at least 15 years old.
But cost is also a concern. Mr. Buckley said the work is labor-intensive, and revising maps for 17,000 communities is a costly proposition.
"We have developed a proposal to update and modernize our maps," he said. "It's being discussed by Congress and the administration as to how to fund it." STEVE STRUNKSY

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 881 words

HEADLINE: CALLINGS;
Partnership, From Cradle To Campus

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN; Laura Pedersen-Pietersen is a Manhattan author and public speaker. Her column profiling people whose work is their passion appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: yourmind@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
ON college campuses, there are now "nonsmoking" dorms and "quiet study" dorms. But with fresh-faced undergraduates increasingly armed with laptops, cell phones, Palm Pilots and -- most important -- ideas, it won't be long before there are "entrepreneurs only" halls, too.
And with all the software and Internet companies being spawned by intrepid undergrads, you may soon be reading of sizable alumni contributions from chief executives with the ink barely dry on their diplomas. 
 Ben Nobel and Adam Menzel, 20-year-old college juniors who go back even further than Bill Gates and Paul Allen, are among the new entrepreneurs. They have built a financial Web site called Javaticker.com, which they run from their respective campuses, Middlebury College, in Vermont, and Brandeis University, outside Boston.
Indeed, colleges may be the perfect hothouses for seeding start-ups, said Lester C. Thurow, the M.I.T. economist and most recently the author of "Building Wealth" (HarperCollins). "Many schools are wired with fiber optics, broadband communications systems and provide access to instant downloading," he said in an interview. "You can do things from your dorm room that you won't be able to do from your home for another 10 years."
MR. NOBEL and Mr. Menzel met when they were barely out of the cradle. At 18 months, they toddled over to each other at a "Mommies and Me" play group in Port Washington, N.Y., and began networking.
It was the start of an extraordinary partnership. While Javaticker.com may be their most ambitious venture to date, it's hardly their first. As 12-year-olds, they hawked pears by the roadside. (Adam's family had a pear tree.)
Pears soon gave way to more practical products. On one wintry day, Ben's father was unable to unlock his car. All the local stores but one were sold out of de-icer. The boys bought the entire inventory, hurried to the train station and sold the canisters for double what they had just paid. Alas, they just "broke even," Mr. Menzel recalled, still with a twinge of regret. "We overstocked and we got frostbite."
In high school, the boys had bigger brainstorms. As comic book connoisseurs, they combed trade shows for comics that they could resell to a local dealer. And when they built shelves for their collections, they reasoned that everyone would want similar cabinetry. Off they went to the lumberyard, but the idea, as Mr. Nobel put it, "failed to get the national recognition we'd hoped for."
But recognition is finally knocking on their dorm-room doors. Two summers ago, Mr. Nobel, a computer science major, and Mr. Menzel, who is studying economics, were watching the financial news while riding side-by-side exercise bicycles at a local gym (apparently the 90's version of the garage). Their conversation turned to the user-unfriendliness of financial Web sites.
The next day they pitched their idea -- for a free, well-organized financial site -- to Greg Leib, a former Bear Stearns broker and now an Internet entrepreneur, who was a member of Mr. Nobel's local Unitarian Church. Mr. Leib signed on as sole investor, taking the chief executive's title.
Sixteen months later, after many all-nighters, no salaries and "tons of Chinese food," they have a solid financial site that offers updated headlines, scrolling stock tickers (which can be customized by the user) research, message boards, charts and weather, all in a colorful, easy-to-use format. Though the goal is to have advertising cover costs, the site has yet to break even. Mr. Menzel estimates that it has eaten $200,000 of Mr. Leib's money so far.
"Not much at all for an Internet company," Mr. Menzel said. And if the company has a future, each student has an 8 percent stake, with Mr. Leib holding the rest..
What is it like to be a chief technology officer while still in college? "I have to remember to turn off my cell phone in class," Mr. Nobel said. "My professors would probably throw me out if it went off."
MR. MENZEL, the chief operating officer, said he was lucky to have a girlfriend who understands his four-hour Friday night disappearances to attend to server problems or respond to user E-mail. His parents have been supportive, too. (And why not? They have a lifetime supply of lock de-icer in their basement.)
Friends on campus ask to work for them, as do some outsiders. "Yesterday this guy from Microsoft asked me for a job," Mr. Nobel recounted, still reeling. "He said our site sounded like a more fun place to work."
To meet a growing user base -- the site has an average of 12,000 hits a day -- three employees have been added. The three, also college students, grew up with the founders.
Future plans include, well, graduation. Then the dot.comsters may move the business to Vermont -- and perhaps eventually to Wall Street, in the form of a stock offering.
The management at Sun Microsystems, owner of the Java trademark, doesn't seem to mind that these cheeky upstarts are using the name. In fact, the company has invited the founders to display their stock in trade -- or trade in stock, as the case may be -- at the big Sun trade show in New York next spring.
"We'd love to go but, well, it's finals week," Mr. Nobel said with a sigh.
"Yeah, finals," Mr. Menzel added, regretfully.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 925 words

HEADLINE: On Politics;
Running Stealth Campaigns, If Not Always by Choice

BYLINE: By Paul Zielbauer; Paul Zielbauer reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey voters are basking in the silence of the October dead zone, the political season when nothing interesting crosses their radar, and even if it did, polls suggest they probably wouldn't care.
The barbed anonymous-fax wars between the dueling Democrats for United States Senate, Jon Corzine and Jim Florio, have paused, for now, while both campaigns stock up on fresh boxes of ink cartridges. The shock of Governor Whitman abdicating from the United State Senate race last month has also subsided, and the crop of aspiring Republican replacements have stayed off the airwaves and out of the headlines. 
 Which leaves the statewide Assembly elections on Nov. 2 as the next big thing, an event the overwhelming majority of voters don't even know about.
According to a recent poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, 96 percent of the registered voters queried could not name which offices were up for election next month, much less articulate what any one candidate had to say. And because the poll's margin of error is 4 percent, statewide voter indifference could actually be as great as 98 percent (or if you're an optimist, as small as 90 percent).
"It's a very low-stimulus campaign," said Gerald Pomper, a professor of political science at Rutgers.
The poll, it should be noted, registered substantial voter concern for certain issues -- auto insurance, health care and property taxes led the list -- just not any awareness of the Assembly officials responsible for making laws about them.
Such apathy has many excuses. Or if you're an optimist, reasons. First, blame 1999, an atypical election year when the Assembly races top the ballot tickets. With no statewide offices or big-name politicians up for a vote, history shows that most people simply tune out until right before Election Day. The last time the Assembly led an election cycle, in 1995, only 38.6 percent of the state's 4.4 million voters showed up. Political analysts aren't offering even the slightest reason to believe that might change next month.
Next, blame Lord John Berkeley and Sir George Carteret, the two guys who in 1664 accepted New Jersey's geographical boundaries as is. Thanks to them, no part of the state would be beyond the reach of television stations in New York or Philadelphia, media markets that make it economically silly for candidates with no statewide recognition (e.g., members of the Assembly) to buy advertising that would reach voters en masse. Thus, Assembly candidates must still rely heavily on mass mailings and local cable television.
Third, blame the news media, which habitually glom onto the sexiest or seediest political stories and ignore the mundane stump fests popular during the October dead zone. Last Sunday, for example, when Mr. Florio debated another Senate candidate, Steve DeVos, at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, most reporters didn't bother to cover it.
Finally, blame the Assembly candidates themselves, incumbents and challengers alike, who thus far have been rather parsimonious about getting their messages out. As of Oct. 4, candidates for the 80 Assembly seats had raised a record $6.9 million, according to the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, but had spent only $2.4 million. Without a burning issue to hammer into voters' heads, said Ingrid Reed of Rutgers' Eagleton Institute, candidates don't bother spending too much.
There are exceptions, of course. Steven J. Corodemus, a Republican from Monmouth County, for instance, had spent $129,346.93 through last week to counter a challenge from Mayor Mike Beson of Neptune. But most candidates have only spent a few thousand dollars to date.
That will change soon enough, candidates from both parties say. By this time next week, mailboxes should begin swallowing a steady diet of direct-mail campaign fliers, while cable-access television shows are expected to glow with ads from candidates heading toward the homestretch.
Television sets will glow the brightest in the eight districts where Democrats have the best hope of picking up Assembly seats, said Joseph V. Doria, the minority leader who is organizing the party's charge up Assembly Hill. Reminded that Republicans control a commanding 48 to 32 advantage over Assembly Democrats, Mr. Doria chuckled and said, "That's when upsets occur."
Pressing to win eight district seats, Democrats say privately they would be happy to win five. Thought to be among the vulnerable Republican incumbents are Mr. Corodemus and Gerald J. Luongo, who is under investigation for allegedly giving tax breaks to his political allies in Gloucester and Camden Counties.
Which brings up one final point. A criminal record traditionally has not been a big boost on the campaign trail, but since this is New Jersey, perhaps it's not altogether crazy to think that could change. Just look at Steve (Weedman) Forschion, of Chesilhurst in Camden County, the Assembly candidate running on a pro-marijuana platform. Mr. Forschion was arrested Monday evening after he was stopped for speeding in Stratford, according to the police. The erstwhile Eighth district Assembly candidate was taken to the county jail after the police discovered he was wanted for failing to appear in court on -- what else? -- marijuana-possession charges earlier this year. His next court date is scheduled for Nov. 1, the day before the election. No word yet on whether the Weedman's campaign has enough petty cash to post bail.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Prosperity as Redemption For a Boomer Generation

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
EVERYBODY knows that journalism thrives on bad news: natural disasters, wars, financial crashes. Where would newspapers be without them?
So when a book comes along titled "The Long Boom: A Vision For the Coming Age of Prosperity," the natural reaction of any self-respecting economics reporter or editor is to examine it with a jaundiced eye. 
 For what if its message -- that the world stands on the edge of a "global economic expansion on a scale never before experienced" -- turns out to be true? In that case, the job of covering the economy in the future, I have to confess, would probably be a lot less engaging than it has been in the thrilling upheavals of the two decades I've been writing or editing articles about economics and business affairs.
Who wants to write an unending series of upbeat stories? Who wants to read them? People pay a lot more attention to the economy, after all, when things are going badly than when they are going well. Even the current obsession with getting rich in the stock market is built on the fear that it may all fall apart at any moment.
Despite my clear interest in finding fault, "The Long Boom" (Perseus Books, October 1999), is not so easy to dismiss.
The book's central thesis, first propounded in an exceptionally long article written by Peter Schwartz and Pete Leyden in Wired magazine in 1997, is by now quite familiar. "We have gone from an economy driven by the production of tangible things to one driven by intangible ideas," they argue. The global economy is in the midst of a "40-year period from 1980 to 2020 encompassing a critical shift from an Industrial Age economy to an Information Age economy, or a Knowledge Economy, or what we simply call the New Economy."
WHILE still controversial among economists, this kind of thinking has been accepted for years in the technology centers on the West Coast. It is reflected in the writings of everyone from Peter Drucker to Paul Hawken, whose seminal 1983 book, "The Next Economy," grew out of futurism scenarios developed at the Stanford Research Institute. Even Alan Greenspan is a convert.
And it turned out to be more prescient than the fashionably pessimistic East Coast views of the 1980's, expressed in critically acclaimed books like "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers," by Paul Kennedy, a professor at Yale. He predicted the decline of the United States as a world power only a few years before America's chief strategic rival, the Soviet Union, fell apart and its chief economic challenger, Japan, entered decade-long stagnation.
But the pessimists have been swept from the field, and American optimism about the nation's technological and economic superiority is running rampant. So what now? "If we do it right, it's an opportunity to build a vastly better world," said Mr. Schwartz, visiting New York the other day with Mr. Leyden, in a wide-ranging conversation. "This is the reverse of World War II. This is about more than simply protecting what we've got against the sea of darkness."
The allusion to World War II is revealing. Millions of baby boomers harbor a not-so-hidden envy of their parents' great crusade. "Saving Private Ryan" and Tom Brokaw's paean to "The Greatest Generation" have touched a chord: Making money doesn't compare to ridding the world of Nazism.
There's nothing wrong, of course, with recognizing the nobility of that heroic struggle. Self-sacrifice is morally superior to self-indulgence. But sometimes that wisdom slops over into a yearning for another war to fight, a hankering simply to risk death for a greater cause.
And that's where "The Long Boom" gets interesting. For what the authors are really doing is trying to infuse that hoariest of cliches -- the moral equivalent of war -- with real meaning for generations who, one hopes, will never experience a real war.
In essence, they offer an ideology for college-educated knowledge workers, who will soon be the largest class in America. They advocate globalization and open markets, and while not particularly anti-government, they are vaguely libertarian in outlook. They see rapid growth built on technologies like fuel cells and genetic engineering as capable of improving the environment rather than degrading it. "It's an anti-Blade Runner vision of the future," Mr. Leyden said.
The payoff from all this in 25 years or so, they argue, will be to pull perhaps half the world's population out of subsistence living into a vast, well-educated global middle class. The average life span would lengthen tremendously. The risk of global warming would disappear.
I've got my doubts. They underestimate the threat of deep cultural conflict and a backlash against technology that would result from fast growth. They tend to congratulate the high-tech centimillionaires of Silicon Valley simply for doing what they do best: getting rich. And their vision is too New Agey for my taste.
Still, their dream looks superior to the likely alternatives. Growth is indeed better than stagnation. Peace beats war. If that's not so good for reporters, so be it.

HEADLINE: 'White Flight' Student Exploited Trenton School

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Lincoln's father says that it "took guts" to attend a predominantly African-American school, and his mother tried to "guide and protect" him. Where did Lincoln get his notion that Trenton High is violent and dangerous? Is it because whites are not in the majority? Shouldn't reaching across barriers begin with honesty and lack of prejudices? Lincoln claims that he wanted to experience life in a poor ghetto. Any place that is not white suburbia is not a ghetto and good parents, rich or poor, raise children who have strong principles and moral values and who do not judge others by the color of their skin or their economic status. 
 And what will Lincoln do with his new-found knowledge that there's not much difference between a white Hopewell teen-ager and a black Trenton teen-ager? Will he be too busy working on early admissions applications to colleges to reflect on his experience or will he help others who may not have access to top-notch college counseling?
I am a teacher who spent the early part of my career living in Trenton and doing substitute teaching in the public school system (yes, even Trenton High). Sure, public schools have their problems all over the country, but I enjoyed getting to know my students and teaching them. I currently teach in an independent school in Princeton. Clothes and slang may vary, but I have learned that basically kids are kids. I only hope that Lincoln and his family will come to this realization.
 
DENISE G. BENCIVENGO
Mercerville

HEADLINE: State Is Far From Reluctant To Aid Its Cities

 BODY:

To The Editor:
At New Jersey's recent Urban Summit, a host of mayors, community leaders and citizens spoke of the positive strides being made in the state's cities. They commended New Jersey state government for its involvement in rebuilding urban neighborhoods and stimulating economic development. Speakers told of new housing, new jobs and a new spirit of optimism taking hold on city streets -- quite a different view than the New Jersey section offered in a recent article ("New Jersey's Cities: Sad Urban Presence Encircle by Wealth," cover, Sept. 26) that strangely described the state's urban efforts as "reluctant." 
 There has been nothing reluctant about the state's approach to improving urban areas. To the contrary, there has never been as much financial, programmatic and technical assistance provided to New Jersey's cities.
Under the leadership of Governor Whitman, the state has put together a tool kit of resources to help urban communities realize their plans for redevelopment. We're helping to create a climate for investment that is key to the long-term health of our cities.
And those efforts are making a measurable difference, putting cities at the top of the construction activity charts and changing the face of troubled neighborhoods.
While development is up, and state aid is up -- not only for cities, but for all municipalities -- crime and unemployment rates in our major cities are down.
There are many signs of progress in New Jersey's cities. But events like the Urban Summit are not held to declare victory. They allow us to take stock of our successes and to focus on the challenges ahead.
The state will continue to aggressively help New Jersey's urban areas fulfill their potential as centers of commerce and community.
 
JANE M. KENNY
Trenton
 
The writer is Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Land in Manhattan for $1 a Lot?

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
THE bird's-eye view of Manhattan, from the southern tip of the island northward at least a hundred blocks, is a continuous stream of concrete, save the expanse of Central Park and a few other swaths of greenery. Only north of 96th Street, in Harlem and East Harlem, are there still large tracts of undeveloped land. So in July when the city offered to sell nine parcels of city-owned land in upper Manhattan for $1 apiece to anyone who submitted a suitable proposal for housing, developers from Washington Heights to Long Island scrambled to submit bids. By the deadline last week, 23 groups had proposed a total of 45 projects for the sites.
The city's offer did not only represent a rare opportunity to build on empty land in Manhattan. It also offered a chance to participate in the redevelopment of Harlem. And the competition is fierce. 
 "These are big sites, they're going to be big projects, and they're going to have a big impact," said Mark S. Alexander, executive director of Hope Community, a nonprofit housing developer in East Harlem that has submitted a bid for one site and is involved in two other proposals. "On the one hand, there's the perception of it being a land grab from people who are bent on gentrifying the area. On the other hand, it could be a part of the comprehensive plan for the redevelopment of Upper Manhattan."
The disposition of the property by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development is part of an effort to increase the supply of housing for what it classifies as middle-income people -- those with household incomes of up to $133,500 a year -- in neighborhoods saturated with low-income housing projects and social services, said Commissioner Richard T. Roberts. "It's a call for diversity in the economic mix in Harlem," he said.
Noreen Clark-Smith, who has been a member of Community Board 10 in central Harlem for more than 30 years, said the board has been asking the city to develop housing for residents with moderate incomes since the 1980's. "Our housing stock has been used for a population of low-income and no-income people," she said. She argues that without higher-income residents commercial and public services in the neighbhorhood are not likely to improve.
But because East Harlem and Harlem are still home to many of Manhattan's poorest residents, some fear that they could be priced out of the market. "With some of the better-situated projects, there is a likelihood that developers are going to be suggesting rents upwards of $2,000 for a two-bedroom apartment," Mr. Alexander said. "Clearly, these apartments are not going to be affordable to large numbers of people in our community, and that is going to be very controversial."
Mr. Roberts said recent attempts to create housing for people with higher incomes, like a program to rehabilitate historic brownstones in Harlem, have shown that there is a significant market for middle-income housing uptown. The city selected the nine sites because officials believed the locations could attract professionals and others who might otherwise be drawn to the suburbs. They are encouraging development of co-ops and rentals middle-income families could afford. Rentals would range from $750 to $1,750 a month depending on apartment size.
Only three of the nine sites -- two on Frederick Douglass Jr. Boulevard and 117th Street, and one on Fifth Avenue between 138th and 139th Streets -- will receive city subsidies to assist development. Those three will be partly financed with up to $2 million per site from the nonprofit Housing Development Corporation, which is linked to the city's housing agency.
From the word go, there have been competing visions for the sites. The Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, said in July that she wanted assisted living centers for the neighborhood's elderly residents to be included among the projects. "These sites give us a chance to respond to needs in the area," she said this week. Ms. Fields offered to provide $1.3 million in borough money if a developer included an assisted- living component. She also suggested that the Frederick Douglass Boulevard site house a charter school and offered to have the her office help with financing.
Mr. Roberts said the housing agency would take Ms. Fields's ideas into account when considering the proposals. But, he added, "That is not to say that those funds will necessarily be utilized."
The city is now reviewing the 45 proposals, a process that is expected to take several months. Among the ideas officials say they will consider are residential high-rises, mixed-use buildings with retail space on the first floor, town houses and co-ops.
Though some developers who have submitted proposals declined to discuss them, others offered a preview of their plans.
Hope Community, with the Velez Organization, a Hispanic-owned development and contracting company, has proposed a $35 million plan for a lot at 102d Street and First Avenue. The group wants to build a six-story building with 147 rental units and 30,000 square feet of commercial, office and community space, possibly including a church, alongside a four-story walk-up with 32 rental apartments.
L & M Equity, a developer in Larchmont, N.Y., has teamed up with another company, BFC Partners, on two proposed projects in East Harlem. On one lot between East 100th and 101st Street from First to Second Avenues, they have proposed a $25 million to $30 million project that would include a six-story building with two- and three-bedroom rental apartments and 20 town houses that would sell for $160,000 to $180,000.
"We're banking on the fact that these are in a fairly good neighborhood and we think we could get good rents," said Ron Moelis, a partner at L & M. "We think we can pull some of that market from the East 90's into these apartments."
The Arker Companies of Woodmere, N.Y., has offered proposals to build 397 apartments on four sites -- on Bradhurst Avenue near West 146th Street, on Frederick Douglass Jr. Boulevard and 117th Street and on First Avenue from 100th to 103d Streets. The $60 million plan calls for several eight-story buildings and a charter school, and includes middle-income housing as well as some apartments for families with annual incomes of $28,000 to $32,000.
The Settlement Housing Fund, a nonprofit housing development group, has plans for a total of 179 co-op apartments on three sites, all at the intersection of Frederick Douglass Jr. Boulevard and 117th Street; a two-bedroom apartment would sell for about $55,000. The group's $36 million plan also includes a charter school, which would be a joint venture with the Study Center for Law and Peace, a public middle school in Harlem.
Developers said they were thrilled to get a shot at the $1 deals.
"It's very exciting," said Nina DeMartini-Day, a partner with DDM Development and Services, a developer in East Harlem that has a hand in two proposals. "It's a wonderful chance to continue the revitalization that's under way."
